DIVISION 2. - BOARD OF REVIEW[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Charter reference- General assessments and taxation, ch. XI. 
State Law reference- Board of review, MCL 211.28 et seq. 

Sec. 2-411. - Created; membership; terms. 
(a)  There is hereby created in and for the city, a board of review consisting of three members. Membership of the board of review shall consist of the three presently appointed and serving board of review members, whose terms shall continue through expiration. Upon expiration of the term of any member, the member's successor shall be appointed to a three-year term. 
(b)  The city commission may appoint two alternate members to the board of review, for the same terms as regular members of the board of review. Each alternate member shall be a property taxpayer and shall qualify by taking the constitutional oath of office within ten days after appointment. An alternate member may be called to perform the duties of a regular member of the board of review in the absence of a regular member. An alternate member may also be called to perform the duties of a regular member of the board of review for the purpose of reaching a decision on issues protested in which a regular member has abstained for reasons of conflict of interest. 
(Code 1988, § 1.42; Ord. No. 369, § 1, 12-14-1993; Ord. No. 499, § 1, 10-25-2005; Ord. No. 515, § 1, 2-13-2007) 
Sec. 2-412. - Duties and functions. 
    The duties and functions of the board of review and qualifications of members shall be as set forth in the city Charter and in the general property tax act, Public Act No. 206 of 1893 (MCL 211.1 et seq.). Any provision of the city Charter to the contrary notwithstanding, the board of review shall meet on the Tuesday immediately following the second Monday in March, and on such other dates and times as necessary to perform its duties and functions. 
(Code 1988, § 1.43; Ord. No. 369, § 2, 12-14-1993) 
Secs. 2-413-2-437. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PLANNING COMMISSION[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
State Law reference- Michigan planning enabling act, MCL 125.3801 et seq. 

Sec. 2-438. - Planning commission continued and reconstituted. 
    The city planning commission, previously created pursuant to Public Act No. 285 of 1931 (MCL 125.31 et seq.), is hereby continued as reconstituted herein. The city planning commission shall possess and exercise such powers and duties as set forth in that act, as are set forth in Public Act No. 110 of 2006 (MCL 125.3101 et seq.), with respect to formulating, recommending, and administering zoning regulations and as may be delegated and expanded by action of the city commission. 
(Code 1988, § 5.221; Ord. No. 381, § 1, 10-17-1995) 
Sec. 2-439. - Composition. 
    The city planning commission shall consist of nine members, eight of whom shall represent insofar as is possible different professions or occupations and shall be appointed by the mayor subject to approval by the city commission, and one of whom shall be a member of the commission to be selected by resolution of the commission to serve as a member ex officio, with full voting rights. 
(Code 1988, § 5.222; Ord. No. 381, § 1, 10-17-1995) 
Sec. 2-440. - Qualifications. 
    No member of the city planning commission other than the ex officio member shall hold another municipal office except that one of the appointed members may be a member of the zoning board of appeals. Every member shall have the qualifications of electors. 
(Code 1988, § 5.223; Ord. No. 381, § 1, 10-17-1995) 
Sec. 2-441. - Terms. 
    All members of the city planning commission shall serve for terms of three years and until their successors are appointed and qualified, except that the term of the ex officio member shall be determined by the city commission and stated in the resolution selecting such member, but shall not exceed the member's official tenure. An appointed member may be removed from office by the mayor, after a public hearing, for inefficiency, neglect of duty, or malfeasance in office. 
(Code 1988, § 5.224; Ord. No. 381, § 1, 10-17-1995) 
Sec. 2-442. - Vacancies. 
    A vacancy on the city planning commission occurring otherwise than through the expiration of the term shall be filled for the unexpired term by the mayor in the case of a member selected or appointed by the mayor and by the commission, in the case of a member appointed by the commission. 
(Code 1988, § 5.225; Ord. No. 381, § 1, 10-17-1995) 
Sec. 2-443. - Procedures for operation. 
(a)  The city planning commission shall elect its chairman for a term of one year, with eligibility for re-election, from amongst its appointed members and create and fill such other offices as it may determine. 
(b)  The city planning commission shall schedule at least one regular meeting in each month and shall adopt rules for transaction of business, including a procedure for canceling a regular scheduled meeting if there is no business to transact. Meetings shall be conducted in accordance with the open meetings act (MCL 15.261 et seq.). The city planning commission shall keep a record of its proceedings and actions, resolutions, transactions, findings and determinations which record shall be a public record. 
(Code 1988, § 5.226; Ord. No. 381, § 1, 10-17-1995) 
Sec. 2-444. - Expenses and liabilities. 
(a)  The city planning commission shall not incur any expense, or create or cause liability against the city, without first having received express authority therefor by resolution of the city commission. 
(b)  A fee shall be charged for all petitions and appeals to the city planning commission, the amount of which shall be prescribed by the city commission by ordinance or resolution. 
(Code 1988, § 5.227; Ord. No. 381, § 1, 10-17-1995) 
Secs. 2-445-2-471. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - PUBLIC ART, BEAUTIFICATION AND TREE ADVISORY BOARD[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 535, s; 1, adopted Dec. 21, 2010, amended Div. 4 in its entirety and enacted the provisions set out herein. The former Div. 4, titled Tree Advisory Board, derived from Code 1988, §§ 3.70-3.72; Ord. No. 482, § 1, adopted Oct. 21, 2003; and Ord. No. 491, §§ 1, 2, adopted Feb. 2, 2005. 

Sec. 2-472. - Creation; members. 
(a)  There is hereby created the city public art, beautification and tree advisory board (hereinafter referred to as the "advisory board" or the "board"), which shall consist of 11 members. 
(b)  All members of the advisory board shall be residents of the city and shall be appointed by the city commission. Prior to January 1 in each year, three members or four members, as the case may be, of the advisory board shall be appointed for terms of three years each. Upon expansion of the board from nine to 11 members, two new members shall be appointed to terms of such length as shall be designated by the city commission and which shall result in the expiration of the terms of either three or four members of the board each year thereafter. In addition, the city commission may appoint one high school student who is a resident of the city and who shall serve as a member of the advisory board for one year beginning in October. 
(c)  Any member of the advisory board may be appointed for a second three-year term. The student member may be reappointed for one additional year. 
(d)  Within ten days after appointment to the advisory board and before entering upon the appointee's duties as a member of the advisory board, each appointee shall file written acceptance with the city clerk and subscribe and file with the clerk an oath to support the Constitution of the United States, the Constitution of the state and to faithfully perform the duties of the office of advisory board member to the best of the member's ability. 
(e)  All advisory board members shall serve without compensation. Each member of the advisory board shall serve until the member's successor is appointed and qualifies. 
(f)  A representative of the department of public services will serve as an ex officio member of the advisory board. 
(Ord. No. 535, § 1, 12-21-2010; Ord. No. 536, § 1, 3-22-2011) 
Sec. 2-473. - Powers and duties. 
(a)  The advisory board shall be an advisory board having the general duty of considering and advising the city commission concerning the physical appearance of public property within the city, the encouragement, promotion and facilitation of art in public places in the city, and all tree related issues. The duties of the advisory board shall more specifically include: 
(1)  Reviewing and making recommendations to the city commission regarding matters which involve the physical appearance of public property within the city; 
(2)  Conducting the annual beautification awards program, including: 
a.  Assisting city administrative staff in promoting the annual beautification awards program to raise awareness, encourage participation and publicly recognize city residents and businesses for the beautification efforts; 
b.  Nominating houses and businesses which have demonstrated an outstanding job harmonizing structure and landscaping; 
c.  Judging nominated houses by completing rating sheets utilizing established criteria; 
d.  Coordinating and hosting the beautification award program reception. 
(3)  Developing, coordinating and implementing, either as a committee or in conjunction with other city departments, boards, committees, groups or clubs, various programs and projects to beautify the city consistent with the city's master plan; 
(4)  Improving the beauty of the city by educating the community about ways to beautify their homes and neighborhood and encouraging community involvement; 
(5)  Studying and recommending to the city commission the availability of public facilities of all kinds relating to the display of art, including but not limited to libraries, other public buildings, and public parks, and shall recommend methods for coordinating such facilities and the activities in such facilities; 
(6)  Studying and recommending to the city commission the availability and acquisition of artwork, including, but not limited to, sculptures, paintings, and murals, for display in public places in the city; 
(7)  Encouraging individual creativity by recognition of individual creative achievements and by recommendations on facilities and supplies to be furnished by public bodies, nonprofit organizations and by businesses; 
(8)  Studying and observing the manner in which the city manages and maintains its urban forest; 
(9)  Making such recommendations concerning trees to the city manager or the city commission as may be expedient and not inconsistent with this division, the Charter of the city and the general laws of the state; 
(10)  Making recommendations concerning comprehensive tree management and preservation programs for the city; 
(11)  Serving as a clearinghouse for information on trees; 
(12)  Engaging in community education regarding trees; 
(13)  Encouraging the planting of trees on both public and private lands and developing resident opportunities for tree planting and preservation. 
(b)  The advisory board may accept donations, contributions and gifts, either general or for specific purposes, on behalf of the city. All monies received by the advisory board shall be deposited with the city treasurer and credited as may be determined appropriate by the city commission. 
(Ord. No. 535, § 1, 12-21-2010) 
Sec. 2-474. - Board organization and meetings. 
(a)  The advisory board shall organize by electing annually at its first regular meeting a chair, vice-chair, secretary, and such other officers as may be necessary for the proper conduct of the duties of the board. In addition, the board shall approve a schedule of regular meetings for the next year. 
(b)  The advisory board shall adopt rules for transaction of business and keep records of its resolutions and recommendations, which records shall be a public record. 
(c)  Six members of the board shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. Six votes shall be necessary for the board to pass a resolution. 
(d)  The advisory board shall conduct its business at a public meeting held in compliance with the Open Meetings Act, Public Act No. 267 of 1976 (MCL 15.261 et seq.). Public notice of the time, date and place of each meeting shall be given in a manner as required by the Open Meetings Act. 
(Ord. No. 535, § 1, 12-21-2010; Ord. No. 536, § 1, 3-22-2011) 
Secs. 2-475-2-501. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - WOODS COMMUNITY FUND BOARD 

Sec. 2-502. - Creation. 
(a)  There is hereby created the Woods Community Fund Board, which shall consist of seven members. 
(b)  The seven members of the board shall be residents of or doing business in the city and shall be appointed by the city commission. Two members of the board shall be appointed from candidates recommended by the parks and recreation advisory board, two members from candidates recommended by the beautification committee, and one member from candidates recommended by the tree advisory board. The two additional members of the board shall be appointed by the city commission to represent other interests of the community. 
(c)  Two or three members, as the case may be, shall be appointed to the board each year for terms of three years, beginning January 1; provided, however, that in the first year, three members shall be selected for three-year terms, two members for two-year terms, and two members for one-year terms. 
(d)  Within ten days after appointment to the board and before entering upon an appointee's duties as a member of the board, each appointee shall subscribe and file the constitutional oath of office with the city clerk. 
(e)  All board members shall serve without compensation. Each member of the board shall serve until the member's successor is appointed and qualified. 
(f)  All other issues related to appointments of members to the board shall be governed by the city's procedures for appointment and operation of citizen advisory boards, commissions and committees. 
(Ord. No. 500, § 1(1.250), 10-25-2005) 
Sec. 2-503. - Purpose. 
    The Woods Community Fund Board is created for the purpose of promoting charitable contributions to the city for the purchase and maintenance of public amenities and facilitating disbursement of such contributions. Among other activities, the board shall: 
(1)  Develop and maintain a list of community needs that are not funded by the city's annual budget, including the development of gift booklets. 
(2)  Maintain a system for the collection of funds for the acquisition and maintenance of public amenities for the city. 
(3)  Assist the city in providing receipts and appropriate public recognition for contributions, including materials. 
(4)  Develop grant procedures to facilitate requests for funding of public amenities not comprehended by the city's annual budget. 
(5)  Except as otherwise provided by the city commission, review any conditions, limitations or requirements associated with any contribution to the city and develop a recommendation for the city commission with respect to whether or not the contribution should be accepted subject to such condition, limitation or requirement. Whenever such a contribution is accepted subject to a condition, limitation or requirement, the board shall assist the city in ensuring compliance with such condition, limitation or requirement. 
(Ord. No. 500, § 1(1.251), 10-25-2005) 
Sec. 2-504. - Membership, terms and bylaws. 
(a)  The Woods Community Fund Board shall elect from its members a chair and such other officers as the board may determine in its bylaws, each of whom shall serve for terms of one year. One or more of the officers shall perform the following functions: 
(1)  Preside over the meetings of the board; 
(2)  Promote the Woods Community Fund at city functions and through city publications; and 
(3)  Act as liaison to the city and to the various clubs of the city, including without limitation the parks and recreation advisory board, the beautification committee and the tree board; supervise the recognition efforts of the board, and assist in the maintenance of books and records of the activities of the board, including without limitation meeting minutes and financial records. 
(b)  The respective officers shall perform such of these and other duties as the board may from time to time determine. 
(c)  The board shall adopt appropriate bylaws. 
(Ord. No. 500, § 1(1.252), 10-25-2005) 
Sec. 2-505. - Meetings. 
(a)  Meetings of the board shall be posted and conducted in accordance with the State Open Meetings Act (MCL 15.261 et seq.) and city policy. Four members of the board shall constitute a quorum. 
(b)  The board shall meet at least six times a year. 
(Ord. No. 500, § 1(1.253), 10-25-2005) 
Sec. 2-506. - Financial and records management. 
    The city, with the assistance of the board, shall keep complete financial records of accounts as well as records and minutes of all proceedings of the board. The board shall follow reasonable auditing, recordkeeping, reporting policies and other procedures as are consistent with city financial regulations, state and federal law and approved by the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 500, § 1(1.254), 10-25-2005) 
Sec. 2-507. - Funds collected. 
    Funds collected by, as a result of the efforts of, or for the benefit of the Woods Community Fund Board shall be promptly surrendered to and managed by the city. The city shall maintain a separate account for such funds, to be known as the Woods Community Fund, and shall provide a statement of activities in such fund to the board in advance of each meeting of the board. At least annually, a detailed accounting of all funds received by the city for deposit in such fund and all disbursements made from such fund shall be provided to the board. The board shall not manage or maintain any funds. 
(Ord. No. 500, § 1(1.255), 10-25-2005) 
Secs. 2-508-2-520. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - SENIOR ADVISORY COMMITTEE 

Sec. 2-521. - Creation and members. 
(a)  There is hereby created the Huntington Woods Senior Advisory Committee, which shall consist of seven members. 
(b)  The seven members of the senior advisory committee shall be residents of the city and be appointed by the city commission. 
(c)  Members shall be appointed to the committee for terms of three years each, beginning January 1; provided, however, that in the first year, two members shall be appointed for three-year terms, two members shall be appointed for two-year terms, and one member shall be appointed for a one-year term. The two members appointed to expand the committee from five members to seven members shall be appointed to initial terms such as will equalize the number of terms expiring each year as much as possible. 
(d)  Within ten days after appointment to the senior advisory committee and before entering upon the appointee's duties as a member of the committee, each appointee shall file written acceptance with the city clerk and subscribe and file with the clerk an oath to support the Constitution of the United States, the Constitution of the state and to faithfully perform the duties of the office of senior advisory committee member to the best of the member's ability. 
(e)  All members of the senior advisory committee shall serve without compensation. Each member shall serve until the member's successor is appointed and qualifies. 
(f)  All other issues related to appointments of members to the committee shall be governed by the city's procedures for appointment and operation of citizen advisory boards, commissions and committees. 
(Ord. No. 532, § 1, 6-15-2010; Ord. No. 557, § 1, 1-15-2013) 
Sec. 2-522. - Powers and duties. 
    The senior advisory committee shall have the general duty of considering senior related issues and advising the recreation department and the city commission concerning such issues. Duties of the committee shall specifically include: 
(1)  Providing a forum for seniors to present issues of concern to them for consideration by the city. 
(2)  Studying the need for and feasibility of senior housing options in the city. 
(3)  Making recommendations regarding senior services. 
(4)  Encouraging senior involvement in senior related activities in the city. 
(Ord. No. 532, § 1, 6-15-2010) 
Sec. 2-523. - Board organization and meetings. 
(a)  The senior advisory committee shall organize by electing annually from its members at its first regular meeting a chairperson, vice chairperson and secretary. 
(b)  The senior advisory committee shall meet four times a year. At the last meeting of each calendar year, the committee shall approve a schedule of meeting dates for the following year. 
(c)  Four members of the committee shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. Four votes shall be necessary for the committee to pass a resolution. 
(d)  The senior advisory committee shall adopt rules for the transaction of business and keep records of it resolutions and recommendations, which records shall be a public record. 
(e)  The senior advisory committee shall conduct its business at a public meeting held in compliance with the Open Meetings Act, Public Act No. 267 of 1976 (MCL 15.261 et seq.). Public notice of the time, date and place of each meeting shall be given in a manner as required by the Open Meetings Act. 
(Ord. No. 532, § 1, 6-15-2010; Ord. No. 557, § 2, 1-15-2013) 
Secs. 2-524-2-537. - Reserved.
