    License fees for dogs shall be in the amounts prescribed by the city commission by resolution, and be paid at the time of making the application. 
(Code 1988, § 9.46; Ord. No. 423, § 1, 5-19-1998) 
Sec. 4-31. - License tags. 
    Upon the issuance of an individual dog license, the city clerk shall deliver to the applicant a metal tag of not less than one inch in length or diameter, which shall be dated and bear a serial number, together with the words "Licensed and Immunized, Huntington Woods, Michigan" and such serial number shall be inscribed upon the license so issued. Such metal tag shall be attached to the dog for which it is issued by means of a substantial collar or harness and no person shall remove any license tag from any dog without the consent of the owner or of the person to whom the license is issued. No tag shall be used on the collar or harness of any other dog than that for which the tag was issued. 
(Code 1988, § 9.47; Ord. No. 423, § 1, 5-19-1998) 
Sec. 4-32. - Loss of license tag. 
    If the metal license tag is lost, the city clerk may issue a duplicate if the owner of the dog for whom the tag was issued presents the certificate showing the dog was immunized against rabies and a certificate of the dog license, and pays the cost of furnishing a replacement tag. 
(Code 1988, § 9.48; Ord. No. 423, § 1, 5-19-1998) 
Sec. 4-33. - Barking or dangerous dogs. 
(a)  No person who owns, possesses, or harbors a dog shall fail to exercise proper care and control of the dog to prevent it from becoming a public nuisance. Excessive, continuous or untimely barking, molesting passersby, chasing vehicles, habitually attacking other domestic animals, trespassing upon school or park grounds, trespassing upon private property in such a manner as to damage property or straying beyond the premises of the owner unless under proper care and control of some person, shall be deemed to constitute a public nuisance. Any person who violates this subsection shall be responsible for a municipal civil infraction. 
(b)  Yards and/or exercise dog runs shall be kept free of dog droppings, uneaten food, and maintained in a sanitary manner so as not to be a nuisance because of odor or attraction for flies and vermin. Any person who violates this subsection shall be responsible for a municipal civil infraction. 
(c)  No person shall own or harbor a vicious dog, defined as a dog which has bitten a person or domestic animal without molestation, or which, by its actions, gives indication that it is liable to bite any person or domestic animal. Whenever a dog is brought to the pound for having bitten a person, the animal control officer or other duly authorized officer may, if deemed necessary and advisable, and after holding such dog a sufficient length of time to meet the requirements of the health department for investigation, cause such dog to be destroyed as a vicious dog. Any person who violates this subsection shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(d)  No person shall own or harbor a dog that has been bitten by any animal known to be afflicted with rabies. Any person who shall have in their possession a dog which has contracted, or is suspected of having contracted rabies or which has been bitten by any animal known to have been afflicted with rabies, shall, upon demand of the health officer, or any public safety officer of the city, produce and surrender said dog to the public safety department to be held for observation and/or treatment; provided that with the approval of the public safety department, any such dog may be surrendered to a registered veterinarian, or to any approved nonprofit corporation organized for the purpose of sheltering dogs. It shall be the duty of any person owning or harboring a dog which has been attacked or bitten by another dog or animal showing the symptoms of rabies to immediately notify the public safety department that such person has such dog in the person's possession. Any person who violates this subsection shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1988, § 9.49; Ord. No. 423, § 1, 5-19-1998) 
State Law reference- Dogs attacking or biting persons, MCL 287.279, 287.286a; dangerous animals, MCL 287.321 et seq. 
Sec. 4-34. - Housing for stray and unwanted animals. 
    The city shall provide a pound strategically located and it shall be the duty of the animal control officer and/or any other person employed by the city manager for that purpose to properly seize, take up and place in said pound, dogs running at large or being kept or harbored in any place of the city contrary to the provisions in this chapter. 
(Code 1988, § 9.50; Ord. No. 423, § 1, 5-19-1998) 
Sec. 4-35. - Dogs released from the dog pound. 
(a)  No dog shall be released from the pound unless the owner or person entitled to claim the dog shall first pay fees for daily boarding of the dog, plus the reasonable cost for necessary care and treatment of the dog including rabies vaccination if required, plus license fee if required, plus impounding fees. The city commission shall establish such fees by resolution from time to time. 
(b)  All dogs released from the pound to owners or purchasers thereof shall receive rabies immunization if the dog has not been vaccinated within the previous 12 months. 
(c)  Adequate records will be kept to report this disposition of all dogs brought to the pound. 
(Code 1988, § 9.51; Ord. No. 423, § 1, 5-19-1998) 
Sec. 4-36. - Duties of the animal control officer. 
    The animal control officer shall fulfill the following duties: 
(1)  Promptly seize, take up and place in the dog pound, all dogs found running at large or being kept or harbored any place within the city contrary to the provisions of this chapter. 
(2)  Make diligent inquiry as to the dogs owned, harbored or kept, or kennels operated in the city, and whether such dogs and kennels are licensed. 
(3)  The animal control officer shall be properly deputized as a police officer for the limited purposes of this chapter, and shall be legally authorized and empowered to issue and serve appearance tickets upon a person where reasonable cause exists to believe that the person owns or harbors a dog contrary to the provisions of this chapter. 
(4)  It shall be the duty of the animal control officer to not sell or otherwise dispose of an impounded dog that does not have a collar, license or other evidence of ownership, within four days after its acquisition. If the impounded dog has a collar, license or other evidence of ownership, it shall be the duty of the animal control office to notify the owner by telephone or certified mail, and disposition of the dog shall not be made within seven days from the date of either mailing the notice or contacting the owner by telephone. The owner shall be advised that failure to claim the animal within seven days of the date of the notice may result in disposition of the animal. The animal control office shall be required to maintain a record of each identifiable dog acquired, indicating a basic description of the dog, the date it was acquired, under what circumstances it was acquired, the date notice was given to the owner and any subsequent disposition of the dog. 
(5)  Any dog that does not have a license or other evidence of ownership that is not claimed within four days after its acquisition, or any dog that does have a license or other evidence of ownership that is not claimed within seven days of either mailing the notice or contacting the owner by telephone, shall become the property of the city and shall be placed for adoption in a suitable home or euthanized in a manner prescribed by the local Humane Society. Any such dog which is adopted shall either be removed from the city or kept and harbored within the city in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. The bodies of all dogs euthanized at the pound or elsewhere in the city shall be disposed of by the animal control office, or other designated authority, in a manner approved by the health department. 
(Code 1988, § 9.52; Ord. No. 423, § 1, 5-19-1998) 
Sec. 4-37. - Personal and property damage. 
    Every owner of a dog shall be liable for damages for any and all injuries to person or property that may be caused by such dog on any public highway or other public place, to be determined and collected in appropriate legal proceedings, in which proceedings any failure or refusal by such owner to comply with the requirements of this chapter shall constitute prima facie evidence of negligence. 
(Code 1988, § 9.54; Ord. No. 423, § 1, 5-19-1998) 
State Law reference- Common law liability for dogs, MCL 287.288. 
Sec. 4-38. - Sanitation. 
(a)  No person owning, harboring, keeping, or in charge of any dog shall cause, suffer, or allow such dog to soil, defile, defecate or to commit any nuisance on any common thoroughfare, sidewalk, passageway, bypass, play area, park, or any place where people congregate or walk, or upon any public property whatsoever, or upon any private property without the permission of the owner of said property unless: 
(1)  The person who so owns, harbors, keeps or is in charge of such dog shall immediately remove all feces deposited by such dog by any sanitary method approved by the local health authority. The person shall possess a container of sufficient size to collect and remove the above-mentioned dog feces and exhibit the container, if requested by any official empowered to enforce this section. 
(2)  The feces removed from the aforementioned designated area shall be disposed of by the person owning, harboring, keeping, or in charge of any dog in accordance with the provisions of this section in a sanitary manner. 
(b)  Any person who violates this section shall be responsible for a municipal civil infraction. 
(c)  The use of leader, guide, hearing and service dogs shall be exempt from the provisions of this section. 
(Code 1988, § 9.55; Ord. No. 423, § 1, 5-19-1998) 
Chapter 5 - RESERVED 
Chapter 6 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 6-1-6-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - STATE CONSTRUCTION CODE 

Sec. 6-19. - Assumption of responsibility for enforcement and administration. 
    Pursuant to sections 8a and 8b of the Stille-DeRossett-Hale single state construction code act, being Public Act No. 230 of 1972 (MCL 125.1508a, 125.1508b), the city hereby elects to assume responsibility for the administration and enforcement of the state construction code. 
(Code 1988, § 8.1; Ord. No. 317, § 1, 6-21-1988; Ord. No. 459, § 1, 9-25-2001) 
Sec. 6-20. - Designation of enforcing agency. 
    The building official is hereby designated as the enforcing agency to discharge the responsibilities of the city under the state construction code. 
(Code 1988, § 8.2; Ord. No. 317, § 1, 6-21-1988) 
Sec. 6-21. - Permits and fees. 
(a)  Permits shall be required and issued in accordance with the state construction code. 
(b)  The permit fees for all work required hereunder shall be established by and may be changed from time to time by resolution of the city commission. 
(c)  All fees shall be paid at the time of application to the city treasurer or in such other manner as the city manager shall direct. 
(Code 1988, § 8.3; Ord. No. 317, § 1, 6-12-1988; Ord. No. 459, § 2, 9-25-2001) 
Sec. 6-22. - Building bond. 
    Upon application for any permit under the state construction code, the applicant shall deposit with such application a building bond, being a sum in cash in an amount to be specified by resolution of the city commission. This deposit is to reimburse the city for the cost, as determined by the city, of any expense which the city may incur as a result of the work covered by the permit including, but not limited to, the cost of further permits, removal of debris, restoration of ground levels, use of unmetered water, repair of damaged sidewalks, and other property and charges in connection with establishing and discontinuing water connections. 
(Code 1988, § 8.4; Ord. No. 317, § 1, 6-21-1988) 
Sec. 6-23. - Violation; penalties. 
(a)  A person who erects, uses, moves, demolishes, occupies, or maintains any building or structure in violation of the state construction code, or causes, permits or suffers any such violation to be committed, or who knowingly constructs or builds a structure or building in violation of a condition of a permit, is responsible for a municipal civil infraction. 
(b)  Any building or structure erected, used, moved, demolished, occupied or maintained in violation of said code is hereby declared to be a nuisance per se. Upon application of any court of competent jurisdiction, the court may order the nuisance abated and/or the violation or threatened violation restrained and enjoined. 
(Code 1988, § 8.5; Ord. No. 317, § 1, 6-21-1988; Ord. No. 411, § 1, 5-19-1998) 
Sec. 6-24. - Unlawful continuance. 
    Any person who shall continue any work in or about the structure after having been served with a stop work order, except such work as that person is directed to perform to remove a violation or unsafe condition, is responsible for a municipal civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 8.6; Ord. No. 317, § 1, 6-21-1988; Ord. No. 411, § 2, 5-19-1998) 
Sec. 6-25. - Designation of board of appeals. 
    The city construction and property maintenance board of appeals is hereby designated as the board of appeals required by section 14 of the Stille-DeRossett-Hale single state construction code act, Public Act No. 230 of 1972 (MCL 125.1514), and shall have the powers and duties required by that act to hear appeals under the state construction code. 
(Code 1988, § 8.7; Ord. No. 317, § 1, 6-21-1988; Ord. No. 496, § 1, 6-21-2005) 
Sec. 6-26. - Creation and composition of construction and property maintenance board of appeals. 
    There is hereby created in and for the city, a construction and property maintenance board of appeals. The board shall consist of three members qualified by experience or training to pass on matters pertaining to construction and maintenance. Members shall be appointed by the mayor, subject to approval of the city commission, to two year terms. Terms of the first members appointed shall be staggered to the extent possible. An alternate board member may be appointed to serve in the absence of a regular board member or in the event a regular board member determines the board member cannot hear an appeal due to a conflict of interest. 
(Code 1988, § 8.8; Ord. No. 317, § 1, 6-21-1988; Ord. No. 341, § 1, 7-25-1989; Ord. No. 496, § 2, 6-21-2005) 
Sec. 6-27. - Operation of construction and property maintenance board of appeals; rules of procedure. 
(a)  The construction and property maintenance board of appeals may adopt rules of procedure, not inconsistent with the single construction code act (MCL 125.1501 et seq.), and shall keep records of appeals to it and decisions rendered. Appeals to the construction and property maintenance board of appeals under any section of the state construction code act shall be taken as prescribed by that act, and pursuant to rules of procedure adopted by the construction and property maintenance board of appeals not inconsistent with that act. 
(b)  The construction and property maintenance board of appeals shall meet as required to hear appeals on building permit denials or any other decision pursuant to or related to the single construction code act or the state construction code. Within ten days after receiving written notice of denial, an applicant may file a petition, in writing, for review of said action with the city manager. Upon payment to the city clerk of the fee prescribed by the city commission by ordinance or resolution, the board shall hear the appeal and render and file its decision with a statement of reasons for the decision with the building official not more than 30 days after submission of the appeal. Failure by the board of appeals to hear an appeal and file a decision within the time limit is a denial of the appeal for purposes of authorizing the institution of an appeal to the state construction commission. A copy of the decision and statement of the reasons for the decision shall be delivered or mailed, before filing, to the party taking the appeal. 
(Code 1988, § 8.9; Ord. No. 317, § 1, 6-21-1988; Ord. No. 496, § 3, 6-21-2005) 
Secs. 6-28-6-57. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - BUILDING GRADE AND DRAINAGE 

Sec. 6-58. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Building line grade means the grade at which the building walls meet the ground. 
    Grade means the height to which the ground is elevated above sea level. 
    Sidewalk grade means the grade at which the front sidewalk is located, except that in the case of corner lots, the sidewalk grade shall be deemed to be the grade at which the front or side sidewalk is located. 
(Code 1988, § 8.10; Ord. No. 497, § 1, 6-21-2005) 
Sec. 6-59. - Grading required. 
(a)  When the existing grade of any property or building is to be changed or modified, or when a building is to be constructed, erected or altered on any property, or when site or landscaping improvements alter any part of the existing grade, the new grade shall be established so that it shall be not more than 18 inches above sidewalk grade. The grade shall not exceed the grade of adjoining properties at the lot line nor shall the flow of surface water be directed toward or permitted to flow, or project unnecessarily or unfairly upon adjacent properties. 
(b)  When the existing grade of any property is to be changed or modified as a result of construction, erection or alteration of a building, proposed grades must be based upon a current topographic survey. Such survey shall be submitted as part of the building permit application. 
(c)  If the grade of a property prior to construction or landscaping is higher than 18 inches above the sidewalk grade, it may be retained, provided it does not cause surface water to drain onto adjacent property. 
(d)  In case the enforcement of this section shall appear to be inequitable or unfair or will cause surface drainage to be projected unnecessarily or unfairly upon adjacent property, or in case the public welfare, health or safety otherwise calls for a modification of the foregoing provisions, then in any of those events, the building official may permit or require such modification or change in the foregoing requirements as may be fair to affected property owners or necessary as a public measure. 
(e)  No person shall change, modify, create or establish the grade of any property within the city other than in conformity with this section. 
(Code 1988, § 8.11; Ord. No. 497, § 1, 6-21-2005) 
Sec. 6-60. - Violations; penalties. 
    A person who changes, modifies, creates or establishes the grade of any property within the city other than in conformity with this article is responsible for a municipal civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 8.12; Ord. No. 411, § 3, 5-19-1998; Ord. No. 497, § 1, 6-21-2005) 
Secs. 6-61-6-78. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - SECURITY BARS 

Sec. 6-79. - Definitions; purpose. 
(a)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Security bar means a rigid framework of patterned bars which inhibits access through a window or door. 
(b)  Security bars are used by residents who are afraid of being victims of crime but these bars have the deadly side effect of trapping people inside during emergencies. Accordingly, the purpose of this article is to protect the health, safety and welfare of residents by prohibiting the installation and use of security bars on doors and windows. 
(Code 1988, § 8.16; Ord. No. 446, § 1, 7-11-2000) 
Sec. 6-80. - Installation and use of security bars prohibited. 
(a)  A person shall not install or use security bars on a window or door of a residential dwelling. 
(b)  A person shall not occupy a residential dwelling which is equipped with security bars on any window or door. 
(Code 1988, § 8.17; Ord. No. 446, § 1, 7-11-2000) 
Sec. 6-81. - Violations; penalties. 
    A person who violates any provision of this article is responsible for a municipal civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 8.18; Ord. No. 446, § 1, 7-11-2000) 
Secs. 6-82-6-105. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - ELECTRICAL WORK 

Sec. 6-106. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Apprentice electrician means an individual other than an electrical contractor, master electrician, or electrical journeyman, who is engaged in learning about and assisting in the installation or alteration of electrical wiring and equipment under the direct personal supervision of an electrical journeyman or master electrician. 
    Electric sign means fixed, stationary, or portable self-contained, electrically illuminated equipment that has words or symbols designed to convey information or attract attention. The term includes outline lighting. The term "electric sign" does not include those signs that are indoor or outdoor portable applications or recognized holiday residential signs listed with a recognized testing and approval agency and that use a cord cap-110 volt plug as the electrical energizing attachment method. 
    Electrical administrative act means Public Act No. 217 of 1956 (MCL 338.881 et seq.). 
    Electrical contractor means a person engaged in the business of erecting, installing, altering, repairing, servicing, or maintaining electrical wiring, devices, appliances or equipment. 
    Electrical equipment means all electrical devices, in connection with the generation, distribution, communication, and utilization of electrical energy, within or on a building, residence, structure, or properties including fire alarm and sign devices. 
    Electrical inspector means any person who has the necessary qualifications, training, experience, and technical knowledge to inspect all electrical apparatus for compliance with the codes and who shall be the agent or employee of the city designated by the building official as an electrical inspector. Inspectors shall be registered pursuant to Public Act No. 54 of 1986, (MCL 338.2301 et seq.), as amended, and known as the Building Officials and Inspectors Registration Act. 
    Electrical journeyman means a person other than an electrical contractor who, as their principal occupation, is engaged in the practical installation or alteration of electrical wiring. An electrical contractor or master electrician may also be an electrical journeyman. 
    Electrical wiring means all wiring, generating equipment, fixtures, appliances, and appurtenances in connection with the generation, distribution, communication, and utilization of electrical energy, within or on a building, residence, structure, or properties, and including service entrance wiring as defined by the code. 
    Fire alarm contractor means a person, firm, or corporation engaged in the business of erecting, installing, altering, repairing, servicing, or maintaining wiring, devices, appliances or equipment of a fire alarm system. 
    Fire alarm specialty apprentice technician means an individual other than a fire alarm contractor or a fire alarm specialty technician who is engaged in learning about and assisting in the installation or alteration of fire alarm system wiring and equipment under the direct personal supervision of a fire alarm specialty technician. 
    Fire alarm specialty licensure means licensure as a fire alarm contractor or a fire alarm specialty or apprentice technician. 
    Fire alarm specialty technician means a person other than a fire alarm contractor who, as their principal occupation, is engaged in the practical installation or alteration of fire alarm system wiring. A fire alarm contractor may also be a fire alarm specialty technician. 
    Fire alarm system means a system designed to detect and annunciate the presence of fire, or by-products of fire, installed within a building or structure. The term "fire alarm system" does not include a single station smoke detector. 
    Jobsite means the immediate work area within the property lines of a single construction project, alteration project or maintenance project where electrical construction or alteration of electrical wiring is in progress. 
    Master electrician means a person having the necessary qualifications, training, experience and technical knowledge to supervise the installation of electrical wiring and equipment in accordance with the standard rules and regulations governing that work. 
    Minor repair work means electrical work such as repairing or replacing flush and snap switches, fuses, lamp sockets or receptacles; replacement of fixtures; repairing or taping bare connections; replacing lamps or the connection of portable electrical equipment to suitable permanently installed receptacles, provided the total value does not exceed $100.00. 
    Outline lighting means an arrangement of incandescent lamps or electric discharge tubing which is an integral part of an electrical sign that outlines certain features, such as the shape of a building or the decoration of a window. 
    Owner means any natural person, and their legal successors. In all proceedings, actions or prosecutions hereunder, in which a corporation is the owner of any building, structure or part thereof, or of premises, any of its officers, directors or persons in control or management thereof, as well as the corporation, shall be subject to the provisions of this article. 
    Related sign wiring means: 
(1)  Except as otherwise provided in subsections (2), (3) and (4) of this section, that portion of the electric sign wiring that originates at the load-side terminals of a disconnecting means located in the vicinity of the electric sign involved but does not include the installation of the disconnecting means, complete with line-side connections. 
(2)  In the case of electric sign installations having sign transformers installed physically apart from the electric sign, that portion of the electric sign wiring that originates at the load-side terminals of a disconnecting means located in the vicinity of the electric sign involved but does not include the installation of the disconnecting means, complete with line-side connections. 
(3)  In the case of the freestanding electric sign installations supplied through underground circuit conductors, that portion of the electric sign wiring that originates at a wiring termination point adjacent to, within or immediately above the permanent base for the electric sign but does not include, if the base of the sign structure is suitable for use as a raceway, the installation of bushing, complete with free-length circuit conductors extending through to accommodate the connection of the related wiring within the sign structure raceway. 
(4)  In the case of electric signs specifically designated to be connected directly to the building wiring raceway or cable supply, that portion of the electric sign wiring that originates at the point where the free-length circuit conductors extend through the building wiring raceway or cable at the specifically designed supply location for the electric sign involved but does not include the installation of the building wiring raceway or cable system to the specifically designated point of supply for the electric sign involved, complete with free-length circuit conductors extending through the building wiring raceway or cable to accommodate the connection of the related wiring. 
    Sign specialist means a person who, as their principal occupation, is engaged in the installation, alteration or repair of electric signs. 
    Sign specialty contractor means a person engaged in the business of manufacturing, installing, maintaining, connecting, or repairing electric sign wiring or devices, including wiring that is directly related to electric signs and is electrically dedicated as a sign circuit. 
    Sign specialty licensure means licensure as a sign specialist or sign specialty contractor. 
(Code 1988, § 8.40; Ord. No. 377, § 1, 1-17-1995; Ord. No. 462, § 1, 9-25-2001) 
Sec. 6-107. - Licensing reciprocity. 
    Licenses or registrations issued by the state electrical administrative board and licenses issued by a municipality having standards for licensing not less than those established by the state electrical administrative board shall be recognized by the city. 
(Code 1988, § 8.50; Ord. No. 377, § 1, 1-17-1995; Ord. No. 464, § 3, 9-25-2001) 
Sec. 6-108. - Contractor's license. 
(a)  No person shall engage in the business of electrical contractor, fire alarm contractor, or sign specialty contractor and install, alter or repair electrical wiring, equipment, apparatus or fixtures for light, heat, power or fire alarm systems in or about buildings and/or structures located within the city without first having procured the appropriate contractor's license. No person other than a master electrician, except a person duly licensed and employed by and working under the direction of a holder of an electrical contractor's license, fire alarm contractor's license, or sign contractor's license, shall in any manner undertake to execute any electrical wiring. A violation of this provision shall be a civil infraction. 
(b)  No license shall be required by the board to perform the following: 
(1)  Any of the following work: 
a.  Minor repair work, as defined in section 6-106. 
b.  The installation, alteration, repairing, rebuilding, or remodeling of elevators, dumbwaiters, escalators, or man lifts performed under a permit issued by an elevator inspection agency of the state or political subdivision of the state. 
c.  The installation, alteration, or repair of electrical equipment and its associated wiring installed on the premises of consumers or subscribers by or for electrical energy supply or communication agencies for use by such agencies in the generation, transmission, distribution, or metering of electrical energy or for the operation of signals or transmission of intelligence. 
d.  The installation, alteration, or repair of electric wiring for the generation and primary distribution of electric current, or the secondary distribution system up to and including the meters, where such work is an integral part of the system owned and operated by an electric light and power utility in rendering its duly authorized service. 
e.  Any work involved in the manufacture of electric equipment, including the testing and repairing of such manufactured equipment. 
f.  The installation, alteration, or repair of equipment and its associated wiring for the generation or distribution of electric energy for the operation of signals or transmission of intelligence where such work is in connection with a communication system owned or operated by a telephone or telegraph company in rendering its duly authorized service as a telephone or telegraph company. 
g.  Any work involved in the use, maintenance, operation, dismantling, or reassembling of motion picture and theatrical equipment used in any building with approved facilities for entertainment or educational use and which has the necessary permanent wiring and floor and wall receptacle outlets designed for the proper and safe use of such theatrical equipment, but not including any permanent wiring. 
(2)  Any installation, alteration or repair of electrical equipment by a homeowner in a single-family home and accompanying outbuildings owned and occupied or to be occupied by the person performing the installation, alteration or repair of electrical equipment. 
(3)  Work performed by mechanical contractors licensed in classifications listed in section 6(3)(a), (b), (d), (e), and (f) of the Forbes Mechanical Contractor Act, Public Act No. 192 of 1984 (MCL 338.976), plumbing contractors licensed under Public Act No. 733 of 2002 (MCL 338.3511 et seq.), and employees of persons licensed under Public Act No. 192 of 1984 (MCL 338.971 et seq.) and Public Act No. 733 of 2002 (MCL 338.3511 et seq.)while performing maintenance, service, repair, replacement, alteration, modification, reconstruction or upgrading of control wiring circuits and electrical component parts within existing mechanical systems defined in the mechanical and plumbing codes provided for in the State Construction Code Act of 1972, including, but not limited to, energy management systems, relays and controls on boilers, water heaters, furnaces, air conditioning compressors and condensers, fan controls, thermostats and sensors, and all interconnected wiring associated with the mechanical systems in buildings which are on the load side of the unit disconnect, which is located on or immediately adjacent to the equipment, except for life safety systems wiring. 
(4)  Electrical wiring associated with the installation, removal, alteration, or repair of a water well pump on a single-family dwelling to the first point of attachment in the house from the well, by a registered pump installer under part 127 of the public health code, Public Act No. 368 of 1978 (MCL 333.12701 et seq.). 
(5)  The installation, maintenance or servicing of burglar alarm systems within a building or structure. 
(6)  The installation, maintenance or servicing of residential lawn sprinkling equipment. 
(7)  The installation, alteration, maintenance or repair of electric signs and related wiring by an unlicensed individual under the direct supervision of a licensed sign specialist, except that the ratio of unlicensed individuals engaged in this activity shall not exceed two unlicensed individuals to one licensed sign specialist. An enforcing agency shall enforce this ratio on a jobsite basis. 
(8)  The construction, installation, maintenance, repair and renovation of telecommunications equipment and related systems by a person primarily engaged in the telecommunications and related information systems industry. This exemption does not include the construction, installation, maintenance, repair and renovation of a fire alarm system. 
(Code 1988, § 8.51; Ord. No. 377, § 1, 1-17-1995; Ord. No. 464, § 4, 9-25-2001) 
Sec. 6-109. - Master and journeyman license; apprentice electrician registration. 
(a)  No person shall engage in the occupation or trade of master, journeyman or apprentice electrician in the installation, alteration, maintenance or repair of electrical wiring equipment, apparatus or fixtures for light, heat, power or medical purposes in or about buildings and/or structures within the city without having first obtained a license or apprentice registration as herein provided. A violation of this provision by a person acting as a master or journeyman electrician shall be a civil infraction. A violation of this provision by a person acting as an apprentice electrician shall be a minor violation. 
(b)  All electrical work done by apprentice electricians shall be performed under the direct personal supervision of a journeyman or master electrician who shall be on the premises at all times when such apprentice electricians are performing such work. Failure to provide such supervision shall be a civil infraction committed by the electrical contractor supervising the jobsite. 
(Code 1988, § 8.53; Ord. No. 377, § 1, 1-17-1995; Ord. No. 464, § 5, 9-25-2001) 
Sec. 6-110. - Fire alarm specialty technician's license. 
    No person shall engage in the occupation or trade of fire alarm specialty technician in or about buildings and/or structures within the city without having first obtained a license. A violation of this provision shall be a civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 8.54; Ord. No. 377, § 1, 1-17-1995; Ord. No. 464, § 6, 9-25-2001) 
Sec. 6-111. - Fire alarm apprentice registration. 
(a)  An individual employed as a fire alarm specialty apprentice technician shall register with the state electrical administrative board within 30 days after employment. A violation of this provision shall be a minor violation. 
(b)  The ratio of fire alarm specialty technicians to registered fire alarm specialty apprentice technicians shall be on the basis of one fire alarm specialty technician to two registered fire alarm specialty apprentice technicians. The building official shall enforce the ratio on a job site basis. Failure to maintain this ratio shall be a civil infraction committed by the electrical contractor supervising the jobsite. 
(Code 1988, § 8.55; Ord. No. 377, § 1, 1-17-1995; Ord. No. 464, § 7, 9-25-2001) 
Sec. 6-112. - Sign specialty technician licenses. 
    No person shall engage in the occupation or trade of sign specialty technician in or about buildings and/or structures within the city without having first obtained a license. A violation of this section shall be a civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 8.56; Ord. No. 377, § 1, 1-17-1995; Ord. No. 464, § 8, 9-25-2001) 
Sec. 6-113. - Requirement to carry identification card and picture identification. 
    An individual licensed or registered under this article shall carry an identification card issued by the state department of labor and economic growth at all times while engaged in activity that is subject to licensure or registration under this article and shall also carry not less than one piece of identification containing the individual's picture. The individual, upon request of the building official, an inspector or other authorized representative, shall produce the identification card as well as the picture identification. An individual who fails to produce the identification card is not considered in violation of this section if such individual produces the card within 24 hours after being requested by the building official, an inspector or other authorized representative, and presents it to the enforcing agency. Failure to produce any identification shall be considered a minor violation of this article by the individual as well as the electrical contractor supervising the jobsite. 
(Code 1988, § 8.58; Ord. No. 377, § 1, 1-17-1995; Ord. No. 464, § 10, 9-25-2001) 
Sec. 6-114. - Minor violations and fines. 
    All of the following violations are minor violations and carry the following prescribed fines: 
(1)  Failure of an apprentice to register with the state electrical administrative board as required by this article, the fine is $5.00. An additional fine of $50.00 shall be assessed if the apprentice fails to register within 15 business days notification. 
(2)  Failure to produce pictured identification and a license or apprentice registration within one business day after requested by the building official, an inspector or other authorized representative of the enforcing agency, the fine is $25.00. If the identification and the license or apprentice registration is not produced, an additional fine of $75.00 shall be assessed after three business days. 
(3)  Employment by an electrical contractor of a person who is in violation of subsection (2) of this section, the fine is $25.00. If the employed person does not produce pictured identification and a license or apprentice registration pursuant to this article, then the employing electrical contractor shall be fined an additional $75.00. This fine will be imposed three days after the time provided in subsection (2) of this section has expired. 
(Code 1988, § 8.59; Ord. No. 377, § 1, 1-17-1995; Ord. No. 464, § 11, 9-25-2001) 
Sec. 6-115. - Civil infractions and fines. 
    A person licensed or registered under this article who commits a violation of this article that is designated as a civil infraction or a person not licensed or registered under this article who is performing any activity regulated by this article and is not exempt from licensure or registration under this article, is guilty of a civil infraction punishable by a fine of not less than $1,000.00 per day for each day the violation occurs, except that a fine shall not exceed $5,000.00 in total per violation. A second or subsequent violation is punishable by a fine of not less than $2,000.00 per day for each day a violation occurs, except that a fine shall not exceed $10,000.00 in total per violation. 
(Code 1988, § 8.60; Ord. No. 377, § 1, 1-17-1995) 
Sec. 6-116. - Criminal penalties. 
    Any person who violates this article by committing an act that is not designated as a civil infraction or a minor violation shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and punished as prescribed in section 1-15. Section 1-15 provides for punishment by a fine of not more than $500.00 and costs of the prosecution or by imprisonment for not more than 90 days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. Each act of violation and every day upon which any such violation shall occur shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1988, § 8.61; Ord. No. 377, § 1, 1-17-1995) 
Secs. 6-117-6-145. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - PROPERTY MAINTENANCE CODE 

Sec. 6-146. - Adoption and purpose. 
    There is hereby adopted that certain code known as the International Property Maintenance Code, 2012 edition, as published by the International Code Council, as the property maintenance code of the city for the purpose of regulating and governing the conditions and maintenance of all property, buildings and structures by providing the standards for supplied utilities and facilities and other physical things and conditions essential to ensure that structures are safe, sanitary and fit for occupation and use; and the condemnation of building and structures unfit for human occupancy and use, providing for the issuance of permits and collection of fees therefor; and each and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of said property maintenance code on file in the office of the city clerk are hereby referred to, adopted, and made a part hereof, as if fully set out in this Code, with the additions, insertions, deletions and changes, if any, prescribed in section 6-147 of this article. 
(Code 1988, § 8.161; Ord. No. 406, § 1, 3-3-1998; Ord. No. 495, § 1, 6-21-2005; Ord. No. 554, § 1, 10-16-2012) 
State Law reference- Authority to adopt technical codes by reference, MCL 117.3(k). 
Sec. 6-147. - Additions, insertions, deletions and amendments. 
    The International Property Maintenance Code adopted by the provisions of this article as the property maintenance code of the city is hereby amended, changed and altered as set forth in this article. 
Section 101.1 Title. These regulations shall be known as the property maintenance code of the City of Huntington Woods, Michigan, hereafter referred to as "this code." 
Section 103.1 Code official. References to the "code official" shall be deemed to refer to the city code enforcement officer. 
Section 103.2 Deleted. 
Section 103.5 Fees. The fees for activities and services performed by the building official in carrying out its responsibilities under this code shall be determined by resolution of the city commission from time to time adopted. 
Section 106.3 Prosecution of violation. Any person failing to comply with a notice of violation or order served in accordance with section 107 shall be responsible for a municipal civil infraction. If the notice of violation is not complied with, the code official shall institute the appropriate proceeding at law or in equity to restrain, correct or abate such violation, or to require the removal or termination of the unlawful occupancy of the structure in violation of the provisions of this code or of the order or direction made pursuant thereto. Any action taken by the authority having jurisdiction on such premises shall be charged against the real estate upon which the structure is located and shall be a lien upon such real estate. 
Section 106.4 Violation; penalties. Any person who shall violate a provision of this code, or fail to comply therewith, or with any other requirements thereof, shall be responsible for a municipal civil infraction. 
Sections 110.1 through 110.4 Deleted. The provisions contained in section 110, Demolition, of the property maintenance code, shall be and hereby are deleted. 
Section 111.2 Board of appeals. The city construction and property maintenance board of appeals, created by section 6-26 of the City Code, shall serve as the board of appeals required by this property maintenance code. All references herein to the "board of appeals" or the "board," shall be deemed to refer to the construction and property maintenance board of appeals. 
Section 111.2.1 Deleted. 
Section 112.4 Failure to comply. Any person who shall continue any work after having been served with a stop work order, except such work as that person is directed to perform to remove a violation or unsafe condition, shall be responsible for a municipal civil infraction. 
Section 302.4 Deleted. 
Section 304.14 Insect screens. During the period from April 1 through October 15, every door, window and other outside opening required for ventilation of habitable rooms, food preparation areas, food service areas or any areas where products to be included or utilized in food for human consumption are processed, manufactured, packaged or stored, shall be supplied with approved tightly fitting screens of not less than 16 mesh per inch (16 mesh per 25 mm) and every swinging door shall have a self-closing device in good working condition. 
Exception. Screens shall not be required where other approved means, such as air curtains or insect repellent fans, are employed. 
Section 602.3 Heat supply. Every owner and operation of any building who rents, leases or lets one or more dwelling units, rooming units, dormitories or guestrooms on terms, either expressed or implied, to furnish heat to the occupants thereof, shall supply heat during the period from October 1 through May 15 to maintain a temperature of not less than 68° Fahrenheit (20° Celsius) in all habitable rooms, bathrooms, and toilet rooms. 
Exceptions: 
1.  When the outdoor temperature is below the winter outdoor design temperature for the locality, maintenance of the minimum room temperature shall not be required; provided that the heating system is operating at its full design capacity. The winter outdoor design temperature for the locality shall be as indicated in appendix D of the plumbing code. 
2.  In areas where the average monthly temperature is above 30° Fahrenheit (-1° Celsius) a minimum temperature of 65° Fahrenheit (18° Celsius) shall be maintained. 
Section 602.4 Occupiable work spaces. Indoor occupiable work spaces shall be supplied with heat during the period from October 1 through May 15 to maintain a temperature of not less than 65° Fahrenheit (18° Celsius), during the period the spaces are occupied. 
Exceptions: 
1.  Processing, storage and operation areas that require cooling or special temperature conditions. 
2.  Areas in which persons are primarily engaged in vigorous physical activities. 
(Code 1988, § 8.162; Ord. No. 406, § 1, 3-3-1998; Ord. No. 495, § 2, 6-21-2005; Ord. No. 554, § 2, 10-16-2012) 
Sec. 6-148. - Copy of code. 
    A complete copy of the International Property Maintenance Code, 2012 Edition, adopted by reference herein together with all amendments thereto shall be maintained in the office of the city clerk and made available to the public. 
(Ord. No. 554, § 3, 10-16-2012) 
Secs. 6-149-6-182. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - DANGEROUS BUILDINGS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 556, § 1, adopted Dec. 18, 2012, amended art. VII in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former art. VII, §§ 6-183-6-191, pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from: Code 1988, §§ 8.130-8.138. 
State Law reference- Dangerous buildings, MCL 125.538 et seq. 

Sec. 6-183. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Board means construction and property maintenance board of appeals. 
    Dangerous building means any building or structure that has any of the following defects or is in any of the following conditions: 
(1)  Whenever any door, aisle, passageway, stairway or other means of exit does not conform to the approved fire code of the city, it shall be considered that such dwelling does not meet the requirements of this article; 
(2)  Whenever any portion of the building or structure has been damaged by fire, wind, flood, deterioration, neglect, abandonment, vandalism, or other cause so that the structural strength or stability of the building or structure is appreciably less than it was before the damage and does not meet the minimum requirements of this article or any state construction code, for a new building or similar structure, purpose or location; 
(3)  Whenever any portion or member or appurtenance is likely to fall or to become detached or dislodged, or to collapse and thereby injure persons or damage property; 
(4)  Whenever any portion has settled to such an extent that walls or other structural portions have materially less resistance to winds than is required in the case of new construction by this article or the state construction code; 
(5)  Whenever the building or structure or any part, because of dilapidation, deterioration, decay, faulty construction, or because of the removal or movement of some portion of the ground necessary for the purpose of supporting such building or portion thereof, or for other reason, is likely to partially or completely collapse, or some portion of the foundation or underpinning is likely to fall or give away; 
(6)  Whenever for any reason whatsoever the building or structure or any portion is manifestly unsafe for the purpose for which it is used; 
(7)  Whenever the building or structure has been so damaged by fire, wind or flood, or has become so dilapidated or deteriorated as to become an attractive nuisance to children who might play therein to their danger, or as to afford a harbor for vagrants, criminals or immoral persons, or as to enable persons to resort thereto for the purpose of committing a nuisance or unlawful or immoral acts; 
(8)  Whenever a building or structure used or intended to be used for dwelling purposes, because of dilapidation, decay, damage or faulty construction or arrangement or otherwise, is unsanitary or unfit for human habitation or is in a condition that is likely to cause sickness or disease when so determined by the health officer, or is likely to work injury to the health, safety or general welfare of those living within; 
(9)  Whenever any building becomes vacant, dilapidated and open at a door or window, leaving the interior of the building exposed to the elements or accessible to entrance by trespassers or 
(10)  Whenever any building or structure remains unoccupied for a period of 180 consecutive days or longer, and is not listed as being available for sale, lease, or rent with a real estate broker licensed under article 25 of the occupational code, 1980 PA 299, MCL 339.2401 to 339.2518. For purposes of this subdivision, "building or structure" includes, but is not limited to, a commercial building or structure. This subdivision does not apply to either of the following: 
a.  A building or structure if the owner or agent does both of the following: 
1.  Notifies a local law enforcement agency in whose jurisdiction the building or structure is located that the building or structure will remain unoccupied for a period of 180 consecutive days. The notice shall be given to the local law enforcement agency by the owner or agent not more than 30 days after the building or structure becomes unoccupied. 
2.  Maintains the exterior of the building or structure and adjoining grounds in accordance with applicable building and property maintenance codes. 
b.  A secondary dwelling of the owner that is regularly unoccupied for a period of 180 days or longer each year, if the owner notifies a local law enforcement agency in whose jurisdiction the dwelling is located that the dwelling will remain unoccupied for a period of 180 consecutive days or more each year. An owner who has given the notice prescribed by this subsection shall notify the law enforcement agency not more than 30 days after the dwelling no longer qualifies for this exception. As used in this subsection, "secondary dwelling" means a dwelling, including, but not limited to, a vacation home, hunting cabin, or summer home, that is occupied by the owner or a member of the owner's family during part of a year. 
    Enforcing agency means the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 556, § 1, 12-18-2012) 
Sec. 6-184. - Prohibition. 
    It shall be unlawful for any owner or agent thereof to keep or maintain any dwelling or part thereof which is a dangerous building as defined in section 6-183. 
(Ord. No. 556, § 1, 12-18-2012) 
Sec. 6-185. - Notice and order. 
(a)  Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, when the whole or any part of any building or structure is found to be in a dangerous or unsafe condition, the enforcing agency shall issue a notice and order of the dangerous and unsafe condition. 
(b)  Such notice shall be directed to the owner, agent or lessee. If no owner, agent or lessee is known, then the notice shall be directed to each owner of or party in interest in the building in whose name the property is listed on the last tax assessment records. 
(c)  The notice shall be in writing and include a description of the property sufficient for identification and may require the owner of the building or premises, within 48 hours, to commence either the required alterations, repairs, or improvements, or the demolition and removal of the building and structure or portions thereof. All such work shall be completed within such period of time as the enforcing agency shall determine to be reasonable to accomplish the work, not to exceed 30 days, which period shall be stated in the notice. If necessary, such notice shall also require the building, structure, or portion thereof, to be vacated forthwith and not to be reoccupied until the required repairs and improvements are completed, inspected, and approved by the enforcing agency. 
(d)  All notices and orders shall be in writing and shall be served upon the person to whom they are directed personally, or in lieu of personal service, may be mailed by certified mail, return receipt requested, addressed to such owner or party in interest at the address shown on the tax records, at least ten days before the date of the hearing described in the notice. If any person to whom a notice and order is directed is not personally served, in addition to mailing the notice and order, a copy thereof shall be posted upon a conspicuous part of the building or structure. 
(e)  The enforcing agency shall file a copy of the notice and order of the dangerous and unsafe condition with the board. 
(Ord. No. 556, § 1, 12-18-2012) 
Sec. 6-186. - Failure to comply; order to show cause; notice lis pendens. 
    If, at the expiration of any time limit in the notice provided for in section 6-185, the owner has not complied with the requirements thereof, the enforcing agency shall issue a notice and order to show cause to the owner of the building. The notice and order to show cause shall specify the conditions making the building or structure dangerous, the action necessary to alleviate the dangerous condition, and shall inform the owner that the city will do the work necessary to alleviate the dangerous condition and assess the costs thereof against the premises if the work is not completed by the owner within a specified time period. The notice shall further inform the owner of the time and place at which he may have an opportunity for a hearing before the board to show cause why the building or structure should not be ordered to be demolished or otherwise made safe. Notice shall be given to the owner in the same manner as provided in section 6-185 and service of the notice shall be accomplished at least ten days prior to hearing. A copy of the notice and order to show cause shall be served on the occupant of the premises, if any, and a copy shall be filed by the enforcing agency with the county register of deeds. 
(Ord. No. 556, § 1, 12-18-2012) 
Sec. 6-187. - Hearing; decision by board. 
(a)  The board shall take testimony of the enforcing agency, the owner of the property and any interested party. The board shall render a decision either closing the proceedings or ordering the building to be demolished or otherwise made safe. 
(b)  If it is determined by the board that the building or structure should be demolished or otherwise made safe, the board shall so order, fixing a time in the order for the owner, agent or lessee to comply herewith. 
(Ord. No. 556, § 1, 12-18-2012) 
Sec. 6-188. - Failure to comply with order of board. 
    If the owner, agent or lessee fails to appear or neglects or refuses to comply with the order under section 6-187, the enforcing agency shall cause such building to be demolished or otherwise made safe. 
(Ord. No. 556, § 1, 12-18-2012) 
Sec. 6-189. - Reserved. 
Sec. 6-190. - Assessment of costs. 
(a)  The cost to the city of the demolition or of making a building safe shall be a lien against the real property and shall be reported to the assessing officer, who shall assess the cost against the property on which the building or structure is located. The costs referred to in this subsection shall include, but are not limited to, attorney fees, title search costs, recording and termination fees related to lis pendens and administrative fees. 
(b)  The owner or party in interest in whose name the property appears upon the last local tax assessment records shall be notified of the amount of such cost by first class mail at the address shown on the records. If the owner or party in interest fails to pay the same within 30 days after mailing by the assessor of the notice of the amount thereof, the assessor shall add the same to the next tax roll and the same shall be collected in the same manner in all respects as provided by law for the collection of taxes by the city. 
(Ord. No. 556, § 1, 12-18-2012) 
Sec. 6-191. - Judicial review. 
    An owner aggrieved by any final decision or order of the board under section 6-187 may appeal the decision or order to the circuit court by filing a petition for an order of superintending control within 20 days from the date of the decision. 
(Ord. No. 556, § 1, 12-18-2012) 
Secs. 6-192-6-220. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - HISTORIC PRESERVATION[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Michigan historical commission, MCL 399.1 et seq.; municipal historical commissions, MCL 399.171 et seq.; Local Historic Districts Act, MCL 399.201 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 6-221-6-248. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - HISTORIC DISTRICT STUDY COMMITTEE 

Sec. 6-249. - Creation. 
(a)  The city commission may create from time to time an Historic District Study Committee, which shall consist of not less than five or more than nine members, as established by resolution of the city commission. Each member shall be a resident of the city or a representative of a duly organized local historic preservation organization. Members shall be appointed by the city commission and serve without compensation. 
(b)  The committee shall be established pursuant to the local historic districts act, Public Act No. 169 1970 (MCL 399.201 et seq.). 
(Code 1988, § 8.301; Ord. No. 476, § 1, 5-6-2003) 
Sec. 6-250. - Appointment of committee. 
    Before establishing, modifying, or eliminating an historic district, the city commission shall appoint a Historic District Study Committee. Insofar as possible, members should have experience in conducting basic research, library studies, or archival information studies. At least one member shall be from a duly organized local historic preservation organization. 
(Code 1988, § 8.302; Ord. No. 476, § 1, 5-6-2003) 
Sec. 6-251. - Terms of members. 
    The city commission shall appoint the members of the Historic District Study Committee for the duration of a particular task or for a specific term, but in no case shall such term exceed a period of three years. Members of the committee can be removed by majority vote of the city commission. Vacancies occurring, other than through the expiration of a term, shall be filled for the unexpired term by the city commission. 
(Code 1988, § 8.303; Ord. No. 476, § 1, 5-6-2003) 
Sec. 6-252. - Organization. 
    The Historic District Study Committee shall elect a chairman from its membership. The committee shall also appoint a secretary who shall keep a record of all its proceedings. 
(Code 1988, § 8.304; Ord. No. 476, § 1, 5-6-2003) 
Sec. 6-253. - Meetings. 
    The Historic District Study Committee shall establish a schedule of regular meetings of the committee. Special meetings may be called by the chairman or by any two members of the committee on at least 18 hour's notice. The committee shall adopt rules of conduct. 
(Code 1988, § 8.305; Ord. No. 476, § 1, 5-6-2003) 
Sec. 6-254. - Duties. 
(a)  The Historic District Study Committee shall do all of the following: 
(1)  Conduct a photographic inventory of resources within each proposed historic district following procedures established or approved by the state department of history, arts and libraries. 
(2)  Conduct basic research of each proposed historic district and the historic resources located within that district. 
(3)  Determine the total number and relative percentages of historic and nonhistoric resources within a proposed historic district. In evaluating the significance of historic resources, the committee shall be guided by the selection criteria for evaluation issued by the United States Secretary of the Interior for inclusion of resources in the National Register of Historic Places, as set forth in 36 CFR 60, and criteria established or approved by the bureau, if any. 
(4)  Prepare a preliminary historic district study committee report that addresses, at a minimum, all of the following: 
a.  The charge of the committee. 
b.  The composition of the committee membership. 
c.  The historic district or districts studied. 
d.  The boundaries for each proposed historic district in writing and on maps. 
e.  The history of each proposed historic district. 
f.  The significance of each district as a whole, as well as a sufficient number of its individual resources to fully represent the variety of resources found within the district, relative to the evaluation criteria. 
(5)  Transmit copies of the preliminary report for review and recommendation to the planning commission, the bureau, the state historical commission, and the state Historic Preservation Review Board. 
(6)  Make copies of the preliminary report available to the public pursuant to subsection (d) of this section. 
(b)  Not less than 60 calendar days after the transmittal of the preliminary report, the committee shall hold a public hearing in compliance with Public Act No. 267 of 1976 (MCL 15.261 et seq.). Public notice of the time, date, and place of the hearing shall be given in the manner required by such Act. Written notice shall be mailed by first class mail not less than 14 calendar days before the hearing to the owners of properties within the proposed historic district, as listed on the tax rolls of the city. 
(c)  After the date of the public hearing, the committee and the city commission shall have not more than one year, unless otherwise authorized by the city commission, to take the following actions: 
(1)  The committee shall prepare and submit a final report with its recommendations and the recommendations, if any, of the planning commission of the city commission. If the recommendation of the city commission is to establish historic districts, the final report shall include a draft of proposed ordinances. 
(2)  After receiving a final report that recommends the establishment of historic districts, the city commission may, at its discretion, introduce and pass or reject ordinances. If the city commission passes an ordinance or ordinances establishing one or more historic districts, the city commission shall file a copy of those ordinances, including a legal description of the properties located within the historic districts, with the register of deeds. 
(d)  A writing prepared, owned, used, in the possession of, or retained by a committee in the performance of an official function shall be made available to the public in compliance with Public Act No. 442 of 1976 (MCL 15.231 et seq.). 
(Code 1988, § 8.306; Ord. No. 476, § 1, 5-6-2003) 
Sec. 6-255. - Reports. 
    The Historic District Study Committee shall prepare and submit to the city commission an annual report of the activities of the committee and tentative outline of its program for the ensuing year for a committee whose term exceeds one year. 
(Code 1988, § 8.307; Ord. No. 476, § 1, 5-6-2003) 
Sec. 6-256. - Procedures for establishing, modifying, or eliminating historic district resolutions. 
(a)  The city commission may, at any time, establish by ordinance additional historic districts, including proposed districts previously considered and rejected, may modify boundaries of an existing historic district, or may eliminate an existing historic district. Before establishing, modifying, or eliminating a historic district, the city commission shall, except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, comply with the procedures set forth in section 6-254, and shall consider any previously written committee reports pertinent to the proposed action. To conduct these activities, the city commission may retain the initial committee or establish a committee to consider only specific proposed districts and then be dissolved. 
(b)  If considering elimination of a historic district, the committee shall follow the procedures set forth in section 6-254 for issuing a preliminary report, holding a public hearing, and issuing a final report but with the intent of showing one or more of the following: 
(1)  The historic district has lost those physical characteristics that enabled establishment of the district. 
(2)  The historic district was not significant in the way previously defined. 
(3)  The historic district was established pursuant to defective procedures. 
(c)  Upon receipt of substantial evidence showing the presence of historic, architectural, archaeological, engineering, or cultural significance of a proposed historic district, the city commission may, at its discretion, establish a historic commission and require that all applications for permits within the proposed historic district be referred to such commission as prescribed by MCL 399.205 and 399.209. The historic commission shall review permit applications with the same powers that would apply if the proposed historic district was an established historic district. The review may continue in the proposed historic district for not more than one year, or until such time as the city commission approves or rejects the establishment of the historic district by ordinance, whichever occurs first. 
(d)  If the city commission determines that pending work will cause irreparable harm to resources located within an established historic district or a proposed historic district, the commission may, by resolution, declare an emergency moratorium of all such work for a period not to exceed six months. The commission may extend the emergency moratorium for an additional period not to exceed six months upon finding that the threat of irreparable harm to resources is still present. Any pending permit application concerning a resource subject to an emergency moratorium may be summarily denied. 
(Code 1988, § 8.308; Ord. No. 476, § 1, 5-6-2003) 
Secs. 6-257-6-275. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - HISTORIC DISTRICT COMMISSION[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Historic district commission, MCL 399.204. 

Sec. 6-276. - Creation; composition. 
(a)  There is hereby created the city historic district commission that shall consist of nine members. Each member shall be a resident of the city. Members shall be appointed by the mayor and shall serve without compensation. 
(b)  The historic district commission is established under the LHDA, Public Act No. 169 of 1970 (MCL 399.201 et seq.). 
(Code 1988, § 8.321; Ord. No. 479, § 1, 8-19-2003; Ord. No. 483, § 1, 9-16-2003; Ord. No. 486, § 1, 11-18-2003) 
Sec. 6-277. - Selection of members. 
    At least one member of the historic district commission shall be appointed from a list of citizens submitted by one or more duly organized and existing local historic preservation organizations, and at least one member shall be an architect duly registered in this state if such person is available for appointment. Members shall have a clearly demonstrated interest in or knowledge of historic preservation. 
(Code 1988, § 8.322; Ord. No. 479, § 1, 8-19-2003) 
Sec. 6-278. - Terms of members. 
    The members of the historic district commission shall serve for terms of office of three years; except that three members of the first historic district commission shall be appointed to serve for a term of one year, three for terms of two years and three for terms of three years. All members shall hold office until their successors are appointed. 
(Code 1988, § 8.323; Ord. No. 479, § 1, 8-19-2003; Ord. No. 483, § 2, 9-16-2003; Ord. No. 486, § 2, 11-18-2003) 
Sec. 6-279. - Removal of members; vacancies. 
(a)  Members of the historic district commission may, after a public hearing, be removed for cause. 
(b)  A vacancy occurring in the membership of the historic district commission for any reason shall be filled within 60 calendar days by a person appointed by the mayor for the duration of the unexpired term. 
(Code 1988, § 8.324; Ord. No. 479, § 1, 8-19-2003) 
Sec. 6-280. - Organization and meetings. 
(a)  The historic district commission shall, from its appointed members, elect a chairman and a vice-chairman. The chairman shall preside over the historic district commission. The vice-chairman shall, in the case of absence or disability of the chairman, perform the duties of the chairman. The historic district commission shall also elect a secretary, who shall keep a record of all resolutions, proceedings and actions of the historic district commission. 
(b)  Five members of the historic district commission shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of its business. The historic district commission shall adopt rules for the transaction of its business, which shall provide for the time and place of holding regular meetings. The historic district commission shall provide for the calling of special meetings by the chairman or by at least two members of the historic district commission. The historic district commission shall keep a full and complete record of its resolutions, transactions, findings and determinations, which record shall be available to the city commission and to the public upon request. 
(c)  The business that the historic district commission may perform shall be conducted at a public meeting held in compliance with the open meetings act, Public Act No. 267 of 1976 (MCL 15.261 et seq.). Public notice of the time, date and place of the meetings shall be given in a manner required by the open meetings act. A meeting agenda shall be part of the notice and shall include a listing of each permit application to be reviewed or considered by the historic district commission. 
(d)  The concurring affirmative vote of five members of the historic district commission shall be required for approval of plans before it for review or for the adoption of any resolution, motion or other action. 
(e)  The historic district commission shall adopt design review standards and guidelines to carry out its duties under the Local Historic Districts Act. 
(Code 1988, § 8.325; Ord. No. 479, § 1, 8-19-2003; Ord. No. 483, § 3, 9-16-2003; Ord. No. 486, § 3, 11-18-2003) 
Sec. 6-281. - Assistance. 
    The historic district commission may call upon the city manager for such services and data from the various departments as it may require. The historic district commission may recommend to the city commission the securing of such professional and consulting services as it may require; however, no expenditures of funds shall be made, or contracts entered into for providing such professional or consulting services, unless the same shall first be approved and authorized by the city commission. 
(Code 1988, § 8.326; Ord. No. 479, § 1, 8-19-2003) 
Sec. 6-282. - Permit required. 
    A permit shall be obtained before any work affecting the exterior appearance of a resource is performed within a historic district or, if required under section 6-283(c), work affecting the interior arrangements of a resource is performed within a historic district. The person proposing to do that work shall file an application for a permit with the city clerk. The application shall be immediately referred, together with all required supporting materials that make the application complete, to the historic district commission. A permit shall not be issued and proposed work shall not proceed until the historic district commission has acted on the application by issuing a Certificate of Appropriateness or a Notice to Proceed as prescribed in LHDA, Public Act No. 169 of 1970 (MCL 399.201 et seq.). The city commission may establish a reasonable fee to process a permit application by resolution. 
(Code 1988, § 8.327; Ord. No. 479, § 1, 8-19-2003) 
Sec. 6-283. - Duties. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the historic district commission to review all applications and supporting materials for permits for the construction, alteration, repair, moving or demolition of resources in a historic district and to determine whether or not a certificate of appropriateness or a notice to proceed shall be issued. 
(b)  In reviewing plans submitted to it, the historic district commission shall follow the United States Secretary of the Interior's Standards for Rehabilitation and Guidelines for Rehabilitating Historic Buildings, as set forth in 36 CFR 67. The local historic commission shall also give consideration to the following: 
(1)  The historical or architectural value and significance of the resource and its relationship to the historic value of the surrounding area; 
(2)  The relationship of any architectural features of the resource to the rest of the resource and to the surrounding area; 
(3)  The general compatibility of the design, arrangement, texture and materials proposed to be used; and 
(4)  Any other factor, including aesthetic value, which it deems relevant, including design review standards and guidelines which the historic district commission may adopt and maintain. 
(c)  The historic district commission shall act only on exterior features of a resource and shall not consider interior arrangements unless interior work will cause visible change to the exterior of the resource. The historic district commission shall only use the criteria set forth in subsection (b) of this section as a basis for its decisions. 
(d)  If the historic district commission approves of the plans submitted to it for its review, it shall issue a certificate of appropriateness. The city building official shall not issue a building permit unless and until such certificate of appropriateness has been issued by the historic district commission. 
(e)  If an application is for work that will adversely affect the exterior of a resource the historic district commission considers valuable to the local unit, state, or nation, and the historic district commission determines that the alteration or loss of that resource will adversely affect the public purpose of the local unit, state, or nation, the historic district commission shall attempt to establish with the owner of the resource an economically feasible plan for preservation of the resource. 
(f)  Work within a historic district shall be permitted through the issuance of a notice to proceed by the historic district commission if any of the following conditions prevail and if the proposed work can be demonstrated by a finding of the historic district commission to be necessary to substantially improve or correct any of the following conditions: 
(1)  The resource constitutes a hazard to the safety of the public or to the resource's occupants. 
(2)  The resource is a deterrent to a major improvement program that will be of substantial benefit to the community and the applicant proposing the work has obtained all necessary planning and zoning approvals, financing, and environmental clearances. 
(3)  Retaining the resource will cause undue financial hardship to the owner when a governmental action, an act of God, or other events beyond the owner's control created the hardship, and all feasible alternatives to eliminate the financial hardship, which may include offering the resource for sale at its fair market value or moving the resource to a vacant site within the historic district, have been attempted and exhausted by the owner. 
(4)  Retaining the resource is not in the interest of the majority of the community. 
(g)  The historic district commission may delegate the issuance of certificates of appropriateness for specified minor classes of work to the building official or to another delegated official. The historic district commission shall provide to the delegated authority specific written standards for issuing certificates of appropriateness under this subsection. On at least a quarterly basis, the historic district commission shall review the certificates of appropriateness, if any, so issued for work to determine whether or not the delegated responsibilities should be continued. 
(h)  Upon a finding by the historic district commission that a historic resource within a historic district or a proposed historic district subject to its review and approval is threatened with demolition by neglect, the historic district commission may do either of the following: 
(1)  Require the owner of the resource to repair all conditions contributing to demolition by neglect. 
(2)  If the owner does not make repairs within a reasonable time as established by the building official, the historic district commission or its agents may enter the property upon obtaining an order from the Circuit Court and make such repairs as are necessary to prevent demolition by neglect. The costs of the work shall be charged to the owner, and may be collected as a special assessment against the property in accordance with chapter XII, section 8 of the city Charter. 
(i)  When work has been done upon a resource without a permit, and the historic district commission finds that the work does not qualify for a certificate of appropriateness, the historic district commission may require an owner to restore the resource to the condition the resource was in before the inappropriate work or to modify the work so that it qualifies for a certificate of appropriateness.
