If the owner does not comply with the restoration or modification requirement within a reasonable time, the historic district commission may request the city commission to seek an order from the Circuit Court to require the owner to restore the resource to its former condition or to modify the work so that it qualifies for a certificate of appropriateness. If the owner does not comply or cannot comply with the order of the court, the historic district commission or its agents may enter the property and conduct work necessary to restore the resource to its former condition or modify the work so that it qualifies for a certificate of appropriateness in accordance with the court's order. The costs of the work shall be charged to the owner, and may be levied as a special assessment against the property in accordance with chapter XII, section 8 of the city Charter. When acting pursuant to an order of the Circuit Court, the historic district commission or its agents may enter a property for purposes of this section. 
(Code 1988, § 8.328; Ord. No. 479, § 1, 8-19-2003; Ord. No. 486, § 4, 11-18-2003) 
Sec. 6-284. - Historic district commission; filings with delegated authority; duties of local public officials, employees, and department. 
    The historic district commission shall file certificates of appropriateness, notices to proceed, and denials of applications for permits with the inspector of buildings or other delegated authority. A permit shall not be issued until the historic district commission has acted as prescribed by this division. If a permit application is denied, the decision shall be binding on the inspector or other authority. A denial shall be accompanied with a written explanation by the historic district commission of the reasons for denial and, if appropriate, a notice that an application may be resubmitted for historic district commission review when suggested changes have been made. The denial shall also include notification of the applicant's rights of appeal to the State Historic Preservation Review Board and to the Circuit Court. The failure of the historic district commission to act within 60 calendar days after the date a complete application is filed with the historic district commission, unless an extension is agreed upon in writing by the applicant and the historic district commission shall be considered to constitute approval. No certificate of appropriateness or notice to proceed shall be valid for a period exceeding one year from the date of approval. Thirty days prior to the expiration date, the applicant may make application for a six month extension with no fee. The applicant shall explain in writing why the work has not proceeded, what the current time frame is and why an extension should be granted. 
(Code 1988, § 8.329; Ord. No. 479, § 1, 8-19-2003; Ord. No. 486, § 5, 11-18-2003) 
Sec. 6-285. - Appeal of decisions. 
    An applicant aggrieved by a decision of the historic district commission concerning a permit application may file an appeal with the state Historic Preservation Review Board of the state historical commission within 60 days after the decision is furnished to the applicant. A permit applicant aggrieved by the decision of the state Historic Preservation Review Board may appeal the decision to the Circuit Court having jurisdiction. 
(Code 1988, § 8.330; Ord. No. 479, § 1, 8-19-2003) 
Sec. 6-286. - Ordinary maintenance. 
    Nothing in this division shall be construed to prevent ordinary maintenance or repair of a resource within a historic district, or to prevent work on any resource under a permit issued by the inspector of buildings or other duly delegated authority before the division was enacted. 
(Code 1988, § 8.331; Ord. No. 479, § 1, 8-19-2003) 
Sec. 6-287. - Violations; penalties. 
    A person that violates this division is responsible for a municipal civil infraction and subject to payment of a civil fine in the amount of $500.00 plus costs. Nothing contained in this section shall limit the availability of injunctive relief to the city in appropriate circumstances or otherwise limit, in any way, such police and remedial actions as are available to the city under law. 
(Code 1988, § 8.332; Ord. No. 479, § 1, 8-19-2003) 
Secs. 6-288-6-307. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - HISTORICAL DISTRICTS 

Sec. 6-308. - Hill Historic District. 
    The Hill Historic District is hereby established and is bounded and described as follows: Property in the Huntington Woods Subdivision, according to the plat thereof as recorded in Liber 16, p. 34 of Plats, Oakland County Records, consisting of lots 104 through 139, lots 226 through 265, lots 487 through 499, and lots 648 through 675 of the Huntington Woods Subdivision along with two parks, the city park bounded by York, Borgman and Huntington (also known as Sidwell #25-21-104-011) and the city park bounded by Nadine, Pembroke and Salem (also known as Sidwell #25-21-155-001). 
(Ord. No. 490, § 1(8.341), 10-19-2004) 
Sec. 6-309. - Rackham Historic District 
    The Rackham Historic District is hereby established and is bounded and described as follows: Land in the City of Huntington Woods, County of Oakland, State of Michigan, more particularly described as follows: 
    Commencing at the south quarter corner of section 20, T.1N., R.11E.; thence N 02°33'21"W along the north-south quarter section line, 221.65 feet to a point on the northerly right-of-way line of Interstate 696, (Walter P. Reuther Freeway); thence S 89°07'21"E. along said line, 43.08 feet to a point on the easterly line of Scotia Road, as widened to 86 feet by the Village of Huntington Woods in 1928, adopted by the City of Detroit and recorded on September 25, 1928 in J.C.C. Pages 2577-2578, said point being the point of beginning of the above described parcel; thence N.02°33'21"W along the easterly line of Scotia Rd., 1,932.36 feet to a line which is 50.0 feet south of the north line of Ludlow Ave., thence N 87°39'07"E. along said line, 2,661.39 feet; thence S 01°47'44"E along the easterly line of section 20, 2,126.68 feet; thence along the northerly right-of-way line of Interstate 696 for the remaining six courses, beginning with a curve, concave to the north, having an arc length of 285.02 feet, a radius of 1,882.96 feet and a long chord of 284.75 feet which bears N 84°19'15"W to a point of tangency; thence N 79°59'04"W, 198.86 feet to a point of curvature; thence 835.05 feet along the arc of a curve, concave to the south having a radius of 3,941.72 feet and a long chord of 833.49 feet which bears N 86°03'12"W to a point of tangency; thence S 87°52'39"W, 888.65 feet to a point of curvature; thence 298.59 feet along the arc of a curve, concave to the north, having a radius of 5,702.58 feet and a long chord of 298.55 feet which bears S 89°22'39"W to a point of tangency; thence N 89°07'21"W, 142.36 feet to the point of beginning, containing 120.7092 acres more or less. 
(Ord. No. 510, § 1(8.342), 11-21-2006) 
Secs. 6-310-6-336. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - FENCES, WALLS AND HEDGES 

Sec. 6-337. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section: 
    Fence: A structure serving to enclose or divide all or part of a lot, or to function as a boundary or barrier between two or more lots. 
    Hedge: A row of shrubs or trees used as a fence. 
    Wall: A fence built of solid material such as stone, brick, concrete or timbers (as used in a retaining wall). 
(Code 1988, § 8.20; Ord. No. 380, § 1, 9-19-1995; Ord. No. 441, § 1, 3-14-2000; Ord. No. 559, § 1, 5-21-2013) 
Sec. 6-338. - Application and permit required. 
    No person shall erect or rebuild any fence or wall unless such person shall first have applied for and received a permit therefor from the city manager or the city manager's designee. Information required on the application for a permit to build or rebuild a fence or wall shall include the name, address, and signature of the applying landowner and the proposed location, height, type, style, and materials of the proposed fence or wall. The city manager or the city manager's designee shall examine all applications and, if the application appears to comply with all provisions of this Code and does not appear to violate any law, and if all applicable fees have been paid, a permit shall be issued to the applicant. 
(Code 1988, § 8.21; Ord. No. 349, § 1, 9-19-1989; Ord. No. 371, § 1, 4-19-1994; Ord. No. 441, § 2, 3-14-2000) 
Sec. 6-339. - Fees. 
    The fees for a permit required by the provisions of this article shall be as determined by the city commission by resolution. 
(Code 1988, § 8.22; Ord. No. 349, § 1, 9-19-1989; Ord. No. 371, § 2, 4-19-1994; Ord. No. 441, § 3, 3-14-2000) 
Sec. 6-340. - Structural requirements. 
(a)  Fences. Fences shall be constructed of an open pattern metal, woven wire, wood or vinyl, in such a manner so that there shall be either horizontal or vertical openings or both, of at least three inches in width provided for the full length or height of the fence, and provided further that said fence shall not obstruct vision to an extent greater than 50 percent of the total area. 
(b)  Walls. Walls on nonresidential property shall be constructed in accordance with the regulations of section 40-220. Walls on residential property shall be constructed in accordance with the following: 
(1)  A wall shall not be constructed in a dedicated easement or within four feet of the location of an underground utility; and 
(2)  A wall that exceeds 30 inches in height shall be a minimum of eight inches in width with a reinforced trench foundation 42 inches below grade and a minimum of four inches wider than the wall to be constructed. 
(c)  Openings. The openings in a fence may be reduced or eliminated, or a solid wall may be constructed if: 
(1)  The fence or wall will be located in a required side or rear yard, and the property owner adjacent to the proposed fence or wall approves, in writing, such variations or deviations of the restrictions contained in this article, and such written consent accompanies the application for a fence or wall permit; 
(2)  The fence or wall will be located in the rear yard adjacent to a public right-of-way; or 
(3)  The fence or wall will enclose a pool or hot tub if part of the enclosure is in a required side or rear yard. Subsection (c)(1) of this section shall also apply. 
(Code 1988, § 8.23; Ord. No. 349, § 1, 9-19-1989; Ord. No. 441, § 4, 3-14-2000) 
Sec. 6-341. - Height and location requirements. 
(a)  Maximum height limit. No fence or wall shall exceed four feet in height, and no hedge shall exceed six feet in height as measured from the surface of the ground, except as follows: 
(1)  Where there is a change in grade between adjacent properties, a fence or wall which runs along the change in grade and defines or outlines the lot line may exceed four feet in height, as measured from the downhill property, so long as it does not exceed four feet as measured from the uphill property. 
(2)  A fence or wall may be constructed up to six feet in height, provided that the property owner adjacent to the proposed fence or wall shall approve, in writing, of the additional height and such written consent shall accompany the application for a fence or wall permit, and provided further that the fence or wall meets all other requirements of this article. 
(3)  On a corner lot, a fence or wall may be constructed up to six feet in height, provided it is constructed in the rear yard and adjacent to a public right-of-way. 
(4)  To protect adjacent residential uses, fences or walls up to six feet in height are permissible in the side or rear yards of nonresidential properties which are adjacent to residential property. 
(5)  To protect adjacent residential uses, fences or screening walls up to eight feet in height are permissible upon nonresidential property used to store dump trucks, cars or heavy equipment, or upon which salt, sand or other raw materials are stockpiled. 
(6)  To protect adjacent property and passers-by, fences up to 20 feet in height are permissible upon public property used for parks, playgrounds, ballfields and golf courses. 
(7)  The columns or support posts of a fence or wall may exceed the height limit of the fence or wall by no more than eight inches. 
(b)  In side yard. No fence, wall or hedge shall be erected, constructed, planted or rebuilt in the side yard (as defined in section 40-1), except as follows: 
(1)  A house having a side door entrance may have a fence or wall up to four feet in height extending toward the front of the house for distance not to exceed three feet in front of the side door. 
(2)  A fence or wall up to six feet in height may be located forward of the rearmost portion of a house; provided that, the fence or wall shall be no further forward than the rear corner of the house that is adjacent to the side yard where the fence or wall will be located; and provided further, that the side yard area to be enclosed contains a side or rear door access. 
(3)  A hedge, not to exceed four feet in height, may be located in the required side yard on either side of the house; however, if the proposed hedge is adjacent to a neighbor's driveway, the property owner adjacent to the proposed hedge shall approve of the hedge, in writing, and such written consent shall be filed with the city manager, or the city manager's designee, prior to the planting of the hedge. 
(4)  Where the side yard is adjacent to Coolidge Highway, a fence, wall or hedge is permitted up to six feet in height. 
(5)  On corner lots, the side yard adjacent to the street shall be treated as an additional front yard and subject to the requirements in subsection (c) of this section. 
(c)  In front yard. No fence, wall or hedge shall be erected, constructed, planted, maintained or rebuilt in the front yard (as defined in section 40-1), except a hedge which is less than 30 inches in height may be located in the front yard, subject to the following conditions: 
(1)  The total length, regardless of location, shall not exceed 50 percent of the lot width as measured along the front lot line. 
(2)  The outer growth of the hedge shall not project over the lot line. 
(d)  Maximum height for driveway clearance. No fence, wall or hedge which obstructs the visibility of sidewalks or streets from any driveway on the property, or any pre-existing driveway on an adjacent property, may exceed 30 inches in height if located within ten feet of the intersection of the driveway edges and the sidewalk. 
(e)  Grandfathering of existing fences and walls. Fences and walls already erected as of the date the ordinance from which this section is derived becomes effective may be maintained at their current height so long as such is in compliance with the law existing at the time of erection. However, the height of any such fence or wall must be made to comply with this section if any structural alteration is made, or if any structural alteration is necessary to safely or properly maintain the fence or wall. All hedges must be maintained at or below the height limits specified herein whether planted before or after the effective date of the ordinance from which this section is derived. 
(Code 1988, § 8.24; Ord. No. 349, § 1, 9-19-1989; Ord. No. 380, § 3, 9-19-1995; Ord. No. 392, § 1, 12-17-1996; Ord. No. 441, § 5, 3-14-2000; Ord. No. 559, § 2, 5-21-2013) 
Sec. 6-342. - Clearance from city property. 
(a)  City sidewalk. A fence, wall or outer growth of a hedge shall be a minimum of one foot from any city sidewalk. 
(b)  City right-of-way. No fence, wall or hedge may be located in the city's right-of-way, including but not limited to, that area between the street and the sidewalk. For any fence or wall equipped with a gate, such gate shall not swing over the city's right-of-way. 
(Code 1988, § 8.25; Ord. No. 349, § 1, 9-19-1989; Ord. No. 380, § 4, 9-19-1995; Ord. No. 441, § 6, 3-14-2000) 
Sec. 6-343. - Other restrictions. 
(a)  Vacant lots. On a vacant lot, no fence or wall may be erected nearer to the front lot line than 50 feet. 
(b)  One fence per lot line. Only one fence or wall may be erected along a common lot line in the combined required side and rear yards. 
(c)  Dog runs prohibited. No fence or wall shall be used for the exclusive containment of a dog. 
(Code 1988, § 8.26; Ord. No. 349, § 2, 9-19-1989; Ord. No. 371, § 4, 4-19-1994; Ord. No. 380, § 5, 9-19-1995; Ord. No. 441, § 7, 3-14-2000) 
Sec. 6-344. - Finished face of partition fences and walls. 
    The finished face of any fence or wall shall face outside the permit holder's property, with the visible posts or supports being located on the inside of the fence or wall, unless: 
(1)  The fence is so constructed that both sides of the fence are the same (such as a board-on-board or shadow box fence); or 
(2)  The adjoining property owner consents in writing to allow the visible posts or supports to be located on the outside of the fence, and such written consent accompanies the application for a fence permit. If a neighbor chooses to add a second finished face to a fence: 
a.  A written consent from the owner of the fence shall accompany the application for a fence permit for the second finished face; and 
b.  The height of the second finished face shall not exceed the height of the original fence. 
(Code 1988, § 8.27; Ord. No. 349, § 2, 9-19-1989; Ord. No. 371, § 5, 4-19-1994; Ord. No. 380, § 6, 9-19-1995; Ord. No. 441, § 8, 3-14-2000) 
Sec. 6-345. - Dilapidated or dangerous fences and walls; blight. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the owner upon whose property the fences or wall are located to ensure that all fences or walls are installed and maintained plumb, with adequate support and footings, and in a safe and sightly manner. If the fences or walls are deemed to be on the lot line and the ownership is not known, it shall be the duty of both adjoining property owners to maintain the fences or walls in a safe and sightly manner. 
(b)  The building official of the city is hereby authorized to order the removal or repair of fences and walls that are dangerous, damaged, paint peeled, dilapidated, or otherwise in violation of this Code or state or federal law. 
(Code 1988, § 8.28; Ord. No. 349, § 2, 9-19-1989; Ord. No. 371, § 6, 4-19-1994) 
Sec. 6-346. - Prohibited materials. 
(a)  No fence or wall shall be constructed, in whole or in part, of barbed wire or in such a manner as to attach any spike, nail, or other sharp point, instrument or material. 
(b)  No fence or wall shall be electrically charged or connected to an electrical current, except for a fence installed below ground as an element of an animal control system. 
(c)  No fence or wall shall be constructed of corrugated plastic or contain woven plastic materials. 
(Code 1988, § 8.29; Ord. No. 349, § 2, 9-19-1989; Ord. No. 380, § 8, 9-19-1995; Ord. No. 407, § 1, 5-5-1998) 
Sec. 6-347. - Violations; remedies. 
(a)  A person who erects, installs or maintains any fence, wall or hedge in violation of any provision of this article, or who builds or constructs a fence, wall or hedge without a required permit, or in violation of the provisions of a permit, is responsible for a municipal civil infraction. 
(b)  Any fence, wall, or hedge erected, installed, or maintained in violation of this article shall be deemed a public nuisance and may be abated by injunctive process. Each day of maintenance contrary to this article after notice of violation shall be deemed an additional and distinct violation thereof. 
(c)  Nothing in this article shall be construed to limit, in any way, the police and remedial actions available to the city under the law. 
(Code 1988, § 8.30; Ord. No. 349, § 2, 9-19-1989; Ord. No. 412, § 1, 5-19-1998) 
Sec. 6-348. - Relief available. 
    An application for relief from sections 6-340 through 6-345, 6-347 and/or 6-349 may be filed with and granted in whole or in part by the zoning board of appeals. An application for relief from section 6-340 may be filed with and granted in whole or in part by the construction board of appeals. Relief may be granted by above-named boards only if it is shown that compliance with the applicable ordinance provision will result in undue hardship to the applicant. 
(Code 1988, § 8.31; Ord. No. 349, § 2, 9-19-1989; Ord. No. 441, § 9, 3-14-2000; Ord. No. 582, § 1, 5-24-2016) 
Sec. 6-349. - Zoo fencing and screening adjacent to Huntington Road. 
(a)  Applicability. This section shall apply to any zoo fencing or screening along the frontage of Huntington Road that is located within 120 feet of the Huntington Road centerline. 
(b)  Fence and screening requirements: 
(1)  Perimeter fence. 
a.  Definition: Fence directly abutting and parallel to Huntington Road. 
b.  Perimeter fence shall be a black chain link fence. Barbwire is permitted only at the top of the fence. Razor wire is prohibited. The planning commission may approve the use of another material. 
c.  No tarp shall be affixed or located within 15 feet of the perimeter fence. 
d.  The maximum permitted perimeter fence height is ten feet, including barbwire portion. 
(2)  Operation, service area, or indoor animal habitat. 
a.  Definition: An exterior area to the rear of a building that is used for zoo operations, services, or indoor animal habitat including, but not limited to, trash enclosure areas, outdoor storage, concession stands, utility areas, and building for animal habitat. 
b.  Operations, service area, or indoor animal habitat areas shall be screened either with a landscape screen located along the existing Huntington Road perimeter fence that provides a minimum of 80 percent opacity; or a fence of a natural material such as wood or bamboo. 
c.  The maximum permitted fence height for operation, service area, or indoor animal habitat areas is six feet. 
(3)  Outside animal habitat. 
a.  Definition: An exterior area in which animals are confined within enclosures, to be displayed, bred, cared for, or rehabilitated. 
b.  Outside animal habitat areas may be screened either by a fence of natural material such as wood or bamboo; or a tarp screening if said tarp is supplemented with landscape screening along the existing Huntington Road perimeter fence that provides a minimum 80 percent opacity. No tarp shall be located within 15 feet of the perimeter fence. 
c.  The maximum permitted fence height for an outside animal habitat area is ten feet. 
(4)  Construction area. 
a.  Definition: An exterior area where construction work is being undertaken. 
b.  Screening for a construction area shall only be valid for six months in length. Any period longer than six months in length shall require an extension from the zoning administrator. 
c.  The maximum permitted fence height for a construction area is eight feet. 
(5)  Other area. 
a.  Definition: Portion of zoo adjacent to Huntington Road that does not meet the definition of operations or service area, animal habitat, or construction area. 
b.  Only landscaping shall be permitted in these areas. 
(6)  For any portion of the zoo adjacent to Huntington Road that meets two or more of the fence type area definitions as set forth in subsections (b)(1)-(b)(5) of this section, the greater fencing or screening requirement shall apply. 
(Ord. No. 582, § 2, 5-24-2016) 
Secs. 6-350-6-369. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - AIR CONDITIONING AND REFRIGERATION EQUIPMENT 

Sec. 6-370. - Purpose. 
(a)  The installation and use of all central air conditioning equipment hereafter installed in the city, for the purpose of reducing the dry bulb temperature or decreasing the absolute humidity of air, whether for physical comfort air conditioning, refrigeration, processing or whatever other purposes, shall conform to this article. 
(b)  This article shall apply to all new refrigerating and air conditioning systems, to the reinstallation of used equipment, to alterations or additions to existing systems, and to existing systems regarding regulation of noise. 
(Code 1988, § 2.100) 
Sec. 6-371. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Air conditioning system means an installation for maintenance, by heat removal, of temperatures which are not less than 60° Fahrenheit as applied to space within the buildings. 
    Air conditioning system and refrigeration system means any combination of equipment, whether compressor or other type, by which heat is removed from the air and from which the accumulated or effluent heat is wholly or partially removed by the use of water or air-cooled refrigerants. 
    Inspector means the chief inspector or the chief inspector's agent. 
    Manager means the city manager or such officer or agent as the city manager shall duly authorize to act in enforcement of these regulations. 
    Refrigeration system means an installation for maintenance, by heat removal, of temperatures which are less than 60° Fahrenheit. 
    System means any combination of apparatus, individual unit, group or collection of units supplied with water through any single customer service pipe connected to the public water system or using air-cooled refrigerants. 
(Code 1988, § 2.101) 
Sec. 6-372. - Permit required. 
    No person shall install, alter or make major replacements in any part of a central refrigerating or air conditioning system until such person has filed with the city and received an approval permit for the work specifically intended on each individual system. 
(1)  Blueprints required. Blueprints or suitable sketches shall be submitted for all central refrigeration or air conditioning systems installed showing the location of major units. 
(2)  Installation. An air conditioner may be installed outside the main building provided such air conditioner is in conformance with regulations of section 40-355 and section 14-56. For the purposes of this section, open patios shall not be considered a portion of the structure. 
(3)  Nuisance. No equipment used for central air conditioning and installed outside shall be operated in such a manner as to create a noise nuisance. 
(4)  Appeals. A person shall have the right to appeal the rulings of the inspector and manager to the city commission in those instances where practical difficulties or unnecessary hardships stand in the way of carrying out the strict letter of the installation provisions. The person shall have the right to a hearing before the city commission and shall have the right to present evidence. In the case of every such variance appeal the city commission shall make specific findings of fact concerning the reason for allowing or disallowing the variance. 
(Code 1988, § 2.102; Ord. No. 307, § 1, 8-18-1987; Ord. No. 489, § 1(2.102), 8-17-2004) 
Sec. 6-373. - Application for permit. 
    Application for permit shall be made to the inspector and shall provide the following information: 
(1)  Name and address of the applicant. 
(2)  Location of the premises where installation is proposed. 
(3)  Name and address of the owners of the premises. 
(4)  Names of manufacturers of the units requiring water. 
(5)  Manufacturer's identification and classification of the refrigeration units. 
(6)  Manufacturer's rating of maximum refrigeration capacity of the unit or units under the conditions of the planned installation. Rating may be stated in tons per 24 hours or in BTU per hour. 
(7)  Horsepower of compressor prime mover, if unit is of compressor type. 
(8)  Where water conservation devices are required, to comply with section 6-378, the manufacturer's name, identification, classification and size of the conservation equipment. 
(9)  Elevation and plan showing general piping arrangement and details of all points of connection to building supply water piping. Piping directly attached to condenser units makeup supply into the tower pan and so forth. 
(10)  Size of water service connection required. 
(11)  Such additional information as shall be required by the inspector. 
(12)  Applications shall be filed in the name of the owner of the equipment, and signed by the owner or the owner's agent. Applications for installation shall designate a master plumber and electrical contractor duly qualified to receive permits under this Code. 
(Code 1988, § 2.103) 
Sec. 6-374. - Rated capacities. 
(a)  For the purposes of these regulations, in no event shall the rated capacity in tons be considered less than the following: 
(1)  Total maximum BTU per hour of capacity of the installation divided by 12,000; 
(2)  The nameplate horsepower of any compressor prime mover unit, for any air conditioning installation; or 
(3)  Two-thirds the nameplate horsepower of subsection (a)(2) of this section, for any refrigeration installation. 
(b)  In the absence of the required manufacturer's maximum rating according to section 6-373(6), the inspector may specify the tonnage of the installation at the ratings indicated by subsection (a)(1), (2) or (3) of this section; or, if these appear inadequate, then by whatever other measure of capacity appears to the inspector to be proper. 
(Code 1988, § 2.104) 
Sec. 6-375. - Inspection fees. 
    Inspection fees as fixed by resolution of the city commission shall be paid by applicants to the city treasurer at the time of the issuance of permits. Such fees shall be in addition to the required plumbing and electrical fees. 
(Code 1988, § 2.105) 
Sec. 6-376. - Permit to install plumbing and electrical wiring. 
(a)  Permits to install plumbing and electrical wiring will be issued by the inspector, but only in the names of licensed plumbers and electrical contractors who are duly registered to do work within the area of the premises involved, or to those in the employ of the municipal, state, or federal governments for premises in their respective charge. 
(b)  Within 48 hours following the completion of any work authorized by permit, notice of completion and request for inspection shall be returned in writing by the applicant receiving the air conditioning permit, to the office from which the permit was obtained. 
(Code 1988, § 2.106) 
Sec. 6-377. - Permit to operate. 
    After the final inspection and approval of the installation, a permit to operate or use the equipment will be issued by the inspector in the name of the owner of the equipment. A record of such inspection, approval and issuance shall be kept on file in the office of the inspector. 
(Code 1988, § 2.107) 
Sec. 6-378. - Water use and conservation. 
(a)  All water-cooled air conditioning equipment shall be of the approved water conserving type. 
(b)  Rated capacity. The capacity of a unit in tons shall be the greatest of the following: 
(1)  The manufacturer's rating in tons per 24 hours of equivalent ice making capacity. 
(2)  The 24-hour BTU rating of heat removal capacity divided by 288,000. 
(3)  The horsepower rating of the motor driving the refrigerant compressor. 
(4)  Nine-tenths of the horsepower rating of a motor driving both compressor and fan. 
(5)  Where none of the above ratings is available, or where question arises as to the accuracy of any rating, the rating shall be determined by measurement of power input to the compressor motor, the rate of fuel consumption, or other suitable means. 
(Code 1988, § 2.108) 
Sec. 6-379. - Approved water conserving type. 
    An approved water conserving type shall be one: 
(1)  Which is equipped with cooling tower, atmospheric condenser, spray pond, or other equipment which shall directly or indirectly cool refrigerant; 
(2)  Which can use water from the city water system only for makeup water to replace water lost by evaporation or by flushing of the equipment; 
(3)  Which uses an average of less than 12 gallons of water from the city water system per hour per ton of cooling capacity when the unit is operating; and 
(4)  Which has no piping connection to allow operation of the air conditioning unit by direct use of water from the city water system either in conjunction with or in place of such cooling tower, atmospheric condenser, spray pond, or other recirculating and heat-exchanging equipment. 
(Code 1988, § 2.109) 
Sec. 6-380. - Sanitary protection. 
(a)  On installations which operate with the use of water directly from the public supply system, every direct connection shall be equipped with a suitable brass-body, brass-fitted check valve installed in the branch supply line to each unit. 
(b)  Discharge connections for the disposal of wastewaters shall be in strict accordance with applicable rules and regulations of state and local health and regulatory bodies. 
(c)  Cooling waters which are to be reused for other purposes shall be provided with free, above the rim discharge before entering other equipment; otherwise, permission shall be obtained in writing from the inspector approving the proposed connections and use. 
(d)  On installations other than those described in this section, there shall be a physical break between the public water supply piping and the piping of the installation, so arranged as to make impossible back siphonage to the public water supply system. 
(Code 1988, § 2.110) 
Sec. 6-381. - Suspension and revocation of permits. 
(a)  Any permit which has been issued under this article to operate or use equipment may be suspended by the chief inspector for any of the following reasons: 
(1)  Failure of the holder of the permit to discontinue using water for the purposes covered by the permit, immediately upon notice to do so issued by the inspector during an emergency or to forestall an impending emergency. 
(2)  Alterations, changes of equipment or piping, improper operation or lack of maintenance which results in conditions that: 
a.  Are hazardous to the potable water supply either within the premises or in supply mains; or 
b.  Cause unnecessary waste of water. 
(3)  Failure to comply with the noise limiting provisions of this article. 
(b)  In case of failure of the holder of the suspended permit to rectify or correct the conditions which caused the suspension, the permit may be revoked by the city manager. The city manager shall give the holder written notice of the revocation of said permit and such holder may at any time within ten days of receipt of said notice ask for a hearing before the city manager. At such hearing, the holder of the revoked permit may produce witnesses and show cause, if the holder has any, why the holder's permit should be reinstated. After such hearing, the city manager shall have authority to either reinstate the permit or confirm the rescinding thereof and the city manager's decision thereon shall be final. 
(c)  In case of suspension or revocation of any license, the city manager shall have authority to disconnect the water supply from such refrigeration or water-cooled equipment. 
(Code 1988, § 2.111) 
Secs. 6-382-6-405. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - PRIVATE OUTDOOR SWIMMING POOLS 

Sec. 6-406. - Legislative determination. 
    It is hereby determined that outdoor swimming pools may endanger the public safety unless carefully regulated and supervised. 
(Code 1988, § 6.61) 
Sec. 6-407. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Swimming pool means a structure either above or below grade, which has a normal water depth at any point of 24 inches or greater. 
(Code 1988, § 6.62; Ord. No. 327, § 1, 6-27-1989; Ord. No. 379, § 1, 5-2-1995) 
Sec. 6-408. - Permit required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to construct or maintain an outdoor swimming pool without first making application to the city manager and obtaining a permit therefor. 
(Code 1988, § 6.63) 
Sec. 6-409. - Application. 
    Such application shall show the name of the owner, the location of the proposed pool, the manner in which its use shall be supervised, the safety precautions to be made to protect those making use thereof, or who might be endangered thereby, and shall be accompanied by such other information necessary for the protection of the public health and safety as may be required by the city manager. 
(Code 1988, § 6.64) 
Sec. 6-410. - Fence. 
    No swimming pool shall be constructed, operated or conducted out-of-doors unless it is located within a fenced enclosure, which is to be locked at all times when unattended, so as to prevent trespassing children or adults from entering upon the premises and being injured. 
(Code 1988, § 6.65) 
Sec. 6-411. - Supervision. 
    No person shall maintain an outdoor swimming pool on their premises without providing adequate supervision at all times when the pool is in use so that no person may be injured or drowned therein. 
(Code 1988, § 6.66) 
Sec. 6-412. - Health standards. 
    Any outdoor swimming pool shall not be used unless adequate public health measures are periodically taken to ensure that the use thereof will not cause the spread of disease. The water of all pools shall be sterilized by chlorinated water. The current standards set by the state department of environmental quality and the county department of public health to protect public health in the use of such swimming pools are hereby adopted and made a part of this article. 
(Code 1988, § 6.67) 
Secs. 6-413-6-437. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XII. - EMERGENCY ALARM SYSTEMS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Emergency telephone service enabling act, MCL 484.1201 et seq. 

Sec. 6-438. - Purpose. 
    It is the purpose of this article to regulate emergency alarms and to prevent the disruption and interference with the telephone communication system of the public safety department by allowing alarm systems which, when activated, connect with the communications facility of the public safety department by means of the department's telephone system. 
(1)  No person engaged in the business of providing such services and facilities shall use or operate, attempt to use or operate, or cause to be used or operated, or arrange, adjust, program or otherwise provide or install any device or combination of devices that will upon activation, either mechanically, electronically or by other automatic means, initiate the intrastate calling, dialing or connection to any telephone number assigned to any subscriber by a public telephone company, without the prior written consent of such subscriber. 
(2)  The term "telephone number," as used in this section, includes any additional numbers assigned by a public utility company engaged in the business of providing communications services and facilities to be used by means of a rotary or other system to connect with the subscriber to such primary number when the primary telephone number is in use. 
(Code 1988, § 8.201) 
Sec. 6-439. - Permit. 
    No person shall have or maintain an alarm system, as defined in section 6-441, in any dwelling or commercial building without first obtaining an alarm user permit from the department of public safety. 
(Code 1988, § 8.202) 
Sec. 6-440. - Fees for permit. 
    The annual fee for residents registering screen system alarms or alarms which do not have direct dialing into the police telephone lines shall be such amount as may be prescribed by the city commission by resolution. Residents owning direct dial alarms will pay an annual fee of such amount as may be prescribed by the city commission by ordinance or resolution. 
(Code 1988, § 8.203; Ord. No. 345, § 1, 7-25-1989) 
Sec. 6-441. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Alarm system means a device or assembly of equipment and devices arranged to signal the presence of a hazard requiring urgent attention and to which police officers are expected to respond. In this article, the term alarm system shall include the terms automatic hold-up alarm system, burglar alarm system, intrusion alarm system, hold-up alarm system, and manual hold up alarm system. 
    Alarm user means any person on whose premises an alarm system is maintained within the city, except for alarm systems on motor vehicles. If, however, an alarm system on a motor vehicle is connected with an alarm system at a premises, the person using such system is an alarm user. Also excluded from this definition and from the coverage of this article are persons who use alarm systems to alert or signal persons within the premises in which that alarm system is located, of an attempted unauthorized intrusion or hold-up attempt. If such a system, however, employs an audible signal emitting sounds or a flashing light or beacon designed to signal persons outside the premises, such system shall be within the definition of an alarm system and shall be subject to this article. 
(Code 1988, § 8.204) 
Sec. 6-442. - Local alarms. 
    Alarm systems employing audible signals commonly referred to as local alarms shall be equipped with shutoff devices that automatically silence the audible signal after 15 minutes. 
(Code 1988, § 8.205) 
Sec. 6-443. - False alarms. 
    The term "false alarm" means any alarm condition which is registered at the public safety department or elsewhere not resulting from criminal activity for which the alarm was intended shall be considered a false alarm. 
(Code 1988, § 8.206) 
Sec. 6-444. - False alarm fee. 
(a)  The alarm user shall be required to pay to the city the sum as designated by resolution of the city commission for each additional false alarm in any given calendar year. No alarm user shall be required to pay said fee on the first occasion of a false alarm during any one calendar year, but shall be advised in writing of said false alarm and of the existence of this article. 
(b)  Alarm conditions caused by the following extenuating circumstances shall not constitute a false alarm and no false alarm fee shall be charged by the city: 
(1)  Storm conditions. 
(2)  Alarm conditions being activated by persons working on the alarm system with prior notification to the public safety department. 
(3)  Alarms activated by disruption or disturbance of Michigan Bell Telephone Company facilities, or motor vehicle-utility pole accidents. 
(c)  Upon the response of a public safety officer to a false alarm call, a representative of the director of public safety shall notify the alarm user about this article. 
(d)  Within ten days of the date of receipt of this notification, the alarm user shall return to the public safety department with all monies due the city. Failure by the alarm user to pay shall cause a special assessment procedure to be initiated against the premises in question, as provided in sections 8, 9, and 10, chapter XII of the Charter of the city. 
(e)  If, upon receiving a false alarm fee notice, the alarm user wishes to request a waiver of the assessment of the fee due to extenuating circumstances, the alarm user may do so in writing within ten days of the assessment date. The notice to the public safety department shall contain documentation of the extenuating circumstances involved. Within ten days of the receipt of the waiver request by the public safety department, the director of public safety shall make a determination on the waiver request and shall notify the alarm user of the decision. 
(Code 1988, § 8.207) 
Sec. 6-445. - Fire alarms. 
    No person shall have a fire alarm device that upon activation, either mechanically, electronically, or by any other means, initiates the automatic calling or dialing of, or makes a connection directly to a telephone of the public safety department. 
(Code 1988, § 8.208) 
Sec. 6-446. - Penalty. 
    Any person who violates this article shall be responsible for a municipal civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 8.209) 
Secs. 6-447-6-475. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIII. - OUTDOOR LIGHTING 

Sec. 6-476. - Purpose. 
    It is the purpose of this article to regulate the use of outdoor lighting in all zone districts to ensure that light does not: 
(1)  Fall where it is not needed or wanted; 
(2)  Cause glare; 
(3)  Waste energy; and/or 
(4)  Change the character and ambiance of the neighborhood in which it is located. 
(Code 1988, § 8.194; Ord. No. 431, § 1, 6-15-1999) 
Sec. 6-477. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Floodlight or spotlight means any light fixture or lamp that incorporates a reflector or a refractor to concentrate the light output into a directed beam. 
    Glare means light emitting from a fixture with an intensity great enough to reduce a viewer's ability to see, cause annoyance or discomfort, and in extreme cases, cause momentary blindness. Glare is most often caused by the fixture itself rather than what the fixture is meant to illuminate. 
    Light trespass means light which is produced on one property and causes direct light on an adjacent or nearby property. 
    Shield means an opaque cover over the light source. 
(Code 1988, § 8.195; Ord. No. 431, § 1, 6-15-1999; Ord. No. 504, § 1, 5-9-2006) 
Sec. 6-478. - Lighting regulations. 
(a)  On all residential property, high intensity discharge lighting including but not limited to high pressure sodium, mercury vapor and metal halide shall be prohibited. 
(b)  On all nonresidential property, high intensity discharge lighting shall be: 
(1)  Directed away from adjacent residences; 
(2)  Shielded to eliminate light trespass; and 
(3)  Shielded so all of the light emitted therefrom is directed toward and confined to the ground areas of lawns and parking lots. 
(c)  Light fixtures and supporting standards shall not exceed a height of 18 feet. 
(d)  Floodlights or spotlights shall be directed or shielded to eliminate light trespass. 
(e)  All light sources shall be stationary and constant in intensity and color, except that light sources operated by a motion sensor shall be permitted. Illuminated signs and other outdoor features shall not be a flashing, moving or intermittent type. 
(f)  No light shall be located, nor be of a type, to cause any obstruction, diversion, glare, confusion or hazard to pedestrians or vehicular traffic. 
(Code 1988, § 8.196; Ord. No. 431, § 1, 6-15-1999; Ord. No. 504, § 2, 5-9-2006) 
Sec. 6-479. - Exceptions. 
    This article shall not apply to traffic control devices, streetlights, municipal lights, and temporary emergency lights. 
(Code 1988, § 8.197; Ord. No. 431, § 1, 6-15-1999; Ord. No. 504, § 3, 5-9-2006) 
Sec. 6-480. - Violations; penalties. 
    A person who violates any provision of this article is responsible for a municipal civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 8.198; Ord. No. 431, § 1, 6-15-1999) 
Secs. 6-481-6-498. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIV. - TEMPORARY PORTABLE TOILETS, DUMPSTERS, STORAGE UNITS AND CONSTRUCTION TRAILERS 

Sec. 6-499. - Portable toilets. 
(a)  Temporary placement. A portable toilet may be temporarily placed upon a lot for which a valid building permit has been issued. Not more than one portable toilet may be located on a lot. The portable toilet must be removed prior to final inspection of the job. 
(b)  Location. The portable toilet may be located in the side or rear yard of the job site and at least five feet inside the side and rear property lines. If the building official determines that the portable toilet cannot be serviced in the side or rear yard, it may be located in the back half of the front yard, provided that it is not closer to the side lot lines than five feet. A portable toilet on a corner lot must be at least ten feet from the corner side lot line. The portable toilet shall not be located in the city right-of-way. 
(Code 1988, § 8.180; Ord. No. 443, § 2, 5-16-2000; Ord. No. 503, § 1(8.180), 10-25-2005) 
Sec. 6-500. - Dumpsters. 
    A dumpster may be temporarily placed upon a lot for the purpose of removing construction materials or other debris. Not more than one dumpster may be located on a lot. It shall not contain any sign other than identification of the owner of the unit. The dumpster shall be emptied at least once in each 30 day-period and at no time shall the debris be visible over the top of the dumpster. 
(1)  Definition. For purposes of this section, a dumpster is defined as any container made of any material, hard or soft, intended for the purpose of holding or containing construction materials or other debris. Any such container of a size or configuration exceeding that which is approved for collection of contract waste by SOCRRA shall be considered a dumpster. 
(2)  Permit required. Prior to the placement of a dumpster, a permit must be obtained from the building official. A permit fee, established by resolution of the city commission, shall be paid at the time of application for the permit. The permit shall include the name and contact information of the contractor and/or entity responsible for servicing the dumpster. A dumpster placed on a property for which a valid building permit has been issued shall be removed prior to final inspection of the job. Any other dumpster shall be removed within 60 days from the date of issuance of the permit. 
(3)  Location. The dumpster may be located in the side or rear yard of the lot. If the building official determines that the dumpster cannot be serviced in the side or rear yard, it may be located in the back half of the front yard, closest to the building or home. The dumpster shall not be located in the city right-of-way or lawn extension. 
(4)  It shall be the responsibility of the property owner and the permittee to assure compliance with this section. 
(Code 1988, § 8.181; Ord. No. 443, § 2, 5-16-2000; Ord. No. 503, § 1(8.181), 10-25-2005; Ord. No. 558, § 1, 1-15-2013) 
Sec. 6-501. - Portable storage units. 
    A portable storage unit, with or without wheels, may be temporarily placed upon a lot for the purpose of storing tools, construction materials or household items. Not more than one portable storage unit may be located on a lot. The portable storage unit shall not contain any sign other than identification of the owner of the unit. 
(1)  Permit required. Prior to the placement of a portable storage unit, a permit must be obtained from the building official. A permit fee, established by resolution of the city commission, shall be paid at the time of application for the permit. A portable storage unit placed on a property for which a valid building permit has been issued shall be removed prior to final inspection of the job. All other portable storage units shall be removed within 60 days from the date of issuance of the permit. 
(2)  Location. The portable storage unit may be located in the side or rear yard of the lot. If the building official determines that the unit cannot be stored in the side or rear yard, it may be located in the back half of the front yard. The portable storage unit shall not be located in the city right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 503, § 1(8.182), 10-25-2005) 
Sec. 6-502. - Construction trailers. 
    A construction trailer may be temporarily placed upon a lot in Zone 2A or Zone 3 for use as a temporary office to manage an on-site construction project for which a valid building permit has been issued. Not more than one construction trailer may be located on a lot. The construction trailer must be removed prior to final inspection of the job. 
(1)  Permit required. Prior to the placement of a construction trailer, a permit must be obtained from the building official. A permit fee, established by resolution of the city commission, shall be paid at the time of application of the permit. 
(2)  Use restrictions; location. The construction trailer shall at no time, be used for living, sleeping or housekeeping purposes. It must be in good repair and carry a current year's license plate as required by law. It shall not contain any sign other than identification of the owner of the trailer. The construction trailer shall not be located in the city right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 503, § 1(8.183), 10-25-2005) 
Sec. 6-503. - Violations; penalties. 
    A person who places a portable toilet, dumpster, portable storage unit or construction trailer upon a lot within the city in violation of the provisions of this article is responsible for a municipal civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 8.182; Ord. No. 443, § 2, 5-16-2000; Ord. No. 503, § 1(8.184), 10-25-2005) 
Chapter 7 - RESERVED 
Chapter 8 - BUSINESSES 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 8-1. - Definition. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    License means any license, permit, certificate or any other type of approval required by this chapter. 
(Code 1988, § 7.1) 
Secs. 8-2-8-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LICENSES 

Sec. 8-21. - License required. 
    No person, as owner, agent, manager, employee, or otherwise, shall operate, conduct, maintain, or otherwise be engaged in the carrying on of any trade, business, profession, occupation, amusement, activity, or privilege for which any license is required by any provision of this Code without first obtaining a license from the city in the manner provided for herein. 
(Code 1988, § 7.2) 
Sec. 8-22. - Multiple licenses required. 
    The granting of a license or permit to any person operating, conducting, maintaining, or otherwise carrying on or engaging in any trade, business, profession, occupation, amusement or privilege required by this Code to be licensed shall not relieve the person so licensed from the necessity of securing such other licenses or permits as may be required by this Code, except as specifically provided elsewhere in this Code. 
(Code 1988, § 7.3) 
Sec. 8-23. - State licensed business. 
    The fact that a license or permit has been granted to any person by the state to engage in the operation of, conduct or carrying on of, any trade, business, profession, occupation, amusement, activity or privilege shall not exempt such person from the necessity of securing a license or permit from the city if such a license or permit is required by this Code. No license required by this Code shall be issued to any person who is required to have a license or permit from state until such person shall submit evidence of having obtained the required state license or permit. 
(Code 1988, § 7.4) 
Sec. 8-24. - Application. 
    Unless otherwise provided for by law or ordinance or in this Code, every person required to obtain a license as provided for in this Code shall make application to the city clerk for such license on forms provided or prescribed by the city clerk. The application shall require such information to be provided as will enable the clerk to determine whether the applicant, if licensed, will serve the public in a fair, honest, safe and competent manner and in compliance with the requirements of this Code and all other applicable federal, state and local laws, ordinances, rules and regulations. The person making application for any license shall state under oath or affirmation that the information provided on such application is true and shall provide, under oath or affirmation, such other information relative to the granting of the license or to the applicant's qualifications as the clerk may require. No person shall make a false statement or false representation on any license application or in connection with the application for any license provided for in this Code. 
(Code 1988, § 7.5) 
Sec. 8-25. - License term. 
(a)  Except as the city commission may otherwise prescribe by ordinance or resolution, the license year applicable to all annual licenses for which a different license year is not specifically provided in this Code shall begin on July 1 of each year and shall end on June 30 of the following year. 
(b)  Any license not issued prior to the beginning of a license year shall be issued for the balance of the license year. 
(c)  Where provision is made in this Code for the issuance of a license for a period of less than one year, the effective date of such a license shall be provided on the face of the license by the city clerk and such license shall be in effect only for the period provided on the face of the license by the clerk. In the absence of a provision by the clerk on the face of a license, the license shall be valid only on the date upon which it is issued. 
(d)  Any person duly licensed on the effective date of this Code shall be deemed licensed hereunder for the balance of the current license year. 
(Code 1988, § 7.6; Ord. No. 336, § 1, 7-25-1989) 
Sec. 8-26. - Conditions for issuance. 
    No license shall be issued to any applicant until the applicant has complied with all the provisions of this Code and all provisions of the laws of the state applicable to the trade, business, profession, occupation, amusement, activity or privilege for which the license is sought have been complied with. 
(Code 1988, § 7.7) 
Sec. 8-27. - Agreement by applicant. 
(a)  All licenses are issued subject to the following conditions, which shall be noted on the application form: 
(1)  The applicant agrees to permit inspection of the licensed premises and/or activity at reasonable times by any properly identified officer or employee of the city. 
(2)  The applicant agrees to the temporary suspension of the license without prior notice or hearing when, in the judgment of the appropriate officials, such a suspension is necessary to preserve the public health, safety, or welfare. 
(3)  The applicant agrees that the applicant will keep aware of and comply with all applicable federal, state and local laws, ordinances, rules and regulations during the term of the license. 
(4)  The applicant agrees that the applicant will not engage in the licensed trade, business, profession, occupation, amusement, activity or privilege at any time after the license has expired, without having been reissued, or at any time when the license is suspended or revoked. 
(5)  No license shall be issued unless and until the applicant has paid all personal property taxes assessed the applicant and unless the applicant has paid all other debts due and owing to the city. 
(b)  Each applicant shall sign a statement indicating that the applicant has read the foregoing and agrees with its provisions prior to the issuance of any license. 
(Code 1988, § 7.8) 
Sec. 8-28. - Certification required. 
(a)  In each case where the certification by any of the following officials or employees is required, such certification shall be based upon such inspection or investigation as may, consistent with law, be deemed appropriate by the official or employee and shall indicate that the requirements following the official's or employee's title have been complied with. 
(1)  Public safety director's certificate. In all cases where the certification of the director of public safety is required, such certification shall be based upon a finding that the criminal history of the applicant, if any, has been checked and that there is no indication that the applicant cannot serve the public in the licensed area in a fair, honest and open manner; and, if the applicant for such license proposes to conduct or is conducting the trade, profession, business or privilege to be licensed within any building in the city that such premises comply with all the fire regulations of the state and of the city. 
(2)  Health officer. That all applicable health and sanitary requirements of the city, county and state have been complied with. 
(3)  Building official. That the building requirements of this Code and of the state have been complied with and that the zoning and other land use provisions of this Code will permit the licensed activity at its proposed location. 
(b)  Whenever the certification of any official or employee of the city is required, no license may be granted or become effective until such certification is made. 
(Code 1988, § 7.9; Ord. No. 336, § 2, 7-25-1989) 
Sec. 8-29. - Bonds. 
    Where a provision of this Code requires that an applicant for any license or permit furnish a bond, such bond shall be furnished in an amount deemed adequate by the proper city officer, or, where the amount thereof is specified by the city commission, in the amount so required. The form of such bond shall be acceptable to the city attorney. 
(Code 1988, § 7.10; Ord. No. 336, § 3, 7-25-1989) 
Sec. 8-30. - Exemption from fee. 
    No license fee shall be required from any person exempt from such fee by state or federal law. Such person shall comply with all other provisions of this Code. 
(Code 1988, § 7.11) 
Sec. 8-31. - Suspension or revocation. 
(a)  Any license issued by the city may be suspended or revoked by the city clerk for cause as herein defined. Any permit issued by the city may be suspended or revoked by the issuing officer or authority for cause as herein defined. In either case, a hearing shall be scheduled to be held by the city manager or the city manager's designee or the issuing authority. Depending upon the necessity for prompt action, the hearing shall be held in accordance with one of the following provisions: 
(1)  If there is no immediate threat to the public health, safety or welfare, the hearing shall be held to determine whether the license or permit should be suspended or revoked. The holder of the license or permit shall be notified of the time, date and place of the hearing and shall be notified of the reason or reasons for the proposed suspension or revocation. The license or permit holder shall be entitled to be represented by counsel, to submit evidence, to cross examine testifying witnesses, and to make arguments concerning the factual and legal issues. The hearing officer or body shall render a written decision stating the reasons for the decision. 
(2)  If there is an immediate threat to the public health, safety and welfare, the license or permit may be suspended prior to the hearing. If a license or permit is suspended prior to the hearing, the hearing shall be commenced as soon as is practical, but in no case more than ten days after the suspension. The hearing shall be held to determine whether to terminate or extend the suspension or whether the suspension should be converted into a revocation of the license or permit. The holder of the license or permit shall be notified of the time, date and place of the hearing and shall be notified of the reason or reasons for the already-imposed suspension and for any contemplated future action. The license or permit holder shall be entitled to be represented by counsel, to submit evidence, to cross examine testifying witnesses, and to make arguments on factual and legal issues. The hearing officer or body shall render a decision stating the reasons for the decision. 
(b)  In any hearing held pursuant to the provisions of this article, the rules of evidence shall be followed as far as practicable, but a hearing officer or body may admit and give probative effect to evidence of a type commonly relied upon by reasonably prudent people in the conduct of their affairs. Irrelevant, immaterial or unduly repetitious evidence may be excluded. Notice may be taken of facts within the general knowledge of the community. 
(c)  Any person dissatisfied with the decision of the city manager or other appropriate hearing officer or body may appeal to the city commission; provided that a written request for such an appeal shall be filed within seven days of the date of the decision to be appealed. 
(d)  The city commission shall schedule a hearing on the appeal within 15 days of the receipt of the request for appeal by the city clerk. The hearing shall be scheduled and held before the city commission. The factual record made in the hearing below shall constitute the basic record for the appeal. 
(e)  The city commission may, but need not, allow the presentation of additional evidence by a majority vote. Argument as to relevant factual and legal issues shall be permitted. The decision of the city commission shall be by majority vote. The city commission may affirm, reverse or modify any action taken relative to a license. The decision of the city commission shall be final. 
(Code 1988, § 7.12; Ord. No. 336, § 4, 7-25-1989) 
Sec. 8-32. - Issuance of license. 
    Where proper application is made for a license or permit and the conditions, requirements and prerequisites for the issuance of the license or permit have been met, the license or permit applied for shall be issued by the city clerk, provided that no cause, as that term is defined herein, exists for denial of the license. 
(Code 1988, § 7.13) 
Sec. 8-33. - Denial of a license. 
    Where proper application is made for a license or permit and such a license or permit is denied by the city clerk or other issuing person or body, the applicant shall have the right to appeal such a denial as elsewhere provided for by law or in this Code. If no such provision is made for an appeal of a denial, the applicant may appeal as set out herein. For purposes of this section, denial of a license shall include refusal to issue an original license or refusal to renew or reissue an existing license. Denial shall be made only for cause as herein defined. Within ten days of notification of denial of a license from the city clerk, an applicant shall file with the city clerk a written notice of appeal. The clerk shall refer a copy of this notice to the city manager. Upon receipt of a notice of appeal, the city clerk shall confer with the city manager or the city manager's designee to set a hearing time as soon as is practical, but not later than ten days after the filing of the notice of appeal with the city clerk. The hearing provided for may be conducted by the city manager or the city manager's designee and it shall be conducted as provided for in section 8-31, except that the issue to be determined is whether the denial of the license was proper. The person conducting the hearing shall render a written decision stating the reasons for the decision. 
(Code 1988, § 7.14) 
Sec. 8-34. - Fees. 
(a)  Fees required by this article for license applications shall be paid to the city clerk prior to submission of the application. Fees required by this article for the issuance of a license shall be paid to the city clerk prior to the issuance of the license. No fees shall be refunded. 
(b)  The amount of every fee required to be paid to obtain any license to engage in the operation, conduct, or carrying-on of any trade, profession, business or privilege for which a license is required by this article shall be determined by the city commission by resolution. No license shall be issued or become effective until the applicant has paid such fees, if any. 
(Code 1988, § 7.15; Ord. No. 336, § 5, 7-25-1989) 
Sec. 8-35. - License reissuance. 
    It shall be the responsibility of all persons engaging in any trade, business, profession, occupation, amusement, activity or privilege required to be licensed to obtain all licenses required by this article prior to engaging in or continuing in the licensed trade, business, profession, occupation, amusement, activity or privilege. To assist in the reissuance of licenses to license holders, the city clerk may send a license renewal application and invoice for the license fee to license holders prior to the end of a license year. Upon receipt of the completed application and the appropriate fee, and after such investigation as the clerk deems necessary, the clerk may issue a license for the following year. If a licensee fails to file an application for renewal and/or fails to pay the license renewal fee prior to the expiration of a license year, that application shall be considered to be an application for a new license. 
(Code 1988, § 7.16) 
Sec. 8-36. - Exhibition of a license. 
    Where certain premises are licensed or where a licensed trade, business, profession, occupation, amusement, activity or privilege is carried on at a fixed place or establishment, all licenses shall be conspicuously displayed upon the premises, or at the fixed place or establishment. All licenses shall be displayed in an area of the premises, fixed place or establishment that is open to the public. Where there is no premises, fixed place or establishment, the licensee shall have the license or licenses issued in the possession of the licensee at all times when conducting, carrying on, or otherwise engaging in the licensed trade, business, profession, occupation, amusement, activity or privilege. The license shall be promptly displayed upon the request of any police officer or any properly identified officer. 
(Code 1988, § 7.17) 
Sec. 8-37. - Exhibition on vehicle and machine. 
(a)  Each license granted for the operation of a vehicle as required under this Code shall include the issuance of a tag, insignia, license plate or number. This tag, insignia, license plate or number shall be prominently displayed on the vehicle in a place where it can readily be seen and read at all times when the vehicle is being used in the licensed activity. 
(b)  Every person who owns or operates any vending machine, amusement device or other coin-operated device which is required to be licensed under this Code shall conspicuously display on each such machine or device their name, address and city license number, in a form approved by the city clerk. 
(Code 1988, § 7.18) 
Sec. 8-38. - Displaying invalid license and surrender of invalid license. 
    No person shall display any expired license, any license for which a duplicate has been issued, or any license which has been suspended or revoked, nor shall any person display any license which has not been duly and regularly issued to or on behalf of the person displaying it for the trade, business, profession, occupation, amusement, activity or privilege in, at, or for which the license is displayed. It shall be the duty of every licensee or any employee, agent or representative of the licensee, to surrender to any properly identified representative of the city, upon demand, any license which is expired, suspended, revoked, altered, amended, modified, changed or damaged or any license for which a duplicate has been issued. 
(Code 1988, § 7.19) 
Sec. 8-39. - Transfer, alteration or misuse of a license. 
    No license issued under the provisions of this Code shall be transferable or assignable unless specifically and explicitly authorized by this Code. No person shall transfer or assign or attempt to transfer or assign any license and no person shall receive or attempt to receive a transferred or assigned license. No person shall, except as authorized by this Code or by the city clerk, write upon, alter, amend, modify, change or damage any license. 
(Code 1988, § 7.20) 
Sec. 8-40. - Revocation. 
    In addition to any other penalties or actions permitted or authorized by this Code, any transfer or assignment of a license or any attempted transfer or assignment shall be void and shall result in the automatic revocation of the license. 
(Code 1988, § 7.21) 
Sec. 8-41. - Curb stands prohibited. 
    No person, whether licensed pursuant to this article or not, shall park at the curb for the purpose of conducting business, nor shall any person establish a stand, booth or other place of business on any street, curb, sidewalk, public right-of-way or thoroughfare without having obtained permission to do so from the city manager. This section shall not be interpreted to prohibit parking for the purpose of making deliveries or for the purpose of consummating sales to persons waiting at the curb, provided that the seller leaves the curb immediately after such deliveries or sales are completed. 
(Code 1988, § 7.22) 
Sec. 8-42. - Curb service prohibited. 
    No person shall engage in the giving of curb service. For purposes of this section, the term "curb service" means the use of a public street, highway, thoroughfare or right-of-way by a person operating from a store or other fixed location for the sale, solicitation for sale, or delivery of any goods, services or property. 
(Code 1988, § 7.23) 
Sec. 8-43. - Responsibility. 
    Any person who aids, abets, counsels, procures, commands or assists in the commission of any violation of the provisions of this article shall be punishable as a principal. 
(Code 1988, § 7.24) 
Sec. 8-44. - Cause defined. 
    As used throughout this article, the term "cause" means the doing or omitting of any act, the permitting of any condition to exist in any trade, business, profession, occupation, amusement, activity or privilege for which a license is provided under the provisions of this article, or upon the premises or facilities used in connection therewith, which act, omission or condition is: 
(1)  A violation of this article. 
(2)  A violation of any other applicable federal, state or local law, ordinance, rule or regulation. 
(3)  Unlawful or fraudulent in nature. 
(4)  Beyond the scope of the license granted. 
(5)  Abandonment of the licensed trade, business, profession, occupation, amusement, activity or privilege. 
(6)  An unfair or deceptive act or practice as defined in section 3 of the Michigan consumer protection act, Public Act No. 331 of 1976 (MCL 445.903). 
(Code 1988, § 7.25) 
Secs. 8-45-8-61. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - MERCHANTS AND COMMERCIAL BUSINESSES 

Sec. 8-62. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Commercial business means any business for the sale of any goods, wares, or merchandise, whether at wholesale or to the public at retail, as well as the manufacture or assembly of goods, or the furnishing of any service to the public for a fee or charge, or providing public amusement or recreational facilities for a fee or charge. 
    Merchant means any person engaged in any commercial business within the city not otherwise licensed under the provisions of this Code, who occupies in whole or in part, any room, building, land, public or private, or premises for the carrying on of such business. 
(Code 1988, § 7.31; Ord. No. 456, § 1, 5-15-2000) 
Sec. 8-63. - Activities excluded. 
    The activities of peddlers, solicitors, commercial travelers, persons conducting enterprises or making sales on behalf of any recognized charitable, religious or public purpose shall not be deemed conducting a commercial business regulated pursuant to this article. 
(Code 1988, § 7.32; Ord. No. 456, § 1, 5-15-2000; Ord. No. 534, § 1, 9-14-2010) 
Sec. 8-64. - License required. 
    No person shall engage in any commercial business in the city without first having obtained a general merchant's license therefor, unless such business is licensed by the city pursuant to other specific regulatory ordinance. 
(Code 1988, § 7.33; Ord. No. 456, § 1, 5-15-2000) 
Sec. 8-65. - Separate locations. 
    Any person conducting a commercial business at more than one separate location in the city shall obtain a general merchant's license for each such location. 
(Code 1988, § 7.34; Ord. No. 456, § 1, 5-15-2000) 
Secs. 8-66-8-88. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - AUCTIONEERS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- UCC sales at public auction, MCL 440.2328; duties upon sales at auctions, MCL 446.26 et seq.; sales at public auction, new merchandise, MCL 446.51. 

Sec. 8-89. - License. 
    No person shall engage in the trade or business of auctioneer without first obtaining a license therefor. No such license shall be granted except upon certification of the director of public safety. 
(Code 1988, § 7.51) 
Sec. 8-90. - Bond. 
    Before any such license is issued, the applicant shall furnish a corporate surety bond in the penal sum of such amount as may be prescribed by the city commission by resolution, which bond shall be conditioned for the due observance during the time of the license of all laws of the state and all provisions of this article. Any person aggrieved by the action of any such license shall have a right of action on the bond for the recovery of money or damages, or both. Such bond shall remain in full force and effect for a period of 90 days after the expiration or conclusion of any action on said bond commenced while it was in force. 
(Code 1988, § 7.52; Ord. No. 338, § 1, 7-25-1989) 
Sec. 8-91. - Prohibited activity. 
    No auctioneer shall knowingly misrepresent the quality of any goods sold by the auctioneer. No auctioneer shall accept any goods from any minor for sale at auction. 
(Code 1988, § 7.53) 
Sec. 8-92. - Auction accounts. 
    Every auctioneer shall keep a full and accurate account of all goods sold by the auctioneer, indicating the prior owner, the price at which sold, and to whom sold. Such account shall be open for inspection by any public safety officer at any reasonable time. No auctioneer shall fail to make such account accessible to any public safety officer upon demand. 
(Code 1988, § 7.54) 
Secs. 8-93-8-112. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - TRANSIENT MERCHANTS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Transient merchants, MCL 445.371 et seq. 

Sec. 8-113. - License required. 
    No person shall engage in a temporary business of selling goods, wares or merchandise at retail within the city from any lot, premises, building, room or structure, including railroad cars, without first obtaining a license therefor. No such license shall be granted except upon certification of the director of public safety and city treasurer. Persons having regularly established places of business in the city, who are not otherwise subject to this article, shall not become subject thereto because of making incidental sales or deliveries direct from railroad cars. 
(Code 1988, § 7.71) 
Sec. 8-114. - Temporary business. 
    Every person engaged in the retail sale and delivery of goods, wares or merchandise, shall be deemed to be engaged in carrying on a temporary business unless their goods, wares or merchandise shall have been assessed for taxation in the city during the current year. 
(Code 1988, § 7.72) 
Sec. 8-115. - Indebtedness to the city. 
    No license shall be granted to any person owing any personal property taxes or other indebtedness to the city, or who contemplates using any personal property on which personal property taxes are owing, in the operation of such business. 
(Code 1988, § 7.73) 
Sec. 8-116. - Benefit sales. 
    Any person selling or offering for sale any goods, wares or merchandise on behalf of and solely for the benefit of any recognized charitable or religious purpose shall, after meeting all other requirements, be granted a license without payment of a business license fee. 
(Code 1988, § 7.74; Ord. No. 339, § 1, 7-25-1989) 
Secs. 8-117-8-145. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - GARAGES, USED CAR SALES AND FILLING STATIONS 

Sec. 8-146. - Definitions.
