    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Filling station means any building or lot having pumps and storage tanks where petroleum products, or accessories for motor vehicles, are sold or offered for sale at retail. 
    Garage means any building or lot where the business of repairing or storing motor vehicles is carried on and shall be deemed to include any building or lot where hammering, pounding, body bumping, welding or other noisy function in connection with the repairs of motor vehicles is carried on, whether or not the operator engages in a business of motor vehicle repair available to the public. 
    Used car sales means the business of keeping used motor vehicles within any building or on any lot for display or sale. 
(Code 1988, § 7.91) 
Sec. 8-147. - License required. 
    No person shall operate any garage or filling station or engage in the business of used car sales without first obtaining a license therefor. No such license shall be granted except upon certification of the director of public safety and the building official. 
(Code 1988, § 7.92) 
Sec. 8-148. - Hours. 
    No garage or used car sales licensee shall, between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. of the following morning, permit on the licensed premises any bumping of car bodies, operation of welding machinery, hammering, pounding or other excessively noisy function, but may conduct office work, vehicle storage, receiving and discharging vehicles or emergency service not involving excessive noise or nuisance. 
(Code 1988, § 7.93) 
Sec. 8-149. - General regulations. 
    Every person licensed under the provisions of this article shall be subject to the following regulations: 
(1)  No automobile or vehicle shall be driven across any sidewalk except upon a driveway where the sidewalk has been reinforced to a thickness of six inches, and with an approaching apron of cement. The location of such driveway shall first be approved by the director of public safety and shall not be so located as to unnecessarily endanger the public safety. 
(2)  No licensee shall permit the storage of vehicles upon premises not owned or leased by the licensee. 
(3)  The repair of motor vehicles shall be conducted exclusively within a completely enclosed building. 
(4)  Every licensee shall, at all times, keep a full and complete written record of the ownership, date of receipt, type of work to be done, or storage to be had, as to every motor vehicle and motor vehicle part on the premises. 
(5)  No motor vehicle shall be parked or stored, except in a completely enclosed building, for a period of time longer than 12 hours, nor between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. of the following morning. The parking or storing of any motor vehicle by any licensee in violation of this section shall be a violation of this article. 
(Code 1988, § 7.95) 
Sec. 8-150. - Gasoline pumps. 
    The location of gasoline filling pumps and tanks on any licensed premises, shall comply with the following conditions: 
(1)  Every pump or gasoline filling device must be equipped with protective fire insulation so that a fire near said pump or device will not cause the gasoline within the pump or storage tank leading to the pump to burn or explode. 
(2)  Gasoline filling pumps shall be located at least 14 feet from any sidewalk. 
(3)  Tanks to contain gasoline shall be buried below ground at least three feet and the lead line from such tank to the filling pumps shall be equipped with adequate protective devices to ensure against fire or explosion. 
(Code 1988, § 7.96) 
Sec. 8-151. - Junk and dismantling. 
    No person licensed under the provisions of this article shall permit the licensed premises to be used as a junkyard for the storage or dismantling of automobiles or parts thereof. 
(Code 1988, § 7.97) 
Secs. 8-152-8-170. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - MECHANICAL AMUSEMENT DEVICES 

Sec. 8-171. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Mechanical amusement device means any machine containing no automatic pay-off device which may, on insertion of a coin or slug, operate or be operated or used as a game, contest or amusement of any sort or description, and which is so constructed that it may not be converted into an automatic pay-off device for the return or discharge of money or tokens, checks or merchandise or which provides no such pay-off by any means whatsoever, including, but not limited to, pinball machines and electronic video games which consist solely of electronic play appearing on a video screen. 
(Code 1988, § 7.141) 
Sec. 8-172. - License. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to establish, maintain, control, operate or keep any mechanical amusement device, as defined in section 8-171, in a commercial establishment within the city, without having procured a license therefor. 
(Code 1988, § 7.142) 
Sec. 8-173. - License fee. 
    The fee for such license shall be as prescribed from time to time by resolution of the city commission. No such license shall be granted except upon certification of the director of public safety and building official and unless a complete set of fingerprints of the applicant therefor are on file in a noncriminal identification file at the department of public safety. 
(Code 1988, § 7.143) 
Sec. 8-174. - Age of licensee. 
    No person shall be granted a license to establish, operate, control, maintain, or keep any mechanical amusement device as defined in section 8-171 unless the person is over the age of 18 years. 
(Code 1988, § 7.144) 
Sec. 8-175. - Size of building. 
    No license shall be granted for a location having a building area of less than 1,000 square feet. 
(Code 1988, § 7.145) 
Sec. 8-176. - Limit of number of machines per location. 
    Each such license shall designate the address of the premises where there is established, operated, controlled, maintained, or kept the mechanical amusement device to which said license pertains and no licensee shall establish, operate, control, maintain or keep more than one such mechanical amusement device at any single building, location or address within the city, nor shall said license be transferable to any address other than the original address designated thereon. 
(Code 1988, § 7.146) 
Sec. 8-177. - Attendance by juveniles. 
(a)  No minor child under the age of 17 years shall be permitted in a place where a mechanical amusement device is located, or shall be permitted to play any such device before 3:00 p.m. on days during which school is in session. 
(b)  No minor child under the age of 17 years shall be permitted to remain in a place where a mechanical amusement device is located between the hours of 10:30 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. 
(c)  It shall be the responsibility of the owner or manager of any place where a mechanical amusement device is located to prohibit minor children from the premises under the provisions of subsections (a) and (b) of this section. Failure to do so shall be considered in violation of this article. 
(Code 1988, § 7.147) 
Sec. 8-178. - Gambling. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to directly, indirectly, or otherwise offer or give any prize, award, merchandise or anything of value to any player or to any operator of a mechanical amusement device or to offer any inducement whatsoever tending to induce persons to make use thereof. This section shall not apply to a mechanical amusement device which may through the application of an element of skill reward the player with the right to replay the mechanical amusement device at no additional cost if the mechanical amusement device is not allowed to accumulate more than 15 replays at one time; devices designed so that accumulated free replays may only be discharged by reactivating the device for one additional play per each accumulated free replay; the device makes no permanent record directly or indirectly of the free replays awarded. 
(Code 1988, § 7.148) 
State Law reference- Gambling generally, MCL 750.301 et seq. 
Sec. 8-179. - Pay-off devices. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any mechanical amusement device, as defined in section 8-171, containing any automatic or semi-automatic pay-off device or which shall be so constructed that the same may be converted into an automatic pay-off device for the return or discharge of coins, tokens, slugs, merchandise or checks to operators thereof. 
(Code 1988, § 7.149) 
Secs. 8-180-8-196. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - DAY CARE HOMES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Child care organizations, MCL 722.111 et seq. 

Sec. 8-197. - License required. 
    No person shall engage in the operation of a family day care home or group day care home, as defined in section 40-123 without first obtaining a license therefor from the city clerk. 
(Code 1988, § 7.161) 
Sec. 8-198. - Application. 
    The city clerk shall issue a license for the operation of a family day care home or a group day care home after receipt of the following: 
(1)  Proof that the proposed licensee is certified by the state department of social services for the operation of such business. 
(2)  Certification within the last 90 days from the city building official or the city building official's agent and the city fire inspector or the city fire inspectors agent that the premises to be used meet all fire and state construction codes and regulations applicable to the dwelling. 
(3)  Certification by the city building official of the number of square feet contained in the entire dwelling. 
(4)  For new licensees, certification that an existing family day care home or group day care home is not in operation within 750 feet of the proposed day care home or that the proposed group or family day care home has been approved for operation by the zoning board of appeals notwithstanding the fact that said proposed home is located within 750 feet of an existing group or family day care home. 
(5)  Certification by the proposed licensee that the dropping off or picking up of children shall not be allowed between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. 
(6)  Certification that the operator will hold the city harmless in the event of litigation against the city involving the operator's day care operation, and proof that the operator has a policy of liability insurance covering the day care activity in an amount not less than established by resolution of the city commission, and proof that the insurance carrier will notify the city if the policy is cancelled, suspended, revoked or lapses, and upon such notice, the city manager, may at the city manager's discretion, suspend the license pursuant to this chapter until such time as the insurance policy is renewed. 
(Code 1988, § 7.162) 
Sec. 8-199. - Form of license. 
    Each license shall contain the following information: 
(1)  Name of licensee; 
(2)  Address of group or family day care home; 
(3)  Expiration date of license; 
(4)  Number of minor children other than children related to the licensee by blood, marriage or adoption, for whom the licensee may give care and supervision to pursuant to the license. For purposes of this section, the licensee may be authorized to care for one child for each 175 square feet of space in the home as measured by the city building official pursuant to section 8-198; provided that an operator of a family day care home may not be authorized to care for more than six children and the operator of a group day care home may not be authorized to care for more than 12 children. For purposes of this subsection, the building official, in computing the number of square feet in the dwelling, shall exclude all bathrooms and storage areas in the dwelling, but shall include all other floor space in the dwelling, including main floor and second floor space. Basement floor space shall also be included in the computation if the basement floor space will be used by and is accessible to the children; 
(5)  That the license is nontransferable from one person to another; and 
(6)  That the license is nontransferable to a new location within the city. 
(Code 1988, § 7.163) 
Secs. 8-200-8-221. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - MASSAGE FACILITIES 

Sec. 8-222. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Massage means the treating of external parts of the body for remedial or hygienic purposes, consisting of rubbing, stroking, kneading, adjusting or tapping with the hand or any instrument, electric, magnetic or otherwise, with or without supplementary aids. 
    Massage facility means any place where a massage, and/or an alcohol rub, fomentation, bath, physiotherapy, manipulation of the body of similar treatment is given on occasion or incidental to its principal operation. 
    Massage school means a school which is licensed by the state department of education or is a public institution in the state, which requires for admission, students with a tenth grade education or its equivalent, which employs one or more competent certified massagists as instructors, and which has minimum requirements of a continuous course of study in physiology, anatomy, massage theory, hydrotherapy, hygiene, ethics and practical massage. For the purposes of this article, a correspondence school shall not be construed to be a recognized school. 
    Massagist means any person who administers to another person, for any form of consideration, a massage, alcohol rub, fomentation, bath, electric or magnetic massage procedure, or manipulation of the body or other similar procedure. 
(Code 1988, § 7.171; Ord. No. 350, § 1, 10-19-1989) 
Sec. 8-223. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to establish or operate a massage facility within the city without first obtaining a license therefor. 
(Code 1988, § 7.12; Ord. No. 350, § 1, 10-19-1989) 
Sec. 8-224. - License procedure. 
(a)  Any applicant for a license shall present a fully completed application and a business license fee to the city clerk pursuant to this chapter. In addition, any application to obtain a license shall be accompanied by an investigation fee, the amount to be determined by the city commission by resolution. No part of the application investigation fee shall be refundable. The applicant shall provide certification that the city will be held harmless in the event of litigation against the city involving the massage facility, and proof that the applicant has a policy of liability insurance issued by a company satisfactory to the city clerk, covering the massage facility in an amount as established by resolution of the city commission, and proof that the insurance carrier will notify the city if the policy is cancelled, suspended, revoked or lapses, and upon such notice, the city clerk may, at the discretion of the city clerk, suspend the license pursuant to this chapter until such time as the insurance policy is renewed. 
(b)  The application shall be referred to the public safety and building officials and the county health officer for certification pursuant to section 8-28 and for recommendations as to the approval or denial of the license. Their recommendations will be forwarded to the city clerk. 
(1)  The public safety director shall recommend denial of an application for a license if the character, reputation, integrity, or physical or mental condition of the applicant or the applicant's employees is found to be inimical to the health, safety, moral or general welfare of the public. In making such determination hereunder, the director of public safety shall consider: 
a.  Criminal history. All applicant's convictions, the reasons therefor, and the demeanor of the applicant subsequent to the applicant's release. A conviction of a felony or crime of moral turpitude shall be sufficient grounds to recommend denial. 
b.  License and permit history. The license and permit history of the applicant; whether such person has previously operated in this city or state or in another city or state under a license or permit; whether such person has had such license or permit revoked or suspended; the reasons therefor; and the demeanor of the application subsequent to such action. 
c.  Any information set forth in the application. 
(2)  The building official, the public safety department and the county health officer shall inspect the premises proposed to be devoted to the massage facility and shall make within a reasonable time separate recommendations to the city manager concerning compliance with the requirements of this article. 
(c)  The city clerk, or the city clerk's designee, shall grant a license to the applicant after receiving the aforementioned certifications, affirmative recommendations and upon determination that all conditions, requirements and prerequisites for the issuance of the license have been met; provided that no cause as defined in section 8-44 exists for denial of the license. 
(d)  Any person denied a license by the city clerk or the city clerk's designee pursuant to these provisions may appeal to the city commission in writing, stating reasons why the license should be granted. The city commission may grant or deny the license after a public hearing, and such decision shall be final. The city commission may elect on its own motion to review any determination of the city clerk granting or denying a license. 
(Code 1988, § 7.173; Ord. No. 350, § 1, 10-19-1989) 
Sec. 8-225. - Required facilities and maintenance. 
(a)  No license to conduct a massage facility shall be issued until an inspection of the premises by the city reveals that the establishment complies with each of the following requirements: 
(1)  A recognizable and readable sign is posted at the main entrance identifying the establishment. All such signs shall comply with the sign requirements of this Code. 
(2)  All provisions of the city building, plumbing, fire and electrical codes have been fulfilled. 
(3)  Hot and cold running water are provided. 
(4)  Adequate dressing, locker and toilet facilities are available including a minimum of one dressing room for each patron to be served, as well as a minimum of one toilet and one wash basin. If male and female patrons are to be served simultaneously at the establishment, separate dressing and separate toilet facilities are provided for male and female patrons. 
(5)  All walls, ceiling, floors, pools, showers, bathtubs, steam rooms, and all other physical facilities for the establishment are in good repair. 
(6)  A minimum of one separate wash basin is to be provided for the use of employees and it is to be located as close as practicable to the area devoted to the performance of massage services. 
(7)  There shall be no entrance or exit way which provides a direct passageway to another type of business, residence or living quarters. 
(8)  During business hours, the premises shall remain open and no exits, entrances or secondary doorways shall be locked or obstructed in any way to prevent the immediate free ingress and egress of persons. 
(9)  The premises shall not be made available for accommodating any person as sleeping quarters. 
(10)  No massage shall be performed in a massage facility in a private room which is capable of being locked or barred. 
(11)  No beds, water mattresses, cots, or other equipment designed for sleeping shall be permitted at the premises. 
(b)  Every massage facility, licensed under this article shall, during the period of its license, comply with the following: 
(1)  All facilities required by subsection (a) of this section shall continue in existence. 
(2)  All walls, ceilings, floors, pools, showers, bathtubs, steam rooms and other facilities shall be kept in good repair and maintained in a clean and sanitary condition. Wet and dry heat rooms, steam or vapor rooms, steam or vapor cabinets, shower compartments, and toilet rooms shall be thoroughly cleaned each day the business is in operation. If available, bathtubs and showers shall be cleaned after each use. 
(3)  Clean and sanitary towels shall be provided for each patron. No common use of towels or linens shall be permitted. 
(4)  Soap or detergent shall be provided at all wash basins. Sanitary towels placed in a permanently installed dispenser shall be provided at all wash basins utilized by employees. 
(5)  It shall be the duty of an owner, operator, manager or licensee to cooperate with all requests of the city in the performance of any duties and obligations required by this article. 
(Code 1988, § 7.174; Ord. No. 350, § 1, 10-19-1989) 
Sec. 8-226. - License fee. 
    The annual license fee for a massage facility shall be in the amount prescribed by the city commission by resolution. The license year shall be the period from the date of license issuance to June 30 next, inclusive, unless otherwise provided. 
(Code 1988, § 7.175; Ord. No. 350, § 1, 10-19-1989) 
Sec. 8-227. - License renewal. 
    Application to renew a license to operate a massage facility shall be filed at least 15 days prior to the date of expiration. The application to renew a license shall be accompanied by a sworn affidavit by the applicants that the matters contained in the original application have not changed. The application shall be referred to the director of public safety, who shall investigate the criminal history of the applicant and any employees since the grant of the original license. 
(Code 1988, § 7.176; Ord. No. 350, § 1, 10-19-1989) 
Sec. 8-228. - Unlawful activities. 
    No person shall massage another person, or give or administer any bath to any person, with contact to the breast, genital area or buttocks, in a manner intended to arouse, appeal to or gratify a person's lust, passions or sexual desires. Any such massage or bath given for monetary gain or profit will be considered illegal. 
(Code 1988, § 7.177; Ord. No. 350, § 1, 10-19-1989) 
Sec. 8-229. - Employees. 
(a)  It shall be the responsibility of the holder of the license for the massage facility, or the employer of any persons purporting to act as massagist to ensure that each person employed as a massagist meets one or more of the following criteria: 
(1)  Proof of graduation from a school of massage as defined in section 8-222; 
(2)  Official transcripts verifying completion of at least 300 hours of massage training from an American community college or university; plus three references from massage therapists who are professional members of a massage association referred to in this section; or 
(3)  Certificate of professional membership in the American Massage Therapy Association, International Myomassethics Federation, or any other recognized massage association with equivalent professional membership standards. 
(b)  A medical certificate shall be provided to the city on an annual basis stating that the employee, or anyone purporting to act as a massagist, has been examined and found to be free of any contagious or communicable disease. 
(Code 1988, § 7.178; Ord. No. 350, § 1, 10-19-1989) 
Sec. 8-230. - Wearing apparel. 
    Uniforms or garments covering the torso shall be worn by massagists or employees attending patrons. Such uniforms or garments shall be nontransparent and of washable material and shall be kept in a clean condition. The sleeves of said uniform or garment shall not reach below the elbow. Such clothing shall cover the person's pubic area, perineum, buttocks, natal cleft and entire chest to four inches below the collarbone and legs not exposed more than two inches above the knees. 
(Code 1988, § 7.179; Ord. No. 350, § 1, 10-19-1989) 
Sec. 8-231. - Patronage of massage business by minors. 
    No person licensed as a massagist shall massage or treat any person under the age of 18 upon the licensed premises, except upon written order by a licensed physician, osteopath or registered physical therapist, such order being dated and in the possession of the massagist giving the massage or treatment. If the person under the age of 18 is accompanied by a parent or legal guardian during the massage or treatment, this provision shall not apply. 
(Code 1988, § 7.180; Ord. No. 350, § 1, 10-19-1989) 
Sec. 8-232. - Name of business. 
    No person licensed to do business as provided in this article shall operate under any name or conduct business under any designation not specified in the license of such person. 
(Code 1988, § 7.181; Ord. No. 350, § 1, 10-19-1989) 
Sec. 8-233. - Hours of operation. 
    No massage facility shall be open to the public for business between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. During all hours of operation, entry doors and doors to the massage area shall remain unlocked. 
(Code 1988, § 7.182; Ord. No. 350, § 1, 10-19-1989) 
Sec. 8-234. - List of employees, employee information. 
    The massage facility shall keep a list of the names and addresses of all employees, both on duty and off duty, and such list shall be shown to the director of public safety or the director of public safety's duly authorized representative upon request. 
(Code 1988, § 7.183; Ord. No. 350, § 1, 10-19-1989) 
Sec. 8-235. - Keeping of records. 
    Every person who operates a massage facility shall maintain an accurate record in a well-bound book of all patrons accommodated. Such record shall include the patron's name, age and current address together with the time, date and place of service, the nature of the service provided, and the name of the massagist who provided the service. Such record book shall be available at all times at the massage facility for inspection by the director of public safety or the director of public safety's duly authorized representative. 
(Code 1988, § 7.184; Ord. No. 350, § 1, 10-19-1989) 
Sec. 8-236. - Inspections. 
(a)  A licensee or any employee, servant or agent shall make the licensed premises available for inspection by the director of public safety or the director of public safety's designees during regular business hours or when the licensed premises are occupied by the licensee or a servant, agent or employee of the licensee for the purpose of enforcing this article or other ordinances, or regulations of the city relating to the public health, safety and welfare. No duly authorized representative of the city shall be denied or refused entry to the premises for the purpose of making lawful inspections as authorized herein. 
(b)  The person conducting any inspection shall have immediate access to the following information and shall have the right to inspect and copy the same: 
(1)  The list of all names and addresses of current employees including any other names for which that employee is known or may have used. 
(2)  Social Security numbers of all current employees. 
(3)  List of all patrons or customers, including their name, address, date and time of service, type of service provided, amount of fee received, name of employee providing service. 
(4)  List of current telephone bills containing the numbers of all calls made throughout the Detroit metropolitan area, or long distance calls made, or billed to the premises. 
(5)  All financial records showing current receipts and expenditures, specifically indicating daily and weekly receipts, type of expenditure made, bank account numbers in which all deposits are made, check register statements, bank statements and any other financial information kept and maintained in the normal and ordinary course of business. 
(c)  Copies of any information obtained hereunder and any information received by the city shall be kept confidential and is assumed to be privileged and not subject to public disclosure except however, as evidence in the commencement of any civil or criminal judicial proceeding or administrative hearing against the licensee or any agent, operator or manager. 
(d)  Copies of any inspection report kept and maintained by the city arising from any inspection authorized hereunder, shall be provided to the licensee or any owner, operator or manager. 
(Code 1988, § 7.185; Ord. No. 350, § 1, 10-19-1989) 
Sec. 8-237. - Sale or transfer. 
    Upon the sale or transfer of any interest in a massage facility, or the sale or transfer of any stock ownership of more than ten percent in such establishment, the license shall be null and void. A new application shall be made by any person desiring to own or operate the massage facility. 
(Code 1988, § 7.187; Ord. No. 350, § 1, 10-19-1989) 
Sec. 8-238. - Change of location. 
    A change of location of any licensed premises shall be approved by the city clerk provided the requirements set forth herein as well as all other provisions of this article and state law are complied with. 
(Code 1988, § 7.188; Ord. No. 350, § 1, 10-19-1989) 
Sec. 8-239. - Extension or expansion. 
    Any extension or expansion of the licensed premises shall require inspection and shall require compliance with section 8-225. 
(Code 1988, § 7.189; Ord. No. 350, § 1, 10-19-1989) 
Sec. 8-240. - Applicability of regulations to existing facilities. 
    The provisions of this article shall be applicable to all persons and facilities described herein, whether the herein described activities were established before or after the effective date of the ordinance from which this section is derived, and including any person whose application is presently under consideration or investigation by the city. 
(Code 1988, § 7.190; Ord. No. 350, § 1, 10-19-1989) 
Sec. 8-241. - Exemptions. 
    This article shall not apply to the following described persons practicing their respective professions: 
(1)  Physicians, surgeons, chiropractors, osteopaths, psychiatrists, psychologists, clinical social workers, and family counselors who are licensed to practice their respective professions in the state. 
(2)  Nurses who are registered under the laws of this state and who administer a massage in the normal course of nursing duties. 
(3)  A trainer of any athletic team who administers a massage in the normal course of training duties. 
(4)  Barbers and cosmetologists who are duly licensed under the laws of this state and who administer a massage in the normal course of their duties. 
(Code 1988, § 7.191; Ord. No. 350, § 1, 10-19-1989) 
Secs. 8-242-8-260. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - LANDLORDS 

Sec. 8-261. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Owner, in addition to the legal owner of property, means the landlord, lessor, sublessor, mortgage company, bank, financial institution or any other entity or person having the legal authority to rent, lease or offer as available for lease or rent, a rental unit or the property of which it is a part and, in addition, means a person authorized to exercise any aspect of the management of the premises, including a person who, directly or indirectly, acts as a rental agent, receives rent or any part thereof, other than as a bona fide purchaser, and who has no obligation to deliver the whole of such receipts to another person. 
    Rental agreement means all agreements that establish or modify the terms, conditions, rules, regulations, or any other provisions concerning the use and occupancy of a rental unit. 
    Rental unit means a structure or part thereof used as a home, residence, or sleeping unit by a single person or household unit, or any grounds, or other facilities or area promised for the use of a residential tenant and includes, without limitation, apartment units, boardinghouses, roominghouses, mobile home spaces, and single- and two-family dwellings. 
(Code 1988, § 8.171; Ord. No. 382, § 1, 12-19-1995; Ord. No. 544, § 1, 1-17-2012) 
Sec. 8-262. - Procedure, duration and license fee. 
(a)  No owner shall enter into an agreement or contract, either written or oral, to lease or rent any house or rental unit rent without first making application for and receiving a current landlord license from the city clerk. The application shall be accompanied by an annual license fee, in such amount as may hereafter be prescribed by the city commission by resolution, for each unit rented by such owner. An owner who fails to secure a license as provided herein, prior to entering into an agreement to rent or lease a house or rental unit shall be charged a fee for such license in the amount of two times the annual license fee. Said applicant shall state the applicant's name, address and telephone number, and specifically identify the number of units that are to be rented or leased as well as the addresses or all address(s) of all such rental houses or units. The city clerk shall issue the license if: 
(1)  The applicant's property is determined, after inspection by the building official, not to be in violation of this article; and 
(2)  The applicant provides a full legal description of all parcels of property for which a license is requested. 
(b)  No owner of any rental unit governed by this article shall hereafter offer to let or hire any rental unit, or permit the reoccupancy of any such unit pursuant to any rental or lease agreement, unless such unit has been reinspected and a certificate of compliance has been issued by the building official. The building official shall cause such inspection to be had within a reasonable time after application therefor and payment of any inspection fee. A certificate of compliance shall be issued if the dwelling unit complies with all applicable provisions of state and city building and housing codes. 
(c)  A certificate of compliance shall be issued on the condition that the premises remain in safe, healthful and fit condition for occupancy. If upon reinspection the building official determines that conditions exist which constitute a hazard to health or safety, the certificate shall be immediately suspended as to the affected areas and the areas may be vacated as provided in subsection (d) of this section. 
(d)  When the building official has not issued a certificate of compliance or when such certificate, once issued, has expired or been suspended, or when such certificate has been withheld pending compliance, no rental unit shall be rented or occupied until reinspection and proof of compliance, in the discretion of the building official. 
(e)  The city manager is hereby empowered to revoke a landlord's license if it is discovered that the applicant has either: 
(1)  Misrepresented self or the state of the property; 
(2)  Refused access to premises for inspection as required hereinafter; or 
(3)  The property is or becomes violative of any of the ordinances of the city and/or the statutes of the state. 
(f)  Every license shall expire annually on December 31. 
(Code 1988, § 8.172; Ord. No. 344, § 1, 7-25-1989; Ord. No. 382, § 2, 12-19-1995; Ord. No. 544, § 2, 1-17-2012) 
Sec. 8-263. - Inspection and enforcement. 
(a)  The city manager shall cause the building official, or such other appropriate public official as the city manager may designate, to make an annual inspection of rental units, and inspections upon reoccupancy of rental units, to which an applicant for a landlord license or licenses shall be deemed to consent, to determine the health and safety conditions of the rental units. For the purpose of making such inspections, the building official or the appointed public official is hereby authorized to enter, examine and survey at all reasonable times all rental units. 
(b)  The tenant or person in charge of a rental unit shall at all reasonable times give the building official or designated official free access only to the leased portion of the same or central facilities serving the same for the purpose of such inspection, examination and survey. 
(c)  Upon learning that any rental unit governed by this article has been vacated, the building official shall post on the premises, in a prominent place, a written notice stating that reoccupancy of such unit pursuant to any lease or rental agreement is prohibited by ordinance of the city until such unit has been inspected and a certificate of compliance issued by the building official. A copy of the notice shall be sent by certified mail to the owner of the rental unit. 
(d)  No rental unit as to which there is no current landlord license and current certificate of compliance in effect shall be occupied. 
(Code 1988, § 8.173; Ord. No. 382, § 3, 12-19-1995) 
Sec. 8-264. - Notice of revocation and hearing. 
    A landlord license may be revoked in accordance with the procedures set forth in this chapter. 
(Code 1988, § 8.174; Ord. No. 382, § 4, 12-19-1995) 
Sec. 8-265. - Violations; penalties. 
    A person who violates any provision of this article is responsible for a municipal civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 8.175; Ord. No. 416, § 1, 5-19-1998) 
Secs. 8-266-8-280. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - LAWN CARE SERVICES 

Sec. 8-281. - Definitions. 
    "Lawn care service" means an individual or business entity engaged in the business of cutting, trimming, fertilizing, rolling or otherwise maintaining or improving any lawn for any house or building in Huntington Woods. It does not include landscape services or services involved in the care of trees even though such entities may be required to fertilize, roll or repair a lawn as long as such service is incidental to the primary service for which they have been engaged. 
(Ord. No. 545, § 1, 2-21-2012) 
Sec. 8-282. - License required. 
    No person or entity shall engage in the business of operating a lawn care service in the City of Huntington Woods without first obtaining a license from the city clerk. The license must be renewed annually and shall expire on December 31 of each year. The fee for the license shall be established by the city commission from time to time. No license shall be required for a lawn care service in which no truck, trailer or other motor vehicle is utilized. 
(Ord. No. 545, § 1, 2-21-2012) 
Sec. 8-283. - Use of vehicles by lawn care services. 
    No person or entity shall operate a truck or other motor vehicle with or without a trailer in the course of operating a lawn care service business in the City of Huntington Woods unless a vehicle tag has been issued by the city clerk for such a vehicle or trailer. The vehicle tag must be prominently displayed on the exterior of the vehicle and/or trailer in a manner so as to be readily observable. Vehicle tags shall be issued to licensed lawn care services upon request made either at the time of issuance of the license or thereafter for specified trucks, trailers or other motor vehicles registered to such licensee and upon payment of such fee per vehicle as may be established by resolution of the city commission. 
(Ord. No. 545, § 1, 2-21-2012) 
Sec. 8-284. - Yard waste. 
    No person engaged in the operation of a lawn care service or employed by a lawn care service business mowing and/or maintaining lawns in the City of Huntington Woods shall place, throw, deposit, scatter or leave grass clippings or other yard waste in any street or public area. Yard waste disposed of in the city shall be in accordance with Huntington Woods City Code section 30-22. 
(Ord. No. 545, § 1, 2-21-2012) 
Sec. 8-285. - Compliance with Huntington Woods ordinances. 
    All licensed lawn care services shall comply with all applicable ordinances of the City of Huntington Woods, including subsection 14-56(12) relating to noise and section 30-22 relating to the placement of bags or debris at curbside. 
(Ord. No. 545, § 1, 2-21-2012) 
Secs. 8-286-8-300. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XII. - SNOW REMOVAL SERVICES 

Sec. 8-301. - Snow removal license required. 
    No person or entity shall engage in the business of snow removal utilizing mechanically driven vehicles without first obtaining a license from the City of Huntington Woods. Licenses shall be issued annually and shall expire on June 30 following issuance. 
(Ord. No. 546, § 1, 2-21-2012) 
Sec. 8-302. - Contents of application for license. 
    Every applicant for a license required by the provisions of this section shall submit an application to the department of public safety on a form provided by the department, which shall include the name and address of the applicant, the type of mechanical equipment to be used, the street, streets or portion of any streets upon which the mechanical snow removal equipment will be used, and the weight of the vehicle including personnel that may be included in the operation of the vehicle. If the vehicle is self-propelled, a description of the type of tires and wheels to be used on the vehicle shall be provided. 
(Ord. No. 546, § 1, 2-21-2012) 
Sec. 8-303. - Grant or denial of license. 
    The decision to grant or deny a license to perform snow removal in the City of Huntington Woods shall be made by the director of public safety. If in the opinion of the director, the equipment described in the application for a permit would damage the street, sidewalk or any other area upon which its use is proposed, the application will be denied. If the director determines that the vehicle or equipment used for snow removal will not damage or tend to damage any street, sidewalk or other area, the license shall be granted. 
(Ord. No. 546, § 1, 2-21-2012) 
Sec. 8-304. - Bond and/or liability insurance. 
    Every person or entity engaged in the business of snow removal in the City of Huntington Woods as regulated by this section shall furnish a cash or surety bond and/or evidence of liability insurance coverage protecting against damage to person and property in an amount not less than $1,000,000.00. 
(Ord. No. 546, § 1, 2-21-2012) 
Sec. 8-305. - Permit applicable to specific equipment. 
    A license issued under this section shall be applicable only to the equipment described in the application for such license. Persons or entities using multiple pieces of equipment must apply for a license for each piece of snow removal equipment as described in this section. 
(Ord. No. 546, § 1, 2-21-2012) 
Sec. 8-306. - Disposal of snow. 
    Snow removed from driveways or sidewalks by licensees shall either be removed from the city or placed on the property of the person or entity who engaged the licensee. A licensee shall not deposit snow, ice or slush onto a city street or onto the private property of a person or entity other than the person or entity who engaged the licensee. 
(Ord. No. 546, § 1, 2-21-2012) 
Secs. 8-307-8-330. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIII. - TREE SERVICES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 565, § 1, adopted June 17, 2014, set out provisions intended for use as art. XII, §§ 8-306-8-312. To avoid duplication of section numbers and to preserve the style of this Code, and at the editor's discretion, these provisions have been included as art. XIII, §§ 8-331-8-337. 

Sec. 8-331. - Definitions. 
    Diameter breast height (DBH): The diameter in inches of the tree measured at 41/2 feet above the existing grade. 
    Tree service, contractor: Any person or entity engaged in the business of removing, relocating, cutting, trimming, pruning, spraying or otherwise treating trees with power equipment. 
(Ord. No. 565, § 1, 6-17-2014) 
Sec. 8-332. - License required. 
    No person or entity shall engage in the business of operating a tree service on public or private land in the City of Huntington Woods without first obtaining a license from the city clerk. The license must be renewed annually and shall expire on December 31 of each year. The application for a license shall be accompanied by a certificate of insurance, proof of worker's compensation insurance for all employees as required by the Workers Disability Compensation Act, and a licensing fee. The certificate of insurance shall be in such form and amount as to protect the city and any person in the city from damage to person or property resulting from the tree service's or contractor's action. The fee for the license and the minimum amounts of insurance shall be established by resolution of the city commission and updated from time-to-time. 
(Ord. No. 565, § 1, 6-17-2014) 
Sec. 8-333. - Exception. 
    An annual license shall not be required of any public utility company granted an annual trimming permit by the city manager in accordance with the regulations in section 14-181. This exemption shall only apply in the case that the public utility itself is performing the trimming or tree service work. In the event the public utility has engaged the services of an outside tree service contractor to perform the tree service work, that tree service contractor shall be required to obtain a license as required in this article. 
(Ord. No. 565, § 1, 6-17-2014) 
Sec. 8-334. - Permit required. 
    A tree removal permit is required for removing or relocating any tree in the City of Huntington Woods with a DBH of six inches or greater on any property, public or private. Such tree removal or relocation shall be in accordance with the regulations of article VII of chapter 14 of the city Code. 
(Ord. No. 565, § 1, 6-17-2014) 
Sec. 8-335. - Work hours. 
    Tree removal, relocation, cutting, trimming, pruning, spraying or other work on trees shall not take place on Sundays or any other day between the hours of 8:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m., except for emergency removal described in section 14-175. 
(Ord. No. 565, § 1, 6-17-2014) 
Sec. 8-336. - Removal of tree trunks, branches and debris required. 
    The tree service or contractor shall remove from the city all tree trunks, limbs, branches and debris resulting from the cutting, trimming or removing of a tree within 48 hours of the actual work performed, and all tree trunks, limbs, branches and debris shall not block, cover or impede any public sidewalk or street after the end of work on any day. 
(Ord. No. 565, § 1, 6-17-2014) 
Sec. 8-337. - Compliance with city ordinances. 
    All licensed tree services and contractors shall comply with all applicable ordinances of the City of Huntington Woods, in particular article VII Trees, of chapter 14 of the city Code. 
(Ord. No. 565, § 1, 6-17-2014) 
Secs. 8-338-8-360. - Reserved. 
Chapter 9 - RESERVED 
Chapter 10 - ELECTIONS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Michigan Election Law, MCL 168.1 et seq. 

Sec. 10-1. - Odd-year election. 
(a)  An election to be known as the "odd-year general election" shall be held on the Tuesday succeeding the first Monday in November in every odd-numbered year. Nominating petitions shall be filed in accordance with the provisions of chapter 4 of the Charter of the city, except that the last day for filing such petitions with the city clerk shall be on or before 4:00 p.m. on the 15th Tuesday prior to the election. Persons who have been notified by the city clerk that timely and sufficient nominating petitions have been filed on their behalf and who desire to become a candidate for any elective city office shall have until no later than 4:00 p.m. of the Friday following the last day for filing nominating petitions to file an acceptance of such nomination with the clerk as set forth in the Charter. 
(b)  In the event that any incumbent elected official desires to become a candidate for any other elective office at an election, and the term of office of such official does not expire on the Monday following such election, then the nominating petitions of such official for such other elective office, together with his acceptance of such nomination, shall be filed with the city clerk on or before 4:00 p.m. on the 18th Tuesday prior to the election, and such acceptance so filed shall constitute the resignation of such official and he shall be deemed to have resigned as of the first Monday following such election. The unexpired term of such office shall be filled by electoral vote at the same election, and nominating petitions may be filed therefor and notice thereof shall be included in the notice of such election as provided by law. 
(Code 1988, § 1.14; Ord. No. 401, § 1, 7-15-1997; Ord. No. 537, § 1, 4-26-2011; Ord. No. 539, § 1, 6-14-2011; Ord. No. 573, § 1, 3-17-2015; Ord. No. 575, § 1, 4-7-2015) 
Sec. 10-2. - Officers elected. 
    The mayor and commissioners shall be elected for four-year terms. At each odd-year general election two city commissioners shall be elected to succeed the two commissioners whose terms are to expire and at the odd-year election prior to the expiration of the mayor's term of office, a mayor shall be elected. The terms to which said officers shall be elected shall expire at 7:30 p.m. on the first Monday after the odd-year general election held four years after the election of said officers. Officers elected to fill a vacancy shall serve for the unexpired term. 
(Code 1988, § 1.14) 
Sec. 10-3. - Constable's office abolished. 
    Pursuant to section 32 of Public Act No. 279 of 1909 (MCL 117.32), the office of constable is abolished in the city. 
(Code 1988, § 1.14) 
Sec. 10-4. - Conduct of elections. 
    All elections shall be conducted in the manner elections for state and county offices are conducted. 
(Code 1988, § 1.14) 
State Law reference- Michigan Election Law, MCL 168.1 et seq. 
Chapter 11 - RESERVED 
Chapter 12 - EMERGENCIES 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 12-1-12-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - EMERGENCY PREPAREDNESS POLICY[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Emergency management act, MCL 30.401 et seq. 

Sec. 12-19. - Definitions. 
(a)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Coordinator means the city manager or the city manager's designee. 
(b)  Terms defined in the emergency management act, Public Act No. 390 of 1976 (MCL 30.401 et seq.) shall have the meanings therein prescribed. 
(Code 1988, § 1.171) 
Sec. 12-20. - Organization for emergency services. 
(a)  The mayor, as executive head of the city government, shall be the director of the emergency services forces of the city and shall be responsible for their organization, administration and operation, working through the city manager. 
(b)  The city manager, with the approval of the commission, is hereby authorized and directed to create an organization to prepare for community disasters utilizing to the fullest extent existing agencies within the city. 
(c)  The organization for providing emergency services shall consist of the following: 
(1)  An office of emergency services established within city government. The office of emergency services shall have an administrative head appointed who will be known as the coordinator, office of emergency services. Such assistants and other employees as are deemed necessary for the proper functioning of the organization will be employed. 
(2)  The employees, equipment and facilities of all city departments, boards, institutions and committees suitable for or adaptable to emergency service activities may be designated as part of the total emergency services forces. Such designations shall be recommended by the city manager with the approval of the commission. 
(d)  All officers and employees of departments, committees, boards, institutions and other agencies of the city government designated by the city manager, with the approval of the commission, as emergency services forces shall cooperate with the emergency services coordinator in the formulation of the emergency operations plan and they shall assist the coordinator in all matters pursuant to the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1988, § 1.172) 
Sec. 12-21. - Emergency services coordinator; assistants; deputies. 
(a)  Assistant coordinators appointed by the city manager shall be designated to work with the coordinator on emergency planning matters. Assistant coordinators shall be appointed as need dictates. 
(b)  Assistant coordinators shall assume the duties of the coordinator whenever the coordinator is unavailable during disasters or emergency situations. 
(Code 1988, § 1.173) 
Sec. 12-22. - Mayor powers, duties. 
(a)  The mayor may exercise the emergency power and authority as specified herein. Whenever a situation requires or is likely to require that the mayor invoke such power and authority, the mayor shall, as soon as reasonably expedient, convene the commission to perform its legislative and administrative duties as the situation demands and shall report to that body relative to emergency activities. Nothing in this article shall be construed as abridging or curtailing the powers of the commission unless specifically provided herein. 
(b)  Under the following circumstances, the mayor may assemble and utilize the emergency services forces and may prescribe the manner and conditions of their use: 
(1)  Whenever on the basis of information received from authoritative sources the mayor feels that a large-scale disaster or emergency situation affecting the city is imminent. 
(2)  During any period of disaster in the city, county or state and thereafter as long as the mayor shall deem it necessary. 
(c)  Whenever any condition in the city has attained or threatens to attain the proportions of a major disaster, the mayor may assemble and utilize emergency services forces and may prescribe the manner and conditions of their use. The mayor, with the approval of the commission, is hereby empowered to enter into mutual aid agreements with other public or private agencies for reciprocal aid and assistance during disasters which are beyond local capabilities and resources. The mayor may, when deemed in the public interest, send emergency services forces of the city to the aid of other communities stricken by disaster as provided by mutual aid agreements; provided that after the commission convenes, the future continuance of any such disaster relief and the period thereof shall be subject to the action of the commission. 
(d)  The city manager, with the approval of the commission, may establish regulations permitting the coordinator to assemble and utilize the emergency services forces and provide disaster relief aid as prescribed in section 12-23(1) and (2). 
(e)  When obtaining formal approvals would result in significant delay of relief activity, the mayor may, until the commission convenes, waive procedures and formalities otherwise required pertaining to the performance of public works, entering into contracts, the incurring of obligations, the employment of temporary workers, the rental of equipment, the purchase and distribution of supplies, materials and facilities and the expenditure of existing funds, and the commission is also empowered to waive any such procedures and formalities. 
(f)  The city manager, with the approval of the commission, shall establish procedures for the succession of government during emergencies where officials are unavailable for exercising the powers and discharging the duties of their respective offices. 
(Code 1988, § 1.174) 
Sec. 12-23. - Emergency services coordinator powers, duties. 
    The emergency services coordinator shall be responsible for all emergency preparedness activities in the city. The coordinator shall maintain liaison with state and federal authorities and the authorities of other nearby political subdivisions so as to ensure the most effective emergency operations. The coordinator's duties shall include, but not be limited to, the following: 
(1)  Development of plans for the immediate use of all of the facilities, equipment, manpower and other resources of the city for the purpose of minimizing or preventing damage to persons or property, and protecting and restoring to usefulness governmental services and public utilities necessary for the public health, safety and general welfare. 
(2)  Coordinating the recruitment and training of volunteer personnel and facilities for emergency purposes. 
(3)  Through public information programs, educating the civilian population as to actions necessary and required for the protection of persons and property in case of disaster. 
(4)  Conducting practice alerts and exercises to ensure the efficient operation of the city's regulations, procedures and operations. 
(5)  Coordinating the activity of all other public and private agencies engaged in any emergency or disaster relief program. 
(6)  Negotiating with owners or persons in control of buildings or other property for the use of such buildings or property for emergency or disaster relief purposes and designating suitable buildings as public shelters. 
(7)  Establish and maintain administrative control over a local radiological defense program, to include emergency preparations for both peacetime radiation incidents and international wartime disasters. 
(8)  Establish property accountability procedures for federal surplus property acquired by the city, federal excess property on loan to the city, or any other property or equipment loaned to the city for use in disaster or emergency situations. 
(Code 1988, § 1.175) 
Sec. 12-24. - Volunteers' appointment; records. 
(a)  Subject to the approval of the coordinator, each department, committee, board or other agency of city government may appoint or authorize the appointment of volunteer citizens to augment the personnel of such city department, committee, board or agency in time of emergency. Such individuals shall be enrolled as emergency services volunteers and shall be subject to the rules and regulations set forth by the respective department, committee, board or agency head for such volunteers. 
(b)  The coordinator may enlist volunteer citizens to form the personnel of an emergency service for which the city has no counterpart or to temporarily augment personnel engaged in emergency activities. The coordinator shall maintain formal records of all such volunteers for worker's compensation purposes. 
(Code 1988, § 1.176) 
Sec. 12-25. - Rights of city employees. 
    City employees assigned to duty as part of the emergency services forces pursuant to the provisions of this chapter shall retain all of the rights, privileges and immunities of city employees and shall receive the compensation incident to their employment. 
(Code 1988, § 1.177) 
Sec. 12-26. - No governmental or private liability. 
(a)  This chapter is an exercise by the city of its governmental functions for the protection of the public health, safety and general welfare. As such, neither the city nor agents and representatives of the city nor any individual, receiver, firm, partnership, corporation, association, trustee nor any of the agents thereof acting in good faith carrying out, complying with or attempting to comply with this chapter shall be liable for any damage sustained to persons or property as a result of said activity. 
(b)  Any person owning or controlling real estate or other premises who voluntarily and without compensation grants to this state or a political subdivision of this state a license or privilege, or otherwise permits this state or a political subdivision of this state the right to inspect, designate and use the whole or any part of the real estate or premises for the purpose of sheltering persons during an actual, impending, mock or practice disaster, together with his successors in interest, if any, is not civilly liable for negligently causing the death of or injury to any person on or about the real estate or premises under the license, privilege or other permission or for loss or damage to the property of the person. 
(Code 1988, § 1.178) 
State Law reference- Liability for personal injury or property damage, MCL 30.411. 
Sec. 12-27. - Federal surplus property. 
    The emergency services coordinator is hereby designated as the person responsible for accepting federal surplus property with the power and full authority to sign for such surplus property. The mayor shall provide a written statement to appropriate federal officials designating the current name of the coordinator as responsible for complying with the provisions of this section. 
(1)  The coordinator is responsible for the accountability and will maintain the necessary records for all surplus property obtained for emergency purposes until relieved from accountability by state and federal authorities. 
(2)  The coordinator is further authorized to direct payment of service charges for surplus property to complete all transactions. 
(3)  Misappropriation or unauthorized private use of such public property while still accountable is subject to prosecution under federal and state statute. 
(Code 1988, § 1.179) 
Chapter 13 - RESERVED 
Chapter 14 - ENVIRONMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Natural Resources and Environmental Protection Act, MCL 324.101 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 14-1. - Public nuisance defined and prohibited. 
    Whatever annoys, injures or endangers the safety, health, comfort or repose of the public; offends public decency; interferes with, obstructs or renders dangerous any street, highway, navigable lake or stream; or in any way renders the public insecure in life or property is hereby declared to be a public nuisance. Public nuisances shall include, but not be limited to, whatever is forbidden by any provision of this chapter. No person shall commit, create, or maintain any nuisance. 
(Code 1988, § 9.1) 
State Law reference- Public nuisances and abatement, MCL 600.3801 et seq. 
Sec. 14-2. - Violations; penalties. 
(a)  Except as otherwise specifically provided, a person who violates any provision of this chapter is responsible for a municipal civil infraction. 
(b)  Nothing contained in this section shall limit the availability of injunctive relief to the city in appropriate circumstances, or otherwise limit, in any way, such police and remedial actions as are available to the city under law. 
(Code 1988, § 9.2; Ord. No. 422, § 1, 5-19-1998) 
Sec. 14-3. - Dense smoke prohibited. 
    No person shall operate any stove, furnace, boiler or combustion apparatus of any kind, nor shall any person owning any stove, furnace, boiler or combustion apparatus of any kind permit the same to be operated, in a manner so as to emit dense smoke and/or the ingredients thereof; provided that the emission of dense smoke and/or the ingredients thereof for a period of 20 minutes in any one hour, once in every 24 hours, when a new fire is being kindled, shall not constitute a violation of this chapter; and provided further that the emission of dense smoke and/or the ingredients thereof for a period aggregating six minutes in any one hour, and not exceeding two minutes of continuous emission, shall not be deemed a violation of this chapter. 
(Code 1988, § 9.6) 
Sec. 14-4. - Smoke measurement. 
    For the purpose of defining the term "dense smoke" which shall constitute a prohibited density hereunder, the standards established by the "Ringelmann Smoke Chart," 1955 edition, are hereby adopted, as published by the Department of Interior, Bureau of Mines (I.C. 7718) with its accompanying publication written by Ralph Rudolph Kudlich and revised by L. R. Durdick, as published by Bureau of Mines, Publication-Distribution Section, 4800 Forbes Street, Pittsburgh 13, Pennsylvania, in accordance with Department of Interior Public Notice Number 84932. Smoke of a density equal to or greater than the density described as number two on the Ringelmann Smoke Chart shall be considered and held to be "dense smoke" as the term is used in this chapter. 
(Code 1988, § 9.7) 
Secs. 14-5-14-22. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LITTERING[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 324.8901 et seq. 

Sec. 14-23. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Litter means rubbish, refuse, waste material, garbage, offal, paper, glass, cans, bottles, trash, debris, or other foreign substances or a vehicle that is considered abandoned under section 252a of the Michigan Vehicle Code, Public Act No. 300 of 1949 (MCL 257.252a). 
    Public or private property or water means, but is not limited to, any of the following: 
(1)  The right-of-way of a road or highway, a body of water or watercourse, or the shore or beach of a body of water or watercourse, including the ice above the water. 
(2)  A park, playground, building, refuge, or conservation or recreation area. 
(3)  Residential or farm properties or timberlands. 
    Vehicle means a motor vehicle registered or required to be registered under the Michigan Vehicle Code, Public Act No. 300 of 1949 (MCL 257.1 et seq.). 
    Vessel means a vessel registered under part 801 of Public Act No. 451 of 1994 (MCL 324.80101 et seq.). 
(Code 1988, § 9.9) 
Sec. 14-24. - Litter. 
(a)  A person shall not knowingly, without the consent of the public authority having supervision of public property, or the owner of private property, dump, deposit, place, throw, or leave, or cause or permit the dumping, depositing, placing, throwing, or leaving of, litter on public or private property or water other than property designated and set aside for such purposes. 
(b)  A person who removes a vehicle that is wrecked or damaged in an accident on a highway, road, or street shall remove all glass and other injurious substances dropped on the highway, road, or street as a result of the accident. 
(Code 1988, § 9.9) 
Sec. 14-25. - Litter on highway. 
    A person shall not knowingly cause litter or any object to fall or to be thrown into the path of or to hit a vehicle traveling upon a highway. 
(Code 1988, § 9.9) 
Sec. 14-26. - Litter violation. 
(a)  Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section involving litter from a leased vehicle or leased vessel, in a proceeding for a violation of this part involving litter from a motor vehicle or vessel, proof that the particular vehicle or vessel described in the citation, complaint, or warrant was used in the violation, together with proof that the defendant named in the citation, complaint, or warrant was the registered owner of the vehicle or vessel at the time of the violation, gives rise to a rebuttable presumption that the registered owner of the vehicle or vessel was the driver of the vehicle or vessel at the time of the violation. 
(b)  There is a rebuttable presumption that the driver of a vehicle or vessel is responsible for litter that is thrown, dumped, deposited, placed, or left from the vehicle or vessel on public or private property or water. 
(c)  In a proceeding for a violation of this part involving litter from a leased motor vehicle or leased vessel, proof that the particular vehicle or vessel described in the citation, complaint, or warrant was used in the violation, together with proof that the defendant named in the citation, complaint, or warrant was the lessee of the vehicle or vessel at the time of the violation, gives rise to a rebuttable presumption that the lessee of the vehicle or vessel was the driver of the vehicle or vessel at the time of the violation. 
(d)  In a proceeding for a violation of this part involving litter consisting of an abandoned vehicle, proof that the particular vehicle described in the citation, complaint, or warrant was abandoned, and that the defendant named in the citation, complaint, or warrant was the titled owner or lessee of the vehicle at the time it was abandoned, gives rise to a rebuttable presumption that the defendant abandoned the vehicle. 
(Code 1988, § 9.9) 
Secs. 14-27-14-55. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - NOISE CONTROL WITHIN THE CITY OF HUNTINGTON WOODS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 576, § 1, adopted June 16, 2015, amended art. III in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former art. III, §§ 14-56 and 14-57 pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from: Code 1988, §§ 9.11, 9.12; Ord. No. 384, § 1, adopted Apr. 16, 1996; Ord. No. 393, § 1, adopted Feb. 4, 1997; Ord. No. 489, § 4, adopted Aug. 17, 2004; Ord. No. 525, § 1, adopted June 17, 2008; and Ord. No. 566, § 1, adopted June 17, 2014. 
State Law reference- Motor vehicle mufflers, MCL 257.707 et seq. 

Sec. 14-56. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this section, all terminology used in this section, not defined in this section, shall be in conformance with the applicable publications of the American National Standards Institute (ANSI). The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    A-weighted sound level means the sound pressure level in decibels as measured on a sound level meter using the A-weighted network as specified in the American National Standards Institute Standard S1.4-1983, or its successor provision. The sound pressure level so read is designated dB(A) or dBA. 
    Authorized city official means all designated Huntington Woods Public Safety Officers, Building Officials or Code Enforcement Officers, authorized to investigate all complaints of violation of this section and who are further authorized to issue municipal civil infractions. 
    City commission means the City Commission of the City of Huntington Woods. 
    Commercial area means property zoned for uses other than residential or parks-recreation, regardless of whether the property has a commercial use. 
    Continuous sound means any sound with a duration of more than one second, as measured with a sound level meter set to the "fast" meter response. 
    Decibel (dB) means a unit of sound pressure level on a logarithmic scale measured relative to the threshold of audible sound by the human ear, in compliance with the American National Standards Institute Standard S1.4-1983, or its successor provision. 
    Extraneous sound means a sound which is relatively intense, intermittent and of short duration and is neither part of the neighborhood residual sound, nor comes from the sound source under investigation. The sources of extraneous sound are noted, but excluded from all measurements (e.g., passing vehicle or distant train). 
    Immediate vicinity means any distance beyond the property line of the parcel or lot from which the source of noise or disturbance is emanating as determined by the authorized city official during the course of investigating a complaint of noise disturbance. 
    Motor vehicle means every vehicle which is self-propelled whether or not licensed or intended for use on the public roads. 
    Neighborhood residual sound level means that measured value which represents the summation of the sound from all of the discrete sources affecting a given site at a given time. Neighborhood residual sounds are differentiated from extraneous sounds by the fact that the former are a more steady state, although they may not be continuous. 
    Parks-Recreation means Zone 4 as defined by the Huntington Woods Code of Ordinances. 
    Person means any owner, lessee or occupant of property, including any individual, corporation, business or other entity; "person" also means any individual in any public place or any private place open to the general public. 
    Property line means the imaginary line which represents the legal limits of property owned, leased, or otherwise occupied by a person or business entity. In cases involving sound from an activity on a public right-of-way, the property line shall be the nearest boundary of the public right-of-way. 
    Public right-of-way means the entire easement width or ownership interest of any publicly dedicated street, avenue, boulevard, highway, sidewalk, alley or similar place. 
    Residential area means property used for temporary or permanent dwelling purposes. 
    Sound level meter means an instrument used to measure sound pressure levels. This instrument shall comply with the standards for type 1 or type 2 sound level meters as specified in the American National Institute Standard ANSI S1.4-1983, or its successor provision. 
    Sound pressure level means 20 times the logarithm to the base ten of the ratio of the RMS sound pressure to the reference pressure of 20 micropascals. This sound pressure level is expressed in decibels (dB). 
    Total sound level means that measured level which represents the summation of the sounds from the sound source under investigation and the neighborhood residual sounds which affect a given place at a given time, exclusive of extraneous sound sources. 
(Ord. No. 576, § 1, 6-16-2015) 
Sec. 14-57. - Interference with sound monitoring equipment. 
    No person shall remove or render inaccurate or inoperative any sound level meter or any similar monitoring instrument or device positioned for the purpose of enforcing the provisions of this section. 
(Ord. No. 576, § 1, 6-16-2015) 
Sec. 14-58. - Prohibited acts; purpose generally. 
    It is the purpose of this article that no person shall create, assist in creating, continue or permit the continuation of any excessive or unnecessarily loud disturbance of noise of a high volume or intensity which is clearly audible and disturbs, annoys or endangers the safety of others beyond the immediate vicinity of the disturbance ("noise disturbances"). Only those noise disturbances not in compliance with section 14-59 or section 14-60 shall be a violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 576, § 1, 6-16-2015) 
Sec. 14-59. - Prohibited acts; specifically. 
    No person shall commit or cause to be committed any of the following acts of noise disturbance which are deemed a violation of this section: 
(1)  The sounding of any horn, car alarm or signaling device in any vehicle while not in motion except as a danger signal, or where the car alarm is properly used or to give warning of intent to enter a lane of traffic. 
(2)  The playing or use of any battery or electrically powered or electronic sound-producing or amplifying device, speaker or instrument, including a musical instrument, in such a manner or in such a loud volume or intensity, at any time or place, that exceeds permissible sound levels in section 14-60. 
(3)  The sound created by any domesticated animal kept or maintained by any person, when such animal creates a noise disturbance that is frequent or continued and clearly audible at a distance within or beyond the immediate vicinity of the noise as determined by an authorized city official. 
(4)  No person shall create a noise disturbance in or with a motor vehicle, motorcycle, or other motorized equipment so as to disturb or destroy or endanger the peace, comfort or repose of a person within or beyond the immediate vicinity of the source of the noise disturbance as determined by an authorized city official. No person shall operate a motor vehicle, motorcycle, or other motorized equipment without a properly functioning muffler. 
(5)  Engaging in the erection, including excavating therefor, demolition, alteration or repair of any building, and the excavation of streets and highways, at any time on Sundays, and on other days, except between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 9:00 p.m. (or between 7:00 a.m. and 9:00 p.m. on properties in Zone 4 Parks and Recreation), unless a permit is first obtained from the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 576, § 1, 6-16-2015) 
Sec. 14-60. - Maximum permissible sound levels for amplified sounds and mechanical devices. 
    Use of any loud speaker, amplifier or other instrument or device, whether stationary or mounted on a vehicle for any purpose, except by speakers in the course of public address which is noncommercial in character (recognized First Amendment speech), shall be subject to the following: 
(1)  Continuous sound. 
a.  No person shall cause, suffer, allow, or permit the operation of any source of amplified sound on any property or in the public right-of-way in such a manner as to create a sound level that exceeds the sound level limits listed in Table I as measured at any location at or within the property line of another person's property. A sound source shall not continuously exceed the sound level listed in Table I for longer than the period of time defined in subsection (1)b. Sound pressure levels in excess of those established in Table I for the period of time in subsection (1)b, shall constitute prima facie evidence that such sound is in violation of this Code. 
TABLE I
  MAXIMUM PERMISSIBLE
  SOUND LEVEL LIMITS DB(A) 
Commercial and Parks-Recreation 
(all times): 65 Residential (all times): 65  
b.  The limits defined in Table I may not be exceeded continuously for more than one minute. 
c.  Nothing in this section supersedes the requirements of employers to comply with the Occupational Noise Exposure Standard of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (29 CFR Part 1910.95). Compliance will help conserve workers' hearing, and reduce potential liability for the source. 
(2)  Steady pure tones. If the sound source under investigation is a mechanical device, and is in the authorized city official's opinion emitting a sound with a steady tonal quality, the maximum permissible sound level limits in Table I shall be reduced by 5dB. The sound emissions must be comprised of a single frequency and/or its harmonics, which may be referred to as a tone, whine, hum or buzz. Such sound sources include, but are not limited to: heating, ventilating or air conditioning units; refrigeration units; and transformers. 
(Ord. No. 576, § 1, 6-16-2015) 
Sec. 14-61. - Procedures for the determination of sound levels. 
    The sound level shall be measured with a field calibrated sound level meter. The sound level meter shall conform with ANSI S1.13 of 1973, or its successor provision. The DB(A) methodology will be used to measure sound levels, and the meter readings will be set for a fast response. 
(Ord. No. 576, § 1, 6-16-2015) 
Sec. 14-62. - General exemptions. 
    The following activities are exempted from specific prohibited acts and/or the sound pressure level limitations set forth in section 14-60: 
(1)  Emergency work necessary to restore property to a safe condition following a fire, accident or natural disaster; to restore public utilities; or to protect persons or property from imminent danger. 
(2)  Sounds made to alert persons to such emergency, danger or attempted crime, which shall not exceed five minutes in duration. 
(3)  Parades, concerts, festivals, fairs or similar activities, if approved by the city commission, subject to any sound pressure limits specified in the city commission's approval. 
(4)  Athletic, musical or cultural activities or events (including practices and rehearsals) conducted by or under the auspices of public or private schools. 
(5)  Bells, chimes or carillons while being used in conjunction with an ongoing religious service.
