ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 16-1-16-22. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FIRE CODE 

Sec. 16-23. - Adoption of International Fire Code. 
    The city hereby adopts by reference as the fire prevention code for the city the 2012 Edition of the International Fire Code, including its appendices, as published and promulgated by the International Code Council, Inc., for the purpose of regulating and governing the safeguarding of life and property from fire and explosion hazards arising from the storage, handling and use of hazardous substances, materials and devices, and from conditions hazardous to life or property in the occupancy of buildings and premises in the city and providing for the issuance of permits for hazardous uses or operations; and each and all of the regulations, provisions, conditions and terms of such International Fire Code, 2012 Edition, hereby referred to, are adopted and made a part hereof as if fully set out herein, with amendments and deletions as set forth in section 16-24. 
(Code 1988, § 8.30; Ord. No. 318, § 1, 6-21-1988; Ord. No. 509, § 1, 11-21-2006; Ord. No. 560, 6-18-2013; Ord. No. 588, § 1, 12-20-2016) 
State Law reference- Authority to adopt technical codes by reference, MCL 117.3(k). 
Sec. 16-24. - Amendments and deletions; limits established. 
(a)  Changes. The fire prevention code adopted by the provisions of this article is hereby amended, changed and altered in the following respects: 
Section 101.1. Title is amended to read as follows: 
These regulations shall be known as the Fire Code of the City of Huntington Woods, Michigan, hereinafter referred to as this Code. 
Section 108.1. Appeals is amended to read as follows: 
The City of Huntington Woods Construction and Property Maintenance Board of Appeals, created by section 6-26 of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Huntington Woods, is hereby designated to hear and decide appeals of orders, decisions or determinations made by the fire code official relative to the application and interpretation of this Code. The Board may, as required, adopt rules or procedures for conducting its business and shall render all decisions and findings in writing to the appellant with a copy to the fire code official. 
Section 109.3. Violation Penalties. 
This section is deleted and penalties shall be as provided by applicable ordinance. 
Section. 114.4. Failure to Comply is amended to read as follows: 
Any person who shall continue any work after having been served with a stop work order, except such work as that person is directed to perform to remove a violation or unsafe condition, shall be responsible for a violation of this Code and liable to a fine as provided by ordinance. Every day that work shall continue shall constitute a separate and additional offense. 
(b)  Limits established. The geographic limits referred to in certain sections of the 2012 International Fire Code are hereby established as follows: 
Section 3204.3.1.1. (geographic limits in which the storage of flammable cryogenic fluids in stationery containers is prohibited): Prohibited in all areas of the city. 
Section 3404.2.9.5. (geographic limits in which the storage of Class I and Class II liquids in above ground tanks outside of buildings is prohibited): Prohibited in all areas of the city. 
Section 3406.2.4.4. (geographic limits in which the storage of Class I and Class II liquids in above ground tanks is prohibited): Prohibited in all areas of the city. 
Section 3804.2. (geographic limits in which the storage of liquefied petroleum gas is restricted for the protection of heavily populated or congested areas): Prohibited in all areas of the city. 
(Code 1988, § 8.31; Ord. No. 318, § 1, 6-21-1988; Ord. No. 509, § 2, 11-21-2006; Ord. No. 560, 6-18-2013; Ord. No. 588, § 1, 12-20-2016) 
Sec. 16-25. - Permits. 
    The fire official shall inspect all structures and premises, except single-family dwellings, at least once each year. 
(1)  An inspection permit shall be issued by such fire official annually and such permit shall remain effective for such period of time as specified on the permit or until the next annual inspection. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful to engage in any business activity without first obtaining such a permit from the fire official. 
(3)  Permits are not transferable and any change in use, operation or tenancy shall require a new permit. 
(Code 1988, § 8.33; Ord. No. 560, 6-18-2013) 
Sec. 16-26. - Fees. 
    A fee shall be charged for such inspection and permit as required under section 16-25 and the permit shall not be issued until the designated fee has been paid. Such fee may be revised by resolution of the city commission from time to time. The fee for any appeal taken to the board of appeals pursuant to this article shall be in such amount as may be prescribed by the city commission by resolution. 
(Code 1988, § 8.34; Ord. No. 342, § 1, 7-25-1989; Ord. No. 560, 6-18-2013) 
Sec. 16-27. - Violations; penalties. 
    A person who violates any provision of this article, or of the fire prevention code adopted in section 16-23 by reference, is responsible for a municipal civil infraction. In addition to the imposition of the penalties herein described, an appropriate action may be instituted to prevent unlawful construction or to restrain, correct or abate a violation; or to prevent illegal occupancy of a structure or premises; or to stop an illegal act, conduct of business or occupancy of a structure on or about any premises. 
(Code 1988, § 8.35; Ord. No. 413, § 1, 5-19-1998; Ord. No. 560, 6-18-2013) 
Chapter 17 - RESERVED 
Chapter 18 - GARAGE SALES 

Sec. 18-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Garage sale means such terms as "home sale," "basement sale," "attic sale," or any other type of so called residential sale of used tangible personal property such as, but not limited to, clothing, household effects, tools, garden implements, toys, recreation equipment or other used or secondhand items customarily found in and about the home and advertised in a manner whereby the public at large is, or can be, aware of such sale. All such sales must be conducted within a home, garage, or other sheltered place. No open yard sales are permitted. 
(Code 1988, § 7.131) 
Sec. 18-2. - Permit. 
    The homeowner or occupant shall first obtain a permit from the public safety department before advertising or conducting any garage sale. The fee for such a permit shall be such amount as may be prescribed by the city commission by resolution. The public safety department shall provide the applicant with three signs to be used to advertise the garage sale. No signs shall be used to advertise a garage sale other than the signs provided by the public safety department. 
(Code 1988, § 7.132; Ord. No. 340, § 1, 7-25-1989) 
Sec. 18-3. - Duration and frequency. 
    Each garage sale shall be limited to two consecutive days of operation and no more than two such sales may be conducted by any household or member thereof per calendar year. No sale shall be conducted before 9:00 a.m. or after 7:00 p.m. of any day. 
(Code 1988, § 7.133) 
Sec. 18-4. - Signs. 
    No more than three signs of four square feet in area shall be used to advertise a garage sale. The signs pertaining to the garage sale must be placed behind the sidewalk on private property and such signs shall be removed immediately after the garage sale. If signs are placed on private property other than on the property of the homeowner or occupant sponsoring the garage sale, permission must be obtained. No other signs pertaining to a garage sale shall be permitted on public or private property. 
(Code 1988, § 7.134) 
Sec. 18-5. - Nature of goods sold. 
    No person other than the homeowner or occupant shall conduct a garage sale, so called, and no merchandise of any nature shall be brought in from any commercial source to supplement such sale. However, this shall not prevent homeowners from conducting a joint garage sale. 
(Code 1988, § 7.135) 
Sec. 18-6. - Exempt sales. 
    This chapter shall not apply to a householder who, during the normal course of housekeeping, advertises or otherwise offers for sale individual pieces of furniture or an appliance of value which is being replaced or is no longer needed. 
(Code 1988, § 7.136) 
Chapter 19 - HUMAN RIGHTS 

Sec. 19-1. - Title. 
    This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the "Huntington Woods Human Rights Ordinance". 
(Ord. No. 541, § 1, 10-18-2011) 
Sec. 19-2. - Purpose. 
    In recognition of the inherent dignity and equal and inalienable rights of all members of the human family, it is the policy of the City of Huntington Woods in the exercise of its police power for the public safety, public health and general welfare, to assure equal opportunity to all persons in the area of employment, housing, public accommodations and public services. 
(Ord. No. 541, § 1, 10-18-2011) 
Sec. 19-3. - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter: 
    Age is defined as an individual's chronological age, except as otherwise provided by law. 
    Color is defined as an individual's skin pigmentation. 
    Discrimination or discriminate means without limitation, any act which, because of race, color, religion, sex, age, height or weight, marital status, sexual orientation, familial status, national origin, or physical or mental disability, results in the unequal treatment or separation of any person, or denies, prevents, limits or otherwise adversely affects the benefit or enjoyment of any person, of employment, ownership or occupancy of real property or public accommodations and public services. 
    Employment is defined as the act of hiring, recruiting, retaining and promoting of a person to perform the duties of a particular job or position. 
    Familial status is defined as one or more individuals under the age of 18 years residing with a parent or other person having custody or in the process of securing legal custody of the individual or individuals or residing with the designee of the parent or other person having or securing custody, with the written permission of the parent or other person. For purposes of this definition, "parent" includes a person who is pregnant. 
    Height or weight is defined as the physical characteristics of an individual as it relates to that individual's size and shall apply only to employment. 
    Housing is defined as the opportunity to purchase, lease, sell, hold, rent, use, and convey dwelling units. 
    Marital status is defined as the state of being single, married, separated, widowed, or divorced. 
    National origin is defined to include the national origin of an ancestor. 
    Person is defined as an individual, firm, partnership, corporation, association, organization, unincorporated organization, labor organization, trustee, receiver or other fiduciary. 
    Physical or mental disability is defined to mean one or more of the following: 
(1)  A determinable physical or mental characteristic of an individual, which may result from disease, injury, congenital condition of birth, or functional disorder, if the characteristic: 
a.  Where applicable, substantially limits one or more of the major life activities of that individual and is unrelated to the individual's ability to perform the duties of a particular job or position or substantially limits one or more of the major life activities of that individual and is unrelated to the individual's qualifications for employment or promotion; 
b.  Where applicable, is unrelated to the individual's ability to utilize and benefit from a place of public accommodations and public services; 
c.  Where applicable, is unrelated to the individual's ability to utilize and benefit from educational opportunities, programs, and facilities at an educational institution; 
d.  Where applicable, substantially limits one or more of that individual's major life activities and is unrelated to the individual's ability to acquire, rent, or maintain property. 
(2)  A history of a determinable physical or mental characteristic described in subparagraph (1)a. 
(3)  Being regarded as having a determinable physical or mental characteristic described in subparagraph (1)a. 
(4)  "Unrelated to the individual's ability" means, with or without accommodation, an individual's disability does not prevent the individual from doing one or more of the following: 
a.  Where applicable, performing the duties of a particular job or position; 
b.  Where applicable, utilizing and benefitting from a place of public accommodation or public services; 
c.  Where applicable, utilizing and benefitting from educational opportunities, programs, and facilities at an educational institution; and 
d.  Where applicable, acquiring, renting, or maintaining property. 
    Place of public accommodations is defined as any business or educational, cultural, governmental, health care, day care, entertainment, recreational, refreshment, transportation, financial institution or facility of any kind, whose goods, services, facilities, privileges, advantages, or accommodations are extended, offered, sold, or otherwise made available to the public. 
    Public services is defined as a public facility, department, or agency owned, operated, or managed by or on behalf of a city, village, township, county or school district, or any authority, agency, or combination thereof, or a tax exempt private agency established to provide services to the public. 
    Sexual orientation is defined as, real or perceived, male or female heterosexuality, bisexuality, homosexuality, or gender identity. 
(Ord. No. 541, § 1, 10-18-2011) 
Sec. 19-4. - Prohibition. 
    No person or persons shall discriminate against any person or persons within the City of Huntington Woods regarding employment, housing, public accommodations and public services on the basis of that person's race, color, religion, sex, age, height or weight, marital status, sexual orientation, familial status, national origin, or physical or mental disability. 
(Ord. No. 541, § 1, 10-18-2011) 
Sec. 19-5. - Exemptions. 
(a)  Private club exemption. The prohibition of section 19-4 shall not apply to a private club, or other establishment not in fact open to the public, except to the extent that the goods, services, facilities, privileges, advantages, or accommodations of the private club or establishment are made available to the customers or patrons of another establishment that is a place of public accommodation or is licensed by the state under Act No. 8 of the Public Acts of 1933, being MCL 436.1-436.58, the Michigan Liquor Control Act, as amended. 
(b)  Religious exemption. The prohibition of section 19-4 shall not apply to a religious educational institution or an educational institution operated, supervised, or controlled by a religious institution or organization which limits admission or gives preference to an applicant of the same religion. 
(c)  Private residence exemption. The prohibition of section 19-4 shall not apply to: 
(1)  The rental of housing accommodations in a building which contains housing accommodations for not more than two families living independently of each other if the owner or a member of the owner's immediate family resides in one of the housing accommodations, or to the rental of a room or rooms in a single-family dwelling by a person if the lessor or a member of the lessor's immediate family resides in the dwelling. 
(2)  The rental of housing accommodations for not more than 12 months by the owner or lessor where it was occupied by him/her and maintained as his/her home for at least three months immediately preceding occupancy by the tenant and is temporarily vacated while maintaining legal residence. 
(3)  With respect to the age provision only, the sale, rental or lease of housing accommodations meeting the requirements of federal, state or local housing programs for senior citizens, or accommodations otherwise intended, advertised, designated or operated, bona fide, for the purpose of providing housing accommodations for persons 50 years of age or older. 
(d)  Bona fide occupational qualification exemption. The prohibition of section 19-4, with respect to employment only, shall not apply where a protected classification set forth in section 19-4 is a bona fide occupational qualification reasonably necessary to the normal operation of a business or enterprise. A person shall have a burden of establishing that the qualification is reasonably necessary to the normal operation of that person's business or enterprise. 
(e)  Private educational institution exemption. The prohibition of section 19-4 relating to sex only shall not apply to an educational institution which now or hereafter provides an education to persons of one sex. 
(f)  Governmental exemption. The prohibition of section 19-4 shall not apply to any action by a governmental entity or agency where a person's qualification is expressly limited by statute, charter, ordinance, policy, or otherwise provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 541, § 1, 10-18-2011) 
Sec. 19-6. - Complaints. 
    All persons claiming to be aggrieved by a discriminatory act(s) may, by themselves or through legal counsel, file a verified complaint with public safety officers who are hereby authorized to process such complaints pursuant to the provisions of chapter 9 (Municipal Civil Infractions) of the City of Huntington Woods Ordinance Code, as it may be amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 541, § 1, 10-18-2011) 
Sec. 19-7. - Violations, fines and penalties. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be responsible for a municipal civil infraction, and upon a determination or admission of responsibility shall be subject to a civil fine of not more than $500.00, costs of prosecution and such other costs, damages, expenses, sanctions and remedies as authorized by law, including but not limited to, the Revised Judicature Act, and specifically MCL 600.8302, as amended. 
(Ord. No. 541, § 1, 10-18-2011) 
Sec. 19-8. - Limitation of action. 
    No complaint shall be accepted, nor action taken unless filed within one year from the date of the alleged discriminatory act(s). 
(Ord. No. 541, § 1, 10-18-2011) 
Chapter 20 - LAND DIVISIONS AND SUBDIVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Land Division Act, MCL 560.101 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 20-1-20-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SUBDIVISION CONTROL 

Sec. 20-19. - Definitions. 
    All terms defined in the Land Division Act, Public Act No. 288 of 1967 (MCL 560.101 et seq.), shall have the meanings therein provided when used in this chapter. 
(Code 1988, § 5.191) 
Sec. 20-20. - Planning commission report. 
    The city planning commission shall consider and report by resolution to the city commission upon any plat or proposed subdivision of land within the incorporated area before the plat shall be approved finally by the city commission. 
(Code 1988, § 5.192) 
Sec. 20-21. - Pre-application review meeting. 
    The proprietor may request that a pre-application review meeting take place by submitting a written request to the chairperson of the county plat board and submitting copies of a concept plan for the preliminary plat to the city and to each officer or agency entitled to review the preliminary plat under sections 113 to 118 of the Land Division Act (MCL 560.113-560.118). A pre-application review meeting shall take place not later than 30 days after the written request and concept plan are received. The meeting shall be attended by the proprietor, representatives of each officer or agency entitled to review the preliminary plat under sections 113, 114 and 118 of the Land Division Act (MCL 560.113, 560.114, 560.118), and a representative of the city. Representatives of each agency entitled to review the preliminary plat under sections 115 to 117 of the Land Division Act (MCL 560.115-560.117) shall be informed of the meeting and may attend. The purpose of the meeting is to conduct an informal review of the proprietor's concept plan for the preliminary plat. 
Sec. 20-22. - Preliminary plat. 
    Any person desiring to subdivide lands in the city, including resubdivision of existing platted lands, shall first submit to the planning commission four copies of preliminary sketches of the proposed subdivision plat. Such preliminary sketch shall be made to a scale of not more than 200 feet to the inch. Each such preliminary sketch shall show: 
(1)  An exact legal description of the land to be contained in the proposed subdivision. 
(2)  The location of existing property lines, streets, culverts, underground structures, buildings, water lines, sewers and other features within the area to be subdivided, and similar facts in property immediately adjacent to such proposed subdivision. 
(3)  The location, number and dimensions of all lots to be platted in the proposed subdivision. 
(4)  The location and width of proposed streets, alleys, building lines and private and public easements in the proposed subdivision. 
(5)  The name of the proposed subdivision, together with the names and addresses of all the proprietors of the proposed subdivision. 
(6)  The names, boundaries and lot division of each adjoining subdivision. 
(Code 1988, § 5.193) 
Sec. 20-23. - Additional preliminary data. 
    There shall be transmitted with every such preliminary sketch of every plat, the following data: 
(1)  An opinion from qualified legal counsel as to status of ownership of the land in the proposed subdivision. 
(2)  Copies of the proposed building and use restrictions to be imposed on the said proposed subdivision. 
(3)  Such other information as the planning commission may reasonably require, including but not limited to, a statement of the character of the development to be had in the proposed subdivision. 
(Code 1988, § 5.194) 
Sec. 20-24. - Planning commission recommendation. 
    Prior to making any recommendation, the planning commission shall conduct a public hearing on a proposed plat in accordance with the requirements of the Michigan Planning Enabling Act, MCL 125.3801 et seq., as amended. The planning commission shall consider the data and documents required in sections 20-22 and 20-23 as soon as may be feasible to allow for the public hearing, and shall promptly forward said recommendation on the preliminary plat to the city commission. The planning commission shall recommend approval, approval with conditions, or denial of the preliminary plat within 63 days after the plat is submitted to the planning commission, unless the proprietor waives this requirement or consents to an extension. 
(Code 1988, § 5.195; Ord. No. 571, § 1, 10-21-2014) 
Sec. 20-25. - Notice of approval. 
    The city commission shall, upon receipt of the recommendation of the planning commission, consider the same together with preliminary sketches and data accompanying the same, and shall, within 60 days after it was submitted to the clerk, if a preapplication review meeting was conducted, or within 90 days after it was submitted to the clerk, if a preapplication review meeting was not conducted, indicate that it will approve or reject the proposed plat. If the city commission indicates that it will approve such plat, the city clerk shall instruct the proprietors, or agents of the proprietors, of the said proposed subdivision, to submit to the city commission five copies of final plats of the proposed subdivision plat, drawn according to the findings of the city commission. Upon receipt by the city commission of said final plats, drawn in conformity to the conditions required by the city commission and the provisions of the Land Division Act, Public Act No. 288 of 1967 (MCL 560.101 et seq.), the plat shall be approved. If the city commission shall reject a proposed plat, corrections, amendments or modifications may be submitted for the city commission's consideration. 
(Code 1988, § 5.196) 
Sec. 20-26. - Fee. 
(a)  A fee of such amount as may be prescribed by the city commission by ordinance shall be payable to the city on the filing of all preliminary and final plats and all such plats shall be in conformity with all pertinent provisions of state law and this article. 
(b)  The fee as described in subsection (a) shall be $500.00 for a preliminary plat and $500.00 for a final plat. 
(Code 1988, § 5.197; Ord. No. 333, § 1, 7-25-1989) 
Sec. 20-27. - Security for improvements. 
    No plat of land on which streets and utilities herein required have not been installed, shall be finally approved until the proprietors shall execute a written agreement to construct streets, and install drains, water and sewer facilities, nor until security for performance of such agreement in the form authorized by section 182 of the Land Division Act (MCL 560.182) shall be filed with the city clerk, approved as to form by the city attorney and accepted by the city commission. Such security shall guarantee the performance of the agreement for construction of streets, water systems and sewer facilities in the proposed subdivision. The amount of such security shall be determined by the city commission on recommendation of the city manager. Except as otherwise provided in this article, the requirements for the construction of streets, drains, water lines and sewer facilities and the agreement for such construction, shall be governed by current city specifications applicable thereto. 
(Code 1988, § 5.198) 
Sec. 20-28. - Street specifications. 
    The minimum requirement for proper surfacing of streets shall be curb and gutter, with a minimum width of 26 feet between faces of said curbs, and bituminous street surfacing in accordance with the specifications of the director of public works. 
(Code 1988, § 5.199) 
Sec. 20-29. - Final plat; filing. 
    It shall be the duty of the city clerk to see that all plats are presented to, and filed, if accepted, with the proper authorities of the state and of the county. 
(Code 1988, § 5.200) 
Sec. 20-30. - Division of land in a subdivision. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words and phrases shall, for the purpose of this section, have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Adjoining lot means the lot or outlot adjoining a sublot. 
Divided lot means a lot or outlot in a recorded plat that is partitioned or divided. 
Lot means a lot or outlot in a recorded plat. 
Owner means a natural person, which may hold any ownership interest in land, whether recorded or not. 
Parcel means the land included within the description on the assessment roll of the city under a single tax parcel identification (Sidwell) number, and may include one or more lots, or parts of lots. 
Partitioning or dividing means the partitioning or dividing of a lot or parcel of land by the owner thereof for the purpose of sale, or lease of more than one year, or of building development. 
Recorded plat or subdivision means land which has been subdivided pursuant to Public Act No. 288 of 1967 (MCL 560.101 et seq.), or any predecessor statute. 
Sublot means one part of a divided lot. 
Sublots means two or more parts of a divided lot. 
Subparcel means one part of a divided parcel. 
Subparcels means two or more parts of a divided parcel. 
(b)  Prohibition against partitioning or dividing lots or parcels of land. It shall be unlawful for any person to divide or partition any lot or parcel of land in a recorded plat except as provided in this section. 
(c)  Approval of partitioning or dividing of lots or parcels that comply with City Code. The city manager, or the city manager's designee, shall review the partitioning or dividing of a lot or a parcel in a recorded plat. If the application is made pursuant to this subsection (c), the city manager shall grant or deny the same within 30 days of its filing if the applicant complies with the procedural requirements of this section, including the filing of a fully executed affidavit pursuant to subsection (e), and: 
(1)  In the case of a lot, each of the sublots is to be combined with and used in conjunction with an adjoining full lot, and the combined size of each such resulting parcel meets or exceeds the minimum lot size requirement of the city applicable to the zoning district in which it is located; 
(2)  In the case of a parcel consisting of more than one lot, each of the subparcels, after division, contains at least one full lot and equals or exceeds the minimum lot size requirements of the city applicable to the zoning district in which it is located; 
(3)  A sublot, whether governed by subsections (c)(1) or (2) of this section, shall be used in conjunction with an adjoining full lot and may not be developed or used separately, except as provided in subsection (c)(4) below; 
(4)  Any sublot that is not to be developed or used with the adjoining lot shall comply with the minimum requirements of the city zoning ordinances; and 
(5)  Each resultant parcel shall be in conformity with all pertinent ordinances of the city, shall have access to a public street or permanent access easement, shall be or can be served by necessary utilities, and shall not in any way adversely affect the integrity of the recorded plat. 
(6)  There are no due or unpaid taxes or special assessments upon the property. 
(d)  Approval of partitioning or dividing lots that do not comply with the City Code where there is a hardship or practical difficulty. 
(1)  An applicant for a partition or division under this subsection (d) shall submit written documentation to the city containing information to support a practical difficulty or unnecessary hardship related to the parcel. After receipt of the written documentation, the city will provide notice to all property owners within 300 feet of the parcel which is the subject of the application. Said notice shall be provided no later than 15 days prior to the meeting where the application will be heard. 
(2)  The members of the zoning board of appeals (sitting in the capacity as the administrative board under this article and not in their capacity acting under the zoning ordinance) may approve the partitioning or dividing of a lot in a recorded plat for the development of and use of a sublot with the adjoining lot or outlot if the use of the lot as platted would result in practical difficulty or undue hardship to the owner of such property. 
(3)  Permission to partition or divide under this section shall only be granted if the following criteria are met: 
a.  The applicant has established a practical difficulty or undue hardship which would support granting the petition; 
b.  The sublot that is to be developed or used with the adjoining lot may not thereafter be developed or used separately unless the parcels after partition or division meet or exceed the minimum lot size requirements of the city applicable to the zoning district in which they are located; 
c.  The relief granted shall in no instance be greater than necessary to relieve the practical difficulty or hardship; 
d.  The applicant complies with the procedural requirements of this section; 
e.  The sublot used in conjunction with the adjoining lot and the remaining sublot both have access to a public street or permanent access easement, are or can be served by necessary utilities, and do not in any way adversely affect the integrity of the recorded plat; and 
f.  There are no due or unpaid taxes or special assessments on the property. 
(e)  Procedure for partitioning or dividing lots in platted subdivisions. 
(1)  Any property owner desiring to partition or divide a lot in a platted subdivision shall file with the city clerk a fully executed affidavit in a form sufficient for recording with the county register of deeds and signed by all persons who have any legal or equitable interest in the lot, and, where a sublot is to be developed or used with an adjoining lot, signed by all persons who have any legal or equitable interest in such adjoining lot. The affidavit shall include the name, business address and telephone number of all such persons. In addition, the affidavit shall provide the following information: 
a.  The legal description of the lot to be partitioned or divided; 
b.  The legal description of the sublots; 
c.  The legal description of the adjoining lot or adjoining lots; 
d.  For each sublot that is to be used with an adjoining lot, the combined legal description of the sublot and adjoining lot; and 
e.  Whether any of the described lots have previously been the subject of an application for partitioning or dividing, the date and disposition of such application. 
(2)  Legal descriptions shall indicate the area involved to the nearest square foot. 
(3)  Affidavits shall be accompanied by a plan illustrating the information contained in the affidavit and meeting the following requirements: 
a.  The plan shall be at least 81/2 inches by 14 inches and of a scale not less than one inch equaling 20 feet; 
b.  The plan shall depict a north arrow; 
c.  The plan shall be dated, including the dates of any revisions; 
d.  The plan shall depict existing utilities and drainage courses within 50 feet of the lot to be partitioned or divided; 
e.  The plan shall depict all roadways, and existing easements for drainage, utilities and floodplain preservation; 
f.  The plan shall depict the location of all property irons and monuments found or to be placed on the lots; 
g.  The plan shall depict existing buildings and all front, rear and side yard setbacks of each of the resulting lots; 
h.  The plan shall depict the zoning classification of the involved lots; and 
i.  The plan shall be signed and sealed by a registered land surveyor. 
(4)  At the time the affidavit and accompanying documents are filed with the city clerk, the applicant shall pay the city clerk a fee in an amount as may be prescribed by the administrative board by ordinance or resolution. 
(5)  If the application is made pursuant to subsection (d) of this section, it shall be returned to the city clerk with the recommendation of the city manager or the city manager's designee, for placement on the city administrative board's agenda. The administrative board shall grant or deny the application within 60 days of its filing. The approval of an application shall be indicated on the endorsed affidavit, which the city clerk shall promptly file with the county register of deeds. 
(Code 1988, § 5.201; Ord. No. 303, § 1, 9-16-1986; Ord. No. 333, § 2, 7-25-1989; Ord. No. 474, § 1, 2-12-2003; Ord. No. 586, § 1, 8-16-2016) 
Sec. 20-31. - Penalties. 
    Any person who shall violate any provision of this article shall be responsible for a municipal civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 5.201; Ord. No. 303, § 1, 9-16-1986; Ord. No. 333, § 2, 7-25-1989; Ord. No. 474, § 1, 2-12-2003) 
Chapter 21 - RESERVED 
Chapter 22 - LIBRARY AND CULTURAL CENTER[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- District library establishment act, MCL 397.171 et seq. 

Sec. 22-1. - Established. 
    The city shall maintain the Public Library and Cultural Center established in said city as a free public library and cultural center and for such purpose the commission shall include in the annual budget such sum as may be deemed necessary for the purpose of maintaining said library and cultural center. 
(Code 1988, § 1.151) 
Sec. 22-2. - Library board. 
(a)  There shall be an advisory library board that shall consist of seven members who shall be citizens of the United States. 
(b)  Five members of the advisory library board shall be residents of the city and shall be appointed by the mayor of the city with the approval of the city commission. The present members of the library board shall serve as members until their respective terms expire. Prior to January 1 in each year, one member or two members, as the case may be, of the library board who are residents of the city shall be appointed for a term of three years. 
(c)  Two members of the advisory library board shall be residents of the City of Pleasant Ridge and shall be appointed to the advisory library board for terms beginning January 1, 1997, in such a manner as may be determined appropriate by the mayor and city commission of the City of Pleasant Ridge. One of these two members shall be appointed to a three years term and the other shall be appointed to a two year term, and successors to each such member shall be appointed upon the expiration of their respective terms of office, such successors to serve full three year terms if the library services agreement between the City of Huntington Woods and the City of Pleasant Ridge is extended; provided that no such term shall extend beyond the termination date of such agreement. 
(d)  Upon termination of the library services agreement between the City of Huntington Woods and the City of Pleasant Ridge, the terms of the two members who are residents of the City of Pleasant Ridge shall end and the advisory library board shall return to a five-member board, all members of which shall be residents of the city. 
(e)  Within ten days after appointment to the library board and before entering upon their duties as members of the library board, each appointee shall file written acceptance with the city clerk and subscribe and file with the clerk an oath to support the Constitution of the United States, the Constitution of the state and to faithfully perform the duties of the office of library board member to the best of the board member's ability. All library board members shall serve without compensation as such. Each member of the present library board, and each member hereafter appointed, shall serve until the member's successor is appointed and qualifies. 
(Code 1988, § 1.152; Ord. No. 310, § 1, 2-16-1988; Ord. No. 391, § 1, 12-17-1996) 
Sec. 22-3. - Board organization. 
    The library board shall organize by electing annually at its first regular meeting a chairman, vice-chairman, secretary, and such other officers as may be necessary for the proper conduct of the duties of the board. The secretary shall notify the commission of the names of all such officers promptly after their appointment. Four members of the board shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. 
(Code 1988, § 1.153; Ord. No. 391, § 2, 12-17-1996) 
Sec. 22-4. - Power and duties. 
    It shall be the duty of the library board to study and observe the manner in which the library is managed and maintained by the city, and for that reason it may make or adopt such recommendations to the city manager or the city commission as may be expedient and not inconsistent with this chapter, the Charter of the city and the general laws of the state. It shall make recommendations concerning library hours, custody and purchase of the books, magazines, furniture, fixtures and equipment in said library and cultural center. The library board may accept donations, contributions and gifts, either general or for specific purposes, on behalf of the city. All monies, including fines, received by the library board shall be deposited with the city treasurer and except as otherwise provided by law or ordinance, credited to the general fund. 
(Code 1988, § 1.154) 
Sec. 22-5. - Records. 
    The library board shall keep a complete record of its proceedings. 
(Code 1988, § 1.155) 
State Law reference- Freedom of information act, MCL 15.231 et seq. 
Sec. 22-6. - Provisions for use. 
    The library and cultural center shall be maintained for the use and benefit of the residents and freeholders of the city. All residents shall have free use of said library and cultural center, subject only to such reasonable rules, regulations and fees as may be adopted by the city commission. Nonresidents may be granted permission to use the library under such conditions and upon payment of such fees as may be prescribed by the city commission. Residents of the City of Pleasant Ridge shall be entitled to receive library services in accordance with the library services agreement between the City of Huntington Woods and the City of Pleasant Ridge, effective January 1, 1997. 
(Code 1988, § 1.156; Ord. No. 391, § 3, 12-17-1996) 
Chapter 23 - RESERVED 
Chapter 24 - OFFENSES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Michigan Penal Code, MCL 750.1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 24-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Public place means any street, alley, park, public building, any place of business or assembly open to or frequented by the public, and any other place which is open to the public view, or to which the public has access. 
(Code 1988, § 9.61) 
Sec. 24-2. - Attempt to commit offenses. 
    Any person who shall attempt to commit an offense prohibited under this chapter, and in such attempt shall do any act towards the commission of such offense, but shall fail in the perpetration, or shall be intercepted or prevented in the execution of the same, shall be in violation of this Code. 
(Code 1988, § 9.205) 
State Law reference- Attempt to commit crime, MCL 750.92. 
Sec. 24-3. - Inducement of illegal acts. 
    No person shall solicit or accost any person for the purpose of inducing the commission of any illegal act. 
(Code 1988, § 9.62(19)) 
State Law reference- Soliciting or accosting, MCL 750.448. 
Secs. 24-4-24-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OFFENSES AFFECTING GOVERNMENTAL FUNCTIONS 

Sec. 24-21. - Obstruction of justice. 
    No person shall obstruct, resist, hinder, or oppose any member of the police force or any peace officer in the discharge of the police force or the officer's duties as such. 
(Code 1988, § 9.62(24)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 750.479. 
Sec. 24-22. - False alarm. 
    No person shall summon, as a joke or prank or otherwise without any good reason therefor, by telephone or otherwise, the police or fire department or any public or private ambulance to go to any address where the service called for is not needed. 
(Code 1988, § 9.62(33)) 
State Law reference- False fire alarms, MCL 750.240; false report of crime, MCL 750.411a. 
Secs. 24-23-24-45. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OFFENSES AGAINST THE PERSON 

Sec. 24-46. - Assault and battery. 
    No person shall commit an assault, or an assault and battery on any person. 
(Code 1988, § 9.62(1)) 
State Law reference- Assaults, MCL 750.81 et seq. 
Sec. 24-47. - Window peeping. 
    No person shall be found looking into the windows or doors of any house, apartment or other residence in the city in such a manner as would be likely to interfere with the occupant's reasonable expectation of privacy and without the occupant's express or implied consent. 
(Code 1988, § 9.62(7)) 
State Law reference- Such person deemed a disorderly person, MCL 750.167(1)(c). 
Sec. 24-48. - Harassment. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, with the intent to harass, annoy or alarm another person, to: 
(1)  Follow a person in or about a public place; or 
(2)  Engage in a course of conduct or repeatedly commit acts that alarm or seriously annoy another person and that serve no legitimate purpose. 
(Code 1988, § 9.62(10), (11), (30)) 
Sec. 24-49. - Malicious use of service provided by telecommunications service provider. 
    A person is guilty of a misdemeanor who maliciously uses any service provided by a telecommunications service provider with the intent to terrorize, frighten, intimidate, threaten, harass, molest or annoy another person, or to disturb the peace and quiet of another person by any of the following: 
(1)  Threatening physical harm or damage to any person or property in the course of a conversation or message through the use of a telecommunications service or device. 
(2)  Falsely and deliberately reporting by message through the use of a telecommunications service or device that a person has been injured, has suddenly taken ill, has suffered death or has been the victim of a crime or an accident. 
(3)  Deliberately refusing or failing to disengage a connection between a telecommunications device and another telecommunications device or between a telecommunications device and other equipment provided for the transmission of messages through the use of a telecommunications service or device. 
(4)  Using vulgar, indecent, obscene or offensive language or suggesting any lewd or lascivious act in the course of a conversation or message through the use of a telecommunications service or device. 
(5)  Repeatedly initiating a telephone call and, without speaking, deliberately hanging up or breaking the telephone connection as or after the telephone call is answered. 
(6)  Making an unsolicited commercial telephone call that is received between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 9:00 a.m. For the purpose of this subsection, the term "an unsolicited commercial telephone call" means a call made by a person or recording device on behalf of a person soliciting business or contributions. 
(7)  Deliberately engaging or causing to engage the use of a telecommunications service or device of another person in a repetitive manner that causes interruption in telecommunications service or prevents the person from utilizing the provider's telecommunications service or device. 
(Code 1988, § 9.62(34)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 750.540e. 
Secs. 24-50-24-77. - Reserved.

    No person shall prowl about any alley or the private premises of any person in the nighttime, without authority or the permission of the owner of such premises. 
(Code 1988, § 9.62(25)) 
Sec. 24-99. - Trespass after entry prohibited. 
    Any person who shall willfully enter upon the lands or premises of another without lawful authority, after having been forbidden to do so by the owner or occupant, agent or servant of the owner or occupant, or any person being upon the land or premises of another, upon being notified to depart therefrom by the owner or occupant, the agent or servant of either, who without lawful authority neglects or refuses to depart therefrom, shall be guilty of a violation of this Code. 
(Code 1988, § 9.91) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 750.552.

State Law reference- Malicious mischief generally, MCL 750.377a et seq. 

Sec. 24-127. - Spitting. 
    No person shall spit on any street or sidewalk, or in any public carrier upon the floor, seat, or walls thereof, or upon the floor, walls, stairs, or seats of any public building or place of public assemblage. 
(Code 1988, § 9.62(26)) 
Sec. 24-128. - Defacing public property. 
    No person shall willfully destroy, remove, damage, alter or in any manner deface any property not owned by such person, or any public school building, or any public building, bridge, fire hydrant, alarm box, streetlight, street sign, traffic control device, railroad sign or signal, parking meter, or shade tree belonging to the city or located in the public places of the city, or mark or post handbills on, or in any manner mar the walls of, any public building, or fence, tree, or pole within the city, or damage, destroy, take, or meddle with any property belonging to the city, or remove the same from the building or place where it may be kept, placed, or stored, without proper authority. 
(Code 1988, § 9.62(27)) 
Sec. 24-129. - Injuring trees; shrubs. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to cut down or carry off any wood, underbrush, trees or timber, or to girdle or otherwise despoil or injure any trees, shrubs, or bushes on any land or private property within the city limits without first having obtained the leave, license or consent of the owner thereof. 
(Code 1988, § 9.93)

DIVISION 4. - THEFT[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Larceny generally, MCL 750.356 et seq. 

Sec. 24-157. - Larceny. 
    Any person who shall commit the offense of larceny, by stealing of the property of another, any money, goods or chattels, or any bank note, bank bill, bond, promissory note, due bill, bill of exchange or other bill, draft, order or certificate, or any book of accounts for or concerning money or goods due or to become due, or to be delivered, or any deed or writing containing a conveyance of land, or any other valuable contract in force, or any receipt, release or defeasance, or any writ, process or public record is in violation of this Code. 
(Code 1988, § 9.63; Ord. No. 428, § 1, 3-23-1999) 
State Law reference- Larceny generally, MCL 750.356 et seq. 
Sec. 24-158. - Receiving and concealing or possessing stolen property. 
    Any person who shall commit the offense of buying, receiving, possessing, concealing or aiding in the concealment of stolen, embezzled, or converted money, goods or property knowing the money, goods or property to be stolen, embezzled, or converted is in violation of this Code. 
(Code 1988, § 9.202) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 750.535. 
Sec. 24-159. - Drawing or delivering a check without sufficient funds. 
(a)  A person shall not make, draw, utter, or deliver any check, draft, or order for the payment of money, to apply on account or otherwise, upon any bank or other depository with intent to defraud and knowing at the time of the making, drawing, uttering, or delivering that the maker or drawer does not have sufficient funds in or credit with the bank or other depository to pay the check, draft, or order, in full, upon its presentation. 
(b)  A person shall not make, draw, utter, or deliver any check, draft, or order for the payment of money, to apply on account or otherwise, upon any bank or other depository with intent to defraud if the person does not have sufficient funds for the payment of the check, draft, or order when presentation for payment is made to the drawee. This subsection does not apply if the lack of funds is due to garnishment, attachment, levy, or other lawful cause and that fact was not known to the person who made, drew, uttered, or delivered the check, draft, or order. 
(Code 1988, § 9.203; Ord. No. 400, § 1, 8-19-1997; Ord. No. 428, § 3, 3-23-1999) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 750.131. 
Sec. 24-160. - Falsely representing or impersonating another. 
    Any person who shall falsely represent or impersonate another, in such assumed character, and receive any money, or other property, which was intended to be delivered to the party so impersonated, with the intent to convert the same to the person's own use, shall be deemed by so doing, to be guilty of a violation of this Code. 
(Code 1988, § 9.204) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 750.363. 
Sec. 24-161. - Retail fraud. 
    A person who does any of the following in a store or in its immediate vicinity shall be in violation of this Code: 
(1)  While a store is open to the public, alters, transfers, removes and replaces, conceals, or otherwise misrepresents the price at which property is offered for sale, with the intent not to pay for the property or to pay less than the price at which the property is offered for sale. 
(2)  While a store is open to the public, steals property of the store that is offered for sale. 
(3)  With intent to defraud, obtains or attempts to obtain money or property from the store as a refund or exchange for property that was not paid for and belongs to the store. 
(Code 1988, § 9.206; Ord. No. 354, § 1, 6-19-1990; Ord. No. 428, § 4, 3-23-1999) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 750.356d(4). 
Sec. 24-162. - Theft of soil; vegetation. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to dig up, excavate, or carry away any stone, ore, gravel, clay, sand, turf or mould, or any roots, fruits, plants, vegetation or flowers from any lands or property within the city, without having first obtained the leave, license or consent of the owner thereof. 
(Code 1988, § 9.92) 
State Law reference- Entering improved land of another, MCL 750.547. 
Sec. 24-163. - Failure to return books. 
    Whoever willfully or negligently detains or fails to return to the city public library any book, magazine, pamphlet, map, manuscript, picture, microfilm, phonograph record, clipping or other property belonging to such library, or pay the reasonable value thereof, within 30 days from the date of the posting by registered or certified mail of a notice addressed to such person at the last address furnished the public library, and which notice may be given at any time after the date on which such person, under the rules of the library, should have returned the loaned property, shall be in violation of this Code. 
(Code 1988, § 9.65) 
State Law reference- Larceny from libraries, MCL 750.364. 
Sec. 24-164. - Deceptive practices. 
    Whoever shall give a fictitious or incorrect name or address at the city public library in order to obtain possession or use of any book, magazine, pamphlet, map, manuscript, picture, microfilm, phonograph record, or clipping, the property of such library, or shall practice any deceit of any kind whatsoever to conceal or mislead in respect to identity or address or place of employment, of such person, shall be in violation of this Code. 
(Code 1988, § 9.66) 
Sec. 24-165. - False pretenses with intent to defraud. 
    Any person who, with intent to defraud or cheat and by color of a false token or writing, by a false or bogus check or other written, printed or engraved instrument, by counterfeit coin or metal that is intended to simulate a coin, or by any other false pretense, causes any person to grant, convey, assign, demise, lease or mortgage land or an interest in land, or obtains a person's signature on a forged written instrument, or obtains from a person any money or personal property or the use of any instrument, facility, article, or other valuable thing or service, or by means of a false weight or measure obtains a larger amount or quantity of property than was bargained for, or by means of a false weight or measure sells or disposes of a smaller amount or quantity of property than was bargained for, if such land or interest in land, money, personal property, use of the instrument, facility, article, or valuable thing, service, larger amount obtained, or smaller amount sold or disposed of, has a value of $200.00 or less, shall be in violation of this Code. 
(Code 1988, § 9.71; Ord. No. 428, § 2, 3-23-1999) 
State Law reference- False pretenses and misrepresentation, MCL 750.217a et seq. 
Secs. 24-166-24-183. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC PEACE 

Sec. 24-184. - Loitering. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Loitering on private property means the concepts of spending time idly, loafing or walking aimlessly, and shall also include knowingly or willingly entering upon the property of another, without the consent of the owner, lessee or other person rightfully in charge or possession thereof, if either of the following conditions exist: 
(1)  The premises is fenced or enclosed in a manner to exclude intruders; or 
(2)  Notice against trespass is given by posting on the premises in a conspicuous manner. 
(b)  Certain types prohibited. 
(1)  No person shall loiter in a public place in such manner as to: 
a.  Create, or cause to be created, any disturbance or annoyance to the comfort and repose of any person; 
b.  Create, or cause to be created, a danger of breach of the peace; 
c.  Obstruct the free passage of pedestrians or vehicles; 
d.  Obstruct, molest or interfere with any person lawfully in any public place. 
(2)  This subsection (b)(2) shall include the making of any unsolicited remarks of an offensive, disgusting or insulting nature or which are calculated to annoy or disturb the person to or in whose hearing such remarks are made. 
(c)  Request to leave. Whenever the presence of any person in any public place is causing any of the conditions enumerated in subsection (b) of this section, the owner, lessee or person rightfully in charge or possession thereof or any police officer may order that person to leave that place. Any person who shall refuse to leave after being ordered to do so shall be guilty of a violation of this section. 
(Code 1988, § 9.62(15)) 
Sec. 24-185. - Under the influence. 
    No person shall be under the influence of narcotics or any other drug or be intoxicated in a public place and either endanger directly the safety of another person or property or act in a manner that causes a public disturbance. 
(Code 1988, § 9.62(2)) 
State Law reference- Disorderly intoxication, MCL 750.167(1)(e). 
Sec. 24-186. - Publicly impaired. 
    No person shall be present in any public place with such person's ability to walk, talk, or see significantly impaired by the use of any controlled substance; provided, however, that this section shall not be construed to apply to a person whose faculties have been impaired by medication prescribed by a physician and taken as directed. 
(Code 1988, § 9.62(3)) 
Sec. 24-187. - Language or gestures causing public disorder. 
    A person shall be in violation of this Code if, with the purpose of causing public danger, alarm, disorder or nuisance, or if the conduct of such person is likely to cause public danger, alarm, disorder or nuisance, such person willfully uses abusive or obscene language or makes an obscene gesture to any other person when such words, by their very utterance, inflict injury or tend to incite an immediate breach of the peace and invade the right of others to pursue their lawful activities. 
(Code 1988, § 9.62(7)) 
Sec. 24-188. - Public affray. 
    No person shall engage in any disturbance, fight, or quarrel in a public place. 
(Code 1988, § 9.62(12)) 
Sec. 24-189. - Illegal gathering. 
    No person shall collect or stand in crowds, or arrange, encourage or abet the collection of persons in crowds for illegal or mischievous purposes in any public place. 
(Code 1988, § 9.62(13)) 
State Law reference- Riots and unlawful assemblies, MCL 752.541 et seq. 
Sec. 24-190. - Public gathering. 
    No person shall jostle or roughly crowd persons in any street, alley, park, public building, or any place open to or frequented by the public. 
(Code 1988, § 9.62(14)) 
State Law reference- Such persons deemed disorderly persons, MCL 750.167(1)(l). 
Sec. 24-191. - Disturbing the public. 
    No person shall disturb the public peace and quiet by loud, boisterous, or vulgar conduct. 
(Code 1988, § 9.62(22)) 
State Law reference- Disturbing public places, MCL 750.170. 
Sec. 24-192. - Disorderly conduct. 
    No person shall permit or suffer any place occupied or controlled by that person to be a resort of noisy, boisterous, or disorderly persons. 
(Code 1988, § 9.62(23)) 
State Law reference- Disturbing public places, MCL 750.170. 
Sec. 24-193. - Disturbing the peace. 
    No person shall willfully make or assist in making any noise, disturbance, trouble or improper diversion, or any rout or riot, by which the peace and good order are disturbed. 
(Code 1988, § 9.62(31)) 
State Law reference- Disturbing public places, MCL 750.170. 
Secs. 24-194-24-224. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC MORALS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 24-225. - Indecent exposure. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly make any indecent exposure of self person or of the person of another. 
(Code 1988, § 9.62(9)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 750.335a. 
Sec. 24-226. - Obscenity. 
    No person shall engage in any indecent or obscene conduct in any public place. 
(Code 1988, § 9.62(4)) 
State Law reference- Such person deemed a disorderly person, MCL 750.167(1)(f). 
Sec. 24-227. - Prostitution. 
    No person shall engage in any act of prostitution. 
(Code 1988, § 9.62(17)) 
State Law reference- Prostitution generally, MCL 750.448 et seq. 
Sec. 24-228. - Illegal business. 
    No person shall knowingly attend, frequent, operate or be an occupant or inmate of any place where prostitution, illegal gambling, the illegal sale of intoxicating liquor, or where any other illegal business or occupation is permitted or conducted. 
(Code 1988, § 9.62(18)) 
Sec. 24-229. - Promote prostitution. 
    No person shall knowingly transport any person to a place where prostitution is practiced, encouraged, or allowed for the purpose of enabling such person to engage in any illegal act. 
(Code 1988, § 9.62(20)) 
Sec. 24-230. - Illegal gaming. 
    No person shall keep or maintain a gaming room, gaming tables, or any policy or pool tickets, used for gaming, or knowingly suffer a gaming room, gaming tables, or any policy or pool tickets to be kept, maintained, played or sold on any premises occupied or controlled by such person, except where such activity is authorized by state law. 
(Code 1988, § 9.62(21)) 
Secs. 24-231-24-260. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CONTROLLED SUBSTANCES[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Controlled substances, MCL 333.7101 et seq. 

Sec. 24-261. - Offenses. 
    It is unlawful for any person to use, or knowingly or intentionally possess, sell, transfer or transport, any controlled substance as defined in Schedules 1 through 5 of the Michigan Public Health Code, Public Act No. 368 of 1978 (MCL 333.7201 et seq., as amended), unless: 
(1)  The controlled substance was obtained directly from, or pursuant to, a valid prescription or order of a practitioner (practitioner being defined in MCL 333.7109(a) and (b)), while acting in the course of such practitioner's professional practice; or 
(2)  The use, possession, sale, transfer or transportation is pursuant to, and in conformance with, the Michigan Medical Marihuana Act, PA 2008, Initiated Law, (MCL 333.26421 et seq., as amended); or 
(3)  The use, possession or transfer is less than one ounce of marihuana, on private property not used by the public, or transportation of one ounce or less of marihuana, by a person who has obtained the age of 21 years, in accordance with the City Charter. 
(Code 1988, § 9.121; Ord. No. 572, § 1, 11-18-2014) 
Sec. 24-262. - First offenders. 
    When any person who has not previously been convicted as set forth in this division, or under any statute of the United States, or state law, or municipal ordinance relating to possession or use of the substances as defined above, pleads guilty to or is found guilty of violating this division, the court, without entering a judgment of guilt and with the consent of the accused person, may defer further proceedings and place the accused person on probation upon certain terms and conditions, including therein such requirement that the accused person attend courses of instruction on rehabilitation on the medical, psychological and social effects of the misuse of drugs and/or the substances defined above. Upon violation of terms or conditions, the court may enter an adjudication of guilt and proceed as the court determines. Upon fulfillment of the terms and conditions, the court shall discharge the person and dismiss the proceeding against such person. Discharge and dismissal under this section shall be without adjudication of guilt and is not a conviction for the purposes of disqualifications or disabilities imposed by law upon the conviction of a crime. There may be only one discharge and dismissal under this section with respect to any person. The police department shall retain a nonpublic record of an arrest and discharge or dismissal under this section. This record shall be furnished to any court or police agency upon request for the purpose of showing that a defendant in a criminal action involving possession or use of the substances, as defined in this division, has already once availed self of the provisions of this section. 
(Code 1988, § 9.122) 
Sec. 24-263. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Controlled substance means a drug, substance or immediate precursor included in schedules 1 to 5 of Public Act No. 368 of 1978 (MCL 333.7201 et seq.). 
    Drug paraphernalia means any equipment, product, material, or combination of equipment, products, or materials, which is specifically designed for use in planting; propagating; cultivating; growing; harvesting; manufacturing; compounding; converting; producing; processing; preparing; testing; analyzing; packaging; repackaging; storing; containing; concealing; injecting, ingesting, inhaling, or otherwise introducing into the human body a controlled substance; including, but not limited to, all of the following: 
(1)  An isomerization device specifically designed for use in increasing the potency of any species of plant which plant is a controlled substance. 
(2)  Testing equipment specifically designed for use in identifying or in analyzing the strength, effectiveness, or purity of a controlled substance. 
(3)  A weight scale or balance specifically designed for use in weighing or measuring a controlled substance. 
(4)  A diluent or adulterant, including, but not limited to, quinine hydrochloride, mannitol, mannite, dextrose, and lactose, specifically designed for use with a controlled substance. 
(5)  A separation gin or sifter specifically designed for use in removing twigs and seeds from, or in otherwise cleaning or refining, marijuana. 
(6)  An object specifically designed for use in ingesting, inhaling, or otherwise introducing marijuana, cocaine, hashish, or hashish oil into the human body. 
(7)  A kit specifically designed for use in planting, propagating, cultivating, growing, or harvesting any species of plant which is a controlled substance or from which a controlled substance can be derived. 
(8)  A kit specifically designed for use in manufacturing, compounding, converting, producing, processing, or preparing controlled substances. 
(9)  A device, commonly known as a cocaine kit, that is specifically designed for use in ingesting, inhaling, or otherwise introducing controlled substances into the human body, and which consists of at least a razor blade and a mirror. 
(10)  A device, commonly known as a bullet, that is specifically designed to deliver a measured amount of controlled substances to the user. 
(11)  A device, commonly known as a snorter, that is specifically designed to carry a small amount of controlled substances to the user's nose. 
(12)  A device, commonly known as an automotive safe, that is specifically designed to carry and conceal a controlled substance in an automobile, including, but not limited to, a can used for brake fluid, oil, or carburetor cleaner which contains a compartment for carrying and concealing controlled substances. 
(13)  A spoon, with or without a chain attached, that has a small diameter bowl and that is specifically designed for use in ingesting, inhaling, or otherwise introducing controlled substances into the human body. 
(Code 1988, § 9.123) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 333.7451. 
Sec. 24-264. - Hypodermic syringes, needles, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to have, possess, sell, offer to sell, dispense or give away any hypodermic syringe, needle or any other instrument or implement for the illegal use of narcotic or dangerous or hallucinatory drugs as defined by Public Act No. 368 of 1978 (MCL 333.7201 et seq.), by subcutaneous injection or intracutaneous injection or any other manner or method of introduction and which is possessed, sold, offered, dispensed or given away for that purpose. 
(Code 1988, § 9.124) 
Sec. 24-265. - Loitering about places where drugs, etc., are illegally stored, kept or used. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, knowing that the substances, devices and/or other instruments enumerated and prescribed within this division are being illegally sold, dispensed, furnished, given away, stored, kept or used, to loiter about, frequent or be present in such building, apartment, automobile, boat or place of any description wherein such illegal activity is being carried on, conducted or operated, or wherein such illegal substances, devices and/or instruments prescribed herein are being illegally kept or stored. 
(Code 1988, § 9.125) 
Sec. 24-266. - Drug paraphernalia. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to have, possess, sell, offer to sell, dispense or give away any pipe, device or contrivance adapted for the use of smoking or inhaling marijuana (Cannabis Sativa L.), hashish or opium; provided, however, that such pipe, device or contrivance has been used for the purpose of smoking or inhaling marijuana, hashish or opium. 
Secs. 24-267-24-302. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - ALCOHOLIC LIQUORS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Michigan Liquor Control Code of 1998, MCL 436.1101 et seq. 

Sec. 24-303. - Possession or consumption of alcoholic liquors in public places. 
    For the purposes of this section, the term "alcoholic liquor" shall be defined as in section 2 of the Michigan Liquor Control Act, and shall include any beverage containing more than one-half of one percent of alcohol by volume, including beer, wine and spirits. 
(1)  No person shall consume any alcoholic liquor while in or upon public streets, alleys, sidewalks, parking lots, or other public ways. 
(2)  No person shall be in possession of any glass, can or other open container containing alcoholic liquor on any thoroughfare, street, sidewalk, alley, parking lot or any other public way. 
(3)  No person licensed to sell alcoholic liquor, or its employees or agents, shall permit any person to remove from such premises, any alcoholic liquor in any open container. 
(4)  No person shall possess alcoholic liquor upon or within any off-street parking lot or parking garage, except in its original unopened container with the seal unbroken. 
(Code 1988, § 9.144) 
State Law reference- Possessing or consuming alcoholic liquor on streets, parks, places of amusement or publicly owned areas, MCL 436.1915. 
Sec. 24-304. - Display of spirits. 
(a)  Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, no person shall display spirits in an area that is open to the public. All such displays shall be behind a counter or similar fixture. 
(b)  A temporary bin display, as specifically authorized by state liquor control commission regulations, and which has a capacity of up to 15 cases of 24, 12-ounce or 0.375-liter containers or the equivalent in other sizes of wine or spirits, may be installed on the premises of a retail licensee who is licensed for off-premises sales only. 
(c)  The term "spirits," as used in this section, means a beverage that contains alcohol obtained by distillation, mixed with potable water or other substances, or both, in solution, and includes wine containing an alcoholic content of more than 21 percent by volume, except sacramental wine and mixed spirit drink. 
(Code 1988, § 9.145; Ord. No. 451, § 1, 2-20-2001) 
Secs. 24-305-24-326. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC SAFETY 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 24-327. - Icebox or refrigerator; abandoned without removing snaplock or locking device, penalty. 
    Any person who knowingly leaves, in a place accessible to children, any abandoned, unattended or discarded icebox, refrigerator or other container of a kind and size sufficient to permit the entrapment and suffocation of a child therein, without first removing the snaplock or other locking device from the lid or cover thereof, is guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1988, § 9.15) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 750.493d. 
Sec. 24-328. - Firearms. 
    No person shall discharge any firearm, air rifle, air pistol or bow and arrow in the city, except when lawfully acting in the defense of persons or property or the enforcement of law or at a duly established range, the operation of which has been approved by the city commission. 
(Code 1988, § 9.62(5)) 
State Law reference- Discharge of weapons, MCL 750.234 et seq. 
Sec. 24-329. - Fireworks. 
(a)  Definitions. As used in this section, the following words and phrases have the meanings set forth herein: 
Act means the Michigan Fireworks Safety Act, Public Act No. 256 of 2011, MCL 28.451 et seq., as amended. 
Alcoholic liquor means that term as defined in Section 1d of the Michigan Vehicle Code, 1949 PA 300, MCL 257.1d. 
Articles pyrotechnic means pyrotechnic devices for professional use that are similar to consumer fireworks in chemical composition and construction but not intended for consumer use, that meet the weight limits for consumer fireworks but are not labeled as such, and that are classified as UN0431 or UN0432 under 49 CFR 172.101. 
Consumer fireworks means fireworks devices that are designed to produce visible effects by combustion, that are required to comply with the construction, chemical composition, and labeling regulations promulgated by the United States Consumer Product Safety Commission under 16 CFR parts 1500 and 1507, and that are listed in APA standards 87-1, 3.1.2, 3.1.3, or 3.5. Consumer fireworks does not include low-impact fireworks. 
Controlled substance means that term as defined in Section 8b of the Michigan Vehicle Code, 1949 PA 300, MCL 257.8b. 
Display fireworks means large fireworks devices that are explosive materials intended for use in fireworks displays and designed to produce visible or audible effects by combustion, deflagration, or detonation, as provided in 27 CFR 555.11, 49 CFR 172, and APA standards 87-1, 4.1. 
Firework or fireworks means any composition or device, except for a starting pistol, a flare gun, or a flare, designed for the purpose of producing a visible or audible effect by combustion, deflagration, or detonation. Fireworks consist of consumer fireworks low-impact fireworks, articles pyrotechnic, display fireworks, and special effects. 
Low-impact fireworks means ground and handheld sparkling devices as that phrase is defined under APA standards 87-1, 3.1, 3.1.1.1 to 3.1.1.8, and 3.5. 
Minor means an individual under 18 years of age. 
National holiday means New Year's Day (January 1); Birthday of Martin Luther King, Jr. (third Monday in January); Washington's Birthday (third Monday in February); Memorial Day (last Monday in May); Independence Day (July 4); Labor Day (first Monday in September); Columbus Day (second Monday in October); Veterans Day (November 11); Thanksgiving Day (fourth Thursday in November); and Christmas Day (December 25). 
Novelties means that term as defined under APA standards 87-1, 3.2, 3.2.1, 3.2.2, 3.2.3, 3.2.4, and 3.2.5 and all of the following: 
(1)  Toy plastic or paper caps for toy pistols in sheets, strips, rolls, or individual caps containing not more than .25 of a grain of explosive content per cap, in packages labeled to indicate the maximum explosive content per cap. 
(2)  Toy pistols, toy cannons, toy canes, toy trick noisemakers, and toy guns in which toy caps as described in paragraph (1) are used, that are constructed so that the hand cannot come in contact with the cap when in place for the explosion, and that are not designed to break apart or be separated so as to form a missile by the explosion. 
(3)  Flitter sparklers in paper tubes not exceeding one-eighth-inch in diameter. 
(4)  Toy snakes not containing mercury, if packed in cardboard boxes with not more than 12 pieces per box for retail sale and if the manufacturer's name and the quantity contained in each box are printed on the box; and toy smoke devices. 
(b)  General prohibitions; exception. No person shall ignite, discharge, or use fireworks within the city at any time, except that: 
(1)  Fireworks may be discharged in strict compliance with any permit issued by the city in accordance with the Act. 
(2)  Consumer fireworks may be discharged between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 12:00 midnight only on the day before, the day of, and the day after, a national holiday, except on New Year's Day when consumer fireworks may also be discharged between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 1:00 a.m. A person who ignites, uses or discharges a consumer firework at any time except as set forth in this subsection is responsible for a municipal civil infraction, which is punishable by a fine of up to $500.00. 
(3)  This subsection (b) shall not apply to low-impact fireworks. 
(c)  Additional prohibitions; penalties. 
(1)  Consumer fireworks shall not be ignited, discharged, or used on public property, including public streets and rights-of-way, or on school property, church property, or the private property of another, without the express written permission from the person or entity legally in possession and control of that property to undertake such action. A person who ignites, uses or discharges a consumer firework at any time except as set forth in this subsection is responsible for a municipal civil infraction, which is punishable by a fine of up to $500.00. 
(2)  Consumer fireworks shall not be ignited, discharged, or used by a person under the influence of alcoholic liquor or a controlled substance or a combination of both. A person who violates this subsection is responsible for a municipal civil infraction, which is punishable by a fine of up to $500.00. 
(3)  Low-impact fireworks shall not be ignited, discharged, or used by a person under the influence of alcoholic liquor or a controlled substance or a combination of both. A person who violates this subsection is responsible for a municipal civil infraction, which is punishable by a fine of up to $500.00. 
(4)  Consumer fireworks shall not be sold to a minor. A person who violates this subsection is responsible for a municipal civil infraction, which is punishable by a fine of up to $500.00 for the first offense, or $1,000.00 for a second or subsequent offense. 
(5)  No minor shall use, ignite or possess any consumer fireworks unless under the direct supervision of an adult at all times. A person who violates this subsection is responsible for a municipal civil infraction, which is punishable by a fine of up to $500.00. 
(d)  Novelties not regulated. This section does not apply to novelties. 
(e)  Enforcement. This section may be enforced by the fire chief, police chief, their designees, and any sworn law enforcement officers. 
(f)  Determination of violation; seizure of fireworks. 
(1)  If an enforcing official determines that a violation of this section has occurred, the official may seize the fireworks as evidence of such violation. Upon a finding of responsibility or guilt, the city may destroy or dispose of any consumer fireworks or low impact fireworks retained as evidence for prosecution of the violation. 
(2)  In addition to any other penalty provided herein, a person found responsible for a violation of this section shall reimburse the city for the costs of storing, disposing of, or destroying any consumer or low-impact fireworks seized. 
(Code 1988, § 9.62(4); Ord. No. 551, § 1, 8-21-2012; Ord. No. 561, § 1, 7-16-2013)
