It is a requirement of each construction permit, whether explicitly stated or not, that the permittee shall not damage any public property, except as specifically required to perform the work authorized by the permit, and will properly restore, to the city's standards, all areas affected by its work, at no cost or expense to the city. It is also a condition of each construction permit, whether explicitly stated or not, that the permittee will not damage, injure or interfere with, by its activities, the facilities or property of any other city authorized user of the right-of-way. 
    Federal Communications Commission (or FCC) means the Federal Communications Commission or its successor. 
    Lease means an agreement between the city and a telecommunications provider or the owner or operator of communications facilities under which the provider or owner or operator is permitted to occupy space on city-owned or controlled public rights-of-way or structures to emplace and maintain a radio frequency antenna. 
    MPSC means The Michigan Public Service Commission in the Department of Consumer and Industry Services. 
    Permit means a nonexclusive permit issued pursuant to the Act and this article to a telecommunications provider to use the public rights-of-way in the city for its telecommunications facilities. 
    Person means and includes any individual, corporation, partnership, association, joint stock company, trust, governmental entity, or any other legal entity, but not the city. 
    Public rights-of-way means the surface and space above, on, and below any public highway, avenue, street, lane, alley, boulevard, concourse, driveway, bridge, tunnel, park, parkway, waterway, public easement, right-of-way or any other public ground or water within or in which the city now or hereafter holds any property interest which, consistent with the purposes for which it was dedicated or otherwise acquired, may be used for the purpose of constructing, operating, and maintaining a telecommunications facility. No reference herein, or in any permit agreement, to a public right-of-way shall be deemed to be a representation or warranty by the city that its interest or other right to control the use of such property is sufficient to permit its use for such purposes, and a permittee shall be deemed to acquire only those rights of user as are properly in the city and as the city may have the undisputed right and power to give. Public right-of-way does not include a federal, state, or private right-of-way. 
    Telecommunication facilities or facilities means the equipment or personal property, such as copper and fiber cables, lines, wires, switches, conduits, pipes, and sheaths, which are used to or can generate, receive, transmit, carry, amplify, or provide telecommunication services or signals. Telecommunication facilities or facilities do not include antennas, supporting structures for antennas, equipment shelters or houses, and any ancillary equipment and miscellaneous hardware used to provide federally licensed commercial mobile service as defined in section 332(d) of part I of title III of the communications act of 1934, chapter 652, 48 Stat. 1064, 47 USC 332 and further defined as commercial mobile radio service in 47 CFR 20.3, and service provided by any wireless, two-way communication device. 
    Telecommunications provider, provider and telecommunications services means those terms as defined in section 102 of the Michigan telecommunications act, Public Act No. 179 of 1991 (MCL 484.2102). The term "telecommunication provider" does not include a person or an affiliate of that person when providing a federally licensed commercial mobile radio service as defined in section 332(d) of part I of the communications act of 1934, chapter 652, 48 Stat. 1064, 47 USC 332 and further defined as commercial mobile radio service in 47 CFR 20.3, or service provided by any wireless, two-way communication device. For the purpose of the Act and this article only, a provider also includes all of the following: 
(1)  A cable television operator that provides a telecommunications service. 
(2)  Except as otherwise provided by the Act, a person who owns telecommunication facilities located within a public right-of-way. 
(3)  A person providing broadband internet transport access service. 
    Transfer means the transfer of an interest in a permit means the sale or transfer, directly or indirectly, of an existing or newly created equity interest in the permittee whether or not it may result in a transfer of control of the permittee. 
(Code 1988, § 2.404; Ord. No. 424, § 1, 9-14-1998; Ord. No. 470, § 3, 10-15-2002) 
Sec. 34-23. - Required permits. 
(a)  Construction. 
(1)  No person shall erect, hang, lay, bury, draw, emplace, or construct any telecommunications facility upon, across, beneath, or over any public right-of-way in this city without first obtaining a construction permit therefor from the city. 
(2)  No person shall enter upon, across, beneath, or over any public right-of-way in this city to relocate or otherwise displace any telecommunications facility that is located upon, across, beneath, or over any public right-of-way without first obtaining a construction permit therefor from the city. 
(b)  Telecommunications. No person shall maintain or operate a telecommunications facility upon, across, beneath, or over any public right-of-way in this city without obtaining a telecommunications permit as required by this article. 
(Code 1988, § 2.405; Ord. No. 424, § 1, 9-14-1998; Ord. No. 437, § 1, 11-16-1999; Ord. No. 470, § 4, 10-15-2002) 
Sec. 34-24. - Administration. 
(a)  The city manager shall issue, or cause to be issued, all construction permits and inspect or cause inspection of the work under each permit to the extent the city manager or a designee deems appropriate. 
(b)  The city manager shall notify the MPSC when a telecommunications permit has been granted or denied, including information regarding the date on which the application was filed and the date on which the permit was granted or denied. 
(c)  If an application for a telecommunications permit is approved, as provided herein, the city manager shall issue the permit in the form provided by the MPSC, with or without additional or different permit terms, in accordance with sections 6(1), 6(2) and 15 of the Act (MCL 484.3106(1), (2), 484.3115). 
(d)  Pursuant to section 15(4) of the Act (MCL 484.3115(4)), the city manager may impose conditions on the issuance of a permit, which conditions shall be limited to the telecommunications provider's access and usage of the public right-of-way. 
(e)  The city manager shall be responsible for the continuing enforcement of all terms and conditions of permits, leases, and other such instruments authorizing the use or employment of public rights-of-way for communications facilities and services. 
(Code 1988, § 2.406; Ord. No. 424, § 1, 9-14-1998; Ord. No. 470, § 5, 10-15-2002) 
Sec. 34-25. - Application for telecommunications permit. 
(a)  An applicant for a telecommunications permit under this article must submit three copies of an application to the city clerk, on a form approved by the MPSC in accordance with section 6(1) of the Act (MCL 484.3106(1)), and include at a minimum the following information: 
(1)  The name, address and telephone number of the applicant. 
(2)  The name, address and telephone number of a responsible person whom the city may notify or contact at any time concerning the applicant's telecommunications facilities. 
(3)  Route maps showing the location of the applicant's existing and proposed facilities in the format prescribed in the Act. If the telecommunications provider claims that any portion of the route maps submitted as part of its application contain trade secret, proprietary or confidential information which is exempt under the freedom of information act (MCL 15.231 et seq.), pursuant to section 6(5) of the Act (MCL 484.3106(5)), the telecommunications provider shall prominently indicate this on the face of each map. 
(4)  The technical standards that the applicant proposes to follow in construction and operation of the telecommunications facilities. 
(5)  A description of the telecommunications services to be provided. 
(6)  The city may require any additional information it deems necessary because of the applicant's specific proposed use. The applicant shall comply with all such requests in compliance with reasonable deadlines for such additional information established by the city manager. 
(b)  Except as otherwise provided in the Act, the application shall be accompanied by a one-time nonrefundable application fee in the amount of $500.00. 
(c)  If the information in an application is incomplete or if the proposed use is inconsistent with the requirements of this article, the application may be returned as unacceptable for filing. 
(d)  If the information provided in an application is complete and meets all the requirements of this article, the city manager shall promptly review the application to determine compliance with the requirements of this article, including the technical and construction standards as set forth in section 34-27. 
(e)  In evaluating an application, the city manager must consider: 
(1)  The applicant's technical, financial, and legal qualifications to construct and operate a telecommunications system; 
(2)  The nature of the proposed facilities, equipment, and services; 
(3)  The applicant's recent performance record of providing telecommunications services in other communities, if any; 
(4)  The ability of the applicant to provide a telecommunications service or services making efficient use of the public right-of-way and justifying any inconvenience of the public attendant thereon; 
(5)  The effects of a grant of a permit on the present and future use of the public rights-of-way, including any foreclosure of future uses of the public rights-of-way; 
(6)  The benefit or detriment to the public from the applicant's proposed use; and 
(7)  Any factors arising from the applicant's specific proposed use that affect the foregoing and the health, safety and welfare of the public. 
(f)  Based upon the application and any other information relevant to the application, the city manager shall determine whether to recommend the grant, with or without conditions, or the denial of a permit and shall notify the applicant of the proposed recommendation. 
(g)  The city manager shall submit a recommendation to grant a telecommunications permit to the city commission or a recommendation not to grant a telecommunications permit. The city commission must approve or disapprove the proposed grant and permit, based on its weighing of the information submitted and on the applicant's ability to provide a telecommunications service or services making efficient use of the public rights-of-way and justifying any inconvenience of the public attendant thereon; provided, however, if the city commission does not act within 45 days from the date of receipt of a complete application by the city manager, the city manager shall be authorized to grant or deny the permit on or before the 45th day. 
(h)  Pursuant to section 5(1) of the Act (MCL 484.3105(1)), authorizations or permits previously issued by the city under section 251 of the state telecommunications act, Public Act No. 179 of 1991 (MCL 484.2251) and authorizations or permits issued by the city to telecommunications providers prior to the 1995 enactment of section 251 of the state telecommunications act but after 1985 shall satisfy the permit requirements of this article. 
(i)  Pursuant to section 5(3) of the Act (MCL 484.3105(3)), within 180 days from November 1, 2002, the effective date of the Act, a telecommunications provider with facilities located in a public right-of-way in the city as of such date, that has not previously obtained authorization or a permit under section 251 of the state telecommunications act, Public Act No. 179 of 1991 (MCL 484.2251), shall submit to the city an application for a permit in accordance with the requirements of this article. Pursuant to section 5(3) of the Act (MCL 484.3105(3)), a telecommunications provider submitting an application under this subsection is not required to pay the $500.00 application fee required under subsection (b) of this section. A provider under this subsection shall be given up to an additional 180 days to submit the permit application if allowed by the authority, as provided in section 5(4) of the Act (MCL 484.3105(4)). 
(Code 1988, § 2.407; Ord. No. 424, § 1, 9-14-1998; Ord. No. 426, § 1, 12-15-1998; Ord. No. 470, § 6, 10-15-2002) 
Sec. 34-26. - Terms of telecommunications permits. 
(a)  No telecommunications permit under this article shall be issued for a term of longer than five years. 
(b)  The permittee of any permit under this article shall promptly commence to exercise its privileges thereunder. Each permittee within six months of the effective date of the permit shall file with the city manager, a report under oath describing the extent of operations and/or preparatory measures thereto since the effective date. On each anniversary of the effective date of grant, the permittee shall file with the city manager, a report under oath describing the extent of operations under the permit. If any such annual report shows nonuse in whole or in part, the city may issue to the permittee an order to show cause why such permit shall not be deemed abandoned, returnable in not less than 60 days. After a hearing, if requested in a timely manner by the permittee, the city may find that the permit has been abandoned and declare it forfeited. Thereupon, the city may either take possession of some or all of the permittee's facilities in the public rights-of-way or require the permittee or its bonding company to remove some or all of the permittee's facilities from the public rights-of-way and to restore the public rights-of-way to their prior condition. 
(Code 1988, § 2.408; Ord. No. 424, § 1, 9-14-1998; Ord. No. 470, § 7, 10-15-2002) 
Sec. 34-27. - Technical and construction standards. 
(a)  Each permittee shall construct, install and maintain its telecommunications system in a manner consistent and in compliance with all applicable laws, ordinances, construction standards, governmental requirements, and technical standards established by the Federal Communications Commission or state agency. 
(b)  In any event, the telecommunications system shall not endanger or interfere with the safety of persons or property within the city or other areas where the permittee may have equipment located. 
(c)  All working facilities, conditions, and procedures, used or occurring during construction of the system shall comply with the standards of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration. 
(d)  Construction, installation and maintenance of a telecommunications system shall be performed in an orderly and workmanlike manner, and in close coordination with public and private utilities serving the city following accepted industry construction procedures and practices and working through existing committees and organizations. 
(e)  All cable and wires shall be installed, where possible, parallel with electric and telephone lines, and multiple cable configurations shall be arranged in parallel and bundled with due respect for engineering consideration. Utility cabinets used to shelter telecommunication equipment or hardware shall be located and installed in accordance with the regulations set forth in chapter 38. 
(f)  Permittee shall mark its telecommunications system as follows: 
(1)  Aerial portions of the telecommunications system shall be marked with a marker on permittee's lines on alternate poles which shall state permittee's name and provide a toll-free number to call for assistance. 
(2)  Direct buried underground portions of the telecommunications system shall have: 
a.  A conducting wire placed in the ground at least several inches above permittee's cable if such cable is nonconductive; 
b.  At least several inches above that, a continuous colored tape with permittee's name and toll-free number and a statement to the effect that there is buried cable beneath; and 
c.  Stakes or other appropriate above-ground markers with permittee's name and a toll-free number indicating that there is buried telephone cable below. Bored underground portions of the telecommunications system shall have a conducting wire at the same depth as the cable and shall not be required to provide the continuous colored tape. 
Portions of the telecommunications system located in the conduit, including conduit of others used by permittee, shall be marked at its entrance into and exit from each manhole and handhole with permittee's name and a toll-free telephone number. 
(g)  Pursuant to section 4(3) of the Act (MCL 484.3104(3)), obtaining a permit or paying the fees required under the Act or under this ordinance does not give a telecommunications provider a right to use conduit or utility poles. 
(h)  Pursuant to section 6(7) of the Act (MCL 484.3106(7)), a telecommunications provider shall, within 90 days of substantial completion of construction of new telecommunications facilities in the city, submit route maps showing the location of the telecommunications facilities to both the MPSC and to the city. The route maps shall be in a format as prescribed by the MPSC in accordance with section 6(8) of the Act (MCL 484.3106(8)). 
(Code 1988, § 2.409; Ord. No. 424, § 1, 9-14-1998; Ord. No. 470, § 8, 10-15-2002; Ord. No. 508, § 2, 9-19-2006) 
Sec. 34-28. - Conditions of permit. 
(a)  No permittee or holder of any construction permit for any telecommunications facility shall erect new aerial plant in or on a public right-of-way in which one or more public service providers of electricity, telephone, or cable television, has placed its lines underground or in an area where the city by ordinance has forbidden new aerial plant to be constructed or existing aerial plant to be maintained. 
(b)  Each permittee or holder of any construction permit for any telecommunications facility shall, upon written notice from the city, reasonably in advance, promptly relocate its lines at its own expense to accommodate realignment or construction of public streets, sidewalks, curbs, drains, sewers, and public improvements of any sort. 
(c)  No permittee or holder of any construction permit for any telecommunications facility shall dig, trench, or otherwise excavate in the public rights-of-way without complying with the "Miss Dig" program. 
(d)  Every permittee and holder of any construction permit shall make available to any permittee space on the poles of the permittee and holder to the extent practicable and at a reasonable charge, calculated in accordance with section 224 of the Communications Act of 1934, as amended, 47 USC 224; and any permittee under this article may request another permittee to rearrange its facilities or charge out its poles to reasonably accommodate the requesting permittee's facilities at the reasonable expense of the requesting permittee. 
(e)  Every permittee or holder of any construction permit shall make available to other permittees any of its conduits that is excess, so long as it is excess, at a reasonable rental fee; provided, further, that the city may require as a condition of issuing any construction permit for underground conduit the installation of which requires excavation in or under or along or across any traveled way that the permittee or holder of the construction permit emplace conduit in excess of its present and reasonably foreseeable requirements for the purpose of accommodating other permittees for a reasonable charge. 
(f)  Every permittee that shall cease operating or maintaining any telecommunications facility in a public right-of-way shall, upon written request of the city within two years of the cessation or maintenance of such telecommunications facility, promptly remove it. Should the permittee neglect, refuse, or fail to remove such facility, the city may remove the facility at the expense of the permittee. The obligation to remove shall survive the termination of the permit for a period of two years and shall be bonded. 
(Code 1988, § 2.410; Ord. No. 424, § 1, 9-14-1998; Ord. No. 470, § 9, 10-15-2002) 
Sec. 34-29. - Insurance; bond. 
(a)  Prior to beginning any construction in or installation of the telecommunications system in the public right-of-way, the permittee shall obtain the following insurance, and submit certificates evidencing the same: 
(1)  Commercial general liability insurance including completed operations liability, independent contractors liability, contractual liability coverage and XCU coverage in an amount not less than $5,000,000.00. 
(2)  Liability insurance for sudden and accidental environmental contamination. 
(3)  Automobile liability insurance in an amount not less than $1,000,000.00. 
(4)  Workers compensation and employer's liability coverage with statutory limits. 
(b)  The city shall be named additional insured on all policies, other than workers compensation and employer's liability, and all policies shall not be canceled, modified or not renewed unless the insurance carrier provides 30 days written notice to the city. 
(c)  Pursuant to section 15(3) of the Act (MCL 484.3115(3)), the city manager shall require that a bond be posted by the telecommunications provider as a condition of the permit. Prior to and during construction of the telecommunications system, the telecommunications provider shall provide a cash bond to the city in an amount not less than $1,000.00 or greater than $20,000.00 to protect both public and private property, and to ensure that any damage to the street surface and all installations on, over, below, or within the public right-of-way will be repaired and restored to its preexisting condition. The amount of the cash bond shall be established by the city manager or the city manager's designee, based upon the size, scope and location of the telecommunications facility, and the potential disruption caused by the construction, installation or excavation. After the construction is complete, the amount of the bond shall not exceed the reasonable cost to ensure that the public right-of-way is returned to its original condition during and after the telecommunications provider's access and use. 
(d)  Pursuant to section 15(5) of the Act (MCL 484.3115(5)), a telecommunications provider undertaking an excavation or construction or installing telecommunications facilities within a public right-of-way or temporarily obstructing a public right-of-way in the city, as authorized by a permit, shall promptly repair all damage done to the street surface and all installations under, over, below, or within the public right-of-way, and shall promptly restore the public right-of-way to its preexisting condition. 
(e)  As a condition of a permit, the permittee shall indemnify and hold harmless the city as set forth in the permit at all times during the life of the permit, and will pay all damages and penalties which the city may be required to pay as a result of granting a permit to the permittee. 
(Code 1988, § 2.411; Ord. No. 424, § 1, 9-14-1998; Ord. No. 470, § 10, 10-15-2002) 
Sec. 34-30. - Reservation of rights; police power. 
    No permit or construction permit shall stop or limit the city in the full exercise of its governmental powers to protect the health and safety of the public, and all other governmental powers may be fully exercised except as expressly provided herein. The city expressly reserves the right to amend the ordinance from which this article is derived from time to time in the exercise of its legislative powers. 
(Code 1988, § 2.412; Ord. No. 424, § 1, 9-14-1998; Ord. No. 470, § 11, 10-15-2002) 
Sec. 34-31. - Transfers and assignments. 
(a)  A permit shall be deemed a privilege that is in the public trust and personal to the original permittee. Notwithstanding any provision of the permit, no transfer of a permit, no assignment of the permit and no delegation of the permittee's rights or duties under the permit to a person other than the permittee shall be effective or permitted during the time period from the date of issuance of the permit until the completion of construction of the telecommunications system without the prior notification to, and express approval by, the city, along with the filing and acceptance by the city, of an application in proper form. 
(b)  Notwithstanding the foregoing, a permit may provide for assignments or transfers if the permittee notifies the city of the assignment or transfer within 30 days after it occurs and, at that time provides the agreements and warranties required by this section, describes the nature of the transfer, and submits complete information describing who will have direct and indirect ownership and control of the facility after the transfer; and the transferee or assignee: 
(1)  Warrants that it has read, accepts, and agrees to be bound by each and every term of the permit and related amendments, regulations, ordinances, and resolutions then in effect; 
(2)  Agrees to assume all responsibility for all liabilities, acts and omissions known and unknown of its predecessor permittees for all purposes, including renewal; 
(3)  Agrees that the transfer shall not permit it take any position or exercise any right which could not have been exercised by its predecessor; 
(4)  Warrants that the transfer will not substantially increase the financial burdens upon or substantially diminish the financial resources available to the permittee, the warranty to be based on comparing the burdens upon and resources that will be available to the transferee compared to its predecessors, or otherwise adversely affect the ability of the permittee to perform; 
(5)  Warrants that the transfer will not in any way adversely affect the city or subscribers including by increasing rates; and 
(6)  Supplies the city with all information required to comply with this article, and complies with any updated insurance and performance bond requirements. 
(Code 1988, § 2.413; Ord. No. 424, § 1, 9-14-1998; Ord. No. 470, § 12, 10-15-2002) 
Sec. 34-32. - Revocation or termination of telecommunications permits. 
(a)  A telecommunications permit may be revoked by the city on the recommendation of the city manager and with the approval of the city commission, for failure to construct, emplace, reconstruct, replace, operate, or maintain the telecommunications facility as required by this article or the permit, or for any other material breach of this article. The city must give a permittee written notice that it is in material breach of this article or the permit. If the permittee does not correct the breach within 60 days or such shorter period of time if provided elsewhere in the telecommunications permit or the notice, or corrective action is not being actively and expeditiously pursued and is not completed to the city's satisfaction within 90 days of the notice, the city must give written notice to the permittee of its intent to revoke the permit. The city must give the permittee written notice of the basis for a revocation, stating its reasons. Upon timely demand by the permittee, an administrative hearing must be held before the city may revoke a permit. The hearing procedures may be modified by the city manager by executive order where appropriate. 
(b)  The presiding officer must issue a recommended decision after the administrative hearing. The city manager may provide for the filing of written comments in response to the recommended decision. After the comment period, the city manager must submit written recommendations to the city commission. 
(c)  The city commission must give notice and hold a public hearing, unless waived by the permittee, and then determine by written resolution or other form of decision whether or not to revoke the permit based on the recommended decision, the recommendations of the city manager, information presented at the public hearing, and other evidence in the record. The resolution or other form of decision must include reasons for the city commission's decision. 
(d)  The city may revoke any permit 120 days after an assignment for the benefit of creditors or the appointment of a receiver or trustee to take over the business of the permittee, whether in a receivership, reorganization, bankruptcy assignment for the benefit of creditors, or other action or proceeding. The city must hold a public hearing before revoking a permit under this subsection upon timely demand of the permittee. The city may not revoke a permit under this subsection if, during the 120 day period: 
(1)  The assignment, receivership, or trusteeship is vacated; or 
(2)  The assignee, receiver, or trustee has fully complied with the terms and conditions of this article and the permit and has executed an agreement, approved by the court having jurisdiction, assuming and agreeing to be bound by the terms, and conditions of the permit, with any changes reasonably deemed necessary by the city. 
(e)  The city may revoke the permit if there is a foreclosure or other judicial sale of any of the facilities, equipment or property of a permittee, by serving notice on the permittee and the successful bidder. The permit and all rights and privileges of the permit will be revoked 30 days after the city serves notice under this subsection unless: 
(1)  The city has approved a transfer of the permit; and 
(2)  The successful bidder has agreed with the city to assume and be bound by the terms and conditions of the permit, with any changes reasonably deemed necessary by the city. 
(f)  If the city revokes a permit, or the permittee surrenders its permit, or if for any other reason a permittee abandons, terminates, or fails to operate or maintain service to its subscribers, the city may require the permittee to remove its facilities and equipment at the surety's or permittee's expense. 
(g)  Notwithstanding any provision in this article or under the permit, a permit shall terminate automatically in the event any of the following occurs: 
(1)  Permittee fails to provide the telecommunications services, facilities, equipment, and capacity for use by the city and other public agencies required by the permit for a period exceeding three days; or 
(2)  Permittee fails within one year from the date of issuance of the telecommunications permit to start construction and installation of the telecommunications system, and/or has not completed within two years from the date of issuance of the telecommunications permit the construction and installation of the telecommunications system. 
(h)  In the event a permit is terminated by operation of subsection (g) of this section, ownership of the telecommunications system shall be deemed abandoned and forfeited to the city unless the city has, at any time prior or subsequent to the termination of the permit, notified the permittee that the permittee is required to remove its facilities and equipment, in which case the permittee shall remove the telecommunications system, telecommunications facilities and equipment at the permittee's or surety's expense. 
(i)  A lease under section 34-40 may be revoked by the city manager after notice of a material violation of the lease terms. 
(Code 1988, § 2.414; Ord. No. 424, § 1, 9-14-1998; Ord. No. 470, § 13, 10-15-2002) 
Sec. 34-33. - Annual maintenance fee. 
(a)  In addition to the nonrefundable application fee paid to the city set forth in section 34-25(b), a telecommunications provider with telecommunications facilities in the city's public rights-of-way shall pay an annual maintenance fee to the authority pursuant to section 8 of the Act. 
(b)  In compliance with the requirements of section 13(1) of the Act (MCL 484.3113(1)), the city hereby modifies, to the extent necessary, any fees charged to telecommunications providers after November 1, 2002, the effective date of the Act, relating to access and usage of the public rights-of-way, to an amount not exceeding the amounts of fees and charges required under the Act, which shall be paid to the authority. In compliance with the requirements of section 13(4) of the Act (MCL 484.3113(4)), the city also hereby approves modification of the fees of providers with telecommunication facilities in public rights-of-way within the city's boundaries, so that those providers pay only those fees required under section 8 of the Act (MCL 484.3108). The city shall provide each telecommunications provider affected by the fee with a copy of the ordinance from which this article is derived, in compliance with the requirement of section 13(4) of the Act (MCL 484.3113(4)). To the extent any fees are charged telecommunications providers in excess of the amounts permitted under the Act, or which are otherwise inconsistent with the Act, such imposition is hereby declared to be contrary to the city's policy and intent, and upon application by a provider or discovery by the city, shall be promptly refunded as having been charged in error. 
(c)  Pursuant to section 13(5) of the Act (MCL 484.3113(5)), if section 8 of the Act (MCL 484.3108) is found to be invalid or unconstitutional, the modification of fees under subsection (b) of this section shall be void from the date the modification was made. 
(d)  Pursuant to section 9(4) of the Act (MCL 484.3109(4)), all amounts received by the city from the authority shall be used by the city solely for rights-of-way related purposes. In conformance with that requirement, all funds received by the city from the authority shall be deposited into the Major Street Fund and/or the Local Street Fund maintained by the city under Public Act No. 51 of 1951 (MCL 247.651 et seq.). 
(e)  Pursuant to section 10(5) of the Act (MCL 484.3110(5)), the city manager may file an annual report with the authority on the use and disposition of funds annually distributed by the authority. 
(f)  Pursuant to section 13(6) of the Act (MCL 484.3113(6)), the city shall not hold a cable television operator in default or seek any remedy for its failure to satisfy an obligation, if any, to pay after November 1, 2002, the effective date of the Act, a franchise fee or similar fee on that portion of gross revenues from charges the cable operator received for cable modem services provided through broadband internet transport access services. 
(Code 1988, § 2.415; Ord. No. 424, § 1, 9-14-1998; Ord. No. 470, § 14, 10-15-2002) 
Sec. 34-34. - Future franchise right reserved. 
    The city reserves the right to require telecommunications providers to obtain a franchise and pay an applicable franchise fee in the future to occupy such rights-of-way if under applicable law, including but not limited to the following, a franchise and a franchise fee are authorized or permitted: 
(1)  The state telecommunications act of 1995 is amended to define telecommunications services as public utility services, and a franchise is required. 
(2)  The state telecommunications act of 1995 is either repealed or superseded by future federal or state law in such a way as to require telecommunications providers obtain a franchise from cities. 
(3)  The state telecommunications act of 1995 as presently in force defining telecommunications services as not constituting public utilities is found by a court of competent jurisdiction in a final, nonappealable determination, to be unconstitutional, unlawful, invalid, or otherwise unenforceable. 
(Code 1988, § 2.416; Ord. No. 424, § 1, 9-14-1998; Ord. No. 470, § 15, 10-15-2002) 
Sec. 34-35. - Maps, records and reports. 
    A permittee shall provide the city with current maps of its existing and proposed installations in a standardized format for use with the city's data system within 30 days of the completion of the telecommunications system and of any extensions, additions or modifications to the telecommunications system. 
(Code 1988, § 2.417; Ord. No. 424, § 1, 9-14-1998; Ord. No. 470, § 16, 10-15-2002) 
Sec. 34-36. - Existing rights. 
    Pursuant to section 4(2) of the Act (MCL 484.3104(2)), except as expressly provided herein with respect to fees, this article shall not affect any existing rights that a telecommunications provider or the city may have under a permit issued by the city or under a contract between the city and a telecommunications provider related to the use of the public rights-of-way. 
(Code 1988, § 2.418; Ord. No. 424, § 1, 9-14-1998; Ord. No. 470, § 17, 10-15-2002) 
Sec. 34-37. - Public emergency. 
    The city shall have the right to sever, disrupt, dig-up, or otherwise destroy facilities of permittee or lessee, without any prior notice, if such action is deemed necessary by the city manager, director of public safety, director of public works, county drain commission, or the managing director of the county road commission because of a public emergency. A public emergency as used in this section, shall be a condition which, in the opinion of any of the officials named, poses an immediate threat to lives or property of the citizens of the city, caused by any natural or manmade disaster, including, but not limited to, storms, floods, fire, accidents, explosions, major water main breaks, hazardous material spills, etc. The permittee or lessee shall be responsible for repair, at its sole expense, of any of its facilities damaged pursuant to any such action taken by the city. 
(Code 1988, § 2.419; Ord. No. 424, § 1, 9-14-1998; Ord. No. 470, § 18, 10-15-2002) 
Sec. 34-38. - Interpretation and severability. 
    The various parts, sentences, paragraphs, sections, and clauses of this article are hereby declared to be severable. If any part, sentence, paragraph, section, or clause of this article is adjudged unconstitutional or invalid by a court or administrative agency of competent jurisdiction, the unconstitutionality or invalidity shall not affect the constitutionality or validity of any remaining provisions of this article, and the remainder of the article shall be construed in a way that will effect the city commission's purpose to the greatest extent possible. 
(Code 1988, § 2.420; Ord. No. 424, § 1, 9-14-1998; Ord. No. 470, § 19, 10-15-2002) 
Sec. 34-39. - Enforcement. 
(a)  Misdemeanor. Any person who knowingly violates any prohibition in section 34-23 shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, may be sentenced to not more than 90 days in jail and fined not more than $500.00, or both, for each and every violation. Each violation shall be a separate offense, and in the case of a continuing violation, each day shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(b)  Forfeiture of facilities. Any telecommunications facility constructed, maintained, or operated upon, across, beneath, or over any public right-of-way in this city in violation of this article is hereby declared to be subject to forfeiture, and the city may seize, disable, remove, or destroy such facility upon 30 days' advance notice in writing to the owner or operator thereof; provided, however, that where the safety of any person or property lawfully within the right-of-way is endangered thereby, only such notice as is practicable under the circumstances need be given. 
(c)  Injunctive relief. In addition to the foregoing remedies, the city may apply to the circuit court for an injunction to mitigate or terminate the violation. The city may also sue to recover its damages for the violation. 
(d)  Reduction of term. Where, after notice and after a hearing, if timely requested by the permittee, the city manager finds that the permit is being operated in substantial violation of its terms or this article, the city may make an appropriate reduction in the remaining term of the permit after a hearing, unless waived, at which the permittee shall have the burden of proof. 
(e)  Waiver. The failure of the city to insist on timely performance or compliance by any person holding a construction permit or telecommunications permit shall not constitute a waiver of the city's right to later insist on timely performance or compliance by that person or any other person holding such a permit. 
(Code 1988, § 2.421; Ord. No. 470, § 20, 10-15-2002) 
Sec. 34-40. - Compliance. 
    The city hereby declares that its policy and intent in adopting this article is to fully comply with the requirements of the Act, and the provisions hereof should be construed in such a manner as to achieve that purpose. The city shall comply in all respects with the requirements of the Act, including but not limited to the following: 
(1)  Exempting certain route maps from the freedom of information act, Public Act No. 442 of 1976 (MCL 15.231 et seq.), as provided in this article; 
(2)  Allowing certain previously issued permits to satisfy the permit requirements hereof, in accordance with this article; 
(3)  Allowing existing providers additional time in which to submit an application for a permit, and excusing such providers from the $500.00 application fee, in accordance with this article; 
(4)  Approving or denying an application for a permit within 45 days from the date a telecommunications provider files an application for a permit for access to and usage of a public right-of-way within the city, in accordance with this article; 
(5)  Notifying the MPSC when the city has granted or denied a permit, in accordance with this article; 
(6)  Not unreasonably denying an application for a permit, in accordance with this article; 
(7)  Issuing a permit as provided in this article; 
(8)  Limiting the conditions imposed on the issuance of a permit to the telecommunications provider's access and usage of the public right-of-way, in accordance with this article; 
(9)  Not requiring a bond of a telecommunications provider which exceeds the reasonable cost to ensure that the public right-of-way is returned to its original condition during and after the telecommunication provider's access and use, in accordance with this article; 
(10)  Not charging any telecommunications providers any additional fees for construction or engineering permits, in accordance with this article; 
(11)  Providing each telecommunications provider affected by the city's right-of-way fees with a copy of this article, in accordance with this article; 
(12)  Submitting an annual report to the Authority, in accordance with this article; and 
(13)  Not holding a cable television operator in default for a failure to pay certain franchise fees, in accordance with this article. 
(Code 1988, § 2.422; Ord. No. 470, § 21, 10-15-2002) 
Sec. 34-41. - Conflict. 
    Nothing in this article shall be construed in such a manner as to conflict with the Act or other applicable law. 
(Code 1988, § 2.423; Ord. No. 470, § 22, 10-15-2002) 
Secs. 34-42-34-70. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - OTHER TELECOMMUNICATIONS FACILITIES 

Sec. 34-71. - Applicability. 
(a)  This division applies: 
(1)  To the erection, emplacement, construction or maintenance of telecommunications facilities upon, across, beneath, or over any public right-of-way, other than for the provision of cable services pursuant to franchise or telecommunications services pursuant to license or approval granted under division 1 of this chapter; and 
(2)  To leases for the erection, attachment, emplacement, or maintenance of antennas or other active or passive devices for the transmission or reception of radio or optical signals through transmission media not physically bounded, including towers and other manmade structures, other than for or in support of the provision of telecommunications or cable services under license. 
(b)  This division does not apply to communications circuits and lines installed in conjunction with the facilities of a public utility, where those circuits and lines are utilized solely for communications for and in connection with the internal conduct of the utility's own affairs. 
(Code 1988, § 2.440; Ord. No. 424, § 1, 9-14-1998) 
Sec. 34-72. - Private communications circuits. 
    Upon approval by the city manager of an application in proper form, the city shall issue a license to any person demonstrating a need in the course of its business to emplace or operate private communications lines in the public rights-of-way to facilitate communications between or among its places of business. Such license shall not authorize the provision of telecommunications services for hire. 
(Code 1988, § 2.441; Ord. No. 424, § 1, 9-14-1998) 
Sec. 34-73. - Tower leases. 
    Upon approval by the city manager, the city may enter into, with telecommunications providers and other radio users, leases for appropriate tower sites, antenna space on towers and other supporting structures, and for accessory buildings on city property. Such leases shall contain commercially reasonable provisions protecting the interests of the city and shall be for terms of not longer than five years. 
(Code 1988, § 2.442; Ord. No. 424, § 1, 9-14-1998) 
Sec. 34-74. - Aeronautical clearance. 
    The lessee shall be responsible for obtaining in a timely manner at its own expense any required approvals for its antenna or antenna structure from the Federal Aviation Administration or the Federal Communications Commission, or the successors of either, any required zoning from the city, and any building or electrical permits and inspections from the city. On any antenna structure which is not occupied by a city-owned antenna already subject to the tower registration, lighting, and aeronautical painting requirements of the FAA or FCC, or the successors of either, the lessee shall be financially responsible for the tower registration, lighting, and aeronautical painting requirements applicable to its antenna and/or supporting structure. 
(Code 1988, § 2.443; Ord. No. 424, § 1, 9-14-1998) 
Sec. 34-75. - Existing facilities. 
(a)  The owner or operator of any existing facility, the operation of which is required to be licensed under this article, shall have three months from the effective date of the ordinance from which this division is derived to file one or more applications for a license under this article. Any operator filing such an application shall not be subject to a penalty under section 34-39 for failure to have such a license for that period during which said application remains pending. 
(b)  Any lessee under a lease from the city for an antenna site, valid and in force on the effective date of the ordinance from which this division is derived, may continue to occupy such antenna site to the conclusion of the term of the lease, but not any renewal or extension thereof, in accordance with the terms of such lease; provided, however, that such lessee may elect at any time to apply for a superseding lease under this article. 
(Code 1988, § 2.444; Ord. No. 424, § 1, 9-14-1998) 
Secs. 34-76-34-100. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - CABLE COMMUNICATION STANDARDS 

Sec. 34-101. - Construction standards. 
    A cable operator or video service provider (both of which are referred to hereinafter as a "provider"), as defined in Public Act No. 480 of 2006, shall comply with the following regulations regarding use and occupation of public rights-of-way with the city: 
(1)  The provider shall not open or disturb the surface of any streets, or public property, without first obtaining a permit from the city for which permit the city may impose a reasonable fee to be paid by the provider. The lines, conduits, cables and other property placed in the streets, and public property pursuant to such permit shall be located in such part of the street or public property as shall be determined by the city. The provider shall, upon completion of any work requiring the opening of any streets or public property, restore the same including the pavement and its foundations to as good a condition as formerly and in a manner and quality approved by the city, and shall exercise reasonable care to maintain the same thereafter in good condition. Such work shall be performed with diligence, and due care and if the provider shall fail to perform the work promptly, to remove all dirt and rubbish and to put the street or public property back into the condition required hereby, the city shall have the right to put the streets or public property back into the condition required hereby; the city shall have the right to put the streets or public property back into such condition at the expense of the provider. The provider shall, upon demand, pay to city the cost of such work done. 
(2)  All wires, conduits, cable and other property and facilities of the provider shall be so located, constructed, installed and maintained as not to endanger or unnecessarily interfere with the usual and customary trade, traffic, and travel upon, or other use of, the streets and public property of the city. The provider shall keep and maintain all of its property in good condition, order and repair so that the same shall not menace or endanger the life or property of any person. The city shall have the right to inspect and examine at all reasonable times and upon reasonable notice the property owned or used, in part or in whole, by the provider. The provider shall keep accurate maps and records of all of its wires, conduits, cables and other property and facilities located, constructed and maintained in the city. Further, the provider shall furnish copies of such maps and records from time to time as requested by the city without charge. 
(3)  All wires, conduits, cables or other property and facilities of the provider shall be constructed and installed in an orderly and workmanlike manner. All wires, conduits, and cables shall be installed, where possible, parallel with electric and telephone lines. Multiple cable configurations shall be arranged in parallel and bundled with due respect for engineering considerations. 
(4)  The provider shall at all times comply with the following codes, rules, and regulations, as amended, and any others supplemental to or in substitution thereof: 
a.  National Electrical Safety Code (National Bureau of Standards). 
b.  National Electrical Code (National Bureau of Fire Underwriters). 
c.  Bell System Code of Pole Line Construction. 
d.  Applicable FCC and other applicable federal, state and local regulations and ordinances. In any event, the installation, operation or maintenance of the system shall not endanger or interfere with the safety of persons or property in the city. 
(5)  Whenever the city shall undertake any public improvement which affects the provider's equipment or facilities, the city may, with due regard to reasonable working conditions and with reasonable notice, direct the provider to remove or relocate its wires, conduits, cables and other property located in streets, or public property. The provider shall relocate or protect its wires, conduits, cables and other property at its own expense. 
(6)  The provider's plans for constructing its system, and the construction of the system, shall be in accordance with its proposal as modified by the franchise agreement. However, the provider shall comply with the following minimum requirements: 
a.  The provider shall construct underground in any area where both the electrical and telephone lines have been installed underground. 
b.  The provider shall change from aerial to underground, at its own expense, in any area where both the telephone and electric utilities are hereafter changed from aerial to underground. 
c.  To enable the provider reasonable opportunity to change its wiring from aerial to underground, and also to allow it to pre-wire all new subdivisions or new development areas, the city shall provide the provider with written notice of the following but without liability for failure to provide such notice: 
1.  Any underground trenching that may be pending. 
2.  All ordinance changes affecting the wiring of the system. 
(7)  The provider shall, upon completion of any work on private property (or easements thereon), restore the same including any and all landscape features, plantings, turf, buildings, pipes, and wires (overhead and underground), pavements, sidewalks, foundations or other features whatsoever, to as good a condition as existed before construction. 
(8)  The provider shall prior to construction make a clear videotape record of all underground construction and other specially designated areas. Such tapes are to be preserved for three years after completion of the applicable construction. 
(Code 1988, § 2.234; Ord. No. 397, § 1, 6-17-1997) 
Sec. 34-102. - Conditions on use. 
    A cable operator or video service provider shall comply with the following regulations regarding use and occupation of public rights-of-way: 
(1)  The provider shall not place poles or other fixtures where the same will interfere with any gas, electric, or telephone fixture, water hydrant or main. 
(2)  The provider, at the request of any person holding a building moving permit and with not less than five days' advance notice, shall temporarily remove, raise or lower its wires, conduits and cables. The expense of such temporary removal, raising or lowering of wires, conduits and cables shall be paid by person requesting the same, and the provider shall have the authority to require such payment in advance. 
(3)  The provider shall have the authority, to the extent the city has authority to grant the same, to trim trees upon or overhanging any street or public property so as to prevent the branches of such trees from coming in contact with the wires, conduit and cables of the provider. All trimming shall be done under the supervision and direction of the city and at the expense of the provider. 
(4)  Utility cabinets used to shelter cable communications equipment or hardware shall be located and installed in accordance with the regulations set forth in chapter 24. 
(Code 1988, § 2.235; Ord. No. 397, § 1, 6-17-1997; Ord. No. 508, § 1, 9-19-2006) 
Secs. 34-103-34-130. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - CABLE OPERATORS AND VIDEO SERVICE PROVIDERS 

Sec. 34-131. - Consumer protection standards. 
    Cable operators and video service providers shall conform to the following consumer protection standards: 
(1)  The following standards are stated in section 10 of the Michigan Uniform Video Services Local Franchise Act (the "Act"), MCL 484.3310: 
a.  A video service provider shall not, in connection with the providing of video services to its subscribers, do any of the following: 
1.  Make a statement or representation, including the omission of material information, regarding the rates, terms or conditions of providing video service that is false, misleading or deceptive. As used in this subsection, the term "material information" includes, but is not limited to, all applicable fees, taxes and charges that will be billed to the subscriber, regardless of whether the fees, taxes or charges are authorized by state or federal law. 
2.  Charge a customer for a subscribed service for which the customer did not make an initial affirmative order. Failure to refuse an offered or proposed subscribed service is not an affirmative order for the service. 
3.  If a customer has canceled a service, charge the customer for service provided after the effective date the service was canceled. 
4.  Cause a probability of confusion or a misunderstanding as to the legal rights, obligations or remedies of a party to a transaction by making a false, deceptive or misleading statement or by failing to inform the customer of a material fact, the omission of which is deceptive or misleading. 
5.  Represent or imply that the subject of a transaction will be provided promptly, or at a specified time, or within a reasonable time, if the provider knows or has reason to know that it will not be so provided. 
6.  Cause coercion and duress as a result of the time and nature of a sales presentation. 
b.  Each video service provider shall establish a dispute resolution process for its customers. Each provider shall maintain a local or toll-free telephone number for customer service contact. 
c.  Each provider shall notify its customers of the dispute resolution process created by the legislature found under the Act. 
(2)  The following customer service standards are stated in the rules of the Federal Communications Commission found at 47 CFR 76.309: 
a.  Cable system office hours and telephone availability. 
1.  The cable operator will maintain a local, toll-free or collect telephone access line which will be available to its subscribers 24 hours a day, seven days a week. 
(i)  Trained company representatives will be available to respond to customer telephone inquiries during normal business hours. 
(ii)  After normal business hours, the access line may be answered by a service or an automated response system, including an answering machine. Inquiries received after normal business hours must be responded to by a trained company representative on the next business day. 
2.  Under normal operating conditions, telephone answer time by a customer representative, including wait time, shall not exceed 30 seconds when the connection is made. If the call needs to be transferred, transfer time shall not exceed 30 seconds. These standards shall be met no less than 90 percent of the time under normal operating conditions, measured on a quarterly basis. 
3.  The operator will not be required to acquire equipment or perform surveys to measure compliance with the telephone answering standards of subsection (2)a.2 of this section unless an historical record of complaints indicates a clear failure to comply. 
4.  Under normal operating conditions, the customer will receive a busy signal less than three percent of the time. 
5.  Customer service center and bill payment locations will be open at least during normal business hours and will be conveniently located. 
b.  Installations, outages and service calls. Under normal operating conditions, each of the following four standards will be met no less than 95 percent of the time, measured on a quarterly basis. 
1.  Standard installations will be performed within seven business days after an order has been placed. Standard installations are those that are located up to 125 feet from the existing distribution system. 
2.  Excluding conditions beyond the control of the operator, the cable operator will begin working on "service interruptions" promptly and in no event later than 24 hours after the interruption becomes known. The cable operator must begin actions to correct other service problems the next business day after notification of the service problem. 
3.  The "appointment window" alternatives for installations, service calls, and other installation activities will be either a specific time or, at maximum, a four-hour time block during normal business hours. (The operator may schedule service call and other installation activities outside of normal business hours for the express convenience of the customer.) 
4.  An operator may not cancel an appointment with a customer after the close of business on the business day prior to the scheduled appointment. 
5.  If a cable operator representative is running late for an appointment with a customer and will not be able to keep the appointment as scheduled, the customer will be contacted. The appointment will be rescheduled, as necessary, at a time which is convenient for the customer. 
c.  Communications between cable operators and cable subscribers. 
1.  Refunds. Refund checks will be issued promptly, but no later than either: 
(i)  The customer's next billing cycle following resolution of the request or 30 days, whichever is earlier; or 
(ii)  The return of the equipment supplied by the cable operator if service is terminated. 
2.  Credits. Credits for service will be issued no later than the customer's next billing cycle following the determination that a credit is warranted. 
d.  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection (2)d., except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Normal business hours means those hours during which most similar businesses in the community are open to serve customers. In all cases, the term "normal business hours" must include some evening hours at least one night per week and/or some weekend hours. 
    Normal operating conditions means those service conditions which are within the control of the cable operator. Those conditions which are not within the control of the cable operator include, but are not limited to, natural disasters, civil disturbances, power outages, telephone network outages, and severe or unusual weather conditions. Those conditions which are ordinarily within the control of the cable operator include, but are not limited to, special promotions, pay-per-view events, rate increases, regular peak or seasonal demand periods, and maintenance or upgrade of the cable system. 
    Service interruption means the loss of picture or sound on one or more cable channels. 
(3)  The applicable customer service standards are in the Michigan Consumers Protection Act, Public Act No. 331 of 1976 (MCL 445.901 et seq.). 
Secs. 34-132-34-160. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - WIRELESS COMMUNICATIONS FACILITIES (WCFs) 

Sec. 34-161. - Purpose. 
    Wireless communication technologies are changing the way information is exchanged in our everyday lives. To access this wireless technology, a network of antennas must be strategically placed within and outside of the community. The purpose of the following regulations is to encourage and promote wireless communications coverage for all areas of the city while retaining the integrity of its neighborhoods and the character, property values and aesthetic quality of the community as a whole. To that end, the goals of this article are: 
(1)  To permit wireless communications facilities (WCFs) on certain public properties and street rights-of-way within the city; 
(2)  To protect residential districts and land uses from the potential adverse impact of WCFs; 
(3)  To strongly encourage the joint use of existing WCF sites, buildings or towers rather than the construction of new WCFs; 
(4)  To minimize the total number of WCFs throughout the community; 
(5)  To consider the public health, safety and welfare of the community; 
(6)  To provide for the disclosure of adequate information about plans for WCFs in order to allow the city to effectively plan for the location of such facilities; 
(7)  To avoid potential damage to adjacent and nearby properties from WCF failure through engineering and careful siting of towers; and 
(8)  To encourage configuration of WCFs in a way that minimizes the negative visual impact of towers and antennas on neighborhoods, community landmarks, historical sites and buildings, natural beauty areas and cultural landscapes through careful design, siting, landscaping and innovative camouflaging techniques. This includes consideration of alternative technologies that do not require the use of towers and the avoidance of unsightly structures such as lattice towers, out-of-scale imitation trees and flag poles. 
    In furtherance of these goals, the city shall give due consideration to the city's master plan, zoning ordinance and map, existing land uses and the environment. 
(Ord. No. 552, § 8, 8-21-2012) 
Sec. 34-162. - Reservation of rights to require franchise. 
    The city is not, at this time, requiring a franchise for the siting of a wireless communications facility (WCF) within the city's boundaries. The city reserves the right however, in accordance with applicable federal, state and local laws, to require such a franchise in the future to the extent such a siting may be deemed to constitute the transacting of local business within the city. Neither the issuance of permits or licenses to operate a WCF shall constitute a waiver of or otherwise adversely affect this reservation of rights. In addition, WCFs shall be regulated and permitted pursuant to this article and shall not be regulated or permitted as essential services, public utilities or private utilities. 
(Ord. No. 552, § 8, 8-21-2012) 
Sec. 34-163. - Historic preservation. 
    No provision in this article shall modify, supercede, or nullify the provisions in article VIII Historic Preservation of chapter 6 of the City Code. In the event that any provision of this article conflicts with a provision in article VIII of chapter 6, the provision in article VIII of chapter 6 shall apply. 
(Ord. No. 552, § 8, 8-21-2012) 
Sec. 34-164. - Definitions. 
    Antenna: An exterior transmission or reception device mounted on a tower or building and used in communications that radiate or capture electromagnetic waves, digital signals, analog signals, radio frequencies (excluding radar signals), wireless telecommunication signals or other communication signals. 
    City: The City of Huntington Woods. 
    City commission: The Commission of the City of Huntington Woods. 
    Co-location: The location by two or more wireless communication providers of wireless communication facilities (WCFs) on a common tower or building with the intent of reducing the overall number of structures required to support wireless communication antennas within the community. 
    Planning commission: The Planning Commission of the City of Huntington Woods. 
    Tower: A structure used to support wireless communication antennas. A tower within this definition, includes but shall not be limited to, a monopole, lattice tower, light pole, utility pole, flag pole, artificial tree or other structure which supports WCF antennas. Buildings, equipment compounds and cabinets, and structures principally used for purposes other than supporting antennas shall not be considered as towers. 
    Tower height: The vertical distance measured from the lowest point of the natural ground level around the base of the tower to the highest point on the tower including any antenna. 
    Wireless communication facility (WCF): A facility for the transmission and/or reception of radio frequency signals, including over-the-air broadcasting signals, usually consisting of antennas, equipment, an equipment cabinet or equipment compound, a tower or other support structure, and/or other transmission and reception devices. The term "wireless communication facility" includes wireless telecommunications, but does not include licensed amateur radio stations, receive-only antennas, and towers and antennas utilized by the City of Huntington Woods in connection with performing its municipal functions. 
    Wireless communication provider: A person, company, or entity providing or intending to provide wireless communication services of any kind, including telecommunications services. 
    Wireless equipment cabinet: An upright, stand-alone cupboard-like enclosure for wireless communications equipment. 
    Wireless equipment compound: An area, covered by a roof, supported by a foundation and enclosed by walls on a minimum of 80 percent of the perimeter, adjacent to the base of a building or tower and within which wireless communications equipment is located. 
(Ord. No. 552, § 8, 8-21-2012) 
Sec. 34-165. - Type and location. 
    All WCFs are classified as one of the following three types and are permitted in Zones R-1A through R-1E One-Family Residential, Zone 4 - Parks and Recreation District and certain rights-of-way subject to the conditions set forth in this article. No WCF shall be permitted on privately owned property. 
    Type 1 WCFs are located within or attached to existing buildings or structures such as bell towers, water towers, municipal buildings, and schools. They generally have the least impact on the surrounding environment. Type 1 WCFs are permitted on public property in Zones R-1A through R-1E One-Family Districts, and in Zone 4 - Parks and Recreation District provided that: 
(1)  All WCF equipment, including power generators, service panels and service connections shall be housed in one of the following: within an existing building, within an addition to the existing building, within a wireless equipment compound, or completely underground. An addition to the existing building or a wireless equipment compound shall be architecturally compatible with the existing building or structure in terms of scale, form, texture, materials, and color. A wireless equipment cabinet shall not be permitted in conjunction with Type 1 WCFs; 
(2)  WCF antennas shall be fully concealed within an existing building or structure, or be snug-mounted; 
(3)  WCF antennas, mounting hardware, and cabling shall be covered or painted to match the color and texture of the building on which it is mounted; 
(4)  Rooftop appurtenances shall not exceed five feet in height and shall not occupy more than ten percent of the roof area; 
(5)  WCFs shall comply with the height and area requirements of the zone district in which it is located; and 
(6)  A WCF shall not exceed a noise level of 65 dB(A). 
    Type 2 WCFs are located on utility poles, traffic signal poles, sports or field light poles and parking lot light poles. They are commonly referred to as a distributed antenna systems. Type 2 WCFs are permitted on public property in Zones R-1A through R-1E One-Family Districts, in Zone 4 - Parks and Recreation District, and in the public right-of-way of Woodward Avenue, Coolidge Highway, Eleven Mile Road, and the Ten Mile/I-696 service drive provided that: 
(1)  Antennas shall not be located on poles planned for removal by the city, county or a utility; 
(2)  Pole size, diameter and height shall be no larger than the city, county or utility would use for its intended purpose without a WCF, as determined by said entities; 
(3)  Antennas shall be limited to snug-mount, canister-mount and concealed antennas; 
(4)  Antennas shall not increase the pole height by more than three feet per WCF and shall not exceed 18 inches in diameter; 
(5)  There shall be no more than two separate WCFs on each pole; 
(6)  A WCF shall not exceed a noise level of 65 dB(A); 
(7)  All cables shall be located inside the pole or within an encasement colored to match the pole and oriented to a side with the least visual impact; 
(8)  Antennas, mounting hardware, and cabling shall be covered or painted to match the color and texture of the pole on which it is mounted; 
(9)  All WCF equipment, including power generators, service panels and service connections shall be housed in one of the following: within a building, within a wireless equipment compound, within a wireless equipment cabinet, or completely underground. The wireless equipment cabinet shall not exceed four feet in height and 80 cubic feet. The building, wireless equipment compound or wireless equipment cabinet shall be architecturally compatible with the surrounding area in terms of scale, form, texture, materials and color. If located in the public right-of-way, the wireless communications equipment shall be buried underground. 
    Type 3 WCFs are stand-alone towers and antennas such as monopoles and lattice towers but also includes towers designed as flagpoles, artificial trees and other similar structures. They generally have the greatest impact on the surrounding environment. Type 3 WCFs are permitted on public property in Zones R-1A through R-1E One-Family Districts, and in Zone 4 - Parks and Recreation District, provided that the following requirements are met: 
(1)  Height. The tower shall not exceed 100 feet in height including the antennas; 
(2)  Cables. All cables shall be located inside the tower; 
(3)  Engineering. The tower shall be designed by a state-licensed structural engineer and shall include a soil report from a state-licensed geotechnical engineer (see subsection 34-168(11)); 
(4)  Setbacks. The setback from the base of the tower to any lot line or public right-of-way shall be the maximum distance that debris from a collapsed tower would spread as determined by a structural engineer but not less than 100 feet from any residential lot line; 
(5)  Lighting. Any exterior lighting for WCF shall be shielded so the source of the light is not visible from any neighboring residential property nor does it cause glare for any motorist, bicyclist or pedestrian; 
(6)  Noise. A WCF shall not exceed a noise level of 65 dB(A); 
(7)  Appearance. WCF antennas, mounting hardware, and cabling shall be covered or painted to match the color and texture of the tower on which it is mounted; 
(8)  A new tower and antenna shall not be permitted unless the applicant demonstrates to the planning commission that no existing WCF or alternative technology is available which would otherwise accommodate the applicant's proposed WCF or need, or the planning commission determines that any co-location of the proposed WCF would have a greater impact on the community than the proposed WCF. Evidence submitted to demonstrate that no existing tower or alternative technology can accommodate the applicant's WCF or need, may consist of factors such as the following: 
a.  No existing tower is located within the geographic area which meets the applicant's engineering requirements; 
b.  Existing towers are not of sufficient height to meet the applicant's engineering requirements and cannot be reasonably modified to accomplish same; 
c.  Existing towers do not have sufficient structural strength to support applicant's proposed antenna and related equipment, and cannot be reasonably modified to accomplish applicant's needs; 
d.  The applicant's proposed antenna would cause electromagnetic interference with antenna(s) on the existing tower or vice-versa; and 
e.  The applicant demonstrates that an alternative technology (such as cable or microcell network using multiple low-powered transmitters/receivers attached to a wireline system, etc.) that does not require the use of towers, is unsuitable. Costs of alternative technology, which exceed the costs of new tower or antenna development, shall not be presumed to render alternative technology unsuitable. 
(9)  Anti-climbing. Towers shall be equipped with an appropriate anti-climbing device; 
(10)  Wireless equipment. All WCF equipment including cabinets, power generators, service panels, and service connections shall be housed in one of the following: within a building, within a wireless equipment compound or completely underground. The building or wireless equipment compound shall be architecturally compatible with the surrounding area in terms scale, form, texture, materials and color. A wireless equipment cabinet shall not be permitted in conjunction with Type 3WCFs. WCFs shall be concealed as much as possible by blending into the natural and/or physical environment; 
(11)  Co-location capability. All new towers over 40 feet in height including antennas, shall allow for co-location by other wireless communications providers. The applicant shall demonstrate that the engineering of the tower, and the size and placement of the equipment building or shelter, will accommodate other providers' WCF. The owner of the tower and the owner of the property on which it is located, must certify that the tower is available for use by other wireless communications service providers on a reasonable and nondiscriminatory basis. If a WCF provider fails or refuses to permit co-location on a facility owned or otherwise controlled by it, where co-location is feasible, such facility shall thereupon and thereafter be deemed to be a nonconforming structure and use, and shall not be altered, expanded or extended in any respect. For example, charging fees in excess of what is customary in the industry shall be deemed to be a refusal to permit co-location; 
(12)  Temporary WCF. No temporary WCF shall be permitted except in conjunction with a special event or be in response to an emergency or disaster as determined by the city manager. 
    In reviewing WCF applications, the planning commission has the authority to waive enforcement of particular restrictions, but only to the extent necessary to avoid denial of an application that would effectively prohibit the provision of wireless services. 
(Ord. No. 552, § 8, 8-21-2012) 
Sec. 34-166. - Required approvals and exceptions. 
(a)  New and modified wireless communication facilities (WCFs) are permitted subject to: 
(1)  Approval of the special land use and site plan by the planning commission as outlined in the regulations of sections 40-356 and 40-357 of chapter 40 and this article; 
(2)  Approval of any required variances by the zoning board of appeals; 
(3)  Approval of the application for a WCF by the city commission; 
(4)  Compliance with all applicable building codes; and 
(5)  Obtaining all required permits, paying required fees, and posting required security. 
Modifications made to an existing WCF shall be treated for purposes of this article as a new WCF, which requires the submission of a new application, new permitting procedure and compliance with this article as if the WCF was a new WCF, and the entire WCF, as modified, shall be subject to all of the provisions of this article, except as outlined in subsection (b) below. 
(b)  Co-location of a WCF on/in an existing tower and equipment compound shall not require special land use and site plan approval by the planning commission, or approval of the application by the city commission, provided that all of the following requirements are met: 
(1)  The existing tower or existing equipment compound is in compliance with the zoning ordinance or was approved by the city. 
(2)  The proposed co-location will not do any of the following: 
a.  Increase the overall tower height by more than 20 feet or ten percent of its original height, whichever is greater. 
b.  Increase the tower width by more than the minimum necessary to permit co-location. 
c.  Increase the area of the existing equipment compound to greater than 2,500 square feet. Any addition to the existing equipment compound shall match the existing equipment compound in terms of scale, form, texture, materials, and color. 
(3)  The proposed co-location complies with the terms and conditions of any previous final approval of the existing tower or equipment compound by the city. 
(4)  All equipment including service panels, service connections, and power generators proposed by the applicant will be housed within the equipment compound. 
(5)  All other applicable requirements and regulations of this article and chapter 40 are met, required permits are obtained, and required fees are paid. 
A WCF that meets all of the above requirements except for subsections (b)(2) or (b)(3) is permitted provided it receives special land use approval in accordance with section 40-357 of the City Code. 
(c)  Amateur radio stations, receive-only antennas, city towers and antennas. This article shall not govern any tower or antenna that is under 20 feet in height and is owned and operated by a federally licensed amateur radio station operator or is used exclusively as a receive-only antenna, nor shall it govern any tower or antenna utilized by the City of Huntington Woods in connection with performing its municipal functions. 
(Ord. No. 552, § 8, 8-21-2012) 
Sec. 34-167. - Application, procedure, authorization.
