(a)  An application, required for authorization to construct, operate, expand, extend or modify a WCF, shall be submitted to the building department at the city offices. The application shall include: 
(1)  A completed WCF application form; 
(2)  A special land use application prepared in accordance with the provisions of section 40-357 of chapter 40, if required; 
(3)  A site plan, prepared by an architect and engineer, both licensed in the State of Michigan, and prepared in accordance with the provisions of section 40-356 of chapter 40, if required; and 
(4)  An application fee as established by resolution of the city commission. The fee will be based on an amount necessary to adequately and thoroughly investigate and review the application for compliance with this article and to provide for the city having the application reviewed by technical consultants, when necessary, to ensure that all current technological considerations have been properly taken into account. 
(b)  After the application has been determined to be complete, the city manager or his or her designee shall review the application and where applicable, refer the application to other city departments and/or consultants for review. The city administration reserves the right to require additional information as needed or waive requirements for information determined unnecessary for complete review of the project. 
(c)  If the WCF is to be located on school property and public meetings other than those conducted by the city are held, the dates, times and places of those public meetings, lists of attendees and minutes of the meetings shall be submitted to the city prior to the city commission's review of the WCF application. 
(d)  If required, the special land use application and site plan shall forwarded to the planning commission for review in accordance with regulations of sections 40-356 and 40-357 of chapter 40. If the special land use and site plan are approved, the planning commission's actions and recommendations shall be submitted, in writing, to the city commission. 
(e)  Following approval of the special land use and site plan by the planning commission, the city commission shall make a final determination regarding the application. 
(f)  If the city commission authorizes construction of the WCF, the commission shall then determine the appropriate amount of cash, irrevocable surety bond, or irrevocable letter of credit to be kept on file with the city to ensure that adequate funds will be available to maintain, repair or remove the WCF if abandoned or in need of repair. It shall be a continuing requirement of any permission given to operate a WCF in the city that the applicant keep in force such cash deposit, irrevocable surety bond, or irrevocable letter of credit as required by the city. 
(g)  Prior to installing, constructing, expanding, extending or modifying the WCF, the applicant shall obtain all necessary building permits. 
(h)  Authorization by the city commission to construct a WCF shall be effective for a period of six months. If the applicant has not applied for a building permit and commenced construction by that date, the authorization for the WCF is terminated, and any permits issued shall be revoked. 
(Ord. No. 552, § 8, 8-21-2012) 
Sec. 34-168. - Application, required information. 
    It is the intent of this section to require sufficient information and plans to allow the city to make educated and informed decisions regarding the location and placement of a proposed WCF. To that end, the application shall include the following information: 
(1)  A written report verifying that, at its maximum load, including the cumulative effects of multiple facilities, the WCF meets or exceeds the Federal Communication Commission's radio frequency safety standards. The form of technology that is proposed and the signal power expressed in effective radiated power (ERP) that is proposed upon the planned service area shall be included in the report. Submission of this report is required before the city commission authorizes construction of the WCF, before improvements or upgrades on an existing WCF have begun and before any extension periods are granted. 
(2)  A site plan, drawn to scale, showing the location, size and design of all buildings and structures, including fences, signs, lighting, outdoor equipment, and a detailed landscape plan, all of which shall be designed to conform to applicable zoning and building codes. 
(3)  As-built drawings and photographs of at least three similar existing WCFs. 
(4)  The reason or purpose for the WCF with specific reference to the provider's coverage, capacity and/or quality needs and goals. 
(5)  A map that shows the planned service area of the proposed facility. 
(6)  A map that shows other existing and planned WCF that will be used by the WCF provider who is making the application. Describe the height, mounting style, and number of antennas on each WCF. 
(7)  A map that shows all existing WCFs within the city, and those WCFs within neighboring cities which are relevant in terms of potential co-location or in demonstrating the need for the proposed facility. For each location identified on the map, the following information shall be provided: 
a.  The structural capacity of the WCF and whether it can accommodate the applicant's facility, as proposed or modified; 
b.  Whether property owner approvals have been requested or obtained; and 
c.  If the location cannot be used, a disclosure of the technological considerations involved, with specific reference as to why and how the location would prohibit the applicant/provider from co-locating on the WCF. 
(8)  Other factual evidence supporting the need for the WCF, and if applicable, justification for its height and an evaluation of alternative designs which could result in lower heights or less visible structures. 
(9)  Photo documentation of existing conditions. 
(10)  A photo simulation with the proposed WCF (except for Type 1 WCF). 
(11)  A soil report from a state-licensed geotechnical engineer if the application involves a proposed Type 2 or Type 3 WCF. The soil report shall include soil boring results and statements confirming the suitability of soil conditions for the proposed WCF. 
(12)  A report from a state-licensed professional engineer which certifies the maximum number of shared users the existing or proposed tower is physically capable of supporting. The report shall include the manner in which the existing or proposed tower would fall under catastrophic conditions. The engineer's notes, drawings, and calculations shall be included with the signed certification. The certification will be utilized, along with other criteria, to determine the appropriate setbacks to be required. 
(13)  The nature and extent of the provider/applicant's ownership or lease interest in the land, buildings, structures and tower upon and within which the WCF is proposed for placement, construction or modification. 
(14)  A signed and notarized removal agreement executed by both the owner of the property and the applicant which states they promise to be bound by the removal requirements of this article. 
(15)  Proof of liability insurance of the type and amount established by the city manager. 
(16)  A description of the form of security to be posted with the city to ensure maintenance, repair and removal of the WCF. 
(17)  Copies of the following agreements: 
a.  An agreement between the land owner or duly authorized representative(s) of all persons with an ownership interest in the property and the applicant, giving the applicant the right to construct and operate the WCF on the property, including certification by all such parties that the applicant has been granted the appropriate legally recordable property rights; 
b.  An agreement between the landowner and applicant permitting future co-location at the proposed WCF, as required by the city; 
c.  An agreement to provide information about the WCF to persons interested in co-locating on the WCF and to charge market rates for co-location on the WCF; 
d.  Any other agreements the city may deem necessary to permit future co-location; 
e.  A copy of all other executed agreements between the owner of the WCF and the applicant; 
f.  A copy of all other executed agreements between the applicant and any other party whose permission or license the applicant needs in order to operate or use the WCF. 
(18)  Identity and contact information for the following: 
a.  The WCF applicant; 
b.  The owner(s) or duly authorized representative(s) of the owner(s) of the land, buildings, structures and tower upon and within which the WCF is proposed for placement, construction, or modification; 
c.  All other persons with an ownership interest in the land, buildings, structures and tower upon and within which the WCF is proposed for placement, construction, or modification; 
d.  The person to contact for engineering, maintenance and emergency purposes. 
(19)  A certification by the owner of the proposed WCF and applicant that the WCF complies with all federal and state statutes, regulations and rules, and all city ordinances. 
(20)  A certification signed by the owners of the WCF and applicant that all franchises and licenses required by federal, state or local law for the construction and/or operation of a WCF in the city have been obtained and they shall file a copy of all required franchises and licenses with the city. 
(21)  The application must be signed by the applicant, and the owner(s), or the duly authorized representative(s) of all persons with an ownership interest in the land on which the WCF is proposed to be located. 
(Ord. No. 552, § 8, 8-21-2012) 
Sec. 34-169. - Permit and security. 
    Building permits are required to proceed with the installation, construction, expansion, extension or modification of all WCFs. Such facilities shall be constructed and maintained in accordance with the approved plans, conditions imposed by the planning commission under special land use and site plan review, the authorization granted by the city commission, the permits issued, all applicable federal regulations such as the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) and the National Environmental Protection Act (NEPA), and all state and local regulations. 
    Each WCF shall be identified by a permanently installed plaque or marker, no larger than four inches by six inches, clearly identifying the wireless communications provider's name, address and contact information; and the name, address, e-mail address, and emergency phone number for the person to contact for engineering, maintenance and emergency purposes. This information shall be continuously updated during all times the WCF is on the premises. Such information shall also be posted and clearly visible on the WCF. 
    Security to ensure maintenance, repair and removal of a WCF shall be posted with the city at the time the building permit is issued. The security shall, at the election of the city, be in the form of cash, an irrevocable surety bond, or an irrevocable letter of credit. 
(Ord. No. 552, § 8, 8-21-2012) 
Sec. 34-170. - Maintenance and repair. 
    The owner(s) of the land, buildings, structures and tower, and the wireless communications providers, hereinafter referred to as the owners and providers, shall be jointly responsible for maintaining the property, buildings, structures and tower, landscaping, and antennas in a neat, safe and orderly condition, both during and after construction of the facility. 
(1)  Property, buildings, structures and landscaping. It shall be the responsibility of the owners and providers to maintain the property, buildings and other structures, and landscaping in a condition that complies with chapter 6, article VI Property Maintenance Code and chapter 14, Environment, and other applicable state and local codes. Failure to do so shall result in the issuance of a violation and penalties as described in the applicable code, or as contained in this article III. 
(2)  Towers and antennas. To ensure the structural integrity of towers and antennas, such towers and antennas shall be maintained by the owners and providers in compliance with standards contained in applicable state and local building codes and the applicable standards for towers and antennas that are published by the electronics industries association, as amended from time to time. If, upon inspection, the city concludes that a building, structure, tower or antenna fails to comply with such codes and standards and constitutes a danger to persons or property, then upon notice being provided to the owners and providers, said owners and providers shall have 30 days to bring the building, structure, tower or antenna into compliance. Failure to do so shall constitute grounds for the removal of the building, structure, tower or antenna at the owners and providers' expense. 
(Ord. No. 552, § 8, 8-21-2012) 
Sec. 34-171. - Removal of facilities. 
(a)  Authorization given by the city commission for a WCF shall terminate and the WCF shall be removed upon the occurrence of one or more of the following events: 
(1)  Abandonment. The WCF has not been used for six months or more. For purposes of this section, the removal of antennas or other equipment from the facility, or the cessation of operations, including transmission and/or reception of radio signals, shall be considered as the beginning of a period of non-use. 
(2)  Maintenance. The WCF is not maintained in accordance with the standards and regulations set forth in this article and in chapter 40 of the City Code, and written notice of the deficiencies has been delivered to the wireless communication provider and the wireless communication provider failed to correct the deficiencies within 30 days thereafter. 
(3)  Noise. The WCF is being operated at noise levels above 65 dB(A) and written notice of the violation has been delivered to the wireless communication provider and the wireless communication provider failed to correct the violation within 30 days thereafter. 
(4)  False information. The WCF applicant; the owner(s) or duly authorized representative(s) of the owner(s) of the land, buildings, structures or tower; or any other persons with an ownership interest in the land, buildings, structures or tower upon which the WCF is proposed for placement, construction, or modification provides false information in the application or other required documents. 
(5)  Noncompliance. The WCF fails to comply with applicable federal, state or local regulations, including the regulations contained in this article III. 
(b)  The wireless communication provider shall immediately notify the building official in writing as soon as the use of a WCF ceases. 
(c)  Upon the occurrence of one or more of the events specified in subsection (a) of this section, the owner(s) of the land, buildings, structures and tower; and the wireless communication providers shall immediately apply for and obtain a demolition permit, and immediately proceed with and complete the demolition, restoring the premises to the condition of the property prior to the construction of the WCF, as determined by the building official. 
(d)  If the removal of the WCF has not been lawfully completed within 60 days from date that authorization for the WCF was terminated, and the city has given at least 30 days' written notice to the wireless provider, the city may remove or procure the removal of the facility, or portions thereof, with its actual cost and reasonable administrative charge, plus attorney fees, to be drawn, collected and/or enforced from or under the security posted at the time the building permit was issued. Notwithstanding the potential or actual recovery costs from the bond or other security, the provider remains liable for the actual costs and administrative charges of demolition, removal and restoration. 
(Ord. No. 552, § 8, 8-21-2012) 
Sec. 34-172. - Violations; penalties. 
    A person who violates any provision of this article or the terms or conditions of a permit is responsible for a municipal civil infraction and the penalty prescribed in section 2-736 of the City Code. 
(Ord. No. 552, § 8, 8-21-2012) 
Secs. 34-173-34-195. - Reserved. 
Chapter 35 - RESERVED 
Chapter 36 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Michigan Vehicle Code, MCL 257.1 et seq.; regulation by local authorities, MCL 257.605, 257.606, 257.610. 

ARTICLE I. - TRAFFIC CODE 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 36-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section and the Michigan Vehicle Code, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning; 
    Alley means any minor thoroughfare, opened to public use, for purpose of ingress and egress to service adjacent buildings. 
    Bus means a motor vehicle designed for carrying 16 or more passengers, including the driver. Bus does not include a school bus. 
    Bus stand means a fixed area in the roadway parallel and adjacent to the curb to be occupied exclusively by buses for layover in operating schedules or waiting for passengers. 
    Center or centerline means a continuous or broken line marked upon the surface of a roadway by paint or otherwise to indicate each portion of the roadway allocated to traffic proceeding in the two opposite directions, and if the line is not so painted or otherwise marked, it is an imaginary line in the roadway equally distant from the edges or curbs of the roadway. 
    Curb loading zone means a space adjacent to a curb for the exclusive use of vehicles licensed as commercial vehicles during the loading or unloading of freight. 
    Electric personal assistive mobility device means a self-balancing nontandem two-wheeled device, designed to transport only one person at a time, having an electrical propulsion system with average power of 750 watts or one horsepower and a maximum speed on a paved level surface of not more than 15 miles per hour. 
    Holidays means, where used in this chapter, or on official signs erected by authorized official agencies, in addition to Sundays, the following legal holidays, to wit: New Year's Day, Memorial Day, Independence Day, Labor Day, Thanksgiving Day and Christmas Day. 
    Low-speed vehicle means a self-propelled motor vehicle to which both of the following apply: 
(1)  The vehicle conforms to the definition of low-speed vehicle under 49 CFR 571.3(b). 
(2)  The vehicle meets the standard for low-speed vehicles under 49 CFR 571.500. 
    Official time standard (whenever certain hours are named herein), shall mean standard time or daylight saving time as may be in current use in this city. 
    Parking means the placing, standing or storing of a vehicle, unattended by an operator, on a roadway, alley, parking lot or other place. 
    Stop, stopping or standing , when prohibited, means any stopping or standing of a vehicle whether occupied or not, other than the temporary stopping of a passenger vehicle for the purpose of and while actually engaged in picking up and discharging passengers, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the directions of a police officer or traffic control sign or signal. 
    Taxicab means a motor vehicle licensed as such. 
    Taxicab stand means a fixed area in the roadway parallel and adjacent to the curb set aside for taxicabs to stand or wait for passengers. 
(Code 1988, § 10.1; Ord. No. 447, § 1, 8-15-2000; Amd. of 6-11-2008, § 10.1) 
Secs. 36-2, 36-3. - Reserved. 
Sec. 36-4. - Prime facie evidence. 
    In any proceeding for violation of the parking provisions of this chapter the registration plate displayed on such motor vehicle shall constitute in evidence a prima facie presumption that the owner of such motor vehicle was the person who parked or placed such motor vehicle at the point where such violation occurred. 
(Code 1988, § 10.4; Ord. No. 305, §§ 1, 2, 12-16-1986; Ord. No. 323, § 1, 10-18-1988; Ord. No. 347, § 1, 7-25-1989; Ord. No. 353, § 1, 6-19-1990; Ord. No. 356, § 1, 2-18-1992; Ord. No. 364, § 1, 12-15-1992; Ord. No. 376, § 1, 12-13-1994; Ord. No. 447, § 4, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-5. - Cancellation of complaint. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to cancel or solicit the cancellation of any valid traffic citation or complaint issued to an alleged violator of this chapter, city ordinance or the motor vehicle laws of this state. 
(Code 1988, § 10.5; Ord. No. 447, § 5, 8-15-2000) 
Secs. 36-6-36-50. - Reserved.

Sec. 36-51. - Bureau established.

(Code 1988, § 10.51) 
Sec. 36-52. - Violation payments. 
    Any person who shall be charged with violating any provision of this Code corresponding to an offense listed in the schedule contained in this article, may, if such person is a first offender, within the past 12 months, in lieu of being required to attend court as a respondent in a criminal case, make the payments to the violations bureau for the offense so charged, in the amount scheduled for such offense. 
(Code 1988, § 10.52)

(1)  Abandoned car: ..... $50.00 
(2)  Handicap parking: ..... $150.00 
(3)  No parking 3:00 a.m. - 5:00 a.m.: ..... $10.00 
(3)  All other parking: ..... $25.00 
(Code 1988, § 10.53; Ord. No. 601, § 1, 4-10-2018)

DIVISION 3. - MOTOR CARRIER SAFETY[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Motor carrier safety act of 1963, MCL 480.11 et seq. 

Sec. 36-80. - Motor carrier safety act adopted. 
    The Motor Carrier Safety Act of 1963, Public Act No. 181 of 1963 (MCL 480.11 et seq.), including regulations adopted thereby, is hereby adopted by reference as an ordinance for the city. 
(Code 1988, § 10.80; Ord. No. 365, § 1, 12-15-1992) 
Sec. 36-81. - Modifications. 
(a)  The following provisions of title 49 of the Code of Federal Regulations as of February 28, 1990, and adopted by the state in section 5 of the Motor Carrier Safety Act of 1963 (MCL 480.15), with modifications, are hereby further modified as stated in subsection (b) of this section. 
(b)  Motor carrier safety regulations, being 49 CFR 387, 390 through 393, 395 through 397 and 399, including appendices C, D, E, and G, shall be modified as follows: 
(1)  Where the term "United States Department of Transportation," "Federal Highway Administration," "director," or "Bureau of Motor Carrier Safety" appear, it shall be construed to refer to the city or the city department of public safety. 
(2)  Where the term "interstate" appears, it shall mean intrastate or interstate, or both, as applicable. 
(3)  Where the term "special agent of the Federal Highway Administration" or "administration personnel" appear, it shall be construed to mean a peace officer or an enforcement member or vehicle inspector of the city department of public safety. 
(Code 1988, § 10.81; Ord. No. 365, § 1, 12-15-1992) 
Sec. 36-82. - Copies on file. 
    The city clerk shall maintain copies of the Motor Carrier Safety Act of 1963 and Federal Regulations adopted by reference in this article on file in the city clerk's office at all times for inspection or review by the public. 
(Code 1988, § 10.82; Ord. No. 365, § 1, 12-15-1992) 
Sec. 36-83. - Violations. 
    Any driver or operator who violates this article or an act, rule or regulation adopted by reference in this article, or any owner or user of any bus, truck, truck tractor, or trailer, or certain other motor vehicles or any officer or agent of any individual, partnership, corporation, or association or their lessees or receivers appointed by any court which is the owner or user of any vehicle, who requires or permits the driver or operator to operate or drive any bus, truck, truck tractor, or trailer, or certain other motor vehicles in violation of this article or an act, rule or regulation adopted by reference in this article, is guilty of a misdemeanor for each violation. 
(Code 1988, § 10.83; Ord. No. 365, § 1, 12-15-1992) 
Secs. 36-84-36-214. - Reserved.

Sec. 36-215. - Registration of vehicle.

A person who violates this section is responsible for a civil infraction.

(Code 1988, § 10.251b; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-251c. - Reserved. 
Sec. 36-251d. - Permitting unlicensed person to use motorcycle.

(Code 1988, § 10.251d; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Secs. 36-252-36-254. - Reserved. 
Sec. 36-255. - Operation without valid registration certificate and plates. 
(a)  No person shall operate, nor shall an owner knowingly permit to be operated, upon any street a vehicle required to be registered under the Michigan Vehicle Code unless a valid registration plate issued for the vehicle for the current registration year is attached to and displayed on the vehicle as required by the Michigan Vehicle Code. 
(b)  A person who violates this section is responsible for a civil infraction. However, if the vehicle is a commercial vehicle required to be registered according to the schedule of elected gross vehicle weights under section 801(l)(k) of the Michigan Vehicle Code (MCL 257.801(1)(k)), the person is guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by imprisonment for not more than 90 days or a fine of not more than $500.00, or both. 
(Code 1988, § 10.255; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000; Ord. No. 477, § 1, 6-17-2003) 
Sec. 36-256. - Unlawful lending or use of certificate of title, registration certificate, plates or permit. 
    No person shall lend to another person, or knowingly permit the use of, any certificate of title, registration certificate, registration plate, special plate, or permit issued to such person if the person receiving or using the certificate of title, registration certificate, registration plate, special plate, or permit would not be entitled to the use thereof. 
(Code 1988, § 10.256; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Secs. 36-257-36-300. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - OPERATOR'S AND CHAUFFEUR'S LICENSE 

Sec. 36-301. - License required. 
    No person shall drive a motor vehicle upon a street unless such person has a valid operator's or chauffeur's license and the appropriate endorsement for the type and class of vehicle being driven or towed as provided in the Michigan Vehicle Code. 
(Code 1988, § 10.301; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Secs. 36-302-36-305. - Reserved. 
Sec. 36-306. - Temporary instruction permit; operation of motor vehicle without operator's license or permit; temporary driver education certificates. 
(a)  The secretary of state, upon receiving from a person who is 18 years of age or older an application for a temporary instruction permit, may issue that permit entitling the applicant, while carrying the permit, to drive a motor vehicle other than a motor vehicle requiring an endorsement under section 312a of the Michigan Vehicle Code (MCL 257.312a) or a vehicle group designation under section 312e of the Michigan Vehicle Code (MCL 257.312e) upon the highways for a period of 180 days when accompanied by a licensed adult operator or chauffeur who is actually occupying a seat beside the driver. 
(b)  A student enrolled in a driver education program or a motorcycle safety course approved by the department of the state may operate a motor vehicle without holding an operator's license or permit while under the direct supervision of the program instructor. 
(c)  A student enrolled in an approved driver education program and who has successfully completed ten hours of classroom instruction and the equivalent of two hours of behind-the-wheel training may be issued a temporary driver education certificate furnished by the department of state which authorizes a student to drive a motor vehicle, other than a motor vehicle requiring an endorsement pursuant to section 312a of the Michigan Vehicle Code or a vehicle group designation pursuant to section 312e of the Michigan Vehicle Code when accompanied by a licensed parent or guardian, or when accompanied by a nonlicensed parent or guardian and a licensed adult for the purpose of receiving additional instruction until the end of the student's driver education course. 
(d)  The secretary of state, upon receiving proper application from a person 16 or 17 years of age who is enrolled in or has successfully completed an approved motorcycle safety course under section 811a of the Michigan Vehicle Code (MCL 257.811a), or a person who is 18 years of age or older and who holds a valid operator's or chauffeur's license, may issue a motorcycle temporary instruction permit, entitling the applicant, while carrying the permit, to operate a motorcycle upon the public streets and highways for a period of 180 days, but only when under the constant visual supervision of a licensed motorcycle operator at least 18 years of age. The applicant shall not operate the motorcycle at night or with a passenger. 
(e)  Except as prohibited under federal law, the secretary of state, upon receiving proper application from a person who is 18 years of age or older, who holds a valid operator's or chauffeur's license other than a restricted license, and who has passed the knowledge test for an original vehicle group designation or endorsement, may issue a temporary instruction permit entitling the person while carrying the permit to drive a vehicle requiring a vehicle group designation or vehicle group endorsement under section 312e of the Michigan Vehicle Code (MCL 257.312e) upon the streets and highways, for a period of 180 days, but only when accompanied by a licensed adult operator or chauffeur who is licensed with the appropriate vehicle group designation and endorsement for the vehicle group being driven and who is actually occupying a seat beside the driver, or behind the driver if the permittee is driving a bus or school bus. In addition, if a permittee is enrolled in a driver training program for drivers of motor vehicles requiring a vehicle group designation or vehicle group endorsement under section 312e of the Michigan Vehicle Code, which program is conducted by a college; university; commercial driver training school licensed by the department pursuant to Public Act No. 369 of 1974 (MCL 256.601 to 256.612); or a local or intermediate school district, the permittee may drive a vehicle requiring a vehicle group designation or vehicle group endorsement on the streets and highways of this state for a period of 180 days when accompanied by an instructor licensed with the appropriate vehicle group designation and endorsement for the vehicle being driven who is either occupying the seat beside the driver or in direct visual and audio communication with the permittee. A person issued a temporary instruction permit under this section shall not operate a vehicle designed to carry 16 or more passengers that is transporting passengers except with an instructor licensed with the appropriate vehicle group designation and endorsement for the vehicle being driven or a driver skills test examiner. 
(f)  It shall be unlawful for an operator holding an instruction permit or a driver education certificate to operate a motor vehicle unless accompanied by a licensed adult operator or chauffeur who is actually occupying a seat beside the driver. 
(Code 1988, § 10.306; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000; Amd. of 6-11-2008, § 10.306) 
Secs. 36-307-36-310. - Reserved. 
Sec. 36-311. - Presentation of license. 
    No person shall operate a motor vehicle without his operator's or chauffeur's license, or the receipt described in section 311a of the Michigan Vehicle Code (MCL257.811a), in his immediate possession at all times, or fail to display the same upon demand of any public safety officer who shall identify himself as such. 
(Code 1988, § 10.311; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-312. - Restrictions. 
    No person shall violate a restriction imposed in a restricted license. 
(Code 1988, § 10.312; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Secs. 36-313-36-319c. - Reserved. 
Sec. 36-319d. - Prohibition on operation of commercial vehicle with certain blood alcohol level. 
(a)  A person, whether licensed or not, shall not operate a commercial motor vehicle within this state with an alcohol content of 0.015 grams or more per 100 milliliters of blood, per 210 liters of breath, or per 67 milliliters of urine. 
(b)  A peace officer who has reasonable cause to believe that a person was operating a commercial motor vehicle within the state with an alcohol content of 0.015 grams or more per 100 milliliters of blood, per 210 liters of breath, or per 67 milliliters of urine, as measured by a preliminary chemical breath analysis or a chemical test provided under section 36-625a, shall order the person out-of-service immediately for 24 hours, which shall begin upon issuance of the order. 
(c)  A peace officer shall immediately order a person who refuses to submit to a preliminary chemical breath analysis requested or a chemical test provided under section 36-625a out-of-service for 24 hours, which shall begin when the order is issued. 
(d)  A person ordered out-of-service under this section, a local ordinance substantially corresponding to this section, or a law or local ordinance of another state substantially corresponding to this section shall not operate a commercial motor vehicle within this state during the 24-hour out-of-service period. 
(e)  A peace officer who issues an out-of-service order under this section shall provide for the safe and expeditious disposition of a product carried by a commercial motor vehicle that is hazardous or would result in damage to the vehicle, human health, or the environment. 
(f)  Failure to comply with subsection (a) of this section is not a civil infraction or criminal violation of this act. 
(g)  A person who violates subsection (d) of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by imprisonment for not more than 90 days or a fine of not more than $100.00, or both. 
(Code 1988, § 10.319d; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Secs. 36-320, 36-321. - Reserved. 
Sec. 36-321a. - Failure to answer citation or notice. 
    No person shall fail to answer a citation or a notice to appear in court for a violation of this chapter or for any matter pending, or fail to comply with an order or judgment of the court, including, but not limited to, paying all fines, costs, fees, and assessments. A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by imprisonment for not more 93 days or a fine of not more than $100.00, or both. 
(Code 1988, § 10.321a; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Secs. 36-322, 36-323. - Reserved. 
Sec. 36-324. - False or canceled license; presentation of fictitious name or information. 
    It shall be unlawful for a person to do any of the following: 
(1)  Operate any motor vehicle when such person's operator's or chauffeur's license is then canceled, revoked, suspended, altered or denied. 
(2)  Display or cause or permit to be displayed, or have in his possession any operator's or chauffeur's license knowing such operator's or chauffeur's license to be fictitious or to have been canceled, revoked, suspended, or altered. 
(3)  Lend to or knowingly permit use of, by one not entitled to its use, the operator's or chauffeur's license issued to the person lending or permitting the use of such operator's or chauffeur's license. 
(4)  Display or represent as his own any operator's or chauffeur's license not issued to the person displaying the operator's or chauffeur's license. 
(5)  Fail or refuse to surrender to a public safety officer for forwarding to the department of state, upon demand, any operator's or chauffeur's license which has been suspended, canceled or revoked as provided by law. 
(6)  Alter or otherwise cause to be altered any operator's or chauffeur's license so as to knowingly make a false statement or knowingly conceal a material fact in order to misrepresent as one's own the operator's or chauffeur's license. 
(7)  Use or have in possession in committing a crime an operator's or chauffeur's license that has been altered or that is used to knowingly make a false statement or to knowingly conceal a material fact in order to misrepresent as one's own the operator's or chauffeur's license. 
(8)  Furnish to a peace officer false, forged, fictitious, or misleading verbal or written information identifying the person as another person, if the person is detained for a violation of this chapter or the Michigan Vehicle Code. 
(Code 1988, § 10.324; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-325. - Permitting unlicensed driver to drive. 
    No person shall cause or knowingly permit any minor to drive a motor vehicle upon a street as an operator, unless the minor has first obtained a license to drive a motor vehicle under the provisions of the Michigan Vehicle Code or is otherwise qualified to operate a motor vehicle under the Michigan Vehicle Code. 
(Code 1988, § 10.325; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-326. - Unlawful to permit violations of act. 
    No person shall knowingly authorize or permit a motor vehicle owned by him or under his control to be driven by any person in violation of any of the provisions of this ordinance or the Michigan Vehicle Code. 
(Code 1988, § 10.326; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-327. - Unlawful to employ unlicensed chauffeur. 
    No person shall knowingly employ any chauffeur to operate a motor vehicle who is not licensed as provided in the Michigan Vehicle Code. 
(Code 1988, § 10.327; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-328. - Evidence of vehicle insurance; production on request of police officer. 
(a)  The owner of a motor vehicle who operates or permits the operation of the motor vehicle within the city or the operator of the motor vehicle shall produce, pursuant to subsection (b) of this section, upon the request of a public safety officer, evidence that the motor vehicle is insured under Public Act No. 218 of 1956 (MCL 500.3101 to 500.3179). An owner or operator of a motor vehicle who fails to produce evidence under this subsection when requested to produce that evidence is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(b)  A certificate of insurance, if issued by an insurance company, which certificate states that security which meets the requirements of sections 3101 and 3102 of Public Act No. 218 of 1956 (MCL 500.3101 and 500.3102) is in force, shall be accepted as prima facie evidence that insurance is in force for the motor vehicle described in the certificate of insurance until the expiration date shown on the certificate. The certificate, in addition to describing the motor vehicle for which insurance is in effect, shall state the name of each person named on the policy, policy declaration, or declaration certificate whose operation of the vehicle would cause the liability coverage of that insurance to become void. 
(c)  If an owner of a motor vehicle is determined to be responsible for a violation of subsection (a) of this section, the court in which the civil infraction is entered may require the person to surrender his operator's or chauffeur's license unless proof that the vehicle has insurance meeting the requirements of sections 3101 and 3102 of Public Act No. 218 (MCL 500.3101 and 500.3102) is submitted to the court. If the court requires the license to be surrendered, the court shall immediately destroy the license and shall forward to the secretary of state an abstract of the court record as required by section 732 of the Michigan Vehicle Code (MCL 257.732). 
(d)  If, before the appearance date on the citation, the person submits proof to the court that the motor vehicle had insurance meeting the requirements of sections 3101 and 3102 of the Insurance Code of 1956, Public Act No. 218 of (MCL 500.3101 and 500.3102), at the time the violation of subsection (a) of this section occurred, all of the following apply: 
(1)  The court shall not assess a fine or costs. 
(2)  The court shall not cause an abstract of the court record to be forwarded to the secretary of state. 
(3)  The court may assess a fee of not more than $25.00, which shall be paid to the court funding unit. 
(e)  An owner or operator of a motor vehicle who knowingly produces false evidence under this section is guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(f)  This section does not apply to the owner or operator of a motor vehicle that is registered in a state other than this state or a foreign country or province. 
(g)  A nonresident owner or registrant of a motor vehicle or motorcycle not registered in this state shall not operate or permit the motor vehicle or motorcycle to be operated in this state for an aggregate of more than 30 days in any calendar year unless he continuously maintains security for the payment of benefits pursuant to this article. 
(h)  An owner or registrant of a motor vehicle or motorcycle with respect to which security is required, who operates the motor vehicle or motorcycle or permits it to be operated upon a public highway in this state, without having in full force and effect security complying with this section or section 3101 or 3103 of the insurance code of the state (MCL 500.3101 or 500.3103) is guilty of a misdemeanor. A person who operates a motor vehicle or motorcycle upon a public highway in this state, with the knowledge that the owner or registrant does not have security in full force and effect, is guilty of a misdemeanor. A person convicted of a misdemeanor under this section shall be fined not less than $200.00 or more than $500.00, imprisoned for not more than 90 days, or both. 
(Code 1988, § 10.328; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000; Amd. of 6-11-2008, § 10.328) 
Secs. 36-329-36-601. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - OBEDIENCE AND EFFECT OF TRAFFIC LAWS 

Sec. 36-602. - Obedience required. 
    No person shall refuse to comply with a lawful order or direction of a public safety officer, crossing guard, or other authorized governmental employee or officer when that person, for public interest and safety, is guiding, directing, controlling or regulating traffic on a street. 
(Code 1988, § 10.602; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-602a. - Failure to obey public safety officer's signal. 
    No person operating a motor vehicle shall willfully fail to obey a direction given by hand, voice, emergency light, or siren, a visual or audible signal by a public safety officer acting in the lawful performance of his duty, directing the person to bring his motor vehicle to a stop. This section does not apply unless the public safety officer giving the signal is in uniform and the officer's vehicle is identified as an official police or public safety vehicle. 
(Code 1988, § 10.602a; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000; Amd. of 6-11-2008, § 10.602a) 
Sec. 36-603. - Emergency vehicle privileges. 
(a)  The driver of any authorized emergency vehicle when responding to an emergency call, but not while returning therefrom, or when pursuing or apprehending a person who has violated or is violating the law or is charged with or suspected of violating the law may exercise the privileges set forth in this section, but subject to the conditions herein stated. 
(b)  The driver of an authorized emergency vehicle may do any of the following: 
(1)  Park or stand, irrespective of the provisions of this division. 
(2)  Proceed past a red or stop signal or stop sign, but only after slowing down as may be necessary for safe operation. 
(3)  Exceed the prima facie speed limits so long as he does not endanger life or property. 
(4)  Disregard regulations governing direction of movement or turning in a specified direction. 
(c)  The exemptions herein granted to an authorized emergency vehicle apply only when the driver of any said vehicle while in motion sounds an audible signal by bell, siren, air horn or exhaust whistle as may be reasonably necessary, except as provided in subsection (d) of this section, and when the vehicle is equipped with at least one lighted lamp displaying a flashing, oscillating or rotating red or blue light visible under normal atmospheric conditions from 500 feet in a 360-degree arc unless it is not advisable to equip a police vehicle operating as an authorized emergency vehicle with a flashing, oscillating or rotating light visible in a 360-degree arc. In those cases, a police vehicle shall display a flashing, oscillating, or rotating red or blue light visible under normal atmospheric conditions from a distance of 500 feet to the front of the vehicle. Only police vehicles that are publicly owned shall be equipped with a flashing, oscillating, or rotating blue light that when activated is visible under normal atmospheric conditions from a distance of 500 feet in a 360-degree arc. 
(d)  A police vehicle shall retain the exemptions granted in this section to an authorized emergency vehicle without sounding an audible signal if the police vehicle is engaged in an emergency run where silence is required. 
(Code 1988, § 10.603; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000; Amd. of 6-11-2008, § 10.603) 
Sec. 36-604. - Application to animal-drawn vehicles. 
    A person riding an animal or driving an animal-drawn vehicle upon a roadway shall be granted all of the rights and shall be subject to all the duties, criminal penalties and civil sanctions applicable to the driver of a vehicle by this division and the Michigan Vehicle Code, except as to special regulations of this division or those provisions of this division which by their very nature may not have application. 
(Code 1988, § 10.604; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-605. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - TRAFFIC CONTROL SIGNS, SIGNALS, DEVICES 

Sec. 36-606. - Traffic control orders. 
(a)  The city manager is hereby authorized to adopt rules and regulations concerning stopping or yielding right-of-way at intersections; restrictions on stopping, standing or parking; designation of one-way streets, roadways or alleys; establishment of crosswalks, turn restrictions; through streets; play streets; angle parking; all night parking; curb loading zones; public carrier stands; parking meter zones and spaces; weight restrictions; establishment of no passing zones; increasing or decreasing prima facie lawful speed limits; and the establishment, maintenance and removal of traffic control signs, signals and devices, in accordance with the provisions of this section. Such rules and regulations shall be issued as traffic control orders and shall become effective upon being filed with the city clerk and upon erection of adequate signs or signals giving notice of the existence of such regulation if such signs or signals are required by the provisions of this chapter pertaining to such regulation. Traffic control orders may be issued by the city manager, on his own authority, but when so issued shall be known as temporary traffic control orders and shall not be effective after the expiration of 90 days from the date of filing. Permanent traffic control orders shall be issued by the city manager and shall be approved by the city commission. Temporary orders shall become permanent orders upon approval by the city commission but notice of such approval shall be filed with the city clerk as in the case of an original traffic control order. All such orders and any action modifying or repealing such orders shall be kept in a separate book by the city clerk to be known as the traffic control order book. 
(b)  A person who fails to observe and obey the instructions of any authorized traffic control sign, signal or device is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 10.606; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-607. - Current regulations. 
    All intersection stops and yield right-of-way requirements, regulations on stopping, standing or parking, one-way streets, roadways and alleys, crosswalks, restricted turns, through streets, play streets, angle parking zones, all night parking restrictions, curb loading zones, public carrier stands, parking meter zones and spaces, weight restrictions, no-passing zones and traffic control devices heretofore established and effective on the effective date of this Code, shall be deemed established under permanent traffic control orders and shall remain effective until rescinded or modified by a traffic control order. 
(Code 1988, § 10.607; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Secs. 36-608-36-610. - Reserved. 
Sec. 36-611. - Instructions of traffic control device not to be disobeyed. 
(a)  No person shall disobey the instructions of a traffic control device placed in accordance with an effective traffic control order. Traffic control devices shall have the meanings and indicate and apply to the actions of persons and vehicles as provided in the Michigan Vehicle Code and this division. 
(b)  No person shall drive upon or through private property, or upon or through public property which is not a street for the purpose of avoiding obedience to a traffic control device placed in accordance with an effective control order. 
(c)  A person who violates this section shall be responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 10.611; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-612. - Traffic control signals. 
(a)  When traffic is controlled by traffic control signals, not less than one signal shall be located over the traveled portion of the roadway so as to give drivers a clear indication of the right-of-way assignment from their normal positions approaching the intersection. The vehicle signals shall exhibit different colored lights successively, one at a time, or with arrows. Red arrow and yellow arrow indications have the same meaning as the corresponding circular indications, except that they apply only to drivers of vehicles intending to make the movement indicated by the arrow. The following colors shall be used and the terms and lights shall indicate and shall apply to drivers of vehicles as follows: 
(1)  If the signal exhibits a green indication, vehicular traffic facing the signal may proceed straight through or turn right or left unless a sign at that place prohibits either turn. Vehicular traffic, including vehicles turning right or left, shall yield the right-of-way to other vehicles and to pedestrians and bicyclists lawfully within the intersection or an adjacent crosswalk at the time the signal is exhibited. 
(2)  If the signal exhibits a steady yellow indication, vehicular traffic facing the signal shall stop before entering the nearest crosswalk at the intersection or at a limit line when marked, but if the stop cannot be made in safety, a vehicle may be driven cautiously through the intersection. 
(3)  If the signal exhibits a steady red indication, the following shall apply: 
a.  Vehicular traffic facing a steady red signal alone shall stop before entering the crosswalk on the near side of the intersection or at a limit line when marked or, if there is no crosswalk or limit line, before entering the intersection, and shall remain standing until a green indication is shown, except as provided in subsection (a)(3)b of this section. 
b.  Vehicular traffic facing a steady red signal, after stopping before entering the crosswalk on the near side of the intersection or at a limit line when marked or, if there is no crosswalk or limit line, before entering the intersection, may make a right turn from a one-way or two-way street into a two-way street or into a one-way street carrying traffic in the direction of the right turn or a left turn from a one-way or two-way street into a one-way roadway carrying traffic in the direction of the left turn unless prohibited by sign, signal, marking, light, or other traffic control device. The vehicular traffic shall yield the right-of-way to pedestrians and bicyclists lawfully within an adjacent crosswalk and to other traffic lawfully using the intersection. 
(4)  If the signal exhibits a steady green arrow indication, vehicular traffic facing the green arrow signal, shown alone or in combination with another indication, may cautiously enter the intersection only to make the movement indicated by the arrow, or other movement permitted by other indications shown at the same time. The vehicular traffic shall yield the right-of-way to pedestrians and bicyclists lawfully within an adjacent crosswalk and to other traffic lawfully using the intersection. 
(b)  If a traffic control signal is erected and maintained at a place other than an intersection, the provisions of this section shall be applicable except as to those provisions which by their nature cannot have application. Any stop required shall be made at a sign or marking on the pavement indicating where the stop shall be made but, in the absence of a sign or marking, the stop shall be made at the signal. 
(c)  A person who violates subsection (a) or (b) of this section is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(d)  A driver of a vehicle who approaches a person using a wheelchair or a device to aid the person to walk at a crosswalk or any other pedestrian crossing shall take such precautions as may be necessary to avoid accident or injury to the person using the wheelchair or device. A person who violates this subsection is guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(e)  A sign prohibiting a turn on a red signal as provided in subsection (a)(3)b of this section shall be located above or adjacent to the traffic control signal or as close as possible to the point where the turn is made, or at both locations, so that one or more of the signs are visible to a vehicle operator intending to turn, at the point where the turn is made. An additional sign may be used at the far side of the intersection in the direct line of vision of the turning vehicle operator. 
(Code 1988, § 10.612; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000; Amd. of 6-11-2008, § 10.612) 
Sec. 36-613. - Application of traffic control signals to pedestrians in absence of pedestrian control signals; special pedestrian control signals. 
(a)  If special pedestrian control signals are not utilized, the regular traffic control signals as indicated in section 36-612 shall apply to pedestrians as follows: 
(1)  Green indication. Pedestrians facing the signal may proceed across the roadway within a marked or unmarked crosswalk. 
(2)  Steady yellow indication. Pedestrians facing the signal are advised that there is insufficient time to cross the roadway and a pedestrian then starting to cross shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles. 
(3)  Steady red indication. Pedestrians facing the signal shall not enter the highway unless they can do so safely and without interfering with vehicular traffic. 
(4)  Red with arrow. Pedestrians facing the signal shall not enter the highway unless they can do so safely without interfering with vehicular traffic. 
(b)  If special pedestrian control signals are installed, they shall be placed at the far end of each crosswalk and shall indicate a "walk" or "don't walk" interval. These special signals shall apply to pedestrians only to the exclusion of a regular traffic control signal or signals which may be present at the same location, as follows: 
(1)  Walk interval. Pedestrians facing the signal may proceed across the highway in the direction of the signal and shall be given the right-of-way by the drivers of all vehicles. 
(2)  Don't walk (steady burning or flashing) interval. A pedestrian shall not start to cross the highway in the direction of the signals, but a pedestrian who has partially completed crossing on the walk interval of the signal shall proceed to a sidewalk or safety island while the don't walk interval of the signal is showing. 
(c)  A person who violates this section is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 10.613; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Secs. 36-613a-36-613c. - Reserved. 
Sec. 36-613d. - Failure to stop on signal of school crossing guard. 
(a)  A driver of a motor vehicle who fails to stop when a school crossing guard is in a school crossing and is holding a stop sign in an upright position visible to approaching vehicular traffic is guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(b)  In a proceeding for a violation of this section, proof that the particular vehicle described in the citation, complaint, or warrant was used in the violation, together with proof that the defendant named in the citation complaint or warrant was the registered owner of the vehicle at the time of the violation, constitutes in evidence a presumption that the registered owner of the vehicle was the driver of the vehicle at the time of the violation. 
(Code 1988, § 10.613d; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-614. - Flashing red or yellow signals. 
(a)  If flashing red or yellow signals are used, they shall require obedience by vehicular traffic as follows: 
(1)  Flashing red (stop signal). When a red lens is illuminated by rapid intermittent flashes, drivers of vehicles shall stop before entering the nearest crosswalk at an intersection or at a limit line when marked and the right to proceed shall be subject to the rules applicable after making a stop at a stop sign. 
(2)  Flashing yellow (caution signal). When a yellow lens is illuminated with rapid intermittent flashes, drivers of vehicles may proceed through the intersection or past the signal only with caution. 
(b)  A person who violates this section is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 10.614; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-615. - Unauthorized display of signs. 
(a)  No person shall place, maintain, or display along any street or upon any structure in or over any street any sign, signal, marking, device, blinking, oscillating or rotating light, decoration or banner which is or purports to be or is in imitation or resembles or which can be mistaken for a traffic control device or railroad sign or signal, or which attempts to direct the movement of traffic, or which hides from view or interferes with the effectiveness of any traffic control device or any railroad sign or signal unless authorized by law or a duly authorized public body or official. No person shall place or maintain on any street any traffic sign or signal bearing thereon any commercial advertising. 
(b)  No person shall place, maintain or display along any street any blinking, oscillating or rotating light sufficiently similar in color and design that may be mistaken for the distinguishing lights authorized by law for emergency vehicles or that creates a hazard for the safety of drivers using said streets. 
(c)  Every such prohibited sign, signal or marking is hereby declared to be a nuisance and the director of public safety is hereby empowered to remove the same or cause it to be removed without notice. This shall not be deemed to prohibit the erection upon private property, adjacent to streets, of signs giving useful directional information and of a type that cannot be mistaken for traffic signs or signals. 
(d)  Decorations or banners which may be placed over the traveled portion of any street or highway shall be placed no closer than ten feet on either side of traffic lights or signals and shall be so placed as to not obstruct a clear view of such traffic lights or signals. 
(Code 1988, § 10.615; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000; Amd. of 6-11-2008, § 10.615) 
Sec. 36-616. - Damaging traffic control device or sign or signal. 
    No person shall without lawful authority attempt to or in fact alter, deface, injure, knock down or remove any traffic control device or any sign or signal or any inscription, shield or insignia thereof, or any part thereof. 
(Code 1988, § 10.616; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-616a. - Possession of portable signal preemption device. 
(a)  Except as provided in subsections (b) and (c) of this section, a person shall not possess a portable signal preemption device. 
(b)  This section does not apply to any of the following: 
(1)  A law enforcement agency in the course of providing law enforcement services. 
(2)  A fire station or a firefighter in the course of providing fire prevention or fire extinguishing services. 
(3)  An emergency medical service or ambulance in the course of providing emergency medical transportation or ambulance services. 
(4)  An operator, passenger, or owner of an authorized emergency vehicle in the course of his emergency duties. 
(c)  This section does not apply to the following: 
(1)  A mail or package delivery service or employee or agent of a mail or package delivery service in the course of shipping or delivering a portable signal preemption device. 
(2)  An employee or agent of a portable signal preemption device manufacturer or retailer in the course of his employment in providing, selling, manufacturing, or transporting a portable signal preemption device to an individual or agency described in this subsection. 
(d)  A person who violates subsection (a) of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by imprisonment for not more than 90 days or a fine of not more than $500.00, or both. 
(e)  As used in this section, the term "portable signal preemption device" means a device that, if activated by a person, is capable of changing a traffic control signal to green out of sequence. 
(Amd. of 6-11-2008, § 10.616a) 
Sec. 36-617. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 8. - ACCIDENTS 

Sec. 36-617a. - Stop at scene. 
    The driver of any vehicle who knows or who has reason to believe that he has been involved in an accident resulting in injury to or death of any person shall immediately stop such vehicle at the scene of such accident or as close thereto as possible, but shall then forthwith return to and in every event remain at the scene of the accident until he has fulfilled the requirements of section 36-619, or the driver may immediately report the accident to the nearest or most convenient police agency or officer to fulfill the requirements of section 36-619 if there is a reasonable and honest belief that remaining at the scene will result in further harm. Every such stop shall be made without obstructing traffic more than is necessary. 
(Code 1988, § 10.617a; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000; Amd. of 6-11-2008, § 10.617a) 
Sec. 36-618. - Stopping at scene of accident resulting in damage to vehicle; penalty. 
    The driver of any vehicle who knows or who has reason to believe that he has been involved in an accident resulting only in damage to a vehicle which is driven or attended by any person shall immediately stop such vehicle at the scene of such accident and shall remain there until he has fulfilled the requirements of section 36-619, or the driver may immediately report the accident to the nearest or most convenient police agency or officer to fulfill the requirements of section 36-619 if there is a reasonable and honest belief that remaining at the scene will result in further harm. Every such stop shall be made without obstructing traffic more than is necessary. 
(Code 1988, § 10.618; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000; Amd. of 6-11-2008, § 10.618) 
Sec. 36-619. - Give information and render aid. 
    The driver of any vehicle who knows or who has reason to believe that he has been involved in an accident resulting in injury to or death of any person or damage to any vehicle which is driven or attended by any person shall give his name, address, and the registration number of the vehicle he is driving, also the name and address of the owner, and exhibit his operator's or chauffeur's license to a public safety officer or the person struck or the driver of, or occupant of, or person attending, any vehicle collided with and where practical shall render to any person injured in such accident reasonable assistance in securing medical aid or transportation of injured persons. 
(Code 1988, § 10.619; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-620. - Duty of driver colliding with vehicle. 
    The driver of any vehicle which collides upon either public or private property with any vehicle which is attended or unattended shall immediately stop and shall then and there either locate and notify the operator or owner of such vehicle of the name and address of the driver and owner of the vehicle striking the vehicle or, if such owner cannot be located, shall forthwith report it to the nearest or most convenient police officer. 
(Code 1988, § 10.620; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-621. - Duty upon striking fixtures on a street or roadway. 
    The driver of any vehicle involved in an accident resulting only in damage to personal property or fixtures legally upon or adjacent to a street shall take reasonable steps to locate and notify the owner or person in charge of such property of such fact and of his name and address and of the registration number of the vehicle he is driving, and shall upon request exhibit his operator's or chauffeur's license and, if such owner cannot be found, shall make a report of such accident to the nearest and most convenient public safety officer. 
(Code 1988, § 10.621; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-622. - Report accidents. 
    The driver of a motor vehicle involved in an accident that injures or kills any person, or that damages property to an apparent extent totaling $1,000.00 or more, shall immediately report that accident at the nearest or most convenient police station, or to the nearest or most convenient public safety officer. The officer receiving the report, or his commanding officer, shall immediately forward each report to the director of state police on forms prescribed by the director of state police. The forms shall be completed in full by the investigating officer. 
(Code 1988, § 10.622; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000; Amd. of 6-11-2008, § 10.622) 
Sec. 36-622a. - When passenger to report. 
    Whenever the driver of a vehicle is physically incapable of making a required accident report and there was another occupant in the vehicle at the time of the accident capable of making a report, such occupant shall make or cause to be made said report. 
(Code 1988, § 10.622a; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-623. - Garages to report. 
    The person in charge of any garage or repair shop to which is brought any motor vehicle which shows evidence of having been involved in an accident, or struck by any bullet, shall report to the public safety department immediately after such vehicle is received and before any repairs are made to such vehicle, giving the engine number, registration number and the name and address of the owner and operator of such vehicle, together with any other discernible information. 
(Code 1988, § 10.623; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-623a. - Removing glass from street. 
    Any person removing a wrecked or damaged vehicle from a street shall remove any glass or other injurious substance dropped upon the street from such vehicle. 
(Code 1988, § 10.623a; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-624. - Accident reports confidential. 
    All accident reports shall be without prejudice to the individual reporting, and shall be for the confidential use of the public safety department and the commissioner of state police, except that the public safety department may disclose the identity of a person involved in an accident when such identity is not otherwise known or when such person denies his presence at such accident. No such report shall be used as evidence in any court action arising out of an accident, except that the public safety department shall furnish, upon demand of any person who has or claims to have made such a report or upon demand of any court, a certificate showing that a specified accident report has or has not been made to the public safety department solely to prove a compliance or a failure to comply with the requirement that such a report be made to the department. 
(Code 1988, § 10.624; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
DIVISION 9. - OPERATION OF VEHICLES GENERALLY 

Sec. 36-624a. - Possession of alcoholic liquor in passenger compartment; prohibition. 
(a)  Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, no person who is an operator or occupant, other than a passenger in a chartered vehicle authorized to operate by the state department of transportation, shall transport or possess alcoholic liquor in a container that is open or uncapped or upon which the seal is broken within the passenger compartment of a vehicle upon a street, or within the passenger compartment of a moving vehicle in any place open to the general public or generally accessible to motor vehicles, including an area designated for the parking of vehicles, in this state. 
(b)  A person may transport or possess alcoholic liquor in a container that is open or uncapped or upon which the seal is broken within the passenger compartment of the vehicle upon a street or other place open to the general public or generally accessible to motor vehicles, included in an area designated for the parking of vehicles in the state, if the vehicle does not have a trunk or compartment separate from the passenger compartment, the container is enclosed or encased, and the container is not readily accessible to the occupants of the vehicle. 
(c)  A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor. As part of the sentence, the person may be ordered to perform community service and undergo substance abuse screening and assessment at his own expense as described in section 703(1) of the Michigan Liquor Control Code of 1998, 1998 Public Act No. 58 of 1998 (MCL 436.1703(1)). A court shall not accept a plea of guilty or nolo contendere for a violation of this Section from a person charged solely with a violation of section 36-625(d). 
(Code 1988, § 10.624a; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-625. - Operating while under the influence; impaired driving due to alcohol or drugs; penalties. 
(a)  A person, whether licensed or not, shall not operate a vehicle upon a highway or other place open to the general public or generally accessible to motor vehicles, including an area designated for the parking of vehicles, within this state if either of the following applies: 
(1)  The person is under the influence of alcoholic liquor or a controlled substance or a combination of alcoholic liquor and a controlled substance. 
(2)  The person has an alcohol content of 0.08 grams or more per 100 milliliters of blood, per 210 liters of breath or per 67 milliliters of urine, or, beginning October 1, 2013, the person has an alcohol content of 0.10 grams or more per 100 milliliters of blood, per 210 liters of breath, or per 67 milliliters of urine. 
(b)  The owner of a vehicle or a person in charge or in control of a vehicle shall not authorize or knowingly permit the vehicle to be operated upon a highway or other place open to the general public or generally accessible to motor vehicles, including an area designated for the parking of motor vehicles, within this state by a person who is under the influence of alcoholic liquor or a controlled substance, or a combination of alcoholic liquor and a controlled substance, or who has an alcohol content of 0.08 grams or more per 100 milliliters of blood, per 210 liters of breath or per 67 milliliters of urine, or, beginning October 1, 2013, the person has an alcohol content of 0.10 grams or more per 100 milliliters of blood, per 210 liters of breath, or per 67 milliliters of urine, or whose ability to operate the motor vehicle is visibly impaired due to the consumption of alcoholic liquor, a controlled substance, or a combination of alcoholic liquor and a controlled substance. 
(c)  A person, whether licensed or not, shall not operate a vehicle upon a highway or other place open to the general public or generally accessible to motor vehicles, including an area designated for the parking of vehicles within this state when, due to the consumption of alcoholic liquor, a controlled substance, or a combination of alcoholic liquor and a controlled substance, the person's ability to operate the vehicle is visibly impaired. If a person is charged with violating subsection (a)(1) or (a)(2) of this section, a finding of guilty under this subsection may be rendered. 
(d)  A person who is less than 21 years of age, whether licensed or not, shall not operate a vehicle upon a highway or other place open to the general public or generally accessible to motor vehicles, including an area designated for the parking of vehicles, within this state if the person has any bodily alcohol content. As used in this subsection, the term "any bodily alcohol content" means either of the following: 
(1)  An alcohol content of not less than 0.02 grams or more than 0.08 grams per 100 milliliters of blood, per 210 liters of breath or per 67 milliliters of urine, or, beginning October 1, 2013, the person has an alcohol content of 0.10 grams or more per 100 milliliters of blood, per 210 liters of breath, or per 67 milliliters of urine. 
(2)  Any presence of alcohol within a person's body resulting from the consumption of alcoholic liquor, other than consumption of alcoholic liquor as a part of a generally recognized religious service or ceremony. The defendant bears the burden of proving that the consumption of alcoholic liquor was a part of a generally recognized religious service or ceremony by a preponderance of the evidence. 
(e)  A person, whether licensed or not, is subject to the following requirements: 
(1)  He shall not operate a vehicle in violation of subsection (a) or (c) of this section, while another person who is less than 16 years of age is occupying the vehicle. A person who violates this subsection is guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be sentenced to pay a fine of not less than $200.00 or more than $500.00 and to one or more of the following: 
a.  Imprisonment for not less than five days or more than 90 days. Not less than 48 hours of this imprisonment shall be served consecutively. This term of imprisonment shall not be suspended. 
b.  Community service for not less than 30 days or more than 90 days. 
(2)  He shall not operate a vehicle in violation of subsection (d) of this section while another person who is less than 16 years of age is occupying the vehicle. A person who violates this subsection is guilty of a misdemeanor punishable as follows: 
a.  Except as provided in subsection (e)(2)b of this section, a person who violates this subsection may be sentenced to one or more of the following: 
1.  Community service for not more than 60 days. 
2.  A fine of not more than $500.00. 
3.  Imprisonment for not more than 93 days. 
b.  If the violation occurs within seven years of a prior conviction or after two or more prior convictions regardless of the number of years that have elapsed since any prior conviction, a person who violates this subsection shall be sentenced to pay a fine of not less than $200.00 or more than $500.00 and to one or more of the following: 
1.  Imprisonment for not less than five days or more than 90 days. Not less than 48 hours of this imprisonment shall be served consecutively. This term of imprisonment shall not be suspended. 
2.  Community service for not less than 30 days or more than 90 days. 
3.  In the judgment of sentence under subsection (e)(2)b.1 or (e)(2)b.2 of this section, the court may order vehicle immobilization as provided in section 904d of the Michigan Vehicle Code (MCL 257.904(d)). 
(f)  If a person is convicted of violating subsection (a) or (m) of this section, all of the following apply: 
(1)  Except as otherwise provided in subsection (f)(2) of this section, the person is guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by one or more of the following: 
a.  Community service for not more than 360 hours. 
b.  Imprisonment for not more than 93 days. 
c.  A fine of not less than $100.00 or more than $500.00. 
(2)  If the violation occurs within seven years of a prior conviction, the person shall be sentenced to pay a fine of not less than $200.00 or more than $500.00 and one or more of the following: 
a.  Community service for not less than 30 days or more than 90 days. 
b.  Imprisonment for not less than five days or more than 90 days, and not less than 48 hours of the term of imprisonment imposed under this subsection shall be served consecutively. 
(3)  A term of imprisonment imposed under subsection (f)(2)b of this section shall not be suspended. 
(4)  In the judgment of sentence under subsection (f)(1) or (2) of this section, the court may order vehicle immobilization as provided in section 904d of the Michigan Vehicle Code (MCL 257.904d). In the judgment of a sentence under subsection (f)(2) of this section, the court shall, unless the vehicle is ordered forfeited under section 625n of the Michigan Vehicle Code (MCL 257.625n), order vehicle immobilization as provided in section 904d of the Michigan Vehicle Code. 
(g)  A person who is convicted of violating subsection (b) of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by imprisonment for not more than 93 days or a fine of not less than $100.00 or more than $500.00, or both. 
(h)  If a person is convicted of violating subsection (c) of this section, all of the following apply: 
(1)  Except as otherwise provided in subsection (h)(2) of this section, the person is guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by one or more of the following: 
a.  Community service for not more than 360 hours. 
b.  Imprisonment for not more than 93 days. 
c.  A fine of not more than $300.00. 
(2)  If the violation occurs within seven years of one prior conviction, the person shall be sentenced to pay a fine of not less than $200.00 or more than $500.00 and one or more of the following: 
a.  Community service for not less than 30 days or more than 90 days. 
b.  Imprisonment for not less than five days or more than 90 days. Not less than 48 hours of the term of imprisonment imposed under this subsection shall be served consecutively. 
(3)  A term of imprisonment imposed under subsection (h)(2) of this section shall not be suspended. 
(4)  In the judgment of sentence under subsection (h)(1) or (2) of this section, the court may order vehicle immobilization as provided in section 904d of the Michigan Vehicle Code (MCL 257.904d). In the judgment of a sentence under subsection (h)(2) of this section, the court shall, unless the vehicle is ordered forfeited under section 625n of the Michigan Vehicle Code (MCL 257.625n), order vehicle immobilization as provided in section 904d of the Michigan Vehicle Code. 
(i)  If a person is convicted of violating subsection (d) of this section, the following shall apply: 
(1)  Except as otherwise provided in subsection (i)(2) of this section, the person is guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by one or both of the following: 
a.  Community service for not more than 360 hours. 
b.  A fine of not more than $250.00. 
(2)  If the violation occurs within seven years of one or more prior convictions, the person may be sentenced to one or more of the following: 
a.  Community service for not more than 60 days. 
b.  A fine of not more than $500.00. 
c.  Imprisonment for not more than 93 days. 
(j)  Subject to subsection (l) of this section, as used in this section, the term "prior conviction" means a conviction for any of the following, whether under an ordinance violation of this article, a law of this state, a local ordinance substantially corresponding to a law of this state, or a law of another state substantially corresponding to a law of this state:
