(1)  Except as provided in subsection (k) of this section, a violation or attempted violation of section 625(1), (3), (4), (5), (6), or (7), section 625m, former section 625(b)(1) or (2), or former section 625b of the Michigan Vehicle Code (MCL 257.625(1), (3), (4), (5), (6) or (7); MCL 257.625m; MCL 257.625b) or subsection (a), (c), (d) or (e) of this section. 
(2)  Negligent homicide, manslaughter, or murder resulting from the operation of a vehicle or an attempt to commit any of those crimes. 
(k)  Except for purposes of enforcement described in subsection (i)(2) of this section, only one violation or attempted violation of section 625(6) of the Michigan Vehicle Code (MCL 257.625(6)), subsection (d) of this section, a local ordinance substantially corresponding to section 625(6) of the Michigan Vehicle Code or subsection (d) of this section, or the law of another state substantially corresponding to section 625(6) of the Michigan Vehicle Code or subsection (d) of this section may be used as a prior conviction. 
(l)  If two or more convictions described in subsection (j) of this section are convictions for violations arising out of the same transaction, only one conviction shall be used to determine whether the person has a prior conviction. 
(m)  A person, whether licensed or not, shall not operate a vehicle upon a highway or other place open to the general public or generally accessible to motor vehicles, including an area designated for the parking of vehicles, within this state if the person has in his body any amount of a controlled substance listed in schedule 1 under section 7212 of the public health code, Public Act No. 368 of 1978 (MCL 333.7212), or a rule promulgated under that section, or of a controlled substance described in section 7214(a)(iv) of the public health code, MCL 333.7214(a)(iv). 
(n)  The court may order as a condition of probation that a person convicted of violating subsection (a) or (m) of this section shall not operate a motor vehicle unless that vehicle is equipped with an ignition interlock device approved, certified, and installed as required under sections 625k and 625l of the Michigan Vehicle Code (MCL 257.625k, 257.625l). 
(Code 1988, § 10.625; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000; Ord. No. 480, § 1, 8-19-2003; Amd. of 6-11-2008, § 10.625) 
Sec. 36-625a. - Refusal to submit to preliminary chemical breath analysis. 
(a)  No person shall refuse to submit to a preliminary chemical breath analysis upon a lawful request by a peace officer. Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, a person who refuses to submit to a preliminary chemical breath analysis upon a lawful request by a peace officer is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(b)  A person who is operating a commercial motor vehicle and who refuses to submit to a preliminary chemical breath analysis upon lawful request by a peace officer is guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by imprisonment for not more than 93 days or a fine of not more than $100.00, or both. 
(Code 1988, § 10.625a; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36.625b. - Super drunk driving. 
    Pursuant to Act 1909, PA 279, as amended by Act 2012, PA 7, Section 625(1)(c) of the Michigan Vehicle Code, 1949 PA 300, MCL 257.625, is hereby adopted by reference. A violation of this provision is punishable by one or more of the following: 
(1)  Community service for not more than 360 hours. 
(2)  Imprisonment for not more than 180 days. 
(3)  A fine of not less than $200.00, or more than $700.00. 
(Ord. No. 548, § 1, 5-1-2012) 
Secs. 36-625c-36-625k. - Reserved. 
Sec. 36-625l. - Ignition interlock device. 
    No person required to use an ignition interlock device shall tamper with or circumvent the device or request or solicit any other person to blow into the device or to start a vehicle equipped with the device, nor shall any person blow into an ignition interlock device or start a vehicle equipped with the device for the purpose of providing an operable vehicle to a person required to use the device. 
(Code 1988, § 10.625l; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-625m. - Prohibition of operation of commercial motor vehicle with certain percentage of alcohol in blood. 
(a)  A person, whether licensed or not, who has an alcohol content of 0.04 grams or more but not more than 0.08 grams per 100 milliliters of blood, per 210 liters of breath, or per 67 milliliters of urine or, beginning October 1, 2013, an alcohol content of 0.04 grams or more but less than 0.10 grams per 100 milliliters of blood, per 210 liters of breath, or per 67 milliliters of urine, shall not operate a commercial motor vehicle within this state. 
(b)  A person who is convicted of violating this section is guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by imprisonment for not more than 93 days or a fine of not more than $300.00, or both, together with costs of the prosecution. 
(Code 1988, § 10.625m; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000; Ord. No. 480, § 2, 8-19-2003; Amd. of 6-11-2008, § 10.625m) 
Sec. 36-626. - Reckless driving. 
    Any person who drives any vehicle upon a street, frozen public lake, stream or pond or other place open to the general public, including any area designated for the parking of motor vehicles, in willful or wanton disregard for the safety of persons or property is guilty of reckless driving. 
(Code 1988, § 10.626; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-626a. - Competitive use of a vehicle; prohibition. 
    No person shall operate any vehicle, or render assistance in any manner to the competitive use of a vehicle, upon any street, or any other place open to the general public, including any area designated for the parking of motor vehicles, in a speed or acceleration contest or for the purpose of making a speed record, whether from a standing start or otherwise over a measured or unmeasured distance, or in a drag race as herein defined. The term "drag racing" means the operation of two or more vehicles from a point side by side at accelerating speeds in a competitive attempt to out-distance each other over a common selected course or where timing is involved or where timing devices are used in competitive accelerations of speeds by participating vehicles. Persons rendering assistance in any manner to such competitive use of vehicles shall be equally charged as participants. The operation of two or more vehicles either at speeds in excess of prima facie lawfully established speeds or rapidly accelerating from a common starting point to a speed in excess of such prima facie lawful speed is prima facie evidence of drag racing and is unlawful. 
(Code 1988, § 10.626a; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-626b. - Careless or negligent driving. 
    Any person who operates a vehicle upon a street, frozen public lake, stream or pond or other place open to the general public, including any area designated for the parking of motor vehicles, in a careless or negligent manner likely to endanger any person or property, but without wantonness or recklessness, is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 10.626b; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-626c. - Drivers to exercise due care. 
(a)  Every driver of a vehicle shall exercise due care to avoid colliding with any pedestrian or vehicle upon any street or highway and shall give warning by sounding the horn when necessary. 
(b)  A person who violates this section is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 10.626c; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
DIVISION 10. - SPEED RESTRICTIONS 

Sec. 36-627. - General speed restrictions. 
(a)  No person shall operate a vehicle at a speed which is other than a careful and prudent speed not greater than nor less than is reasonable and proper, having due regard to the traffic, surface, and width of the street and of any other condition then existing. No person shall operate a vehicle at a speed greater than that which will permit a stop within the assured, clear distance ahead. 
(b)  Subject to subsection (a) of this section and except in those instances where a lower speed is specified in this division, it is prima facie lawful for the driver of a vehicle to drive at a speed not exceeding the following, except when this speed would be unsafe: 
(1)  Twenty-five miles an hour on all streets in a business or residence district. 
(2)  Twenty-five miles an hour in public parks unless a different speed is fixed and duly posted. 
(3)  Twenty-five miles per hour on all highways or parts of highways within the boundaries of land platted under the land division act, Public Act No. 288 of 1967 (MCL 560.101 to 560.293), or the condominium act, Public Act No. 59 of 1978 (MCL 559.101 to 559.276), unless a different speed is fixed and posted. 
(c)  It is prima facie unlawful for a person to exceed the speed limits prescribed in subsection (b) of this section, except as provided in section 629 of the Michigan Vehicle Code (MCL 257.629). 
(d)  No person shall operate a vehicle at a speed greater than that fixed and posted with respect to any street, or greater than any applicable prima facie speed limit established pursuant to the Michigan Vehicle Code if no speed limit be otherwise posted. 
(e)  A person driving a passenger vehicle drawing another vehicle or trailer shall not exceed a speed of 55 miles per hour, unless the vehicle or trailer has two wheels or less and does not exceed the combined weight of 750 pounds for the vehicle or trailer and load, or a trailer coach of not more than 26 feet in length with brakes on each wheel and attached to the passenger vehicle with an equalizing or stabilizing coupling unit. 
(f)  A truck with a gross weight of 10,000 pounds or more, a truck-tractor with a trailer, or a combination of these vehicles shall not exceed a speed of 55 miles per hour on highways, streets, or freeways, and shall not exceed a speed of 35 miles per hour on highways, streets, or freeways, during the period when reduced loadings are being enforced in accordance with this division. 
(g)  A person driving a school bus shall not exceed the speed of 50 miles per hour. 
(h)  The maximum rates of speeds allowed pursuant to this section are subject to the maximum rate established pursuant to section 629b of the Michigan Vehicle Code (MCL 257.629b). 
(i)  A person operating a vehicle on a highway, when entering and passing through a designated work area where a normal lane or part of the lane of traffic has been closed due to highway construction, maintenance, or surveying activities, shall not exceed a speed of 45 miles per hour unless otherwise determined and posted by the state transportation department, a county road commission, or a local authority. The state transportation department, a county road commission, or a local authority, based on accepted engineering practice, shall post speed limit signs in each work zone described in section 79d(a) of the Michigan Vehicle Code (MCL 257.79d(a)) that indicate the speed limit in that work zone and shall identify that work zone with any other traffic control devices necessary to conform to the Michigan Manual of Uniform Traffic Control Devices. A person shall not exceed a speed limit established under this Section or a speed limit established pursuant to section 628 or 629 of the Michigan Vehicle Code (MCL 257.628 or 257.629). 
(j)  Subject to subsections (a) and (b)(3) of this section, speed limits established pursuant to this section are not valid unless properly posted. In the absence of a properly posted sign, the speed limit in effect shall be the general speed limit pursuant to section 628(1) of the Michigan Vehicle Code (MCL 257.628(1)). 
(k)  A person who violates this section is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 10.627; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000; Amd. of 6-11-2008, § 10.627) 
Secs. 36-628-36-630. - Reserved. 
Sec. 36-631. - Bridges, causeways or viaducts; speed and load restrictions. 
    No person shall operate a vehicle upon a public bridge, causeway, or viaduct at a speed or with a load which is greater than the maximum speed or load which can be maintained with safety to the structure, when the structure is signposted as provided in the Michigan Vehicle Code. A person who violates this section is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 10.631; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-632. - Reserved. 
Sec. 36-633. - Specification of speeding violation in complaint. 
    In every charge of a violation of a speed regulation in this division, the complaint or citation and the summons or notice to appear shall specify the speed at which the defendant is alleged to have driven and the speed applicable within the district or at the location. 
(Code 1988, § 10.633; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
DIVISION 11. - DRIVING ON RIGHT SIDE OF ROADWAY, OVERTAKING AND PASSING 

Sec. 36-634. - Driving on right side of roadway; two or more lane roadway for travel in same direction. 
(a)  Upon each roadway of sufficient width, the driver of a vehicle shall drive the vehicle upon the right-half of the roadway, except as follows: 
(1)  When overtaking and passing another vehicle proceeding in the same direction under the rules governing that movement. 
(2)  When the right-half of a roadway is closed to traffic while under construction or repair or when an obstruction exists making it necessary to drive to the left of the center of the highway. A driver who is driving on the left half of a roadway under this subdivision shall yield the right-of-way to an oncoming vehicle traveling in the proper direction upon the unobstructed portion of the roadway. 
(3)  When a vehicle operated by a state agency or a local authority or an agent of a state agency or local authority is engaged in work on the roadway. 
(4)  Upon a roadway divided into three marked lanes for traffic under the rules applicable on the roadway. 
(b)  Upon a roadway having two or more lanes for travel in one direction, the driver of a vehicle shall drive the vehicle in the extreme right-hand lane available for travel except as otherwise provided in this section. However, the driver of a vehicle may drive the vehicle in any lane lawfully available to traffic moving in the same direction of travel when the lanes are occupied by vehicles moving in substantially continuous lanes of traffic and in any left-hand lane lawfully available to traffic moving in the same direction of travel for a reasonable distance before making a left turn. 
(c)  A person who violates this section is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 10.634; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-635. - Passing of oncoming vehicles. 
(a)  Drivers of vehicles proceeding in opposite directions shall pass each other to the right, each giving to the other not less than one-half of the main traveled portion of the roadway as nearly as possible. 
(b)  A person who violates this section is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 10.635; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-636. - Overtaking and passing of vehicles. 
(a)  The following rules shall govern the overtaking and passing of vehicles proceeding in the same direction, subject to those limitations, exceptions, and special rules stated in sections 36-637 through 36-643a: 
(1)  The driver of a vehicle overtaking another vehicle proceeding in the same direction shall pass at a safe distance to the left of that vehicle, and when safely clear of the overtaken vehicle shall take up a position as near the right-hand edge of the main traveled portion of the highway as is practicable. 
(2)  Except when overtaking and passing on the right is permitted, the driver of an overtaken vehicle shall give way to the right in favor of the overtaking vehicle on audible signal and shall not increase the speed of his vehicle until completely passed by the overtaking vehicle. 
(b)  A person who violates this section is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 10.636; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-637. - Overtaking and passing on right of another vehicle. 
(a)  The driver of a vehicle may overtake and pass upon the right of another vehicle only if one or more of the following conditions exist: 
(1)  When the vehicle overtaken is making or about to make a left turn. 
(2)  Upon a street or highway with unobstructed pavement not occupied by parked vehicles of sufficient width for two or more lanes of moving vehicles in each direction and when the vehicles are moving in substantially continuous lanes of traffic. 
(3)  Upon a one-way street, or upon a roadway on which traffic is restricted to one direction of movement, where the roadway is free from obstructions and of sufficient width for two or more lanes of moving vehicles and when the vehicles are moving in substantially continuous lanes of traffic. 
(b)  The driver of a vehicle may overtake and pass another vehicle upon the right only under conditions permitting the overtaking and passing in safety. The driver of a vehicle shall not overtake and pass another vehicle upon the right by driving off the pavement or main-traveled portion of the roadway. 
(c)  A person who violates this section is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 10.637; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-638. - Passing on left; visibility; oncoming traffic. 
(a)  A vehicle shall not be driven to the left side of the center of a two-lane highway or in the center lane of a three-lane highway in overtaking and passing another vehicle proceeding in the same direction unless the left side or center lane is clearly visible and is free of oncoming traffic for a sufficient distance ahead to permit the overtaking and passing to be completely made without interference with the safe operation of a vehicle approaching from the opposite direction or the vehicle overtaken. 
(b)  A person who violates this section is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 10.638; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-639. - Vehicles prohibited from driving on left side of roadway under certain conditions. 
(a)  No person shall operate a vehicle on the left side of a two-way street when approaching the crest of a grade or upon a curve in the street where the person's view is obstructed within a distance as to create a hazard to possible on-coming traffic or, when the view is obstructed upon approaching within 100 feet of a bridge, viaduct, or tunnel. 
(b)  The limitations of subsection (a) of this section shall not apply upon a one-way roadway. 
(c)  A person who violates this section is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 10.639; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-640. - No-passing zone. 
(a)  No driver of any vehicle shall overtake or pass any vehicle in a designated no-passing zone. 
(b)  A person who violates this section is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 10.640; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-640a. - Passing vehicle at intersection. 
(a)  Whenever any vehicle is stopped at a marked crosswalk or at any unmarked crosswalk at an intersection to permit a pedestrian to cross the roadway, the driver of any other vehicle approaching from the rear shall not overtake and pass such stopped vehicle. 
(b)  A person who violates this section is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 10.640a; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-641. - Designation of roadway for one-way traffic. 
(a)  Upon a roadway designated and signposted for one-way traffic a vehicle shall be driven only in the direction designated. 
(b)  A vehicle passing around a rotary traffic island shall be driven only to the right of that island. 
(c)  A person who violates subsection (a) or (b) of this section is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 10.641; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-642. - Driving on roadways divided into two or more marked lanes. 
(a)  When a roadway has been divided into two or more clearly marked lanes for traffic the following rules in addition to all others consistent with this act shall apply: 
(1)  A vehicle shall be driven as nearly as practicable entirely within a single lane and shall not be moved from the lane until the driver has first ascertained that the movement can be made with safety. Upon a roadway with four or more lanes which provides for two-way movement of traffic, a vehicle shall be driven within the extreme right-hand lane except when overtaking and passing, but shall not cross the centerline of the roadway except where making a left turn. 
(2)  Upon a roadway which is divided into three lanes and provides for two-way movement of traffic, a vehicle shall not be driven in the center lane except when overtaking and passing another vehicle traveling in the same direction, when the center lane is clear of traffic within a safe distance, or in preparation for a left turn, or where the center lane is at the time allocated exclusively to traffic moving in the same direction the vehicle is proceeding and the allocation is designated by official traffic control devices. 
(3)  Official traffic control devices may be erected directing specified traffic to use a designated lane or designating those lanes to be used by traffic moving in a particular direction regardless of the center of the roadway and drivers of vehicles shall obey the directions of the traffic control device. 
(4)  Official traffic control devices may be installed prohibiting the changing of lanes on sections of roadway, and drivers of vehicles shall obey the directions of the traffic control devices. 
(b)  A person who violates this section is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 10.642; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-643. - Tailgating prohibited. 
(a)  No person shall operate a vehicle following another vehicle more closely than is reasonable and prudent, having due regard for the speed of the vehicles and the traffic upon, and the condition of, the street. 
(b)  A person who violates this section is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 10.643; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-643a. - Leaving space between trucks or truck tractors; passing. 
(a)  No driver of a truck or truck tractor, when traveling upon a street outside of a business or residence district, when conditions permit, shall fail to leave sufficient space between the vehicle and another truck or truck tractor so that an overtaking vehicle may enter and occupy the space without danger, except that this shall not prevent the driver of a truck or truck tractor from overtaking and passing another truck, truck tractor or other vehicle in a lawful manner. 
(b)  A person who violates this section is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 10.643a; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-644. - Driving on divided highway. 
(a)  No person shall operate a vehicle other than on the right-hand roadway of a street divided into two roadways by leaving an intervening space or by a physical barrier or clearly indicated dividing section constructed to impede vehicular traffic, or park or drive over, across, or within the dividing space, barrier or section of such street, except through an opening in the physical barrier, dividing section, or space or at a crossover or intersection established by public authority on a street which has been divided into two roadways. 
(b)  No person shall operate any vehicle upon any crossover on a limited access highway except an authorized emergency vehicle, a road service vehicle going to or returning from servicing a disabled vehicle, or vehicles actually engaged in work upon the surface of a street. 
(c)  A person who violates this section is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 10.644; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-645. - Limited access roadways, entering and exiting. 
(a)  No person shall drive a vehicle onto or from a limited access roadway except at entrances and exits established by public authority. 
(b)  A person who violates this section is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 10.645; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-646. - Operation only on property normally open to vehicular traffic. 
    No person shall operate, or cause to be driven, any motor vehicle, motorcycle, motor-driven cycle, go-cart, or any other driven vehicle on any property owned by the city not normally open to vehicular traffic, or on any property owned by the School District of the City of Berkley, not normally open to vehicular traffic, except as authorized by the city manager or the director of public safety. Property owned by the city shall be construed to include, but not be limited to, city parks and playgrounds. Property owned by the School District of the City of Berkley shall be construed to include, but shall not be limited to, school playgrounds and athletic fields. The violation of this section is punishable as a violation of the city Code. 
(Code 1988, § 10.646; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
DIVISION 12. - TURNING MOVEMENTS 

Sec. 36-647. - Turning at intersections. 
(a)  The driver of a vehicle intending to turn at an intersection shall do so as follows: 
(1)  Both the approach for a right turn and a right turn shall be made as close as practicable to the right-hand curb or edge of the roadway. 
(2)  Approach for a left turn shall be made in that portion of the right half of the roadway nearest the centerline, and after entering the intersection the left turn shall be made so as to leave the intersection to the right of the centerline of the roadway being entered. 
(3)  Approach for a left turn from a two-way roadway into a one-way roadway shall be made in that portion of the right half of the roadway nearest the centerline and clear of existing car tracks in use, and bypassing to the right of the centerline where it enters the intersection. Approach for a left turn from a one-way roadway into a two-way roadway shall be made as close as practicable to the left curb or edge of the roadway and bypassing to the right of the centerline of the roadway being entered. 
(4)  Where both streets and roadways are one-way, both the approach for a left turn and a left turn shall be made as close as practicable to the left-hand curb or edge of the roadway. 
(5)  Where markers, signs, or signals have been placed within or adjacent to intersections and thereby require and direct that a different course from that specified in this section be traveled by vehicles turning at an intersection, a driver of a vehicle shall not turn a vehicle at an intersection other than as directed and required by those markers, signs, or signals. 
(b)  A person who violates this section is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 10.647; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-648. - Signals on stopping or turning required. 
(a)  The driver of a vehicle or bicycle upon a highway, before stopping or turning from a direct line, shall first see that the stopping or turning can be made in safety and shall give a signal as required in this section. 
(b)  A signal required in this section shall be given either by means of the hand and arm in the manner specified in this section or by a mechanical or electrical signal device which conveys an intelligible signal or warning to other highway traffic, except as otherwise provided in subsection (c) of this section. When a signal is given by means of the hand and arm, the driver shall indicate his intention to stop or turn by extending his hand and arm from and beyond the left side of the vehicle and signal as follows: 
(1)  Left turn-Hand and arm extended horizontally. 
(2)  Right turn-Hand and arm extended upward. 
(3)  Stop or decrease speed-Hand and arm extended downward. 
(c)  A commercial motor vehicle, other than those in transit from a manufacturer to a dealer, in use on a highway shall be equipped with, and required signal shall be given by, a signal lamp or mechanical signal device when the distance from the center of the top of the steering post to the left outside limit of the body, cab, or load of the commercial motor vehicle exceeds 24 inches or when the distance from the center of the top of the steering post to the rear limit of the body or load of the commercial vehicle exceeds 14 feet. The measurement from steering post to rear limit shall apply to a single vehicle or combination of vehicles. 
(d)  A person who violates this section is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 10.648; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
DIVISION 13. - RIGHT-OF-WAY 

Sec. 36-649. - Yielding to vehicle with right-of-way required. 
(a)  The driver of a vehicle approaching an intersection shall yield the right-of-way to a vehicle which has entered the intersection from a different highway. 
(b)  When two vehicles enter an intersection from different highways at approximately the same time, the driver of the vehicle on the left shall yield the right-of-way to the vehicle on the right. 
(c)  The right-of-way rules declared in subsections (a) and (b) of this section are modified at through highways and otherwise as stated in this chapter. 
(d)  The driver of a vehicle approaching a yield sign, in obedience to the sign, shall slow down to a speed reasonable for the existing conditions and shall yield the right-of-way to a vehicle in the intersection or approaching on another highway so closely as to constitute an immediate hazard during the time the driver would be moving across or within the intersection. However, if required for safety to stop, the driver shall stop before entering the crosswalk on the near side of the intersection or, if there is not a crosswalk, at a clearly marked stop line; but if there is not a crosswalk or a clearly marked stop line, then at the point nearest the intersecting roadway where the driver has a view of approaching traffic on the intersecting roadway. 
(e)  The driver of a vehicle traveling at an unlawful speed shall forfeit a right-of-way which the driver might otherwise have under this section. 
(f)  Except when directed to proceed by a police officer, the driver of a vehicle approaching a stop intersection indicated by a stop sign shall stop before entering the crosswalk on the near side of the intersection, or if there is not a crosswalk shall stop at a clearly marked stop line; or if there is not a crosswalk or a clearly marked stop line, then at the point nearest the intersecting roadway where the driver has a view of approaching traffic on the intersecting roadway. After having stopped, the driver shall yield the right-of-way to a vehicle which has entered the intersection from another highway or which is approaching so closely on the highway as to constitute an immediate hazard during the time when the driver would be moving across or within the intersection. 
(g)  When a vehicle approaches the intersection of a highway from an intersecting highway or street which is intended to be, and is constructed as, a merging highway or street, and is plainly marked at the intersection with appropriate merge signs, the vehicle shall yield the right-of-way to a vehicle so close as to constitute an immediate hazard on the highway about to be entered and shall adjust its speed so as to enable it to merge safely with the through traffic. 
(h)  A person who violates this section is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 10.649; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-650. - Right-of-way; vehicles turning left at intersection. 
(a)  The driver of a vehicle within an intersection intending to turn to the left shall yield the right-of-way to a vehicle approaching from the opposite direction which is within the intersection or so close to the intersection as to constitute an immediate hazard; but the driver, having so yielded and having given a signal when and as required by this division, may make the left turn and the drivers of all other vehicles approaching the intersection from the opposite direction shall yield the right-of-way. At an intersection at which a traffic signal is located, a driver intending to make a left turn shall permit vehicles bound straight through in the opposite direction which are waiting a go signal to pass through the intersection before making the turn. 
(b)  A person who violates this section is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 10.650; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-651. - Reserved. 
Sec. 36-652. - Emerging from alley or private way. 
(a)  No driver of a vehicle shall enter or cross a street from an alley, private road, or driveway without coming to a full stop before entering the street and shall yield the right-of-way to vehicles and pedestrians approaching on the street. 
(b)  A person who violates this section is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 10.652; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-653. - Approach of emergency vehicles; required response. 
    Upon the immediate approach of an authorized emergency vehicle equipped with at least one lighted flashing, rotating or oscillating lamp exhibiting red or blue light visible under normal atmospheric conditions from a distance of 500 feet to the front of such vehicles, and when the driver is giving audible signal by siren, exhaust whistle, or bell, and without regard to emergency run where silence is required in giving audible signal by siren, exhaust whistle, or bell, the driver of every other vehicle shall yield the right-of-way and shall immediately drive to a position parallel to, and as close as possible to, the right edge or curb of the roadway, or left edge of one-way street, clear of any intersection and shall stop and remain in such position until the authorized emergency vehicle has passed, except when otherwise directed by a public safety officer. A person who violates this section is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 10.653; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-653a. - Approaching and passing stationary emergency vehicles. 
(a)  Upon approaching and passing a stationary authorized emergency vehicle that is giving a visual signal by means of flashing, rotating, or oscillating red, blue, or white lights, the driver of an approaching vehicle shall exhibit due care and caution, as required under the following: 
(1)  On any public roadway with at least two adjacent lanes proceeding in the same direction of the stationary authorized emergency vehicle, the driver of the approaching vehicle shall proceed with caution and yield the right-of-way by moving into a lane at least one moving lane or two vehicle widths apart from the stationary authorized emergency vehicle, unless directed otherwise by a public safety officer. If movement to an adjacent lane or two vehicle widths apart is not possible due to weather, road conditions, or the immediate presence of vehicular or pedestrian traffic in parallel moving lanes, the driver of the approaching vehicle shall proceed as required in subsection (a)(2) of this section. 
(2)  On any public roadway that does not have at least two adjacent lanes proceeding in the same direction as the stationary authorized emergency vehicle, or if the movement by the driver of the vehicle into an adjacent lane or two vehicle widths apart is not possible as described in subsection (a)(2) of this section, the approaching vehicle shall reduce and maintain a safe speed for weather, road conditions, and vehicular or pedestrian traffic and proceed with due care and caution, or as directed by a public safety officer. 
(b)  A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by a fine of not more than $500.00 or imprisonment for not more than 90 days, or both. 
(c)  The term "authorized emergency vehicle" means vehicles of the public safety department, fire department, police department, ambulances, privately owned motor vehicles of volunteer or paid firemen, or privately owned motor vehicles of volunteer ambulance drivers or licensed ambulance drivers or attendants as are authorized by the department of state police. 
(Code 1988, § 10.653a; Ord. No. 453, § 1, 4-9-2001) 
Sec. 36-654. - Driving through funeral procession. 
(a)  A motor vehicle forming part of a funeral procession, when going to a place of burial, shall have the right-of-way over all other vehicles except fire apparatus, ambulances, and public safety patrol vehicles at a street or highway intersection within this state if the vehicle in the funeral procession displays a flag which shall be fluorescent orange in color, and upon which shall be printed, stamped, or stained a black cross, the Star of David, or the crescent and star. The lead vehicle and the last vehicle in the funeral procession may carry an additional flag. The flag shall not contain a name embossed or printed on the flag, except the term "funeral." 
(b)  A person passing through a funeral procession of motor vehicles, designated pursuant to subsection (a) of this section, with a vehicle of any kind, is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 10.654; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
DIVISION 14. - PEDESTRIANS 

Sec. 36-655. - Pedestrians on streets. 
(a)  No pedestrian shall walk upon the main traveled portion of a street where sidewalks are provided, or, if sidewalks are not provided, other than on the left side of the street facing traffic which passes nearest when practicable. 
(b)  A person who violates this section is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 10.655; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-655a. - Obstructing roadway. 
(a)  No person shall stand in a roadway for the purpose of soliciting a ride, employment or business from the occupant of any vehicle. 
(b)  A person who violates this section is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 10.655a; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-655b. - Yield right-of-way generally. 
(a)  Every pedestrian crossing a roadway at any point other than within a marked crosswalk or within an unmarked crosswalk at an intersection shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles upon the roadway. 
(b)  A person who violates this section is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 10.655b; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-655c. - Yield to emergency vehicles. 
(a)  A pedestrian shall yield the right-of-way to an emergency vehicle under the conditions prescribed in section 36-653. 
(b)  A person who violates this section is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 10.655c; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-655d. - Sleds, coasting wagons, roller skates restricted. 
(a)  No person upon roller skates, or riding in or by means of any sled, coasting wagon, skis, toboggan, skateboard, toy vehicle, or similar device, shall go upon any roadway except while crossing a street on a crosswalk, and when so crossing such persons shall be granted all of the rights, and shall be subject to all the duties of pedestrians. 
(b)  A person who violates this section is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 10.655d; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-655e. - Manner of crossing roadway. 
(a)  No pedestrian shall, except in a marked crosswalk, cross a roadway at any other place than by a route at right angles to the curb or by the shortest route to the opposite curb. 
(b)  A person who violates this section is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 10.655e; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-655f. - White canes. 
    Any driver of a vehicle who approaches within ten feet of a person wholly or partially blind, carrying a cane or walking stick which is white or white-tipped with red, or being led by a guide dog wearing a harness and walking on either side of or slightly in front of said blind person, shall immediately come to a full stop and take such precautions before proceeding as may be necessary to avoid accident or injury to the person wholly or partially blind. 
(Code 1988, § 10.655f; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
DIVISION 15. - MOTORCYCLES, MOPEDS, AND BICYCLES 
Subdivision I. - In General 

Sec. 36-656. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Bicycle means every device propelled by human power upon which any person may ride, having either two or three wheels in a tandem or tricycle arrangement, all of which are over 14 inches in diameter. 
    Moped means a two- or three-wheeled vehicle which is equipped with a motor that does not exceed 50 cubic centimeters piston displacement, produces 2.0 brake horsepower or less, and cannot propel the vehicle at a speed greater than 30 miles per hour on a level surface. The power drive system shall not require the operator to shift gears. 
    Motorcycle means every motor vehicle having a saddle or seat for the use of a rider and designed to travel on not more than three wheels in contact with the ground, but excluding a tractor. 
(Code 1988, § 10.656; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-656a. - Violations permitted by parent or guardian prohibited. 
    No parent of a child or guardian of a ward shall authorize or knowingly permit the child or ward to violate any provision of this division respecting operation or use of bicycles, mopeds, motorcycles, autocycles, coasters, roller skates, sleds, or toy vehicles. 
(Code 1988, § 10.656a; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-657. - Riding on roadway; rights and duties. 
(a)  A person riding a bicycle, electric personal assistive mobility device, or moped or operating a low-speed vehicle upon a roadway shall be granted all of the rights and shall be subject to all the duties applicable to the driver of a vehicle by this division, except as to special regulations of this division which by their very nature may not have application. 
(b)  The regulations applicable to motorcycles in this division shall be supplementary to other provisions of this division governing motorcycles. 
(Code 1988, § 10.657; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000; Amd. of 6-11-2008, § 10.657) 
Sec. 36-658. - Riding restrictions. 
(a)  No person propelling a bicycle or operating a motorcycle or moped shall ride other than upon and astride a permanent and regular seat attached to such bicycle or vehicle. 
(b)  No person shall use a bicycle or motorcycle to carry more persons at one time than the number for which it is designed and equipped. 
(c)  No person shall use a moped or an electric personal assistive mobility device to carry more than one person at a time. 
(d)  No person operating or riding on a motorcycle and no person less than 19 years of age operating a moped on a street shall fail to wear a crash helmet, as approved by the department of state police, on his head. 
(e)  No person shall operate or ride in an autocycle on a street without wearing seat belts. 
(f)  A person who violates this section is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 10.658; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000; Amd. of 6-11-2008, § 10.658) 
Sec. 36-658a. - Reserved. 
Sec. 36-658b. - Low-speed vehicles; crash helmets. 
(a)  Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, a person operating or riding in a low-speed vehicle shall wear a crash helmet on his head. The crash helmet shall meet the requirements of the rules promulgated by the department of state police under section 36-658. 
(b)  Subsection (a) of this section does not apply to a person operating or riding in a low-speed vehicle equipped with a roof that meets or exceeds the standards for roof-crush resistance, provided under 49 CFR 571.500. 
(Amd. of 6-11-2008, § 10.658b) 
Sec. 36-659. - Clinging to vehicles. 
(a)  No person riding upon a bicycle, moped or motorcycle, coaster, roller skates, sled, or toy vehicle shall attach the same or himself to a vehicle upon a roadway. 
(b)  A person who violates this section is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 10.659; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-660. - Operation generally. 
(a)  No person operating an electric personal assistive mobility device, low-speed vehicle, or moped upon a roadway shall ride other than as near to the right side of the roadway as practicable and with the exercise of due care when passing a standing vehicle or one proceeding in the same direction. 
(b)  No person operating an electric personal assistive mobility device, motorcycle, or moped upon a street shall ride more than two abreast except on a path or part of a roadway set aside for the exclusive use of those vehicles. 
(c)  No person shall operate a bicycle on a roadway where a usable and designated path for bicycles is provided adjacent to a roadway. 
(d)  No person operating a motorcycle, moped, a low-speed vehicle, or electric personal assistive mobility shall pass between lines of traffic, but may pass on the left of traffic moving in that persons direction in the case of a two-way street, or on the left or right of traffic in the case of a one-way street in an unoccupied lane. 
(e)  No person shall: 
(1)  Operate a bicycle on a sidewalk constructed for the use of pedestrians and overtake and pass a pedestrian without first giving an audible signal and yielding the right-of-way to such pedestrian; 
(2)  Ride a bicycle upon a sidewalk within a business district; and 
(3)  Disobey any sign erected on any sidewalk or street which prohibits the riding of bicycles thereon. 
(f)  No person shall operate a moped on a sidewalk constructed for the use of pedestrians. 
(g)  A motorcycle or moped shall not be operated within any city park, unless permitted by traffic control order, nor operated upon property of any school or religious corporation within the city the controlling body of which has prohibited such operation by resolution adopted as a traffic control order by the department of public safety. 
(h)  No bicycle rider who is less than 16 years of age shall fail to use a designated path for bicycles if provided adjacent to a roadway, unless accompanied by an adult. 
(i)  The hands of the operator of a bicycle shall be on the handlebars at all times except when he is in the act of signaling. 
(j)  A person operating an electric personal assistive mobility device on a sidewalk constructed for the use of pedestrians shall yield the right-of-way to a pedestrian and shall give an audible signal before overtaking and passing the pedestrian. 
(k)  A low-speed vehicle shall be operated at a speed of not to exceed 25 miles per hour and shall not be operated on a highway or street with a speed limit of more than 35 miles per hour except for the purpose of crossing that highway or street. The state transportation department may prohibit the operation of a low-speed vehicle on any highway or street under its jurisdiction if it determines that the prohibition is necessary in the interest of public safety. 
(l)  This section does not apply to a police officer in the performance of his official duties. 
(m)  An electric personal assistive mobility device shall be operated at a speed not to exceed 15 miles per hour and shall not be operated on a highway or street with a speed limit of more than 25 miles per hour except to cross that highway or street. 
(n)  A person who violates this section is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 10.660; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000; Amd. of 6-11-2008, § 10.660) 
Sec. 36-660a. - Operating bicycles upon highways or streets at less than existing speed; riding as close as possible to right hand curb or edge required; exceptions. 
    A person operating a bicycle upon a highway or street at less than the existing speed of traffic shall ride as close as practicable to the right-hand curb or edge of the roadway except as follows: 
(1)  When overtaking and passing another bicycle or any other vehicle proceeding in the same direction. 
(2)  When preparing to turn left. 
(3)  When conditions make the right-hand edge of the roadway unsafe or reasonably unusable by bicycles, including, but not limited to, surface hazards, an uneven roadway surface, drain openings, debris, parked or moving vehicles or bicycles, pedestrians, animals, or other obstacles, or if the lane is too narrow to permit a vehicle to safely overtake and pass a bicycle. 
(4)  When operating a bicycle in a lane in which the traffic is turning right but the individual intends to go straight through the intersection. 
(5)  When operating a bicycle upon a one-way highway or street that has two or more marked traffic lanes, in which case the individual may ride as near the left-hand curb or edge of that roadway as practicable. 
(Amd. of 6-11-2008, § 10.660a) 
Sec. 36-660b. - Operating bicycles on streets or highways abreast. 
    Two or more individuals operating bicycles upon a highway or street shall not ride more than two abreast except upon a path or portion of the highway or street set aside for the use of bicycles. 
(Amd. of 6-11-2008, § 10.660b) 
Sec. 36-660c. - Operating bicycles upon sidewalks or pedestrian crosswalks. 
(a)  An individual operating a bicycle upon a sidewalk or a pedestrian crosswalk shall yield the right-of-way to pedestrians and shall give an audible signal before overtaking and passing a pedestrian. 
(b)  An individual shall not operate a bicycle upon a sidewalk or a pedestrian crosswalk if that operation is prohibited by an official traffic control device. 
(c)  An individual lawfully operating a bicycle upon a sidewalk or a pedestrian crosswalk has all of the rights and responsibilities applicable to a pedestrian using that sidewalk or crosswalk. 
(Amd. of 6-11-2008, § 10.660c) 
Sec. 36-661. - Carrying packages, bundles, etc. 
(a)  No person shall operate a bicycle, electric personal assistive mobility device, moped, or motorcycle while carrying any package, bundle, or division which prevents the driver from keeping both hands upon the handlebars of the vehicle. 
(b)  A person who violates this section is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 10.661; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000; Amd. of 6-11-2008, § 10.661) 
Sec. 36-661a. - Position of handlebars. 
(a)  No person shall operate a bicycle, moped, or motorcycle on a public highway if it is equipped with handlebars higher than 15 inches from the lowest point of the undepressed saddle to the highest point of the handle grip of the operator. 
(b)  A person who violates this section is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 10.661a; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-662. - Required equipment for bicycles. 
(a)  Every bicycle or electric personal assistive mobility device being operated on a roadway between one-half hour after sunset and one-half hour before sunrise shall be equipped with a lamp on the front which shall emit a white light visible from a distance of at least 500 feet to the front and with a red reflector on the rear which shall be visible from all distances from 100 feet to 600 feet to the rear when directly in front of lawful lower beams of head lamps on a motor vehicle. A lamp emitting a red light visible from a distance of 500 feet to the rear may be used in addition to the red reflector. 
(b)  No person shall operate a bicycle unless it is equipped with a bell or other device capable of giving an audible signal, except that such bicycle shall not be equipped with, nor shall any person use upon such bicycle, any siren or whistle. 
(c)  Every bicycle shall be equipped with a brake which will enable the operator to make the braked wheel skid on dry, level, clean pavement. 
(d)  An electric personal assistive mobility device shall enable the operator to bring it to a controlled stop. 
(e)  A person who violates this section is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 10.662; Amd. of 6-11-2008, § 10.662) 
Sec. 36-662a. - Required equipment for motorcycles and mopeds. 
(a)  No person shall operate a motorcycle or moped within the city unless said vehicle is equipped with all safety devices required by state law, including but not limited to the following: 
(1)  Adequate headlamps; 
(2)  Red tail lamps; 
(3)  Rear stop lamps; 
(4)  A horn, but no siren, whistle, or bell; and 
(5)  Adequate brakes. 
(b)  When a motorcycle operated on a street or highway in the city in excess of 35 miles per hour is not equipped with a windshield, the operator shall wear goggles with transparent lenses or a transparent face shield or eyeglasses in accordance with state law. 
(c)  A motorcycle or moped shall not be equipped with more than one spot lamp, and every lighted spot lamp shall be so aimed and used upon approaching another vehicle that no part of the beam will be directed into the eyes of the approaching driver. Spotlights may not emit other than a white or amber light. 
(d)  A motorcycle or moped shall at all times be equipped with a muffler in good working order and in constant operation to prevent excessive or unusual noise and annoying smoke. A person shall not remove, destroy, or damage any of the baffles contained in the muffler nor shall a person use a muffler cutout, bypass, or similar device upon a motorcycle or moped on a highway or street. 
(e)  A person who violates this section is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 10.662a; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-663. - Reserved. 
Sec. 36-664. - Parking. 
(a)  An individual may park a bicycle on a sidewalk except as prohibited by an official traffic control device. 
(b)  An individual shall not park a bicycle on a sidewalk in such a manner that the bicycle impedes the lawful movement of pedestrians or other traffic. 
(c)  An individual may park a bicycle on a highway or street at any location where parking is allowed for motor vehicles, may park at any angle to the curb or the edge of the highway, and may park abreast of another bicycle. 
(d)  An individual shall not park a bicycle on a highway or street in such a manner as to obstruct the movement of a legally parked motor vehicle. 
(e)  A person who violates this section is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 10.664; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000; Amd. of 6-11-2008, § 10.664) 
Sec. 36-665. - Required license. 
(a)  No person shall operate a motorcycle or moped within the city unless such person is licensed to do so as required by state law. 
(b)  No person shall ride or propel a bicycle on any street or alley unless such bicycle has been registered and licensed with the public safety department. The public safety department shall issue a suitable license tag with each license issued bearing a distinctive number. Each license or tag pertaining to a registered bicycle shall be firmly affixed to the bicycle in such place or manner as prescribed by the public safety department. 
(Code 1988, § 10.665; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-666. - Regulations. 
    The city commission shall have the authority from time to time to promulgate and issue traffic control orders as is elsewhere authorized in this Code with respect to the control of the operation and use of motorcycles and mopeds in the city. 
(Code 1988, § 10.666; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-667. - Reserved. 
Sec. 36-668. - Impoundment for violation of division. 
    It shall be the duty of all members of the public safety department to impound any and all bicycles operated in violation of any of the provisions of this division. All bicycles impounded shall be held for a period of 24 hours. After such period any bicycle so impounded shall be released upon application of the owner thereof, upon compliance with the provisions of this article; provided, however, that the owner shall have arrived at the age of 18 years; otherwise, upon application of the owner, accompanied by his parent or legal guardian. 
(Code 1988, § 10.668; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Subdivision II. - Registration of Bicycles 

Sec. 36-669. - Registration; records. 
(a)  The director of public safety shall cause all applications for registering of bicycles to be filed in the director of public safety's office and keep a complete and accurate record of the facts appearing therein, together with a numerical list of the bicycle numbers assigned to registered bicycles. Each license so issued shall be valid for the life of said bicycle and shall be transferred as an incident to the transfer of ownership thereof. 
(b)  Fees for the registration and licensing, transfer of registration and license, and duplication of lost, mutilated, or destroyed license plates or tags for bicycles shall be in the amounts prescribed by the city commission by ordinance or resolution. 
(c)  Upon payment of a sum as determined by the city commission to the public safety department, it shall assign a number to each bicycle so registered and shall issue and deliver to the owner thereof a registration card, which card shall contain the number assigned and the words "Bicycle Registration Certificate, Huntington Woods Department of Public Safety," in such style and arrangement as the public safety director may elect. There shall be issued also to the owner, a numbered license in such style and material as the public safety director may elect. 
(d)  It shall be the duty of the owner of the bicycle to attach the license in the proper location on the bicycle, as instructed by the public safety department. The license shall remain attached to the bicycle as long as the bicycle is operated by the owner or others authorized by the owner to operate the bicycle. Licenses shall not be covered, obscured, altered or defaced in any manner, and they shall be kept free from dirt or any other substance likely to destroy their legibility. No person shall remove, destroy, mutilate, alter, or counterfeit any license or use any forged or counterfeit license. 
(e)  No person shall willfully or maliciously remove, destroy, mutilate, or alter the serial number of any bicycle registered pursuant to this article. It shall be unlawful for any person to mutilate or alter any registration card during the time which such card is operative; provided, however, that nothing contained in this article shall prohibit the public safety department from stamping numbers on the frames of bicycles on which no serial number can be found or on which the number is illegible or insufficient for identification purposes. 
(f)  It shall be the duty of every person who sells or transfers ownership of any bicycle to report such sale or transfer by returning to the public safety department, the registration issued to such person, together with the name and address of the person to whom said bicycle was sold or transferred. It shall be the duty of the purchaser, or transferee of the bicycle to apply for a transfer of the registration within seven days of the sale or transfer. The transfer shall be made upon payment of the specified fee. 
(g)  No bicycle shall be registered unless it is in safe operating condition. 
(h)  The violation of this section is punishable as a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1988, § 10.669; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Secs. 36-670, 36-671. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 16. - STOPPING, STANDING, AND PARKING 

Sec. 36-672. - Stopping or parking on highway. 
(a)  No person shall stop, park, or leave a vehicle standing, whether attended or unattended, upon the paved or unpaved part of a limited access highway, or in a moving lane of traffic of any street, except in an emergency or case of mechanical difficulty. 
(b)  A person who violates this section is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 10.672; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-673. - Reserved. 
Sec. 36-674. - Parking prohibitions generally. 
(a)  No person shall park a vehicle in any manner prohibited by the state vehicle code except if necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the directions of a police officer or traffic control device, in any of the following places: 
(1)  On a sidewalk, across a sidewalk or in any way that impedes a pedestrian's use of the sidewalk as a walkway. 
(2)  In front of a public or private driveway. 
(3)  Within an intersection. 
(4)  Within 15 feet of a fire hydrant. 
(5)  On a crosswalk. 
(6)  Within 20 feet of a crosswalk, or if there is not a crosswalk, then within 15 feet of the intersection of property lines at an intersection of highways. 
(7)  Within 30 feet of the approach to a flashing beacon, stop sign or traffic control signal located at the side of the highway. 
(8)  Between a safety zone and the adjacent curb or within 30 feet of a point on the curb immediately opposite the end of a safety zone, unless a different length is indicated by an official sign or marking. 
(9)  Within 20 feet of the driveway entrance to a fire station and on the side of the street opposite the entrance to a fire station within 75 feet of the entrance if properly marked by an official sign. 
(10)  Alongside or opposite a street excavation or obstruction, if the stopping, standing or parking would obstruct traffic. 
(11)  On the roadway side of a vehicle stopped or parked at the edge or curb of a street. 
(12)  Upon a bridge or other elevated highway structure or within a highway tunnel. 
(13)  At a place where an official sign prohibits stopping or parking. 
(14)  Within 500 feet of an accident at which a police officer is in attendance. 
(15)  In front of a theater. 
(16)  In a place or in a manner which blocks immediate egress from an emergency exit conspicuously marked as an emergency exit of a building. 
(17)  In a place or in a manner which blocks or hampers the immediate use of an immediate egress from a fire escape conspicuously marked as a fire escape providing an emergency means of egress from a building. 
(18)  In a parking space clearly identified by an official sign as being reserved for use by disabled persons which is on public property or private property available for public use, unless a person is a disabled person as defined in section 19a of the Michigan Vehicle Code (MCL 257.19a) or unless the person is parking the vehicle for the benefit of a disabled person. In order for the vehicle to be parked in the parking space the vehicle shall display one of the following: 
a.  A certificate of identification or windshield placard issued by the secretary of state under section 675 of the Michigan Vehicle Code (MCL 257.675) to a disabled person. 
b.  A special registration plate issued by the secretary of state under section 803d of the Michigan Vehicle Code (MCL 257.803d) to a disabled person. 
c.  A similar certificate of identification or windshield placard issued by another state to a disabled person. 
d.  A similar special registration plate issued by another state to a disabled person. 
e.  A special registration plate to which a tab for persons with disabilities is attached issued under this Act. 
(19)  In a clearly identified access aisle or access lane immediately adjacent to a space designated for parking by persons with disabilities. 
(20)  On a street or other area open to the parking of vehicles that results in the vehicle interfering with the use of a curb cut or ramp by persons with disabilities. 
(21)  Within 500 feet of a fire at which fire apparatus is in attendance. However, volunteer firefighters responding to the fire may park within 500 feet of the fire in a manner not to interfere with fire apparatus at the scene. A vehicle parked legally previous to the fire is exempt from this subsection. 
(22)  In violation of an official sign restricting the period of time for or manner of parking. 
(23)  On a street or highway in such a way as to obstruct the delivery of mail to a rural mailbox by a carrier of the United States Postal Service. 
(24)  In a place or in a manner which blocks the use of an alley. 
(b)  A person shall not move a vehicle not owned by the person into a prohibited area or away from a curb a distance which makes the parking unlawful. 
(c)  A bus, for the purpose of taking on or discharging passengers, may be stopped at a place described in subsections (a)(2), (4) or (6) of this section or on the roadway side of a vehicle illegally parked in a legally designated bus loading zone. A bus, for the purpose of taking on or discharging a passenger, may be stopped at a place described in subsection (a) of this section if the place is posted by an appropriate bus stop sign, except that a bus shall not stop at such a place if the stopping is specifically prohibited by the local authority, the state transportation department or the director of the department of state police. 
(d)  A person who violates this section is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 10.674; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000; Ord. No. 450, § 1, 9-12-2000; Ord. No. 478, § 1, 7-15-2003; Ord. No. 450, § 1, 9-12-2000; Ord. No. 543, § 1, 1-17-2012) 
Sec. 36-674a. - Clear vision areas, prohibited activities. 
(a)  No person shall conduct vending or other commercial enterprises on any street except as licensed or permitted by applicable authority and no person, whether licensed or not, shall conduct vending or other commercial enterprises in a clear vision area. 
(b)  A person who violates this section is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 10.674a; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-675. - Reserved. 
Sec. 36-675a. - Curb parking generally. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided in this article, every vehicle stopped or parked upon a highway or off-street parking facility where there is an adjacent curb shall be stopped or parked with the right-hand wheels of such vehicle parallel to and within 12 inches of the right-hand curb; except that where there is no right-hand curb, every vehicle stopped or parked upon such highway shall be so stopped or parked with the right-hand wheels of such vehicle parallel to and within 12 inches of the right-hand edge of the roadway. 
(b)  A person who violates this section is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 10.675a; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-675b. - One-way street parking. 
(a)  Vehicles may park with the left-hand wheels adjacent to and within 12 inches of the left-hand curb of properly signed one-way streets or off-street parking facilities. 
(b)  A person who violates this section is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 10.675b; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-675c. - Angle parking. 
(a)  Upon those streets which have been signed or marked for angle parking, no person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle other than at the angle to the curb, or edge or the roadway indicated by such signs or markings. 
(b)  A person who violates this section is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 10.675c; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-675d. - Compliance with markings. 
(a)  Whenever parallel or angle spaces are marked upon any street, alley or off-street parking facility for the parking of vehicles, the operator or driver of a vehicle shall not stop, stand or park such vehicle except within such markings. 
(b)  A person who violates this section is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 10.675d; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-675e. - Prohibitions for certain purposes. 
(a)  No person shall park a vehicle upon any street or highway for the principal purpose of: 
(1)  Displaying such vehicle for sale; 
(2)  Washing, polishing, greasing, or repairing such vehicle, except repairs necessitated by an emergency; 
(3)  Displaying advertising; 
(4)  Selling merchandise from such vehicle except in a duly established market place, or when so authorized or licensed under chapter 8; 
(5)  Storage for more than 48 continuous hours; provided that when any vehicle shall have been parked for more than 48 continuous hours, it shall be deemed an abandoned vehicle, and impounded as provided in sections 36-852 and 36-853. 
(b)  A person who violates this section is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 10.675e; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-675f. - Parking in alley. 
(a)  No person shall park a vehicle in a public alley, except when authorized by a current traffic control order, nor shall any person stop or stand a vehicle in a public alley except while actually in the process of loading or unloading such vehicle. 
(b)  A person who violates this section is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 10.675f; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-675g. - Parking restrictions. 
(a)  No person shall stop, stand, or park a vehicle except when necessary to avoid conflict with traffic or in compliance with law or the direction of a public safety officer, in violation of any legally established parking restriction or prohibition; provided that signs stating such restrictions or prohibitions are duly posted in accordance with this article, except that a driver of a passenger vehicle may stop temporarily in such restricted or prohibited parking zone for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading of passengers when such stopping does not interfere with traffic. 
(b)  A person shall not park a vehicle upon a street between the hours of 3:00 a.m. and 5:00 a.m., except: 
(1)  When necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic, 
(2)  In compliance with the law or the directions of a public safety officer, or 
(3)  Residents who obtain an annual permit to park on a public street between the hours of 3:00 a.m. and 5:00 a.m. For purposes of determining whether the department of public safety will issue a permit, the resident must meet the following criteria: 
a.  A two-car garage counts as one parking space and a one-car garage counts as one parking space. 
b.  The number of registered vehicles must exceed the parking capacity on the resident's property. 
c.  Parking capacity will be determined by public safety measuring the length and width of the driveway between the garage door and the property line. A parking space is defined as an area that is eight feet in width and 20 feet in length. For corner lots, driveways less than 18 feet in length will not count as a parking space. 
d.  All vehicles must be registered to the address of the resident requesting the permit. 
e.  Vehicle registration must be presented at the time of application. 
f.  The parking permit shall be displayed in the lower left corner of the rear window of the vehicle. 
g.  There shall be only one parking permit issued for a residence. 
h.  The fee for the parking permit shall be established by resolution of the city commission. 
(c)  A person who violates this section is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 10.675g; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000; Ord. No. 473, § 1, 12-17-2002; Ord. No. 526, § 1, 7-15-2008; Ord. No. 583, § 1, 7-19-2016; Ord. No. 587, § 1, 10-10-2016) 
Sec. 36-675h. - Parking on private property or on public property. 
(a)  No person shall leave a vehicle unattended on private property owned by another person without the express or implied consent of the owner or person entitled to possession of the property. 
(b)  No person shall leave a vehicle unattended off the street on public property without the express or implied consent of the duly constituted public authority. 
(c)  A person who violates this section is responsible for a misdemeanor, and any such vehicle may be removed to the city vehicle pound by any public safety officer. 
(Code 1988, § 10.675h; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-675i. - Commercial vehicle parking. 
(a)  No person shall park any commercial vehicle on any public street, highway, alley or other public right-of-way in the city for any purpose or length of time other than for the expeditious unloading and delivery or pickup and loading of materials, goods or merchandise. 
(b)  A person shall not park a commercial vehicle on residentially zoned property except in a driveway and to the rear of the front line of the residence, except while actually in the process of loading or unloading such vehicle. 
(c)  A person shall not park a commercial vehicle which weighs more than 6,000 pounds on any residentially zoned property, except that "recreational equipment" as defined in section 40-311 may be parked pursuant to the provisions of section 40-311. 
(d)  In the event a provision enacted by this section would result in peculiar and exceptional practical difficulties to or undue hardship upon the owner of a commercial vehicle, the owner may submit an application for a variance from the provisions of this section to the zoning board of appeals which is empowered to grant such a variance pursuant to section 40-52. 
(e)  For the purpose of this section, the term "commercial vehicle" shall include any motor vehicle which: 
(1)  Displays any form of commercial advertising other than the make and model of the vehicle which exceeds six square feet in total area; 
(2)  Has more than two axles; 
(3)  Exceeds a three-quarter ton load carrying capacity; or 
(4)  By virtue of any equipment such as ladders, roof tarring equipment, grass cutting equipment, snow plows, or otherwise attached to the vehicle or exposed within any exterior bed of the vehicle, appears to be for use in carrying on a trade or business. 
(f)  Traffic control orders may be issued to modify or further regulate the parking of commercial vehicles in the city; provided that signs stating such modifications and regulations are duly posted in accordance with this Code. 
(g)  A person who violates this section is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 10.675i; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000; Ord. No. 473, § 2, 12-17-2002) 
Sec. 36-675j. - Curb loading zones. 
(a)  No person shall stop, stand or park any vehicle other than a commercially licensed vehicle in any place marked as a curb loading zone during hours when the provisions applicable to such zones are in effect except as permitted in section 36-675g. No person shall stop, stand or park any commercially licensed vehicle in any place marked as a curb loading zone during hours when the provisions applicable to such zones are in effect for any purpose or length of time other than for the expeditious unloading and delivery or pickup and loading of materials, goods or merchandise. 
(b)  A person who violates this section is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 10.675j; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-675k. - Stopping and standing of buses, taxicabs. 
(a)  The operator of a bus or taxicab shall not stop, stand, or park upon any street in any business district at any place other than at a bus stop, or taxicab stand, respectively, except that this provision shall not prevent the operator of any such vehicle from temporarily stopping in accordance with other stopping, standing or parking regulations at any place for the purpose of and while engaged in the expeditious unloading or loading of passengers. 
(b)  A person who violates this section is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 10.675k; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-675l. - Restricted use of bus and taxicab stands. 
(a)  No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle other than a bus in a bus stop, or other than a taxicab in a taxicab stand, when such stop or stand has been officially designated and appropriately signed, except as permitted in section 36-675g. 
(b)  A person who violates this section is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 10.675l; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-675m. - Traffic control regulations within parking areas; signs and devices to conform to state manual; violation of order. 
(a)  Upon the request, or with the consent, of the owner or person in charge of the general operation and control of any parking area, as defined herein, traffic control orders regulating the operation of vehicles within the parking area and/or the stopping, standing, or parking of vehicles in the parking area, as may be necessary for the safety and convenience of the public or of the users of the parking area, may be adopted as provided in this chapter. 
(b)  As used in this section, the term "parking area" means an area used by the public as a means of access to and egress from, and for the free parking of motor vehicles by patrons of a shopping center, business, factory, hospital, institution, or similar building or location. 
(c)  Signs or other traffic control devices required to give notice of traffic control orders issued pursuant to this section shall be duly erected, and shall conform to the requirements of the state manual of uniform traffic control devices. 
(d)  A person who violates a traffic control order established pursuant to this section shall be responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Code 1988, § 10.675m; Ord. No. 434, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 36-675n. - Parking on streets during snow and ice conditions. 
(a)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Director means the director of services, or, in the director's absence, the duly designated and acting representative. 
    Roadway means that portion of a street or highway improved, designed, or ordinarily used for vehicular travel, exclusive of the berm or shoulder. 
    Street or highway means the entire width between the boundary lines of every way publicly maintained when any part thereof is open to the use of the public for purposes of vehicular travel. 
(b)  The parking restrictions of this section may be invoked as follows: 
(1)  Whenever the finds, on the basis of falling snow, sleet, or freezing rain, or on the basis of a forecast by the U.S. Weather Bureau or other weather service of snow, sleet, or freezing rain, that weather conditions will make it necessary that motor vehicle traffic be expedited and that parking on city streets be prohibited or restricted for snow plowing and other purposes, the director shall put into effect a parking prohibition on parts of or all city streets by declaring it in a manner prescribed in this section. 
(2)  Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection (b)(1) of this section, a parking prohibition shall automatically go into effect on any street on which there has been an accumulation of snow and ice of four inches or more for any one hour or more. 
(3)  Once in effect, a prohibition under this section shall remain in effect until terminated by announcement of the director in accordance with this section, except that any street area which has become substantially clear of snow and ice from curb to curb for the length of the entire block shall be automatically excluded therefrom. While the prohibition is in effect, no person shall park or allow to remain parked any vehicle on any portion of a city street to which it applies. However, nothing in this section shall be construed to permit parking at any time or place where it is forbidden by any other provision of law. 
(c)  Whenever a vehicle becomes stalled for any reason, whether or not in violation of this section, on any city street on which there is a parking prohibition in effect, the person operating such vehicle shall take immediate action to have the vehicle towed or pushed off the roadway.
